VIEW OF THE PRESIDENT 4 One of the main objectives of the Court and its tasks of transparency and accountability is to bring the European Court of Auditors closer to EU citizens.
I am therefore very pleased to welcome you as a reader of the first annual report on the activities of the European Court of Auditors.
The purpose of the report is to provide an overview of the Court's situation and the Court's activity report in 2007, in the year in which it celebrates the European Union's 30-year external audit activity, which, in accordance with its mission, contributes to the improvement of the EU's financial management and is an independent guardian of the financial interests of Union citizens.
The Court shall make its main contribution to its audits and reports which enable the audit authority to improve its financial management and assist the discharge authority (the European Parliament and the Council) in the control of the implementation of the EU budget.
This report reviews the audit reports published in 2007 and includes the main proposals for the implementation of the EU budget for 2006 and for sound financial management within the EU budget.
The Court not only informs about the financial management of previous years but also actively participates in the creation of an EU financial control framework.
2007 was very important for EU financial management.
In part of the financial instruments, the Court discussed the Court's opinion on significant changes in the responsibility of the Member States and the Court's contribution to the public consultation on the budgetary reform launched by the European Commission.
None of the Court's 2007 results would have been possible without the involvement, know-how and competences of 850 employees.
Staff is the main capital of the future-oriented body that strives for continuous improvement.
This first annual activity report contains detailed information on the Court's reform process, which started in 2006 with self-assessment.
Progress was made in 2007 in the implementation of the Action Plan and the so-called peer review procedure was launched at the end of 2007 under the direction of a group of auditors which belong to the national accounting offices of Canada, Austria, Norway and Portugal.
The first outcome of this reform process was the following declaration on the mandate, guidelines, values and strategic objectives of the Court, which will be based on future actions on which the Court will report in due time.
I wish you a great deal of joy in reading the first annual activity report and I hope that this will be of benefit to you.
Vítor Manuel da Silva Caldeira President 5
6 AGREEMENTS, AGREEMENTS, AGREEMENTS AND STRATEGIC OBJECTIVES The European Court of Auditors shall be responsible, in accordance with the Treaty, for the control of the EU's finances.
As an external EU auditor, it contributes to improving the financial management of the EU and, at the same time, acts as an independent guardian of the financial interests of EU citizens.

Develop relevant and timely high-quality reports based on sound findings and evidence, taking into account stakeholders' issues and taking into account important and guiding statements.
contribute to the effective improvement of the management of the EU budget and the improvement of the responsibility for the management of EU funds.
Promoting the spirit of teamwork through effective communication.
STRATEGIC OBJECTIVES In order to implement its mission, the European Court of Auditors took note of the following strategic objectives: Professionality of collective productivity Development and growth Audit methodology, adequate audit strategy, evolution of audit practice in the public sector, the development of common audit standards and comparable audit standards from the EU budget, cooperation with EU-ORKB, an effective Community audit framework Development and growth: selection of the relevant audit topics, approach to time, transparency and readability of the reports, the quality of the economic audit, increase the impact of reports on the development of relations with the audit entities with the aim of improving understanding of the audit process and greater acceptance of the audit results; strengthening contacts with the European Parliament and the Council as the budgetary authority and discharge authority; and effective communication with EU citizens using peer review experience to strengthen and develop peer review processes with a view to achieving the highest level of effectiveness; implementation of effective and dynamic personnel policy, quality vocational training and modernisation of infrastructure;
8 THE THE COURT'S ROLE AND WORK IN WHAT ROLE THE COURT'S ROLE?
The European Union budget is around EUR 120 billion, representing around 1% of gross national income (GNI) in the 27 Member States.
This represents a small percentage compared to national budgets.
However, for some Member States EU funds play an important role in the financing of public activities, which corresponds approximately to the GNI of some countries, for example Romania.
Over time, the structure of the budget has changed and agricultural and cohesion policy are the main areas of expenditure (see Box 1).
The budget shall be adopted annually by the Council, i.e. representatives of the Member States, and by the European Parliament, directly on a proposal from the European Commission, on the basis of a seven-year financial framework.
The Commission is implementing the budget on its own, but is sharing a large part of its administrative tasks with the Member States, in particular with regard to agricultural and cohesion policy expenditure.
Depending on the expenditure system, national authorities may be responsible for defining the expenditure strategy, selecting beneficiaries and projects, as well as for the implementation of payments.
A specific feature of Community expenditure is the high percentage of payments on the basis of applications from beneficiaries, whether farmers or project managers, across the Union.
9 BOX 1 is how does the EU spend what it does?
The EU budget serves to a large extent objectives other than national budgets, partly depending on different areas of competence.
For example, the Union is not responsible for social security systems, which usually represent the majority of national expenditure.
Since the 1960s, agricultural expenditure, which generally takes the form of payments to farmers across the Union, has been the main contribution of budget expenditure, although the trend is currently decreasing.
In 2008, slightly less than half of the budget allocated to the conservation and management of natural resources, mainly in agriculture and rural development.
Since the 1980s, a significant proportion of expenditure has come from cohesion, i.e. regional and social development, in order to co-finance a wide range of projects, from the construction of roads in Slovakia to the training courses for the unemployed in Denmark.
In 2008, expenditure on sustainable growth, some of which are cohesion expenditure, was estimated at 38% of the budget.
This heading also covers a significant proportion of the EU's research funding.
About 6% of the budget is spent on the management of the Community institutions.

Democratic companies need complete and reliable publicly available information that will form the basis for discussion and decision-making both to improve financial management and to ensure accountability.
The European Court of Auditors acts as an external EU auditor who ensures that EU funds, wherever they are used, have been properly booked and spent in accordance with the rules, taking due account of the optimal spending of funds.
The Court's audit work is used by the Commission, Parliament and Council and by the Member States to improve the EU's financial management.
In addition to the Court's work, many national audit authorities control EU funds, provided that they are managed and spent by public authorities in the Member States.
Review of the internal and external audit of the EU budget at level 10 Commission (DG, Internal Audit Service) Member States Implementing bodies European Court of Auditors National at national level Audit of Internal Audit
The Court applies three different types of audit to 1: audit of accounts, compliance audit (compliance check) and economic audit, which of the following three issues is the starting point of the audit: 11 • • • Does the accounts contain, in all material respects, a true, fair view of the financial situation, the results and the cash flow of a year, in accordance with the current accounting framework? • The Court applies three different types of audit to 1: audit of the accounts, check of compliance with the rules (compliance check) and economic control, which of the three following issues is the starting point of the audit: 11 • • • • • Does the accounts contain, in all material respects, a true, fair view of the financial situation, results and the cash flow of a year in accordance with the current accounting framework?
According to the Treaty, the Court is required to issue such a statement or a review opinion on the reliability of the accounts and the legality and regularity of the underlying transactions.
The annual statement of assurance is commonly known under the French acronym DAS ( commonly known as the acronym "Déclaration d Courisurance " (The acronym DAS).
1 For more information on the Court's audit methods, see the Court's website (www.eca.europa.eu).
The Court carries out an audit of the EU's annual accounts in accordance with the International Audit Principles (ISA), which apply both in the public and private sectors.
The Court, in cooperation with the national audit bodies, actively participates in the development of international audit standards, which in turn are promoted by standardisation bodies (Intosai, IFAC) 2.
In order to ensure compliance of payments with the rules and legal framework, the Court is based on the results of both the analysis of supervisory and control systems to prevent and detect and correct errors of legality and regularity and the sample of individual transactions (payments) (see Box 2).
Where systems are checked and considered reliable, the number of operations which the Court will have to examine will be reduced in order to reach credible conclusions on their legality and regularity.
With regard to the selection of topics for performance control, the Court seeks to identify the control areas for which the greatest impact can be expected to be determined, to identify the potential for improvement in terms of savings, efficiency and effectiveness of EU spending.

The Court follows these measures up to the final recipient of aid, e.g. the farmer in southern Germany.
The Court then carries out on-the-spot checks, for example, in order to determine the size of the agricultural land, in order to determine whether the data contained in the aid application comply with the reality.

14 THE Structure of Structures of Structures of Structures of Structures and Organisation of Structures of Structures of Structures of Structures of Structures of Structures of Structures of the European Court of Auditors The Court of Auditors shall act as a collegial body composed of 27 members, composed of one member from each Member State.
As is apparent from the Organisation (see page 17), there are four thematic control groups covering different budgetary areas (the retention and management of natural resources of four structural policy areas, transport, research and energy... external policies designated by Member States, own resources, banking activities, administrative expenditure, Community institutions and bodies and internal policies).
The fifth audit group (CEAD or coordination, communication, evaluation, quality assurance and development) is responsible for horizontal issues such as coordination in the area of assurance, quality assurance, the development of the audit methodology by the Court, and the dissemination of the Court's audit results and reports.
In addition, a management committee composed of members of all audit groups shall be responsible for preparing all administrative matters requiring a formal decision of the Court.
MEMBERS of the Court shall be appointed by the Council, after consulting the European Parliament, for a six-year term, as proposed by each Member State.
In addition to the functions of the College, which is responsible for final decisions on audits and opinions, as well as for further strategic and administrative issues, each member shall be responsible for its specific tasks, in particular in the field of audit.
The member shall then accept the presentation of the report to the audit group or the Court and after its adoption in the European Parliament, the Council and the other interested parties.
On 1 January 2007, together with the accession of Bulgaria and Romania, the Court welcomed two new members, Nadešda Sandolova and Ovidiu Ipir.
A year later, on 1 January 2008, the Court adopted three new members: Michel Cretin (France), Henri Grethen (Luxembourg) and Harald Noack (Germany) because the mandates of their predecessors had expired.
In addition, the Council extended the term of office of four members (Greece, the Netherlands, Austria and the United Kingdom) for another six years.

The President-in-Office of the European Court of Auditors shall be the President, elected from among the members of the European Court of Auditors for a period of three years, with the possibility of voting again.
The President's role is a priority interpares.
The President shall represent the Court in all its external relations, in particular in relations with the discharge authority, with the other institutions of the European Union and with the highest audit bodies of the Member States and of the beneficiary countries.
On 16 January 2008, Vítor Manuel da Silva Caldeira, a Portuguese member, was elected President of the Court.
The Secretary-General Secretary-General shall be the highest-ranking member of the institution and shall be appointed by the Court for a period of six years which may be re-elected.
The Secretary-General shall be responsible for the management of the Court's staff and staff, including vocational training, and for the Directorate-General for Translation, with the exception of Gaelic language, broken down by official language (22).
The Secretary-General shall also be subject to the General Secretariat.
The mandate of the current Secretary-General of the Court of Justice, Michel Hervé, was extended on 1 July 2007.
THE COURT'S STAFF Human resources of the European Court of Auditors amount to approximately 850 employees (836 on 31 December 2007) and include auditors (484), translators (162) and administrative staff.
The Court's auditors shall have broad profiles and appropriate professional experience in both the public and private sectors, in particular in the field of accounting, financial management, internal and external audit, and in the field of legal and economic sciences.
Like other EU institutions, the Court employs citizens of all Member States.
18 SUMMARY OF THE AUDIT REPORTS AND 3 THE COURT'S OPINION The results of the Court's audits on accounting and compliance audits are in most cases included in the annual reports on the general budget of the EU and the European Development Fund (EDF) and in the specific annual reports on Union agencies and bodies.
Performance control results shall be published during the year in the form of special reports.
The Court shall also publish opinions on draft legal acts having an impact on financial management.
ANNUAL REPORT 2006 ANNUAL REPORT ON THE IMPLEMENTATION OF THE EU BUDGET As the Court has repeatedly stated in its annual reports on the implementation of the EU general budget, the relevant and relevant internal control systems set up by the Commission and the Member States are key to ensuring the sound financial management of the EU.
In recent years, the Court has recognised the Commission's efforts to promote and apply improved internal control and management procedures, both with regard to the reliability of the EU's annual accounts and to the legality and regularity of the operations set out therein.
The 2006 Annual Report continued this tradition by identifying areas where significant improvements are needed in some cases, as well as significant areas of expenditure where the situation is still unsatisfactory.
The Court found that the final annual accounts of the European Communities, showing the implementation of the EU budget for 2006, provide a fair and fair view of the financial situation and the Community's performance in all material respects, except for the showing of excessive amounts in respect of commitments and advance payments in the balance sheet.
It is therefore considered necessary that further improvements are made to ensure that the newly introduced accrual accounting rules are fully satisfactory and that their potential as a reliable management and control tool is fully exploited.
3 This section aims at bringing it into the Court's reports and opinions and not the summary thereof.
For more information, see the full text of the Court's documents published on the Court's website (www.eca.europa.eu) after their adoption.
As regards the expenditure areas included in the final accounts of the European Communities, in respect of expenditure areas where the majority of payments come from agriculture (mainly agricultural expenditure not covered by the integrated management and control system (IACS), structural measures, internal policies and external policies, the Court concludes that there are still serious errors in these expenditure areas.
For payments in these areas, supervisory and control systems have only partially reduced the risk of errors in legality and regularity in transactions.
The Court stresses that complex or unclear eligibility criteria or complex rules have had a significant impact on the legality and regularity of the operations.
However, the Court noted a significant decrease in the estimated overall level of errors in the agricultural operations and found that the IACS is an effective system for reducing the risk of irregular expenditure, insofar as it is properly applied.
Furthermore, the Court concluded that the underlying transactions did not show significant errors, including payments related to administrative expenditure, a significant part of the pre-accession strategy and part of the external policy (see Box 3). 19

ANNUAL REPORT ON THE EUROPEAN DEVELOPMENT FUND (EFF) In 2007, the Court also published an annual report on the European Development Fund (EFF).
While the Court was able to deliver an opinion on the reliability of the EDF accounts to the full, the opinion on the legality and regularity of the transactions on the basis of which the payments approved by the delegations in the beneficiary countries were limited in the light of the material error in the operations.
OTHER ANNUAL REPORT In addition, a further 28 special annual reports on European agencies and other decentralised bodies and an annual report on the assessment of the effectiveness of the management of the European Central Bank were published in 2007.
SPECIAL REPORTS PUBLISHED IN 2007The Court published a total of nine special reports in 2007.
The reports dealt with research on financial management issues in many different fields, ranging from VAT cooperation (No 8/2007) to capacity building in distant countries such as Angola and Vietnam (No 6/2007).
The Court's audit revealed various types of problems with different consequences.
With regard to the expenditure of the EU institutions on buildings (No 2/2007), the shortcomings identified by the Court show that not all EU funds have been used for this purpose.
The shortcomings identified in the report on monitoring, inspection and sanctioning systems with regard to the rules for the conservation of Community fish stocks (No 7/2007) may have serious consequences not only for water resources but also for the future of the fisheries sector.
Despite the different uses of resources in the different areas of the EU budget, the Court's reports show a number of common themes, which can be considered as follows: 22 • • • Despite the fact that the use of resources should be both fast and effective, tensions may arise in the pursuit of these two objectives.
This topic is the subject of the report on the mid-term processes of the Structural Funds (No 1/2007) and the Commission report on the management of the CARDS programme in the Western Balkan countries (No 5/2007).
Although planning does not guarantee effectiveness, it is important.
Issues related to strategic and long-term planning were discussed in the reports on the expenditure of the EU institutions on buildings (No 2/2007) and the evaluation of the EU Framework Programmes for Research and Technological Development (RTD) (No 9/2007) and in the two external assistance reports, one for CARDS (No 5/2007) and the other on the effectiveness of the capacity-building technical assistance (No 6/2007).
The Commission's evaluations are a key element of their performance management system in the performance evaluation process and, where necessary, in order to identify the need to improve performance.
If the evaluation takes place at an early stage in the programming cycle, this means that progress is insufficient and insufficient data is available for the evaluation.
On the other hand, it is possible to reduce the possibility of making changes in due time in the current period, as well as improvements before the start of the next period, where evaluations will be carried out at a later date.
The issue of a proper evaluation schedule was addressed both in the report on the mid-term processes of the Structural Funds (No 1/2007) and in the report on the evaluation of RTD (No 9/2007).
23 • • Evaluation, like audits, is more difficult when the objectives of the spending programmes are unclear; this is another subject raised in the last two reports.
The management and control of EU expenditure are subject to complex rules and must be made clear and clear to ensure that the appropriations are used for the purposes set out.
Clear definitions and rules are crucial for the collection or use of resources in accordance with the timetable.
This was the subject of reports on the European Refugee Fund (No 2007/2007) and on the control of goods and substitutions carried out by Member States in the field of agricultural exports (No 4/2007).
The lack of common definitions is one of the factors that may affect the completeness, comparability and reliability of data from different Member States.
This may have consequences where data are the basis for a decision, including the allocation decision.

OPINIONS PUBLISHED In 2007, the Court also contributes to improving the EU's financial management by issuing opinions on proposals or issues relating to financial management.
These opinions are required under the procedure for the adoption of financial rules 4 or may be issued at the request of one of the other institutions of the Community 5. In addition, the Court may issue opinions on its own initiative.
The Court's opinions may concern certain areas of expenditure, such as the two 2007 opinions, which concern the new regulations of the European Development Fund (Nos 2/2007 and 9/2007).
They may also cover broader issues related to EU financial management, such as the Court's opinion on the annual summaries, national declarations and audit work of the national audit authorities (No 6/2007).
Opinions are based on the Court's expertise in managing the EU's financial management over the years in the course of the audit and in some cases relate to certain audits.
For example, in its opinion on ensuring the correct application of customs and agricultural legislation (No 3/2007), the Court recalls the recommendation in the previous special report that the Commission should take action to improve the reliability of sources of information on fraud.
The need for simplification is a recurring issue in the Court's opinions (see, for example, Opinion No 7/2007 on the Financial Regulation applicable to the general budget of the European Communities).
In its 2007 opinion (No 6/2007), the Court presented its position on the annual summaries as well as on the so-called national own-initiative declarations presented by certain Member States.
This opinion is discussed in detail in the section on the Court's position.

Most of the Court's opinions have been published in the Official Journal of the European Union and are available on the Court's website.
26 SUPERVISION AND EFFECTIVENESS In modern democratic society, the financial control of the public sector, with a view to effective financial management, plays a key role.
The control activities shall be communicated to the addressees at the end of the information chain, in this case to European citizens, in order to determine whether their taxpayers' money is spent properly and properly.
Public financial control is a fundamental element of accountability and a useful basis for public debate.
In this respect, the Court's activities have significant potential for impact.
The Court's audits serve decision-makers in the relevant institutions in the European context, in particular the Commission, the Parliament, the Council and the Member States, as a direct source of information.
On the basis of this information, they may take action, with or without reference to the conclusions of the checks.
Although the Court's audit activities have a major impact on the published reports, the Court's activities already have an impact on the audit process as a whole.
In particular, all checks shall lead to detailed checks to be submitted to the audited entity to confirm the accuracy of the Court's observations.
The final text of the report shall also be subject to the adversarial procedure.
The German Commission shall not publish the answers of the investigating authority together with the reports.
In its replies, the audit authority often presents the problems identified by the Court and presents the measures it intends to take to resolve them.
Following the audit work and the publication of the report, the audit results shall be assessed and used by Parliament and the Council to carry out their policy tasks to monitor the use of budgetary resources.
In the framework of the annual discharge procedure, the Court's reports form the basis of the Council's recommendation and Parliament's decision.
The 2006 discharge procedure drew particular attention to the Court's conclusions on structural measures.
In its resolution on discharge for 2006, Parliament refers directly to the action plan proposed by the Commission following the conclusions of the Court's annual report and asks for quarterly reports on its implementation.
Parliament also calls for a better view of the corrective action taken to remedy errors and errors.
Special reports shall also be taken into account in the discharge procedure.
However, given that they are published during the year, the presentation of special reports and the discussion of them took place at Parliament and the Council meetings, usually at an earlier stage.
A good example of possible further action is the recent special report on building expenditure (No 2/2007).
Parliament has already entrusted its administration with preparing a report assessing the possibility of creating a European Construction Office entrusted with the building and maintenance of European Union institutions and bodies.
The Court's report on the checks on agricultural exports (No 4/2007) carried out by the Member States can be given as a further example.
The Council and the Commission responded promptly to the Court's recommendations and amended the existing rules.
The effectiveness of audit reports can be increased in view of them in the relevant media, paying more attention to them and encouraging public debate.
The media is the most direct source of information for citizens.
As a general rule, the press reports in the Court's annual report are fairly comprehensive, but the press has also followed some special reports with interest.
The report on fisheries (No 7/2007) is of great interest to the media.
In order to discuss the Court's report, an Extraordinary Council for Fisheries was set up and the Commission launched a procedure which could lead to amendments to the legislation in order to address the shortcomings identified.
This is an example of a report which, due to its relevance and relevance, can make a very valuable contribution to the decision-making process.
This section provides some guidance on the impact of the Court's reports published in 2007.
Detailed information on the follow-up of the Court in the past is provided in the relevant chapters of the Court's annual report.
The Court's most widespread comment in its most recent annual report is that, in spite of the recent action taken in the last year, the doubts detected in the previous year were only partially removed.
Opinions should also be considered when analysing the impact of the Court's work.
The Court's task is increasingly to analyse the long-term effects of its work of the undertaking at the same time as its opinions on the subject, as well as its effects on the subject, as well as its 27 BOX 4 TO THE COURT'S OPINION ON PARTICIPTION Over the years, the Court has published several opinions setting out ways to strengthen the overall system of internal control of the EU budget.
The opinion on a single study in 2004 (No 2/2004) made a significant contribution.
In this opinion, the Court proposes to introduce the definition and implementation of the entire internal control system into a single integrated control system, including common principles and guidelines, and to ensure a proportionate level of costs and benefits.
Opinion on a single audit in 2007 on a reference document for the Commission, but also for the Court, in its comments on the definition of effective and effective internal control in the updated rules for the implementation of the Financial Regulation (opinion No 1/2007).
The integrated audit approach is reflected in the Commission Action Plan for the Integrated Internal Control Framework for 2006.
The Commission has taken steps to highlight the role and responsibilities of the Member States in the field of internal control, including the new commitment to submit annual summaries of opinions, declarations and audits carried out in accordance with the regulations applicable to the various areas of expenditure.
28 THE COURT'S OPINIONS SUMMARY AND DECLARATIONS The Commission and the Member States have taken initiatives to increase the involvement of Member States in the cycle of responsibility for EU measures.
The aim is to address in part the problem of significant errors in legality and regularity in the main areas of budgetary expenditure, in particular in areas in which the Commission and the Member States co-manage these actions.
Important recent events are the obligation of Member States to submit annual summaries of available research results and declarations, voluntary initiatives of certain Member States to submit national declarations, and the decision of certain national audit authorities to draw up audit reports on the management of EU funds.
In its opinion No 6/2007, the Court considers that all these elements, if properly implemented, can contribute to better management and control of EU funds.
The opinion sets out the conditions under which these elements can be added value and can be applied by the Court in accordance with international control standards in accordance with the requirements.
Since annual summaries form part of the internal control system, the Court will assess, within the framework of its usual control procedures, to the extent that they improve the functioning of internal control.
Annual summaries, to the extent that they reflect strengths and weaknesses, may lead to improved overall control of EU funds in the areas of shared management.
National statements are based on voluntary initiatives by some Member States, which are issued at the highest level and transmitted to national Parliaments.
Although they do not in themselves constitute conclusive evidence, they constitute a new element of internal control and provide valuable information on the implementation of the EU budget.
The Court recognises the potential benefits of the statements of national and national audit work with a view to raising awareness of the importance of internal control of EU funds in the Member States.
The audit work carried out by national control authorities (national control reports) on the legality and regularity of EU expenditure or by national declarations could provide the Court with evidence of the control if the Court is able to verify the suitability and quality of the audit work in accordance with international control standards.
In such a case, the Court will take into account the information provided by the national control authorities in the planning and carrying out of its own controls.
National declarations and control reports shall contain declarations concerning control systems.
National declarations may also contain certain audit opinions on the legality and regularity of transactions.
Experience has shown that the main risk to the legality and regularity of transactions is the reliability of the information provided by the beneficiaries when they ask for EU funding and not the way in which the data is processed by the Member States and the Commission.
A declaration that systems operate in accordance with the requirements of the EU Regulation cannot guarantee the legality and regularity of the transactions in question.
Recognising the need to increase the role of national audit authorities in the overall context of responsibility for EU expenditure, the EU Supreme Audit Authority Contact Committee has set up a working group on the harmonisation of audit standards and standards, adapted to the EU context.
Common methods and methods of control shall increase the possibility for the Court of Justice to use the work of the national control authorities, provided that the quality of the work is directly demonstrated.
EU BUDGET BUDGETografiaisation In September 2007, the Commission published a consultative document aimed at launching an open debate on EU funding in the framework of a wide-ranging budget review.
At the beginning of April 2008, the Court presented its contribution to the debate, in which it presented the key principles to be taken into account when drawing up the new programmes in order to ensure European added value in order to ensure clarity of objectives, simplification, dealing with reality, transparency and accountability.
The Court recommended, inter alia, that: • • • • targeting expenditure programmes not according to expenditure but according to results; making better use of the concept of acceptable risks when drawing up and adopting expenditure programmes; the degree of discretion to be granted to national or regional authorities in the management of expenditure programmes and financial reporting on expenditure; whether own resources under VAT continue to be a sensible part of the own resources system; taking due account of all the compensatory mechanisms that comply with the guiding principles of the own resources system; the degree of fairness, transparency, cost-effectiveness, simplicity and cost-effectiveness of the individual Member States in terms of cost-effectiveness29.
30 THE COURT'S WORKS IN 2007 AND THE AUDIT WORKS IN 2007 The Court presents its future audit work annually in the work programme submitted to the European Parliament's Committee on Budgetary Control and available to the public on the Court's website.
The Court monitors the implementation of the work programme as a basis for improvement in the coming years.
In 2007, there was a significant increase in the number of specific annual reports adopted on European agencies and other decentralised agencies.
The number of special reports and opinions developed at a similar level as in previous years.
Annual reports on the general budget and the European Development Fund have been published as planned.
Results 2004 2005 2006 2007 Special reports 10 6 11 9 Annual reports (including EDFs) 1 1 Special Annual Reports 23 20 23 29 Opinions 2 11 8 9 In 2007 the Court first applied its new Assurance model (in order to ensure the security of controls) to achieve the most effective results.
The Court also decided to provide more detailed information on the results of its Statement of Assurance, in particular on the results of the audits of individual transactions.
The Court considers that this is linked to the provision of useful information for monitoring purposes, which will enable the measurement of the progress of financial management, together with the schematic presentation of the results of the system assessments.
The Court's action plan and procedures have continuously sought to improve all aspects of its work.
In 2005, the Court decided to undergo peer review.
In this case, senior staff of a small number of the highest audit authorities shall assess the organisation or performance of a sister institution on the basis of professional standards and professional experience.
Since all the highest audit bodies have similar tasks, peer review mechanisms can be a very valuable contribution to improving the functioning of the audit authorities.
In 2006, in preparation for the peer review procedure, the Court carried out a self-assessment which enabled the institution to examine its strengths and weaknesses.
In 2007, the Court adopted an action plan to remedy the shortcomings identified.
The programme included a total of 23 actions, of which six concerned task forces, involving members of the Court and the staff from different fields and levels of institution hierarchy: 31 1.Model, mission, strategic objectives and planning 2. Management structure, structure and organisation 3. Internal performance indicators 4. Workers and communication 5.Models, external communication strategy 6.Improving the quality of the reports The results of these task forces included new declarations on orders, reports and values, as well as strategic objectives for the Court, a new strategy and guidelines for internal communication and a report on how to improve the quality of reports.

The Court seeks to increase the visibility of its audit results through the selection of relevant topics, the approximation of time and a clearer and clearer preparation of its reports.

In 2007, considerable efforts were made to further develop the methodological basis for the Court's work as a key prerequisite for a high quality audit work.
A new manual for accounting control and compliance control to be completed in 2008 has been developed with high workloads.
The new Economic Audit Manual of the Court was adopted at the end of 2006 and was first made available as guidelines for auditors in 2007.

In the new IT strategy adopted in 2007, the Court expressed its intention to increase its capacity to carry out IT control and to transform.

IMPROVING THE IMPROVEMENT OF THE ASPECTS OF THE COURT A lot of the tasks set out in the Action Plan concern communication, which in 2007 was devoted to increased efforts.
Among other things, a new website was launched and information material was published on the annual report in a format which was easier to access and the Court agreed to a new procedure for the presentation of special reports to the Committee on Budgetary Control of the European Parliament.
Further developments, usually directly or partly related to the Action Plan, related to the modernisation of the Court's accounting system and the new strategic documents on human resources and IT.
The Court has also launched the modernisation of its IT systems in the areas of control, translation, knowledge and communication, management and staff information.
In addition, the Court made progress in 2007 in preparing for the second extension of its main building, which is necessary in view of the recent and planned increase in the number of employees.
The Court will present an annual report on the European Development Funds, together with the annual report on the general budget of the EU, as well as the special annual reports on the European agencies and other bodies, in 2008, as in previous years.
Expenditure planning within the general budget of the European Union shall take place in seven-year cycles, i.e. within the financial framework.
2007 was the first year of the new financial framework focusing on the implementation of policies.
The Court uses this opportunity to look at earlier innovations, namely the Commission's shift to business-related budgeting, business-related management, and the distribution of the budget to 31 policy areas, with some 220 actions.
The 2007 Annual Report is divided into policy groups, which are largely but not fully linked to the new headings of the financial framework.

36 INTERNATIONAL COOPERATION WITH THE EU'S INTERNATIONAL CONTROLS IN ACCORDANCE WITH THE TREATY The European Court of Auditors is to carry out an audit with the highest audit authorities of the Member States (ORKB) in connection with the Treaty of Amsterdam: Accommodation and national control authorities shall cooperate in a trusty and independent manner. The Nice Treaty obliges the Court of Auditors to set up a committee for contacts with the national control authorities in which all the Presidents and the Court meet each year in order to discuss matters of common interest.
Ongoing contacts shall be maintained by liaison officers designated by the CMRs concerned.
Working groups have been set up to support the development of common positions and practices.
In 2007, the delegation of the Court attended the annual meeting in Helsinki on 3 and 4 December, organised by the Finnish Court of Auditors.
The meeting focused on risk management, on acceptable risks and on an integrated internal control system for managing EU funds and focused on the role it plays in risk management in this area.
The Court will host the next meeting of the Contact Committee on 1 and 2 December 2008.
In 2007, two meetings of liaison officers were held to prepare a meeting of the Contact Committee.
The first meeting was held on 23 and 24 April in The Hague and the second in Luxembourg on 11 and 12 October, chaired by the European Court of Auditors.
The two meetings discussed recent developments in EU financial management and discussed the work of the Task Force Task Force on Cooperation in Cooperation in Cooperation in Cooperation in Cooperation in the field of Cooperation, on the contact committee itself and on its functioning and on improving its functioning and, in this respect, proposals on improving its functioning.
The meeting also addressed the activities of the various working groups and expert groups set up by the Contact Committee to discuss specific issues of common interest.
The Court has been involved in the meetings of the network of candidate and candidate countries in the field of education and training and training and in the field of education and training in the field of education and training and education and training and in the field of education, education and training, and in the field of education, training and training in the field of education, education and training.
The presidents of the ORKB of the candidate and candidate countries of the medium-term and the European Court of Auditors met in Skopje on 11 and 12 June 2007 (the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia).
The principles of control are an important aspect of all efforts to improve practical cooperation in the control of EU funds.
In this context, in 2006, the Contact Committee decided to set up a working group chaired by one of the members of the Court, Josef Bonnici, in order to develop common control standards and comparable control standards, based on internationally recognised control principles, adapted to the EU context.
The first meetings of the European Court of Auditors were held in Luxembourg in 2007.
In December 2007, the Helsinki Contact Committee received a progress report from the Working Group and adopted a resolution on the subject.
OTHER INTERNATIONAL COOPERATION The Court continued its active participation and participation in the improvement of international control rules through membership of European and international organisations of public financial control bodies, including Eurosai and Intosai.
Within Eurosai, the Court is represented in the Working Party on the Environment and the Working Party on Information Technology and participates in the Eurosai Education Committee.
The Court hosted a seminar on the analysis of the most common IT problems of the Luxembourg ORB of 17 and 18 April 2007, as well as a seminar on "Control of Economics" of 4-6 December 2007.
Since joining Intosai in 2004, he has joined the advisory sub-committee (FAS), the audit sub-committee (CAS) and the economic control sub-committee (PAS).
The Court participated in all meetings of the vehicle alarm system held in 2007 and actively contributed to the published and discussed guidelines.
As part of the FAS alarm system, he appointed a representative of the ERI (Mr Jesúsa Lázaro Cuenca) as one of the representatives of the alarm system for the draft Steering Committee for Technical Standards for Testing (ERI) for the New Delhi Technical Standards Committee (CESC) meeting in January 2007 in New Delhi.
In addition, the Translation Directorate of the Court made available resources for the linguistic review of the document in Spanish and German.
In addition, on the 19th Intosai Congress (Incosai) on 5-10 November 2007 in Mexico, in which two main issues were addressed: public debt, governance, responsibility and audit, and performance assessment systems based on commonly accepted key indicators.
In 2008, the Court will continue to participate actively in Eurosai and Intosai working groups, seminars and meetings.

38 STAFF POLICY The Court's most important capital is its staff.
They have a broad academic and professional context and the quality of their work and their commitment are reflected in the Court's work.
As part of the recent modernisation of staff policy, the Court focused on employment, training, career development and improving working conditions.
The participation of men and women in active service (officials and temporary and temporary and temporary staff, but without members, seconded national experts and trainees) was almost the same.
As shown in the chart below, since 2001, the number of women employed in the Court has increased as a result of the actions taken by the Court in order to achieve a gender balance.

Like the other European institutions, the Court uses a policy of equal opportunities in the management of human resources and recruitment and recognises the need to promote a more active increase in the number of women at the higher levels of the Court's management.
13 of 56 directors and heads of departments and departments (23%) are women, representing an increase of 3% compared to 2006.
Most of them are employed in the Translation Directorate and in the administrative departments.

Visits are usually carried out by central and local authorities involved in the approval, management and payment of EU funds and by their final recipients.
The examination teams usually consist of two to three examiners, and the length of the examination trip may be up to two weeks depending on the type of examination and the distance.
In 2007, travel costs related to test travel amounted to EUR 0,49 million (compared to EUR 0,43 million in 2006).
This represents a significant investment to ensure a sufficient level of control of all levels and the location of the management of EU funds.

In 2007, the Court's staff averaged 12 days of vocational training.
The percentage of specialised training increased significantly compared to 2006.
The main changes to training are the introduction of training courses for the Court's performance control manual and related guidelines, the Commission's accounting rules, the use of accrual accounting (ABAC), SAP financial systems and other IT applications and IT audits.
Language courses in 2007 accounted for 52% of the total number of training days.
The Court adopted a vocational training plan for 2008-2011, which provides for the development of vocational training in the coming years, focusing on the implementation of individual development plans for individual workers.
In addition, the Court examines the possibility of introducing a European Public Sector Auditor Diploma ector Diploma (POD).

43 BOX 6 has decided to apply the report on fishing activities, accompanied by the results of the report on control, control and sanctions of fisheries resources, adopted by the Court in 2007 (Special Report No 7/2007), which has aroused great interest among policy makers and the media.
The articles in many newspapers and the rapid reactions of both the Commission and the Council have shown the importance and relevance of the report.
The starting point for this success was a team consisting of a dozen auditors of the Court, who worked closely with the rapporteur member, Mr Kikis Kazamas and his office.
Emmanuel Lauch, a French auditor who has been working on the farm for several years, and his Spanish colleague, Mr Alejandro Ballester, were the team leaders during the preparatory phase in autumn 2005.
The audit included travel in six Member States, between Denmark and Italy, both to central managing authorities to gain insight into control systems and to major ports, in order to assess the functioning of the systems in practice.
To the extent that the language skills of the members of the team were insufficient, the translators of the language service of the Court provided assistance.
The audit team is very proud to have contributed to the fact that political decision-makers are gradually seeing the serious consequences of the implementation of the Community fisheries policy.
Other audit authorities have shown interest in the study as it provides suggestions and know-how, for example, on the forthcoming analysis of a similar issue in the Baltic States.

44 FINANCIAL INFORMATION OF THE BUDGET The Court's budget accounts for approximately 0,1% of the EU's general budget or 1.8% of the administrative appropriations of the EU institutions and bodies.
In the last three years, a 17% increase has been observed.
This increase is mainly linked to the consequences of the enlargement of the EU in 2004 and 2007.
Another substantial increase in the Court's budget for building activities (the building funds have almost doubled in the period 2006-2008), as the future new people that will be hired will be transferred to the second vacancy that is scheduled to be completed for 2013.
In 2007, approximately 72% of the total budget comes from human resources.

The INTERNAL Service of the Court's Internal Audit Service aims to assist the Court in the achievement of its objectives through a systematic and methodological assessment of risk management, internal control and administrative procedures.
Furthermore, the Internal Audit Department proposes to increase the efficiency of the Court.
Overall, the aim is to assess the performance of the different services in the implementation of strategies, programmes and actions to continuously improve.
In 2007, the Court's Internal Audit Division focused on the audit of accounts (including the support of the Court's external auditor's work), ex ante audit, the implementation of internal audit standards, the Court's most recent support (Building K2) and the Court's recruitment procedures.
The Court's Internal Audit Committee, composed of three members of the Court and an external expert, shall monitor and ensure the independence of the internal auditor.
The Committee shall also examine and approve the work programme and internal auditor reports and shall entrust them with certain audit tasks if necessary.
The Committee met eight times in 2007.

The presentation of the President of the Court of Auditors, as an independent audit body of the EU, makes an exceptional contribution to improving the EU's financial management and promoting transparency and accountability by providing audit services and as an example.
2008 was characterised by significant progress and important changes in the EU financial management referred to in this Annual Activity Report.
One extraordinary event was the expert assessment of the European Court of Auditors carried out by an international expert team which led to a positive conclusion on the adequacy of the Court's audit management framework and the independence and objectivity of the Court's work.
In its annual report for the financial year 2007, published in November 2008, the Court issued for the first time an opinion on the reliability of the EU accounts.
However, as in previous years, there have been too high levels of errors as regards legality and regularity in areas of the EU budget, which represent the largest part of the expenditure.
In 2008, the Court also recognised developments at EU and national level which should lead to a significant improvement in the EU's financial management in the future.
The two examples presented in this annual activity report relate to the ongoing review process of the EU budget to which the Court has made an active contribution and to the Commission Communication on an acceptable risk of error.
In the field of international relations, the Court has taken the lead in organising the meeting of the Contact Committee of the Presidents of the European Union's Supreme Audit Authorities on the reform of the European Union's budget and the renewed Lisbon Strategy, as well as the hosts of the recent EU-ORKB workshop on the role of the EU-ORKB in response to the current financial crisis.
Given that the control environment is changing rapidly, the Court considers that internal reforms are necessary to better fulfil its obligations under the Treaty and to fulfil its tasks effectively.
In 2008, the Court took significant steps to implement its mandate and to develop an audit strategy for the period 2009-2012.
The audit strategy is based on two priority objectives: maximising the overall impact of controls and improving efficiency through the best use of resources.
These objectives will have a decisive impact on the Court's work programmes during this period and on its efforts to continuously improve and exploit the main challenges and opportunities of exploiting the potential of improvement identified in the framework of the peer review.
With their competences and involvement, the Court's staff have a key role to play in carrying out the audit work, which the Court does as an independent guardian of the citizens' financial interests in order to improve financial management.
On behalf of the Court and on my own behalf, I would like to thank all the workers for their commitment and professional work last year.
Special thanks for our personal commitment and commitment are due to our former Secretary-General, Michel Hervé, who was withdrawn at the end of 2008.
I wish you a pleasant reading of this annual activity report, which will provide an insight into the Court and an overview of the activities carried out in 2008.
Vítor Manuel da Silva Caldeira President 5

THE COURT'S ROLE AND WORK THE COURT'S WORK IS THE EU BUDGET The European Union's budget is around EUR 120 billion, which represents around 1% of the gross national income (GNI) of the 27 Member States.
However, for some Member States, EU funds play an important role in the financing of public activities, which is approximately the equivalent of the GNI of some Member States.
The revenue of the European Union consists mainly of contributions from Member States from their gross national income (GNI allocated, 65,4 %) or from VAT collected by Member States (VAT 16,9 %).
Customs duties and agricultural duties (so-called traditional own resources. 16,5 %) also represent a significant part of revenue.
Over time, budget composition has changed and agricultural and cohesion policy are the main areas of expenditure (see Box 1).
BOX 1 IN THANKS TO THANKS TO HIS HIS ARMS? THANKS TO HIS ARMS?
The EU budget is financed by Member States' financial contributions (mainly based on GNI) and by agricultural duties and duties.
The EU budget largely serves objectives other than the national budget, partly due to different responsibilities.
For example, the Union is not responsible for social security systems, which usually represent a significant part of national expenditure.
Since the 1960s, agricultural expenditure, which generally takes the form of payments to farmers across the Union, has been the main part of the budget expenditure, although it is now declining.
In 2009, 45.3% of the budget for the conservation and management of natural resources, mainly for agriculture and rural development, was allocated.
Since the 1980s, a large proportion of cohesion policy expenditure, i.e. regional and social development, has been allocated to co-financing various projects.
For 2009, expenditure on sustainable growth is planned at 39.6% of the budget, most of which is cohesion policy.
This budget area also covers most of the EU's research budget.
In addition, EU funds are heavily allocated to development and humanitarian aid, as well as to countries close to the Union or candidate countries.
6.7% of the budget is allocated to the management of the Community institutions.
Citizenship, freedom, security and justice The European Union, as a global partner The management of agriculture and management of natural resources 45.3% 1.2% 7.2 % 6,7% EU expenditure Cohesion for sustainable growth Source: European Union's general budget for the financial year 2009 (OJ L 69, 13.3.2009) 39.6%
The budget shall be decided annually by the Council, i.e. the representatives of the Member States, and by the European Parliament, directly on a proposal from the European Commission on the basis of a seven-year financial framework.
The Commission shall draw up and be responsible for the implementation of the budget.
Most of the budget cannot be used to cover agricultural and cohesion policy expenditure, notably agricultural and cohesion expenditure, in particular in cooperation with the Member States.
A particular feature of Community expenditure is the high percentage of payments based on the applications of the beneficiaries themselves, both farmers and project managers throughout the Union 8.
Democratic society needs complete and correct information available to the public, which is the basis for discussion and decision-making, both to improve financial management and to ensure accountability.
The EU, like its Member States, has an external audit body, which acts as an independent guardian of citizens' financial interests.
The European Court of Auditors, acting as an EU external auditor, shall ensure that EU funds have been correctly booked and spent in accordance with the rules, with due regard for the optimal use of funds, regardless of where they are used.
The Court's audit work is being used by Parliament, the Council and the Commission, as well as by the Member States, to improve the EU's financial management.
The Court's work is an important basis for the annual discharge procedure during which Parliament takes a decision, on the basis of Council recommendations, whether the Commission has fulfilled its responsibility for the implementation of the budget during the previous year.
The Court has no judicial powers, even though it has no powers.
In the budgetary areas where shared management is carried out, Member States shall cooperate with the Commission in establishing supervisory and control systems, i.e. internal control and internal control, in order to ensure the correct and correct use of the funds.
In this way, internal control has a European and national dimension.
In addition to the Court's activities, many national control authorities control EU funds, provided that they are managed and spent by public authorities in the Member States.

Special annual reports on the results of the audit of the accounts of the agencies and bodies of the Communities.
Special reports above containing the results of the performance and compliance checks.

The Court shall audit the EU's annual accounts in accordance with the international audit rules (ISA), which apply both in the public and private sectors.
However, the existing international control rules do not fully cover the conformity control carried out by the Court.
The Court, together with the national audit bodies, is actively involved in the development of international audit standards, which promote standardisation bodies (INTOSAI, IFAC) 4.
In order to ensure compliance of payments with the rules and legal framework, the Court is based on the results of the analysis of supervisory and control systems to prevent errors in the legality and regularity of payments, to detect and correct errors in legality and regularity and in payments and on the sample of individual transactions (payments) (see Box 2).
Where systems are reviewed and are considered reliable, the number of operations which the Court needs to examine to obtain reliable conclusions on their legality and regularity.
Other sources, such as the work of other auditors, are also used to support the Court's conclusions.
The Court uses a number of control methods to assess management and control systems and assess results on the basis of the criteria of legislation to ensure compliance with the principles of sound financial management.
With regard to the selection of topics for performance control, the Court seeks to identify the control areas for which they are expected to have the greatest impact in the form of the demonstrated potential for improvement in the savings, efficiency and effectiveness of EU expenditure. 11 is closed, as well as the Council Decision on the association of overseas countries and territories (OCTs).
The Commission manages most of the expenditure related to the ACP States, partly through the EuropeAid Cooperation Office (see external relations, development and enlargement matters) and partly through delegations in beneficiary countries.
Investment instruments under the EDF shall be managed by the European Investment Bank (EIB) and shall not be audited by the Court.

The sample shall be carried out by random selection of a representative sample of transactions underlying transactions underlying settlements carried out in all areas of the Union budget, such as agriculture, in order to carry out a detailed assessment.
The Court monitors these operations up to the final recipient of the aid, such as the farmer in France.

As a statistical sample, the results can be statistically calculated for a given population, i.e. for a specific area of revenue or expenditure, and can be used as the basis for the general assessment as a basis for the general assessment, together with the information resulting from the systemic assessment.

The Court of Auditors shall act as a collegial body of 27 members, each of which has one member from each Member State.
All audit reports and opinions shall be adopted by the College.
The Court shall consist of five audit groups to which individual members shall be assigned.
As is apparent from the organisational chart (see page 17), there are four thematic control groups, covering different budgetary areas (care and management of natural resources and structural measures, transport, research and energy,...,...,... external measures and... financial measures, banking measures, administrative expenditure, Community institutions and bodies and internal policies).
The Fifth Audit Group (CEAD or coordination, communication, evaluation, quality assurance and development) is responsible for horizontal issues such as coordination in the field of assurance, quality assurance, development of the Court's audit methodology and the general dissemination of the Court's audit results and reports.
In addition, the Management Committee shall be responsible for preparing all administrative matters requiring a formal decision of the Court.
MEMBERS of the Court shall be appointed by the Council after consulting the European Parliament for a six-year term, as proposed by each Member State; the term of office shall be renewable.
Members shall carry out their activities in a fully independent manner for the general good of the European Union.
In addition to its role in the college, which is responsible for taking the final decision on audits and opinions, as well as on further strategic and administrative issues, each member shall be responsible for its specific tasks, in particular in the field of audits.
The competent examination work is usually the task of examiners in each examination department and is coordinated by the competent member with the support of his office.
The member shall then adopt the report in the audit group or in the Court and after its adoption in the European Parliament, the Council and the other interested parties.
On 1 January 2008, three new members... Mr Michel Cretin (France), Mr Harald Noack (Germany) and Mr Henri Grethen (Luxembourg) (Luxembourg) replaced their predecessors after their term of office.
The Council extended the mandate of four members: Hubert Weber (Austria), Maarten B. England (the Netherlands), David Bostock (the United Kingdom) and Ioannis Sarmas (Greece) (Greece) for six years.
The President-in-Office of the European Court of Auditors shall be the President of the European Court of Auditors, who shall be elected from among the members of the European Court of Auditors for three years and may be re-elected.
The President shall represent the Court in all its external relations, in particular in relations with the discharge authority, with the other institutions of the European Union and with the highest control bodies of the Member States and of the beneficiary countries.
On 16 January 2008, a member of the Portuguese Vítor Manuel da Silva Caldeira was elected President of the Court. 14
The Secretary-General of the Secretary-General shall be the highest-ranking member of the institution and shall be appointed by the Court for a period of six years and shall be renewable.
The Secretary-General shall be responsible for the management of the Court's staff and staff, including vocational training and the Directorate-General for Translation, including, in any case, one unit per official language (22), with the exception of the Irish language.
The Secretary-General shall also be responsible for the secretariat of the Court.

The Court's auditors shall have broad training profiles and appropriate professional experience in both the public and private sectors, in particular in the field of accounting, financial management, internal and external audit, as well as in the field of law and economics.
Like other EU institutions, the Court employs citizens from all Member States and employees are subject to the EU Staff Regulations.

SUMMARY OF THE AUDIT REPORTS AND OPINION5 OF THE ANNUAL REPORTS FOR THE FINANCIAL YEAR 2007 OF THE ANNUAL REPORT ON THE IMPLEMENTATION OF THE EU BUDGET FOR ANNUAL OPERATIONS AND THE PROTECTION OF THE EU BUDGET
The limits on the reliability of the accounts for the financial year 2006 reported in last year's annual report for the financial year 2006 have ceased to apply due to the improvements made in the meantime in 2007.
In certain areas, such as the Union's administrative expenditure, the Court issues unlimited opinions on legality and regularity.
However, the Court cannot deliver an unqualified opinion on most expenditure areas.
Although most of the payments verified by the Court have been made in accordance with legal provisions, the Court still considers that the level of error in payments to final beneficiaries, such as farmers and entities that finance projects financed by EU funds, is too high.
With the exception of cohesion policy measures with an error rate of at least 11%, the error rate estimated by the Court in these policy groups varies from 2 to 5 %.
In some areas of expenditure, in particular in areas where they were covered by internal or external policy, the estimated error rate fell but would not change in such a way as to change the overall picture.
This does not mean that infringements are the result of fraud or that most of the activities in these areas are illegal or illegal.
SITUATION IN CERTAIN AREAS In three areas: administrative and other, economic and financial expenditure, as well as revenue, the audit of a representative sample of transactions carried out by the Court showed a low estimated error rate.
In the largest area of European Union expenditure In the area of agriculture and natural resources, the overall error rate in the projections remains significant.
The disproportionately high proportion of these error rates is due to rural development and to their often complex systems.
In the case of the expenditure of the European Agricultural Guarantee Fund (EAGF), the error rate estimated by the Court is slightly below the materiality threshold of 2%.
As in previous years, cohesion actions, which account for more than a third of the budget, constitute the area which is most likely to be affected by errors.
Due to the Court's random assessment of the proportion of transactions in which errors occurred, at least 11% of the total amount of the refund could not be paid.
5 This section aims to include it in the Court's reports and opinions and not to summarise them.
For more information, see the full text of the Court's documents published on the Court's website (www.eca.europa.eu) after their adoption.
19. IMPROVING MONITORING AND CONTROL The high level of error in areas such as cohesion is partly due to inherent risks arising from a large number of beneficiaries applying for EU funds under complex rules and regulations.
The shortcomings identified also contribute to the design and functioning of the systems.
Most EU funded programmes contain provisions on corrective actions which, on a multi-annual basis, provide for the recovery of funds unduly paid for errors.
However, there is no information on the impact of these measures.
This means that it cannot be concluded that it effectively reduces the proportion of illegal and/or irregular expenditure.
Since 2000, the Commission has been working on a reform programme to improve the management of the EU budget, including the 2006 Action Plan.
By the end of 2007, the Commission implemented two thirds of the sub-measures contained in the Action Plan.
However, it is still too early to assess the impact of these measures.
Improved high-level controls, including controls carried out by the Commission in the Member States, do not compensate for insufficient controls carried out at the lower level, such as on-the-spot checks.
However, the benefits of increased on-the-spot checks should be considered in relation to costs.
The Court recommends that the Union's political bodies determine the appropriate level of risk of error.
In order to reduce the level of error in EU payments, the Court recommends simplifying rules and rules, improving internal control and improving monitoring and reporting.

The Court published, in 2008, a total of twelve special reports.
In order to improve the readability and readability of the reports, the Court decided to publish its special reports in a new format and to make them available directly on its website (www.eca.europa.eu), and in the Official Journal only reference is made to their publication.
As in previous years, the reports concerned investigations into financial management in many areas and covered, from the effectiveness of the European Solidarity Fund (N° 3/2008) to the European Union's aid for the storage of cereals in public storage (N° 11/2008).
The Court's audits have revealed different types of problems with different effects and have led to recommendations aimed at improving financial management and improving efficiency and efficiency.
The thematic choice for and design of economic efficiency checks is the responsibility of the Court and is based on criteria such as risk analysis, potential for improvement and public interest.

OPINIONS PUBLISHED IN 2008 The Court also contributes to improving the EU's financial management by issuing opinions on proposals or issues related to financial management.
These opinions are required as part of the procedure for the adoption of financial rules7 or may be issued at the request of one of the other Community institutions8.
Moreover, the Court may present own-initiative opinions.
The Court's opinions may concern certain areas of EU expenditure, such as the revision of the Financial Regulation of the European Aviation Safety Agency (No 1/2008) or issues relating to EU revenue, such as the revision of the Regulation on the system of the Communities' own resources (No 2/2008).
Opinions shall be based on the Court's expertise over the years in audits on EU financial management and in some cases on certain audits or opinions.
For example, in its opinion on the new Financial Regulation of the European Joint Undertaking for Reactor Reactor Reactor, the Court referred to its annual report for the financial year 2006, in which it already drew attention to the high risks associated with the legality and regularity of the research aid payments.
