ADOPTION AND IMPLEMENTATION The public control policy plays a key role in promoting accountability and contributes to public debate.
Audit activities shall be transmitted to addressees at the end of the information chain, in this case to European citizens, in order to determine whether taxpayers' money is spent properly and properly.
The Court's audits serve the decision-makers in the institutions concerned in the institutions concerned in the European context, in particular the Parliament, the Council, the Commission and the Member States, as a direct source of information.
On the basis of this information, they may take action with or without reference to the conclusions of the checks.
Although the Court's audit activity mainly affects the published reports, the audit itself had a certain effect.
In its replies, the evaluation body often reveals the problems identified by the Court and presents the steps it intends to take to resolve them.
Following the audit work and the publication of the report, the results of the audit will be analysed and used by Parliament and the Council to carry out their policy tasks in monitoring the use of budgetary resources.
In the framework of the Court's annual discharge procedure, the Court's reports form the basis for the Council's recommendation and Parliament's decision.
29 Examples are included in the discharge procedure for the implementation of the 2007 budget, in which the European Parliament calls on the Commission and the Member States to make efforts to simplify and further clarify the rules in order to reduce the risk of errors, to improve controls and to reduce costs.
This applies both to shared management areas and to expenditure on agriculture and cohesion policy, and to direct management areas and expenditure on research, culture and education.
Special reports will also be taken into account in the discharge procedure.
However, given that they are published during the year, during Parliament and the Council meetings, the presentation of the special reports and the debate in this regard were usually held at an earlier stage.
The impact of audit reports can be increased by maximizing them in the relevant media, paying more attention and encouraging public debate.
The press reports on the Court's annual report are usually quite extensive, but the press has also followed some special reports with interest.
An example of this is the special report on cross compliance (No 8/2008) which was published at the time of the adoption of the Health Check of the common agricultural policy (CAP).
Due to the importance of cross compliance and its key role within the CAP and the moment of publication, in several of the media, the report on this publication has taken on the importance of television, newspapers, specialised newspapers, Internet publications (press, agricultural organisations, MIP websites, Internet blogs, etc.).
The report has also been widely discussed in the European Parliament and almost all the recommendations of the Court have been taken into account in the draft report on discharge.
Detailed information on the follow-up to the Court's earlier observations is provided in the relevant chapters of the Court's annual report.
The Court's most frequently stated statement in the most recent annual report is the statement that, despite the actions taken in the previous year, the shortcomings identified in the previous year have only been partially remedied.
The Court intends to examine increasingly the long-term impact of its work, as well as of its work, including its opinion, as well as its opinion.
For example, the Court uses the Commission's database, which takes into account the follow-up to the Commission's audit recommendations, as a basis for assessing the impact of the audit.
In the light of this assessment, separate detailed studies may be carried out leading to further findings and recommendations.
They may be taken into account in the special report on the field concerned or in the report on the follow-up and impact of the recommendations on financial management.
THE COURT'S OPINION ON THE RISK-TARIFF-CONCEPT In the context of the development of the Community internal control framework, the Court held in its Opinion No 2/2004 that the responsibility to decide the level of risk which they are willing to accept lies with the political bodies at the time of the approval of the Union's expenditure systems.
The Court proposed that Parliament and the Council agree on an appropriate cost-benefit ratio, in other words an acceptable residual risk of error in expenditure.
The costs of controls should be proportionate to the monetary and political benefits they bring.
Since the publication of this opinion, both the European Parliament and the Council have expressed their desire in their resolutions on discharge to continue their work on the common understanding of the acceptable level of risk.
At the end of 2008, the Commission issued a Communication entitled "Towards a common understanding of the concept of tolerated risk of error........ " (Towards a common understanding of the concept of acceptable risk of error).
The Court welcomed this Communication and forwarded a response to the Commission with some restrictions and a clarification of the key issues to be taken into account to be taken into account in the future follow-up.
In the Communication, the Commission notes that any decision on the acceptable risk of error should be based, inter alia, on the possibility of further simplification.
The Court also stresses the importance and importance of further simplifications and the potential consequences of reducing errors and irregularities.
The concept of acceptable risk of error not fully separated from the concept of materiality threshold, defined and applied by the Court, falls within the competence of the external auditor10.
The Court considers that an analysis of the costs and benefits of expenditure programmes could provide information not only for the purpose of discussing the acceptable risks but also for the review of the regulatory framework and the administrative structure of the programmes.
In this context, it cannot be an important question whether an acceptable risk of an error exists, but whether the risk of an error is high enough to remove/regulate or radically change the system or programme concerned.
In the design of expenditure and revenue schemes or programmes, particular attention should be paid to the concept of acceptable risks.
It would be good if expenditure programmes were sufficiently detailed at the time of their adoption to be sufficiently detailed about the risks involved and about the costs of the planned controls to reduce these risks to an acceptable level.
In this way, decisions would be taken in a conscious manner and with a clear consideration of the risks and costs involved.
The budgetary reform process may provide an opportunity to reflect on how the Court's response to the Commission's Communication entitled "Budgetary money" urged reform in Europe to change11.
31 10 The concept of "knowledge" is defined in the International Rule of Control of ISA 320 as follows: "Information" is necessary where their omission or misconception may affect the economic decisions of the persons who have taken decisions on their basis on the basis of the financial statements.
The importance depends on the size of the position or error resulting from the particular circumstances of omission or misrepresentation.
This means that importance is rather a threshold or a limit rather than a basic quality requirement that must contain information to be useful.

33 STRATEGIC OBJECTIVES Professionalism Customer areas Further development and increase Audit methods, adequate audit strategy, further development of audit practice in the public sector, the development of common audit standards and comparable audit standards of EU funds, cooperation with EU-ORKB, an effective Community control framework for control practices, in time, clarity and readability of reports, quality of performance control, increase the impact of reports on the strengthening of relations with the entities under review, in order to better understand the control process, as well as to better accept the results of controls, in order to strengthen contacts with the European Parliament and the Council as the budgetary authority and discharge authority Effective communication with EU citizens on the peer review process in order to strengthen the organisation, methods, processes and results and to strengthen and achieve as effective and as effective as possible for monitoring effective and dynamic staffing of high quality vocational training; modernisation of infrastructure Implementation of the STRATEGII control IT policy for 2009-2012 Maximising the overall results of controls in terms of efficiency through the best use of resources
The objective of the Court's audits and reports is to contribute to improving the EU's financial management and the protection of the EU's financial interests to EU citizens.
The main aspects were taken into account in the formulation of the Court's strategy of action: The implementation of the reports: Audit actions The work programme The audit strategies for 2009-2012 for 2009-2012 were developed in 2008.
A summary of this document is available on the Court's website.
The Court's strategy is based on two priority objectives: maximising the overall impact of controls and improving efficiency by making the best use of resources.
These objectives will have a significant impact on the Court's work programmes during this period and on its efforts to improve.
The Court seeks to maximise the overall impact of the checks over a given period by: • selecting and planning checks which focus on risk areas and which are most interested in the Court's addressees; • continuing to present conclusions from the checks and favourable conclusions on the improvement of whether these proposals are implemented; • more audits are being carried out and new types of products are presented to complement the current annual and special reports; • preparing more special reports which are in line with time and more user-friendly; • continuing to develop relations with the main addressees, including the relevant parliamentary committees, the media and the general public; in this period, the Court seeks to improve efficiency by maximising resources.
These include: • better governance; • efficient and dynamic human resources policy; • rationalisation of control tasks; • improvement of IT tools; • development of expertise; • strengthening relations with stakeholders34.
The 2009 work programme includes the drawing up of annual reports presenting the results of audits of the accounts carried out by the Court in accordance with the EC Treaty and other EU rules.
In 2009, the Court identified a number of issues relating to the development of EU financial management policies and issues.
In terms of change in EU policies, the following topics have been selected: • growth and employment; • climate change and sustainable development; • Europe as a global partner; • better regulation.
In addition, the Court stresses the following issues in the field of EU financial management which, in its view, deserve particular attention: • the completion of expenditure programmes for the period 2000-2006, in particular in the field of the Structural Funds; • EU accountability and reform; • the progress made in implementing the Commission action plan on an integrated internal control framework, taking into account the concept of acceptable risks; • management and control activities at Member State level.
The Court's objective is to consider these issues in the annual reports, special reports and some new types of reports, from 2009 onwards, as outlined below.
The Court intends to publish a number of special reports and related new reports on the basis of the audit tasks it has chosen.
The planning and performance of selected control tasks and reporting in this area usually last longer than one year.
Therefore, most of the reports published in a given year are based on studies carried out in previous years.
Box 5 contains selected audit tasks which have been completed or completed and the results of which will be published in the special reports in 2009 or early 2010.
35 12 A more complete and detailed review of the Court's future work can be found in the Court's 2009 work programme, available on its website (www.eca.europa.eu).
Monitoring recommendations is an important tool for the Court to actively contribute to improving financial management.
The report will analyse how we have implemented our recommendations and, where appropriate, assess the effectiveness of the measures taken.
It is expected to be published approximately at the same time as the annual report at the same time as the annual report.
The report is addressed to the new Commission, which will start work at the end of the year, and is intended to serve as guidelines.
In 2006, the Court carried out a self-assessment which identified its strengths and weaknesses.
An action plan was then drawn up to address shortcomings.
The Action Plan sets out a number of actions as a result of which the Court has identified • its orientations, tasks, strategic objectives and strategic planning, • the internal performance indicators that will be gradually implemented (see section below); • the internal communication strategy, which is already being implemented and which has opened up new channels to improve the dissemination of information within the institution; • a number of actions to improve the quality of its reports, for example through new graphical planning to improve the legibility and external evaluation; • the gradually implemented strategy to improve the Court's relations with its addressees, the press and the general public.
In 2009, the Court will seek to take into account the observations and recommendations contained in the International Report on the peer review of the European Court of Auditors, published in December 2008, which represents an important step in the current Court's reform process.
Representatives of the national control authorities of Canada, Norway, Austria and Portugal have made a special assessment of the peer review carried out by their colleagues.
They also spoke with the Committee on Budgetary Control of the European Parliament in 2008. The final report was presented at the end of 2008.
The purpose of the peer review procedure was to assess the concept and functioning of the control framework established by the Court.
The evaluation covered the following areas: • planning and audit of financial statements and audit of budget implementation; • reporting on audit results; • services supporting the Court in achieving its objectives; • on-the-spot checks; • on-the-spot checks; • on-the-spot audits; • on-the-spot audits; • reporting on audit results; • on-the-spot audits; • on-the-spot audits; • on-the-spot audits; • on-the-spot audits; • on-the-spot audits.
The peer review team concluded that the structure of the review framework established by the Court is in line with international control rules and good practice with regard to the highest control authorities.
In addition, experts have stated that: • the Court does its work independently and objectively; • the Court's audit reports are based on appropriate and appropriate audit evidence, in accordance with international control rules; • the persons concerned; • the persons with whom the audit has been carried out are of great trust in the Court's reports and, as a rule, consider them to be fair, factual and objective.
The Court welcomes the constructive comments and recommendations of stakeholders which indicate how to further strengthen the role of the main audit body and point to the challenges involved.
This includes, inter alia, the need to:• develop a culture focusing on the Court's single approach as an audit body;• strengthen quality assurance and quality control activities to ensure a coherent interpretation and application of its strategy and control methods; • develop a risk-based control strategy to make the best use of resources to meet the different needs of the public.
The peer review report acknowledges that most of the recommendations have already been adopted under the Action Plan that was drawn up before the start of the procedure.
The Court intends to incorporate the other recommendations in its audit strategy for 2009-2012 after the exchange with workers and addressees and will make every effort to implement them in that period.

IN 2008 the Court decided to introduce a system of key performance indicators (CL) for its control and non-audit activities to measure the performance of the Court's strategic objectives and objectives set out in the annual work programme.
CLI aims to increase internal and external responsibility and to increase productivity and quality of work.
In order to inform management of how effectively the Court, as an institution, is carrying out what it has carried out; • to support the decision-making process, they place an emphasis on efficiency and improve; • to inform stakeholders about the relevant issues relating to the efficiency of the Court.
Their role is to provide information on the Court's performance as an undertaking and becomes an integral part of the Court's management system.
The number and quality of audit work can also be improved taking into account the impact of the Court's reports and opinions on financial management.
The four key performance indicators (1 to 4) measure the impact of the Court's work.
They will be designed to be included in the Court's annual work programme for 2010.
In 2008, the Court carried out a performance check on the basis of ZLI 5 and 6.

INTERNATIONAL COOPERATION COOPERATION WITH THE EU NATIONAL CONTROL AUTHORITIES In accordance with the EC Treaty, the ECA must carry out checks with the highest audit authorities of the Member States (ORKB), while the Treaty of Amsterdam later added: With full confidence, the Court of Auditors and national audit authorities shall cooperate, with respect for their independence, in the Nice Treaty, with a view to extending the system through a clear call by the Court of Auditors in the 18th Declaration of the Final Act to establish a Contact Committee with the national audit authorities, in which all audit Presidents and the Court shall meet each year in order to discuss matters of common interest.
In December 2008, the Court hosted the annual meeting of the EU-ORKB Contact Committee.
The meeting focused mainly on the reform of the EU budget and on the renewed Lisbon Strategy for the period 2008-2011.
The Contact Committee seeks to strengthen cooperation between its members in order to improve external audit and accountability in the EU.
Over the years, the role of the Contact Committee has developed in parallel with European integration.
In addition to facilitating the exchange of information between CMR and the ERC, the team has made significant progress in the effective cooperation between the different control bodies.
At its 2007 Helsinki meeting, the Contact Committee recognised the need to address emerging or emerging new issues in due course, and considered that a permanent agenda to address such current issues should be established.
Therefore, the meeting of the Contact Committee in 2008 discussed the economic and financial crisis and agreed to organise workshops on the role of the EU-ORKB in the context of the crisis.
A network was subsequently set up to support cooperation in the control of the Lisbon Strategy and EU crisis management activities.
The Court took part in meetings of the WFD of candidate and candidate countries in the Institute and took part in meetings of the Expert Group (Turkey, Croatia, the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia, Albania, Bosnia and Herzegovina and Montenegro).
These meetings took place at the same time as the liaison officers' meetings in May and October.
The delegation of the Court also participated in workshops organised in Ankara, Turkey, on 8 and 9 July in order to examine/evaluate the internal control systems of public finances.
Throughout 2008 the Court has actively participated in the various working groups set up by the Contact Committee.
In 2008, which aims to develop common audit standards adapted to the EU environment and comparable control standards based on international audit principles, it held four meetings chaired by the Court.
Since December 2008, the Court has taken over the (mobile) Presidency of the Tax Working Group.
The Court continued to actively participate in the improvement of international control rules and procedures through membership of European and international organisations of public financial control bodies, including EUROSAI and INOSAI.
The delegation of the Court took part in the VII Congress of EUROSAI, which took place on 2-5 June in Krakow (Poland).
The main topics of the discussion were the introduction of quality management systems in control systems, the control of social programmes in the field of education and professional integration of people with disabilities.
The President of the Court has contributed to the role of the management in the implementation of the quality management system of the control system.
Within EUROSAI, the Court is represented in the Environment Working Group and the IT Working Group and participates in the EUROSAI Education Committee.
The Committee also participates in the work of the Working Group set up at the 7th EUROSAI Conference in order to develop a Guide on Best Practices in order to achieve quality within the Working Group.
The Court is also a member of the EUROSAI Task Force on the control of civil protection assistance measures. 42
The European Court of Auditors, together with the highest audit authority of the Slovak Republic, was appointed an auditor for the period 2009-2011 for the Congress of EUROSAI.
Since the Court took the position of a full member of INTOSAI in 2004, it has been actively involved in the work of the Audit Guidelines Sub-Committee (FAS), the Compliance Audit Sub-Committee (CAS), and the Performance Control Sub-Committee (PAS).
The Court has contributed to the subcommittee on promoting best practices and quality assurance through voluntary peer reviews.
Since 2008, the Court has chaired the Working Group on Liability and Control of Civil Protection Assistance (Tsunami successors within the INTOSAI Task Force).
The first meeting of this working group took place between 30 June 2008 and 2 July 2008.
This meeting discussed and adopted the draft work programme for the period 2008-2010.
The main objective is to develop guidelines on accountability and control in this field in order to achieve all stakeholders through the competent authority, which is responsible for the development of guidelines on accountability and control in this field.

In 2008, the Court had 97 staff: 48 officials, 18 temporary staff and 31 contract staff.
Employment depends on the availability of reserve lists from EPSO competitions.
In the absence of suitable candidates, the Court was unable to recruit as many new workers as was planned in many departments, so in the end of 2008 the total number of job vacancies (69) was higher than at the end of 2007.
However, it should be noted that, at the end of the year, a significant number of workers were held and that the workers concerned should start work in the first quarter of 2009.
The Court is currently working to shorten the time limits for recruitment procedures.
Translation is an important administrative task that enables the Court to achieve its communication objectives and is in line with its legal obligation to publish in 22 languages.
In 2008, the value of translations increased by 17%, mainly due to the adoption of more special reports.
The vast majority of translations are made internally, and during peak periods, during which normal translation capacity has been exceeded, translation orders are made available to the Translation Centre (CTOU) or external translation agencies.
In addition, translators participate in examinations visits and support examiners before, during and after examination visits, including in the subsequent stages of the examination reports.
Translators constantly support the updating of the content of the intranet and the website in English and French.
They shall also assist INTOSAI working groups and ensure that other specific needs related to the Court's activities are met.
The Translation Directorate of the Court actively participates in the work of the Interinstitutional Committee for Interpretation (CITI), is a member of international committees and participates in international conferences in the development of electronic translation and documentation tools.
CONTROL AS During the Court's audit work, auditors must travel to the Member States and to other countries benefiting from EU funds to obtain the relevant evidence.
These checks shall normally apply to central and local authorities involved in the approval, management and payment of EU funds as well as to final beneficiaries.
The team of controllers usually consists of two to three controllers, and the length of the examination trip can be up to two weeks, depending on the type of examination and the distance.
Within the EU, control missions are often carried out in conjunction with the highest control authorities in the visited Member State, which provide useful logistical and practical support 47.
In 2008, audit travel costs amounted to EUR 3.29 million.
This comprehensive investment is essential to ensure a sufficient level of control of all levels and the location of the management of EU funds.

4 Welcome to the 2009 annual report on the activities of the European Court of Auditors.
The purpose of this report is to present to the readers the most important results and the progress achieved by the Court this year and to present to them the significant changes in the control environment and the internal organisation.
2009 was an important year of renewal for the EU, which was the year the EU chose a new European Parliament, the year the Lisbon Treaty entered into force, and the year the new European Commission was launched.
The new Treaty reaffirms the role and role of the Court and the status of the EU institutions and introduces changes to the management and control of EU funds, stressing the role of the European Parliament and stressing the responsibility of the Member States for the implementation of the budget.
The Court expects these changes to provide good opportunities to improve the EU's financial management.
In the section, the section decided to draw up a summary opinion on the risks and challenges facing the new Commission.
In this context, emphasis is placed on improving the quality of EU spending.
This year we have made significant progress in the implementation of our audit strategy for 2009-2012 and in achieving our objectives this time we have increased our performance and increased the use of our resources this year.
Our decision to submit to the Council of the European Union to approve the new Rules of Procedure to improve our procedures for the adoption of reports and opinions was a key step.
In addition, the number of Court reports increased from 42 in 2008 to 57 in 2009.
I am also pleased to say that our main product, our annual report on the implementation of the EU budget, has also received another positive acceptance by our main institutional audiences, who have agreed with many of our recommendations.
In 2009, the Court continued its active cooperation with the Supreme Audit Authorities of the Member States (ORKB) to develop a common approach to the control of EU funds and to consider how the ECB can help governments deal with the financial and economic crisis.
The Court's results depend on the competence and motivation of 880 employees.
Their satisfaction is key to the success of the Court and is set out for the first time in this report.
I would like to thank the Court's staff for their tirelessness and commitment to their work in order to enable the Court to implement its mandate.

As an external EU auditor, it contributes to improving EU financial management while acting as an independent guardian of the financial interests of EU citizens.

8 THE COURT'S ROLE AND WORK 8 THE COURT'S ROLE 8 IS THE EU BUDGET The European Union's budget for 2010 is around EUR 123 billion, representing around 1% of the national gross income of the 27 Member States.
However, for some Member States EU funding plays an important role in funding public actions, and the overall budget compared to the GNI of several Member States is significant.
The revenue of the European Union consists mainly of contributions from Member States resulting from their gross national income (GNI change from 76%), customs duties and agricultural duties (so-called traditional own resources own resources. 12%) and VAT collected by the Member States (VAT) (VAT of 11%).
BOX 1. FOR WHAT DOES THE EU EXPECT ITS NEWS?
The EU budget is financed by contributions from Member States (mainly on the basis of national GNI), agricultural duties and duties and VAT contributions.
The EU budget is mainly used for purposes other than the national budget, mainly because of different responsibilities.
Citizenship, freedom, security and justice 1.1% Conservation and management of natural resources (mainly agriculture) 47.3% The largest area of expenditure in the EU is agriculture and rural development, primarily in the form of payments to farmers in the EU resources, in the form of payments to farmers of 1% of the budget expenditure, of which almost half of the budget is allocated to agriculture and rural development.
Another major part is the regional and social cohesion actions in the context of the launch of a wide range of projects, ranging from road projects in Latvia to training for the unemployed in the Netherlands.
This sector accounts for about one third of the budget expenditure.

The budget shall be approved annually by the Council, i.e. representatives of the Member States, on the basis of the seven-year financial framework and by the European Parliament directly elected.
The European Commission shall draw up the budget and shall be responsible for its implementation.
Most of the budget In particular, in the area of agricultural and cohesion policy expenditure, the CAP is working in cooperation with the Member States.
A particular feature of Community expenditure is the high percentage of payments based on applications of the beneficiaries themselves, whether farmers or project managers across the Union9.
10 WHEN DOES THE COURT HAVE THE ROLE?
Democratic society needs reliable and publicly available information as a basis for discussion and decision-making both to improve financial management and to ensure accountability.
The European Court of Auditors shall act as an external EU controller to ensure that EU funds, regardless of their place of use, have been properly booked and spent in accordance with the law and with due regard to the requirement to make the best use of the funds.
The Court's audit work is used by the Commission, the Parliament and the Council and by the Member States to improve the EU's financial management.
In addition to the Court's activities, many national audit authorities check whether EU funds are managed and spent by public authorities in the Member States.

3. Is financial management in line with the principle of sound financial management, i.e. the resources have been kept to a minimum (savings), have the results been achieved with the least possible use of resources (efficiency) and have the desired objectives (efficiency) been achieved?

12 HOW DOES THE COURT REQUIRE IN THE CASE OF REQUIRINGING THE VALUATION OF VALUATION?
The Court shall audit the annual accounts of the EU in accordance with the international audit rules in force in both the public and private sectors.
However, the existing international control rules do not include the Court's conformity control.
The Court is actively involved in the development of international control rules in cooperation with the national control authorities, which promote organisations which will standardise (INTOSAI, IFAC) 4.
In order to ensure that payments are compatible with the legal framework and other regulatory frameworks, the Court is based on the results of the examination of both the supervisory and control systems to prevent, detect and correct errors of legality and regularity and on the sample of individual transactions (payments) (see Box 2).
Other sources, such as statements by the management of the bodies audited in the form of annual reports on the activities of the Directors-General of the Commission, as well as the work of other auditors, shall also be used in support of the Court's conclusions.
With regard to performance control, the Court uses a wide range of control methods to evaluate management and monitoring systems and to evaluate performance data on the basis of regulatory criteria and the principles of sound financial management.
As regards the selection of subjects for the audit of the performance of the tasks, the Court seeks to identify the areas of control for which the greatest impact can be expected, in the form of significant potential for improvement in terms of savings, efficiency and effectiveness of EU expenditure.

The Commission manages most of the expenditure related to ACP countries, partly through the EuropeAid Cooperation Office (see external relations, development and enlargement) and partly through delegations from beneficiary countries.

BOX 2 pickup EU BUDGETARY MSS 13 The Court does not have the resources necessary for the detailed examination of all EU budget-related operations.
Therefore, it uses statistical sampling techniques to present the results representative of the population concerned.
The Court monitors these operations until the final beneficiary of the grant, e.g. the project promoter in Italy.
The Court has repeatedly examined whether the proposal is compatible with the reality.
The representative sample allows for extrapolating the results to the appropriate population, i.e. the specific area of revenue or expenditure, and may form the basis for the general audit opinion, together with the information resulting from the evaluation of management and control systems and other sources.

14 TASKS AND TASKS5 14 STRUCTURAL STRUCTURAL AND ORGANISATION The Court of Auditors acts as a collegial body consisting of 27 members, each consisting of one member per Member State and members appointed by the Council for a six-year term after consulting the European Parliament.
Members shall elect a chairman from among themselves for a term of three years, with the possibility of re-election.
The five audit groups to which each member of the Court is assigned shall prepare reports and opinions to be adopted by the Court.
According to the organisational scheme, there are four thematic audit groups covering different budgetary areas, as well as other audit groups dealing with horizontal issues at the horizontal level at national level.
In addition, the Management Committee, composed of the members of the Court, shall be responsible for preparing the Court's administrative decisions.
At the end of 2009, the Court presented to the Council a proposal to amend the Rules of Procedure in order to allow the adoption of certain categories of Court opinions and reports instead of the entire College of Chambers.
These changes will improve and improve the Court's decision-making process, inter alia by reducing the time needed for the adoption of the decision.
Each Chamber has two areas of competence: the first area is the adoption of special reports, special annual reports and opinions; the second area is the preparation of draft annual reports on the general budget of the EU and the European Development Fund and draft opinions to be adopted by the College.
As in the case of the Court, decisions shall be taken by a majority of the Members of the Chamber.
Members may attend meetings of each Chamber but shall have the right to vote only in the Chamber to which they have the right to which they have been assigned by the Court.
Of course, all the Colleges are meeting to discuss and adopt documents for which the Court is, in itself, responsible, such as annual reports on the general budget of the EU and the European Development Fund.
Strengthening the role of the Management Committee.
The Committee shall consist of the President of the Court holding the Presidency and the President of the Chambers.
Administrative matters requiring decisions of the Court and decisions on procedures, principles or strategic matters shall be prepared by the Committee before they are submitted for approval by the Court.
The Member shall then present the report to the audit group and to the Court and present it to the European Parliament, the Council and the other interested parties following the adoption of the report.
For more details, see the Court's website (www.eca.europa.eu).
THE COURT'S STAFF The budget for the financial year 2009 provides for 880 posts for the European Court of Auditors (at 31 December 2009).
The Court's audit staff shall be responsible for the planning and carrying out of audits and the preparation of draft reports on them.
Auditors work in groups of different sizes: for certain specific audits, the team consists of four or five auditors, whereas for some more detailed audits of the Court (e.g. audits of accounting/compliance audits on agricultural expenditure and consistency in order to produce an annual statement of assurance) there are at least 20 auditors.
In general, auditors need to obtain evidence as part of controls under different procedures: documentary checks in Luxembourg, visits to the European Commission and visits to Member States, where revenue from the EU budget is generated and where actions financed from the EU budget are implemented.
The Court's reports and opinions must be accessible to readers throughout the Union and throughout the EU in the framework of the audit activities, the Court must maintain contacts with bodies and other bodies throughout the Union.
This would not be possible without the Court's interpreters who translate their reports and opinions (in almost all cases, in English or French) into 22 official languages of the Union.
They also translate correspondence between the Court and other bodies as necessary and, in some cases, assist inspectors in carrying out inspection visits in the Member States.
The Court's administrative staff shall be responsible for a number of tasks relating to assistance to a multi-national organisation operating in the context of the EU.
This applies to finance, accounting, budget, buildings, information technology, transport, security, etc. The Secretary-General is the Court's highest representative and is responsible for the management and management of the Court. 15

In the field of rural development, the estimated error rate is lower than in previous years, but is still significant.

The Court estimates that at least 11 per cent of the total amount of reimbursement could not be made. • The Court's recommendations on the improvement of the supervisory and control systems adopted in the past remain valid.
They should be considered as part of an ongoing process where appropriate measures can be considered effective only after a certain period of time. • In addition, particular attention should be paid to areas of expenditure where the Court continues to face a high level of error.
In many cases, errors arise from excessively complex rules and regulations.

26 Have the management instruments for the market in milk and milk products achieved their main objectives?
The Court has assessed the functioning of the milk and milk products market since the introduction of milk quotas in 1984 and has assessed the way in which the Commission manages the gradual deregulation of the dairy sector which started in 2003.
The situation at the end of 2008 is the basis of the Court's recommendations to the Commission: the prevention of new overproduction, the monitoring of the price-setting process in the food chain, the deepening of the reflection on the future of producers in less-favoured areas and the impact in which milk production on the environment is concentrated geographically, the further targeting of milk production to meet the needs of the European internal market and the high added value milk products which are able to export to the world market without budget support.
CITIZENSHIP, CITIZENSHIP, SECURITY AND LAW • No 2/2009 W • The European Union Public Health Programme (2003-2007): an effective public health solution? The European Union Public Health Programme (2003-2007): an effective way to improve health?
The Court has examined the European Union's action programme in the field of public health for the period 2003-2007.
The Court's audit was intended to determine whether the framework conditions for projects financed from the EU budget were defined in such a way as to effectively complement Member States' efforts to protect and improve public health.
The report shall include detailed proposals and recommendations for the development, implementation and management of the programme.
On the basis of its findings, the Court disputes the benefits of certain elements of the European public health programmes, such as the PHP.
The Commission and the Member States are invited to reconsider the EU's approach to public health funding.
EU AS A GLOBAL PARTNER • No 1/2009 AL Banking activities in the Mediterranean under the MEDA programme and previous protocols • No 4/2009 on the Commission's management of non-state actors in development cooperation • No 12/2009 on the effectiveness of the Commission's projects in the field of justice and home affairs for the Western Balkans • No 15/2009 on the EU's assistance through United Nations organisations in the management of decisions and non-public control on development assistance development cooperation for Turkey in the framework of the management of pre-accession assistance to Turkey by the European Commission • No 15/2009 on the effectiveness of EDF assistance for regional economic integration in East Africa and West Africa in West Africa on 27 The European Commission's management of pre-accession assistance for Turkey has examined the management of pre-accession assistance to Turkey by the European Commission.
In particular, the first period of implementation of pre-accession assistance (2002-2006) was characterised by a number of shortcomings that had already occurred in previous pre-accession programmes.
The objectives set by the Commission for grants were not specific enough to enable the impact of the project to be assessed and to demonstrate the effectiveness of pre-accession assistance, the Commission did not have the necessary information.
However, the projects audited have produced the planned results and the results are likely to be sustainable.
While some significant improvements have already been made by the Commission, the Court, however, makes recommendations for further corrective action.
The areas where improvement is most needed include the definition of strategic grant targets, more realistic deadlines for achieving the objectives and the monitoring of the real results of the projects and the results of the projects, based on clear objectives and relevant indicators.

The Court's audits serve the decision-makers in the institutions concerned, in particular the Commission, Parliament, the Council and the Member States, as a direct source of information in the European context.
On the basis of this information, they may take action with or without reference to the Court's conclusions.
Although the Court's audit activities have the greatest impact on published reports and opinions, they have an impact on the entire audit process.
The Commission's replies, in particular, lead 29 As examples of the impact of the Court's work, the actions taken by the Commission in response to the resolution on discharge in respect of the implementation of the 2007 budget (which mainly impacted in 2009): in the area of agricultural expenditure, the management and control system of expenditure under the newly created European Agricultural Fund for Rural Development (EAFRD) has been adapted to the EAGF guarantee scheme, so that the benefits of this system are to a large extent recognised for EAFRD expenditure (see paragraph 5.54 of the 2004 Annual Report and paragraph 5.57 of the 2007 Annual Report).
In the field of cohesion, the Commission is still working on a review of the existing legislation for the period 2007-2013, with a view to simplifying the reporting system for irregularities and committed itself to prepare a report at the beginning of 2010 on the action taken in 2009 and on the first effects of its action to strengthen the Commission's supervisory function for the management of structural actions (see paragraphs 1.53 and 6.36 (a) of the annual report for the financial year 2007).
In the field of external policy In order to strengthen control at the level of implementing organisations, the Commission intends to develop a specific tool to support these organisations in the management of EU funds and in compliance with EU rules (see point 8.33 (a) of the 2007 Annual Report).
In the area of internal policy, including research, the Commission has developed a multiannual control strategy under the Sixth Framework Programme, based on the detection and correction of errors which could not be detected as part of the documentary control before payment.
In order to simplify the procedures of the Seventh Framework Programme, the Commission introduced a Participant Guarantee Fund, which allowed for a significant reduction in the number of ex ante controls and safeguard measures to be taken (see paragraphs 7.43 (b), 10.34 and 2.42 (a) of the 2007 Annual Report).

Special reports shall also be taken into account in the discharge procedure.
As they are published during the year, the presentation of special reports and the debate on this issue were usually held at Parliament and Council meetings at an earlier stage.
The results of the audit reports can be increased by addressing them in the relevant media in order to raise their attention and stimulate public debate.
As a general rule, the media report on the Court's annual report is quite extensive.
This was also the case in 2009, with the media focusing in particular on improving agricultural spending.
The press also followed several special reports with interest.
For example, the special report on the milk market (No 14/2009), assessing the extent to which the management instruments for the market in milk and milk products have achieved their main objectives, was the subject of intensive discussions in the Council and in Parliament and, during the period in which the sector was faced with various problems, the sector had a broad impact in the media and in the sectors concerned.
The Court is working on a further analysis of the impact of its activities.
In 2009 a mechanism for systematic monitoring of special reports was launched in order to identify and document progress in addressing the shortcomings identified and in the implementation of the recommendations contained therein.
This procedure will provide the Court, as well as Parliament and other interested parties, with additional feedback on the impact of its activities.
31 OPINION No 1/2010 of the Court of Justice on the improvement of financial management in the European Union: RISKS AND CHALLENGES In February 2010, the Court first expressed its views in its opinion on measures to reduce the scale of irregular payments in the EU budget and to improve the quality of expenditure (savings, efficiency and effectiveness).
The Court found that in order to increase recent progress in reducing irregular payments, legislation in high risk areas needs to be simplified, as well as more cost-effective control systems.
Such reforms should be carried out in the context of an ongoing comprehensive review of the EU spending systems.
The Court considers that improving the quality of expenditure is important, which can be achieved by applying the concept of European added value in the definition of expenditure priorities, as well as by addressing specific problems in the selection, development and implementation of expenditure programmes and grant programmes as defined by the Court.
CUSTOMS DIMENSIONS ON THE AREA OF INTERESTED HIGHEST AREA OF PAYMENT FOR PAYMENT, although the overall level of irregular payments has fallen, remain high in thematic groups of inconsistencies over time, in the framework of the Framework Programme for Research and Technological Development, and in rural development expenditure, and in the external aid, development and enlargement programme.
Most irregularities are based on reporting on ineligible expenditure by beneficiaries, reporting on excessive eligible expenditure and non-compliance with payment conditions, for example in the field of public procurement rules.
These are mainly due to the complexity of payment systems and conditions and to shortcomings in risk control systems at the level of final beneficiaries.
SIMPLIFICATION OF SIMPLIFICATED LAW FRAMEWORK AND IMPROVEMENT OF MONITORING AND CONTROLS The Commission should address the specific systemic deficiencies identified by the Court in high risk areas and improve its supervision.
However, in the case of an increasing number of controls and, consequently, in the event of a decrease in the level of error, a point has been reached where the costs of controls are no longer proportionate to the benefits obtained.
Simplification should therefore remain a priority objective.
Rules and legislation that are clear and simple to interpret may not only reduce the risk of error, but also reduce the costs of controls 31.
32 ENTITLEMENTS TO THE CONCEPT OF EXPENDITURE PROGRAMMES In addition to simplification, the Commission should ensure clear objectives during the review of existing and the development of new measures.
More awareness of reality, greater transparency and accountability are often needed.
To this end, the Commission could further strengthen the existing procedures for the development of future strategies, in particular ex ante evaluation and impact assessments.
Taking into account the European added value in defining expenditure priorities, the Court proposes to clarify the concept of European added value in the relevant political declaration or in EU legislation to give guidance to EU political bodies in defining expenditure priorities.
The Court considers that the Commission should complete the budget review as soon as possible and take account of the results of the financial framework starting in 2014.
Improving the quality of expenditure should be of particular importance to the institutions of the European Union and thus be the main objective of the new Commission.
33 THE COURT'S WORK PLAN FOR 201010 The Court presents its future audit work annually in the work programme submitted to the European Parliament's Committee on Budgetary Control and available to the public on the Court's website.
The work programme shall provide stakeholders with information on new and ongoing audits and on planned reports.
The Court has drawn up a control strategy for 2009-2012 which is based on two priority objectives: maximising the overall impact of controls and improving efficiency by making the best use of resources.
These objectives will have a decisive impact on the Court's 2010 work programme and its efforts to continue to improve.
The Court seeks to maximise the overall impact of the checks over a given period by: • selecting and developing audits in areas of risk and the greatest interest among the Court's addressees; and • to further explore the conclusions of the checks and the useful proposals for improvement; • ensuring that these proposals are implemented; • selecting audits, including the overall scope of the proposals; • ensuring that the new types of control products are added to the current annual and special reports; • developing more special reports, bringing together time and facilities; • improving relations with the main addressees, including with the relevant parliamentary committees, and with the media and the general public; in this period the Court seeks to improve efficiency by making the best use of resources.
These include: • better governance; • effective and dynamic human resources policy; • rationalisation of control tasks; • improving IT tools; • improving competence; • strengthening links with research units.
33 10 A more comprehensive and detailed review of the Court's future work can be found in the Court's 2010 work programme, available on its website (www.eca.europa.eu).
34 For the 2010 work programme, the Court has selected certain audit priorities, including: • the multi-annual nature of a significant part of Community expenditure, including lump sums and recovery; • innovation and the single market; • human capital; • sustainable energy; • the Commission's strategy to simplify the legal framework for businesses and citizens.
On 1 July 2009, Luxembourg founded a new building and the second extended the composition of the European Court of Auditors.
Vítor Caldeira, President of the European Court of Auditors, Claude Wiseler, Luxembourg's Minister for Construction, Patrick Gille, President of the European Development Fund, the choirs under consideration by Kirchberg, and Eduardo Ruiz García, General Secretary of the Court, this symbolic first spade, bearing the signal that the construction had begun.
This extension of the existing two buildings of the European Court of Auditors will enable the staff of the Union to be accommodated as a result of successive enlargements.
In 2009-2012, the Court will seek to broaden the scope of the audit reports.
To this end, it will coordinate its activities with its main external addressees in order to ensure that it is able to better understand their diverse needs and to best meet their expectations as part of the implementation of the mandate under the Treaty.
A large proportion of the resources at the Court's disposal is intended to be audited by the Court in order to produce a Statement of Assurance (the so-called Statement of Assurance).
This requires an analysis and an audit of the accounts and operations of the general budget of the EU each financial year.
European development funds and each of the 40 European agencies and bodies shall draw up separate declarations of assurance.
The audit activities shall cover the period from June of year n to June of year n+1 so that the annual reports can be published in accordance with the Financial Regulation in November of year n+1.
Therefore, a statement of assurance for the financial year 2009 will be drawn up and published in 2010, and at the same time a statement of assurance for the financial year 201011 will be started.
The objective of the Court's work is to present clear conclusions on the state of financial and financial management in the various areas of the general budget and to make appropriate and cost-effective recommendations where possible.
The Court's annual report on the general budget for the financial year 2009 will continue to be in line with the structure established in 2007, taking into account the new budget structure12.
The arrangements will be drawn up within chapters relating to related policy groups (thematic areas), but this structure is largely not in line with the chapters of the new financial framework.
Furthermore, the Court will seek to present more transparent and coherent results and conclusions to make them clearer and more transparent and easier to compare between and between thematic groups, and between them and between the financial years.

The aim of the ZLI is to strengthen internal and external accountability and to increase productivity and quality of work. SOURCE IndicatorS. • To inform management of how effectively the Court is the implementing body, of which it has taken, • to support the decision-making process which draws the institutions' attention to efficiency and quality issues, and • to inform the management of the relevant aspects which the Court is guided.
The purpose of the CLI is primarily the achievement of the Court's strategic objectives, as they concern the quality of the Court's controls, products, impact and economic management of the Court's resources.
They provide information on the functioning of the Court as an undertaking and do not form an integral part of the Court's management system.

TERMINATION The employment policy of the Court is in line with the general principles and conditions of employment of the EU institutions and staff is composed of both officials and contract staff.
The general procedures for the selection of posts at the Court are organised by the European Personnel Selection Office (EPSO).
The Court also provides a limited number of traineeships for higher education graduates for a period of between three and five months.
In 2009, the Court had 112 staff: 69 officials, 14 temporary staff and 29 contract staff.
The employment of these employees depends on the availability and availability of reserve lists from EPSO competitions.
In 2009, the Court managed to employ an adequate number of new workers.
The number of jobs that were not occupied on 31 December 2009 decreased by 33% to 49 by 26 January 2010 and the number of jobs will continue to decrease in the coming months as the recent recruitment collapse will continue to decrease.
At 31 December 2008, 68 posts were not planted.
The reserve list for posts based on EPSO AD/126/08 was published in August and the first successful candidates joined the Court at the beginning of November, i.e. only three months later.
EDUCATION BORROWING EDUCATION The profession of examiner requires continuous training.
Moreover, due to the specific nature of the Court's audit environment, the auditors need good knowledge of foreign languages.
In 2009, the Court's staff completed an average of 9 days of vocational training.
Language courses in 2009 accounted for 64% of the total number of training days (compared with 48% in 2008).
In 2009, without taking into account language courses, the inspectors completed four days of vocational training (see ZLI 10 on page 38).
This figure is expected to increase in 2010 as the number of new workers will have to undergo a compulsory training programme.
Based on the long-term strategic objective of getan. "Development and growth" Together with the "training action plan for 2008-2011" and the "training paths" adopted in 2009, the vocational training department introduced substantive improvements in training activities and developed new training courses in line with the priorities identified by the Court.
Furthermore, cooperation with other interinstitutional institutions and bodies, such as the European Administrative School, has been successfully continued.

CONTROL During the Court's audit work, the auditors must go to the Member States and to the other beneficiary countries of EU funds to obtain appropriate audit evidence.
Visits normally apply to central and local authorities involved in the approval, management and allocation of EU funds, as well as to final beneficiaries.
The team of controllers usually consists of two to three controllers, and the duration of the trip with the exam may be up to two weeks depending on the type of exam and the distance.
In the EU, controls are often carried out in conjunction with the highest control authorities in the visited Member State, which provide useful logistical and practical support.

50 REVISION The Commission's preparation and administrative and internal control services aim to support the Court's objectives through a systematic and methodological assessment of risk management, internal control and administrative procedures.
Moreover, the Internal Audit Department, which proposes the Court's effectiveness.
This requires a continuous evaluation of the internal control systems within the Court in order to assess their effectiveness.
In 2009, within the Internal Audit Section, the Court focused mainly on accounting checks (accounting checks), ex ante checks, checks on remuneration and deposit accounts, monitoring of contracts and procedures for the award of public contracts, as well as analysis of the transport process.
Most audit recommendations issued by the internal auditor in 2009 were accepted by audit entities and included in the corrective action plans.
The Court's internal audit committee shall supervise the internal auditor's activities and ensure his independence.
It shall re-examine and approve the work programme and the internal auditor's reports and shall entrust them with specific audit tasks if necessary.

European Court of Auditors Annual Activity Report 2010
The European Court of Auditors has set the following values: The European Court of Auditors shall be responsible for the audit of EU funds in accordance with the Treaty.
As an EU external auditor, it contributes to improving EU financial management while, at the same time, acting as an independent guardian of the financial interests of EU citizens by promoting accountability and transparency.
The independent and dynamic Court of Auditors, which is characterised by fairness and impartiality, which is recognised as a professional and quality and influence of its work, and which provides its addressees with valuable support for improving EU financial management.

4 COMPANIES Welcome to the fourth edition of the annual report of the European Court of Auditors. This year, we took the opportunity to re-divide the content into two main sections: two main sections: our activities....
In 2010, the Court of Auditors had two important opportunities to participate in the debate on the reform of EU financial management.
At the beginning of the year, the Court presented an opinion to the new Commission on the main risks and challenges of improving the EU's financial management and at the end of the year an opinion on the Commission's proposals for amending the Financial Regulation applicable to the general budget of the EU.
In the perspective of 2011, the Court will continue to implement its values and continue to develop the results and results achieved.
We will once again present high-quality, independent and objective reports and opinions, which will contribute to improving EU financial management and contribute to improving accountability and transparency, and, in particular, will continue to monitor progress in EU economic governance and will address new legislative proposals which will have an impact on EU financial management after 2013.
We are planning to publish 45 annual reports, i.e. annual reports on the implementation of the EU budget and of the European Development Funds, as well as specific annual reports on agencies, institutions and other bodies.
Special reports are an important opportunity to achieve added value, as they focus on areas where there is an increased risk and, in particular, on areas that are of particular importance to consumers and, in particular, to provide information on the quality of EU spending in different areas, ranging from the financial instruments and guarantee instrument for SMEs, to projects funded by the EU in the field of electronic administration and the single payment scheme in agriculture.
In continuing to implement the 2009-2012 strategy, the Court hopes that it will be able to make full use of the advantages of its recent reforms, including improved decision-making procedures; the Court will continue its efforts to recruit appropriate staff, to minimise the number of employees to the number of jobs and to continue to develop its employees.
Without the involvement and professionalism of all the Court's staff in 2010, we would not have achieved what we have achieved.

12 Special reports adopted in 2010 When selecting and selecting tasks related to performance and legality checks, the Court always aims at achieving the maximum impact and making the best use of the resources allocated to these tasks.
The Court takes into account the following factors when choosing the subject matter: • the risk to the economy or compliance with legal standards in the area of revenue or expenditure, • the level of revenue or expenditure, • the time since any previous control, • future developments in the legal or operational framework, • the political and public interest.
In order to obtain the necessary control evidence, the Court should carefully plan and carry out the selected performance and compliance checks and, before the report is published, give the audited authorities the opportunity to express their views on their findings and to formulate their replies.
Therefore, these checks usually last longer than one year.

18 Conservation and management of natural resources In view of the amount of EUR 413 billion for 2007-2013, the EU has extensive political competence and responsibility for agriculture and rural development, fisheries and the environment, and three quarters of the resources are allocated to the agricultural markets and direct payments to farmers, which are financed by the European Agricultural Guarantee Fund (EGF), the most interested in the pillar of the common agricultural policy (CAP).
More than one fifth of the expenditure is intended to support rural development financed by the European Agricultural Fund for Rural Development (EAFRD), the second Agricultural Fund for Rural Development.
Agriculture and rural development shall be managed jointly by the Commission and the Member States.

On 4 February 2011, the Court continued its active participation and participation in the improvement of international audit rules and procedures through the membership of European and international organisations of public financial control bodies, in particular INTOSAI5 and their European regional group EUROSAI.
The delegation of the Court took part in the 20th INCOSAI conference held in South Africa on 22 and 27 November 2010.
Since 2004, when the Court became a full member of INTOSAI, it has actively participated in the sub-committees on the various types of examinations, and the Court has also contributed to the subcommittee on promoting best practices and quality assurance through voluntary peer reviews and has contributed to the promotion of more intensive efforts to develop the competences of INTOSAI members.
Since 2008, the Court has been chairing the referral Working Party.
The main objective of these groups is to develop guidelines on responsibility for crisis assistance and to identify and disseminate best practices and to focus on activities aimed at stakeholders (Multilateral Organisations, Aid Organisations, Governments and Private Controllers) which were presented in November 2010.
In 2010, the Court also participated in the INTOSAI Task Force provided by EUROSAI. The Court is represented in the Environment Working Group and in the IT Task Force and participates in the EUROSAI Education Committee.
The Court also participated in the work of the Working Group set up at the 7th EUROSAI Summit in 2008, in order to draw up a guide on best practice in order to achieve quality in the OPCW. The Court is also one of the auditors of EUROSAI 25.
26 OUR MANAGEMENT OF THE IMPLEMENTATION OF THE STRATEGIES FOR 2009 audited by the Court in recent years, following self-assessment and peer review (2008), on the framework conditions for audit management, the internal reform process has started.
As a result, a strategy was developed for 2009-2012 to address the shortcomings identified; the overall objectives for the period are to maximise the overall impact of controls; to improve efficiency through the best use of resources.
Many of the priority actions of the strategy have already been completed; the remaining actions will be implemented in 2011 and 2012; the main achievements in 2010 include: the achievement of the objective: 12-15 reports on economic control per year; the development of new products; the risk and challenges document for the new Commission (opinion No 1/2010) and the new reporting system on the Court's recommendations since 2012; the revision of the Court's rules on the improvement of decision-making procedures by introducing chambers and strengthening the governance structure; and the revision of all performance indicators; the further development of the approach to the annual review of the implementation of the EU budget (certificate of assurance) on the basis of the recommendations of the panel of experts supported by external experts; and the revision of the structure of the positions of the control services support services.

27 The implementation of KAMTERN on the basis of the new internal regulation One of the main recommendations of the Court's reform process was the Court's use of the possibility for the Court to adopt certain categories of reports and opinions of the chambers referred to in Article 287 (4) of the Treaty, while respecting the principle of collegiality.
Following the approval by the Council of the necessary amendments to the Court's Rules of Procedure by the Council on 1 June 2010, the Council established chambers composed of the members of the Court of Justice and adopting special reports, special annual reports and opinions on draft legislative acts; earlier, all these reports and opinions were adopted by the College as a whole and continue to take place in the case of annual reports on the EU budget and the EDF.
Although most of the Court's reports are now adopted by the Chambers, the Chambers are given the opportunity to submit their documents to the Court for approval.
All members may attend meetings of chambers to which they do not belong without the right to vote.

28 DATA ON THE IMPLEMENTATION OF THE COURT In 2010, since 2008, the Court has gradually developed a set of key performance indicators (ZLI) to inform the management of the progress made in achieving the objectives of 2009-2012; to assist the decision-making process; to provide information on the performance of the addressees of the Court.
Since, for the first time, the compilation of all indicators is available this year, this is the reference year for future progress assessments. The Court is very pleased with the results in 2010 of key performance indicators, in particular in terms of the quality and impact of its work.
More importantly, indicators clearly identify areas where progress needs to be made and areas where problems need to be addressed in order to achieve better results in the future.

30 Follow-up of the recommendations The Court uses its audit experience primarily in the form of recommendations to improve financial management; in order to amend the Court's recommendations, the Court's recommendations must first be adopted and subsequently implemented by the audited entities; this indicator is based on recommendations published in 2009, i.e. in the latest available, annual and special reports.
In 2010, the objective of 90% ≥ 90% of the audit recommendations adopted by the audited entity the Court seeks to maintain or even improve this high level of acceptance in its recommendations.
In 2010, the Court established a system for monitoring the implementation of the recommendations by the audited bodies.
In the coming years, this system is intended to serve as a basis for a further indicator of the level of practical implementation of the recommendations and to improve them.
In addition, the Court will provide valuable information to improve the quality of its recommendations and thus to improve their acceptance among the authorities which it has audited.
31 The efficiency and effectiveness of the use of resources The Court shall assess the effectiveness and efficiency of the use of resources, depending on the extent to which it is in a timely position to report and audit reports, to meet its financial management commitments and to ensure the well-being and well-being of its staff.
For the purposes of the publication of the annual reports and of the detailed annual reports, the time limits laid down in the legislation should apply.
In the case of special reports for which there is no publication date specified in the legislation, the time limit within which the decision is to be adopted shall be deemed to be the time limit.

The level of employee satisfaction As part of the internal employee satisfaction survey carried out in 2009, 86% of the Court's staff were generally satisfied with the work, of which the level of employee satisfaction was 2.8 on a scale of 1 to 4, of which each value above 2,5 indicates the general satisfaction of the staff, and the Court seeks to maintain or improve this result when a similar survey is carried out at the end of 2012.
34 CONTROL SUPPORT The success of the Court's audit activities depends to a large extent on the quality of the support provided by its specialised services, which provide technical and logical technical knowledge enabling the Court to recruit, maintain and motivate its staff and to develop professional skills, to disseminate audit results in all the official languages of the EU, to make the best use of information technology, to manage the budget and to maintain infrastructure, to make audit visits to all countries where EU funds are transferred.
The Court's staff at 31 December 2010 was 889 staff (officials and temporary staff, but without members, contract staff, seconded national experts and trainees).
Of these, 557 people work at the control chambers (including 123 members' offices), 151 in the temporary translation Directorate (including 151), 157 in the administrative services and 24 in the President's services. In 2010 in order to achieve optimal use of resources, the possibility to increase the efficiency of all activities was re-examined and implemented by simplifying procedures and rationalising services.
As far as possible, the jobs released as a result of increased productivity outside the control area were transferred to the control services, which increased the number of posts used for control tasks by 6% and which will continue in 2011.

AUDIT AND INTERNAL CONTROL The Court's internal audit service should assist the Court in the implementation of its objectives through a systematic, methodological assessment of risk management, internal control and administrative procedures, and on the basis of assessments of the effectiveness of the Court's internal control.
In 2010, the Court's internal audit services focused primarily on the implementation of the recommendations of previous years, the review of the Court's ex ante audit system, the audit of the implementation of the Court's SOS II/SAP and on the compatibility of the video monitoring system with data protection rules and requirements.
In 2009, the internal audit services of the Court were checked and certified in accordance with the international standards of the Institute of Internal Auditors.
