European Court of Auditors Annual Activity Report 2011
The European Court of Auditors shall be responsible for the control of the EU's finances in accordance with the Treaty.
As an external EU controller, it contributes to the improvement of EU financial management and, at the same time, it is an independent guardian of the financial interests of EU citizens.
The independent and dynamic Court of Auditors, which is characterised by its integrity and impartiality, recognised as professional as well as as its high quality and impact of its work, which provides valuable assistance to its addressees to improve the EU's financial management.
Incompatibility, Integrity and Inconclusiveness PROFESSIONALITY MORE MORE EXTERNAL VALUE AND EFFIciency Independence, honesty and impartiality for institutions, its members and employees.
Unbiased examination of the views of the stakeholders but rejecting any form of interference by means of instructions or external pressures.
Maintaining a high and exemplary level of professionalism in all aspects of his work.
contribute to the further development of public financial control at EU and worldwide level.
preparing appropriate and timely high quality reports, based on sound findings and evidence, taking into account the needs of the recipients and containing relevant and constructive comments.
contribute to the effective improvement of EU governance and contribute to increasing responsibility for the management of EU funds.
Promoting a spirit of cooperation through effective communication.
increase efficiency in all aspects of his work.
3 CONTENTS Page 4 CONTENTS OF THE PRESIDENT 7 2011 FOR THE SUBMISSION 9 OUR ACTIONS 9 Audit reports and opinions 23 Cooperation with other MEMBERS 28 Other actions 31 OUR MANAGEMENT 31 Implementation of the Strategy 2009-2012 33 Measuring data on the results of the Court's audit in 2011 37 Support for audit actions 43 Financial information 46 Audit and accountability
4 Welcome to the annual report on the European Court of Auditors' activities for 2011.
In 2011, the economic and financial crisis led to a significant development of economic governance in the EU, which has a significant impact on the use of public funds in the future.
In this context, the Court published a document in May showing the impact of the measures taken in response to the financial and economic crisis on accountability, transparency and financial control.
Later in the year, the Contact Committee of the Presidents of the Supreme Audit Authorities (ORCB) of the EU Member States and the European Court of Auditors called on EU decision-makers to ensure that the principles of accountability, transparency and public control are properly respected in terms of the use of public funds.
In particular, the euro area ORKB requested the introduction of appropriate provisions for the public external financial control of the European Stability Mechanism.
This led to a decision on the establishment of the audit committee of the stability mechanism to which the member proposed by the Court will join.
In 2011, the results of our key performance indicators are also encouraging, especially as regards the monitoring of recommendations adopted by our units, as well as the assessment of our monitoring activities by the addressees and external experts.
We have managed to increase our performance with regard to the number of audit reports and opinions adopted in 2011, but we have failed to achieve ambitious targets for timely reporting.
Our annual reports now contained even more detailed information and a new chapter on the follow-up issues, as well as 42 annual reports and 16 special reports, together with seven opinions and a descriptive document.
The scope of the audit powers of the institutions in respect of the revenue and expenditure of the Union, in particular in respect of VAT-based own resources in the Member States, was confirmed by the European Court of Justice in November 2011.
Since 2012, we will be able to inform you of the extent to which our recommendations will be implemented in practice.
Our methods of economic control will also be peer reviewed in order to further improve the process of preparing special reports.
In 2011, we published ethical guidelines to further strengthen the Court's audit management framework and to modify the audit strategies and guidelines of the Court's audit to improve the audit and reporting process.
In addition, we will launch a new investigation into employee satisfaction in 2012.
With the future in mind, in 2012 we will complete the preparation of our strategy for 2013-2017.
Some of the main challenges are already evident: the EU regulatory framework will continue to develop and we must continue to ensure that the principles of accountability, transparency and public financial control are properly respected.
The need to ensure a high quality and timely guarantee of the use of EU funds is constantly increasing and we need to develop our audits and reports accordingly.
As the EU is constantly changing, we, too, will try to make the best of our audit experience to help decision-makers improve financial management.
Strengthening the EU's financial responsibility is one of the objectives that we have in common with other actors and we will seek to combine our efforts through strategic partnerships.
Finally, like other EU institutions and bodies, we need to be prepared to be less prepared to achieve the objective of improving the efficiency of our organisation.
These challenges will depend to a large extent on the efforts of all the Court's staff.
The development of excellence of our employees in our institutions is for us and remains for us an important value.
From the point of view of professionalism, commitment and past performance of our employees, I am convinced that the Court will also be able to achieve these future objectives.
Vítor Manuel da Silva CALDEIRA President 5

For the first time, the Court published the estimated error rates for both the EU budget as a whole and for the various thematic groups.
Error levels shall be determined by extrapolating the quantifiable errors found in the transaction trials examined.
The Court compares the estimated error rate with the materiality threshold of 2% to determine whether the error is material, taking into account further evidence that the error is material.
The error rate is not an indicator of fraud, but reflects the Court's estimates of an infringement of the rules on expenditure.
This includes breaches of public procurement rules, ineligible or miscalculated costs, ineligible or miscalculated costs of projects co-financed by the EU, or unnecessary information on areas provided by farmers.

ANNUAL REPORT ON THE EUROPEAN DEVELOPMENT FUND 2010 In its annual report on the European Development Fund (EDF) for the financial year 2010 (published on 10 November 2011), the Court concluded that the financial statements of the EDF for 2010 constitute essentially the financial situation of the EDF and the results of its operations and cash flows, in accordance with the Financial Regulation.
The revenue of the EDF shall not contain material errors.
The EDF's commitments were legal and correct, regardless of the non-quantifiable errors observed in the field of public procurement.
However, EDF payments for projects were largely affected by error; the estimated error rate is 3.4%.
The error detected concerned non-compliance with eligibility conditions.
The Court has assessed that the control systems established under the EDF ensure that all payments are to a limited extent correct.
SPECIAL ANNUAL REPORTS ON THE EU AGENCIES, DECENTRAL AUTHORITIES AND OTHER AUTHORITIES FOR THE DAY 2010 The Court published special annual reports for the financial year 2010 for all 42 agencies, decentralised agencies (e.g. joint undertakings) and other EU agencies (in particular the effectiveness of the management of the European Central Bank).
The Court delivered an unqualified opinion with respect to all bodies that were subject to scrutiny, with the exception of the European GNSS Agency, since certain properties were not included in the accounts and the ENIAC Joint Undertaking was not included in the accounts.
EU agencies and decentralised bodies have been set up by the EU legislator to carry out specific tasks.
Each agency shall have a mandate, a management, a director, a staff and a budget.
Agencies operate in many areas such as safety, health, research, finance, migration and travel.

12 SPECIAL REPORTS ADOPTED IN 2011 In addition to its annual reports, the Court shall publish, during the year, special reports containing the results of the economic control and compliance with the Court's control rules in each budgetary area or in the management areas of its choice.
In selecting and selecting audit tasks, the Court seeks to achieve the maximum impact and to make the best use of its resources.
When selecting the subject matter, the Court takes into account the following factors: the risks associated with cost-effectiveness or compliance with legal standards in the area of income or expenditure; the level of income or expenditure in the area; the time elapsed since any prior evaluation; possible changes in the relevant legal framework; the political and public interest.
In 2011, the Court adopted 16 special reports on a number of issues, which means an increase compared to the 14 special reports adopted in 2010.
The special reports are summarised below in the relevant headings of the financial framework in the EU's annual budget in the lean budget.
Special reports are available in 22 EU languages on the Court's website www.eca.europa.eu on a full scale or available in EU Bookshop.
SUSTAINABLE GROWTH 13 Sustainable economic growth focuses on economic growth and employment and covers two issues: competitiveness includes promoting research and technological development, the creation of European networks, education and training, promoting competitiveness in a fully integrated internal market, the social agenda and decommissioning of nuclear facilities.
EU expenditure on growth and employment for 2007-2013 amounts to EUR 89.4 billion, i.e. 9.2 % of the total, of which almost two thirds are R &amp; D. Cohesion for growth and employment mainly concerns cohesion policy implemented in the form of specific actions, the European Social Fund, the Cohesion Fund, the European Regional Development Fund and the European Regional Development Fund.
The Commission and the Member States shall allocate resources for shared management measures.
The EU budget for cohesion for 2007-2013 amounts to EUR 344.4 billion (35.7% of the total EU budget).
In 2011, the Court adopted the following special reports in this area: on the effectiveness of the SME Guarantee Facility (Special Report No 4/2011) on the design, planning, management and implementation of related operations.
The SME Guarantee Facility (SMEG) is a financial instrument managed by the European Investment Fund on behalf of the European Commission, which provides financial intermediaries with guarantees or reimbursements of loans granted to SMEs by financial institutions with a view to increasing the availability of debt financing. on The effectiveness of tourism projects co-financed by the European Regional Development Fund (EFERE) (Special Report No 6/2011) taking into account the expected results, their sustainability, European added value and the design of projects.
The evaluation was based on a wide-ranging study of projects in the new Member States and 26 regions.
Between 2000-2006, EUR 4.6 billion was allocated to in-kind investments in tourism projects and projects are selected and managed by managing authorities in the Member States.
14 on The effectiveness of e-government projects financed by the European Regional Development Fund (ERDF) (Special Report No 9/2011), with particular reference to the 2000-2006 programming period and four Member States: Spain, France, Italy and Poland.
The audit assessed whether the co-financed projects were selected on the basis of specific needs, whether they were carried out in accordance with the plan, and whether they were adequate and sustainable.
This appropriation is intended to cover support for the information society of EUR 6,7 billion for the development of new secure technologies, the development of infrastructure and the development of broadband networks. on the effectiveness of State aid management by the Commission (Special Report No 15/2011).
The audit examined whether the procedures and systems ensured that the Commission would consider all relevant State aid cases, that cases were dealt with effectively and dealt with within the time limits and that the Commission would be able to monitor the effects of the State aid control.
The Commission is responsible for ensuring that the State aid granted by the Member States is compatible with the internal market of the European Union.
Member States must notify State aid measures to the Commission and request the Commission's approval before granting State aid. for the implementation of EU financial assistance for the decommissioning of nuclear power plants in Bulgaria, Lithuania and Slovakia (Special Report No 16/2011) to assess whether the decommissioning programmes of nuclear power plants have been adapted to the demand, whether they have been implemented in accordance with the plan and whether the structures for responsible management and accountability have been built in such a way as to ensure the effective use of EU funds.
Bulgaria, Lithuania and Slovakia committed to early closure and then to closure of the eight nuclear reactors, which cannot be re-equipped, in the framework of the accession negotiations.
Due to its exceptional burdens, the EU has committed €2.9 billion to three national programmes in the period 1999-2013.
The European Union has a strong political responsibility in agriculture and rural development, fisheries and the environment.
The planned budget for 2007-2013 is EUR 413.1 billion, i.e. 42.3% of the total budget.
Three quarters of the expenditure concern direct payments to farmers and support to the agricultural markets through the European Agricultural Guarantee Fund (EFG) is the most identical pillar of the common agricultural policy (CAP).
More than one fifth of the expenditure comes from EU rural development support financed by the European Agricultural Fund for Rural Development (EAFRD), the second pillar of the CAP.
Agriculture and rural development shall be managed jointly by the Commission and the Member States.
The Court adopted the following special reports on the subject in 2011: on the Single Payment Scheme under the common agricultural policy (Special Report No 5/2011) More... See the box: The entry into force of the budget implementation control... on How the project and management of agri-environment measures are supported? (Special Report No 7/2011). (Special Report No 7/2011).
The report assesses whether agri-environment policy is shaped and supervised in such a way as to bring significant environmental benefits, whether it is sufficiently supported by the relevant guidelines and relevant aid amounts, and whether the management of agri-environment policy takes account of specific environmental needs.
The aim of agri-environmental policy is to meet the growing demand of the public for environmental services by encouraging farmers to introduce or maintain environmentally compatible production processes.
This area is subject to joint management by the Commission and the Member States. to recover undue payments under the common agricultural policy (Special Report No 8/2011) in order to assess the effectiveness of recovery systems for identified claims established and managed by the Member States.
This verification examined whether Member States correctly register and process claims, whether actions taken by Member States to recover certain unduly paid payments are successful, whether Member States are taking appropriate actions to recover irrecoverable claims, and whether the Commission's supervision and supervision are effective.
The European Union spends around EUR 55 billion annually on agriculture and rural development, and part of the funding is wrongly paid on account of incorrect or incorrect proposals15.
16 on The effectiveness of the School Milk and School Fruit Schemes to assess whether EU aid has a direct impact on the consumption of the beneficiaries and whether they are able to revive the way they are able to raise and influence future eating habits.
The aim of these EU programmes is to encourage children to eat healthy food through the consumption of dairy products and fruit and vegetables and to contribute to improving the market conditions of these products.
The EU is currently spending EUR 180 million per year on these two programmes. on Is the geographical indication programme effective and managed? (Special Report No 11/2011).
This assessment assessed the reliability of the control system, the attractiveness of the system to producers, their visibility to consumers.
The purpose of the Union system of geographical indications is to protect the names of products for which the characteristics of the products relate and the geographical area from which they originate.
This programme creates economic opportunities for farmers and food producers and can have a positive impact on the rural economy in EU regions. on the effectiveness of EU action to adapt the fishing capacity of fishing fleets to the fishing opportunities in force (Special Report No 12/2011).
The audit examined whether there was a clear framework for reducing fleet capacity and whether specific measures had been specifically identified and implemented.
The Commission and Denmark, Spain, France, Italy, Poland, Portugal and the United Kingdom carried out the inspection.
The objective of the EU Common Fisheries Policy is to promote sustainable fisheries by ensuring a balance between fish stocks and the fleet in order to prevent these stocks from being overfished.
Overcapacity of the fishing fleet has been a problem for many years that threatens both the sustainability of fish stocks and the long-term viability of the fishing sector.
The European Fisheries Fund has EUR 4.3 billion for the programming period 2007-2013.
17 SUPERVISION OF THE HOLDING SYSTEM 5/2011 OF OPERATIONAL PAYMENT: SUPERVISIONS ON THE BETTER MANAGEMENT OF FINANSAMIR: The evaluation of sound financial management concerned sound financial management of payments under the single payment scheme which is currently used in 17 of the 27 EU Member States.
The expenditure related to this programme amounted to around €28,8 billion in 2009.
The introduction of the single payment scheme was one of the main elements of the 2003 reform of the EU's common agricultural policy.
The aim of this programme was to encourage farmers to respond better to market demand and to provide income support to them.
The reform has dissolved the link between support and production (implementation of the differences between production and production Implementation (implementation (implementation of resolution) Implementation) Supporting the differences between production and production (implementation) Supporting the differences between production and production (implementation)) As part of the reform, implementation (implementation (implementation) Implementation) of the reform (implementation) of the reform (implementation) As part of the reform (implementation) As part of the reform (implementation) Implementation) Implementation (Implementation) of the implementation (Implementation) last year.
Instead, farmers must have eligible agricultural land and payment entitlements.
Since 2006, the Court has carried out a number of checks on the procedures laid down by the Commission and the Member States to ensure the accuracy of payment entitlements and the accuracy of payments to farmers.
These checks covered all 17 Member States that applied the scheme and their results were taken into account in the 2006 and 2007 annual reports on the implementation of the EU budget.
On the basis of these results, the Court decided to carry out a performance check focusing on: the beneficiaries of the scheme, access to payments per farm and the definition of eligible areas; the contribution of the scheme to the objectives of income support to farmers and the maintenance of agricultural land in good condition in agriculture and the environment; the specific consequences of the application of the different models of application of the scheme.
Verification visits were carried out in 2009 and 2010 in the Commission and in France, Italy and the United Kingdom.
It was therefore concluded that the single payment scheme contributed to the two main objectives of the common agricultural policy: farmers were encouraged to respond better to market demand and that the incomes of the whole agricultural sector were supported.
However, in general, a number of questionable features have emerged during the implementation of the scheme, which relate to the definition of beneficiaries under this policy, the nature of eligible parcels and activities, the environmental impact of the scheme, the distribution of aid between the Member States and within the Member States, and the specific impact of the historical and regional model.
18 The Court recommends in its report that agricultural payments should be better granted to active farmers and that non-agricultural parcels and activities which do not contribute to increasing agricultural productivity or to maintaining the ecological value of land should be excluded from support.
The Court also recommends that the level of the single payment should take account of environmental costs and other externalities, and that the level of aid should be more balanced between farmers.
The calculation of farm payments should be based on current management conditions.
The audit was carried out by a multidisciplinary team consisting of eight controllers from Chamber I. The audit work provided additional information not only on the concept of unseparated payments but also on the impact of the transition from the previous production-related support system on the current system.
According to Sven Kolling's team leader, checking the various models and options existing under the single payment scheme to implement the scheme together with national and regional administrative strategies and their impact on the cost-effectiveness and effectiveness of the premium is a particular challenge.
Verification visits to final beneficiaries and on-the-spot checks on holdings have proved necessary to obtain evidence to support the findings and conclusions.
Many of the Court's recommendations are reflected in the Commission's proposals for the reform of the common agricultural policy after 2013 (at the time of the preparation of this report in the debate), including the definition of active farmers and agricultural activities in specific areas and the distribution of premium payments among beneficiaries, in reducing the number of models for the implementation of the single payment scheme and in taking better account of the environmental externalities in the calculation of the single payment.

The audit was based on the question whether OLAF had already transferred the priority of its activities to its investigative functions and whether its investigations were more effective, as the effectiveness of its investigative work had been demonstrated and whether the functions of the Supervisory Committee had been clarified.
OLAF's task is to combat fraud and other illegal activities to the detriment of the EU budget.

In 2011, the Court adopted the following special report: on the control of the customs procedure 42 can it prevent and disclose VAT evasion? (Special report No 13/2011) In this audit, the Court assessed whether there was a solid legal framework to combat VAT evasion under the customs procedure No 42.
It was checked in Belgium, Denmark, Spain, France, Austria, Slovenia and Sweden.
Customs procedure 42 is the mechanism used by an EU importer to obtain an exemption from VAT.
This procedure shall apply in the case of the transport of goods imported from outside the EU into another Member State.
In such cases, VAT is due in the Member State of destination.

22. The Court's Court's composition: the assessment of today's financial and economic risks for the public and economic risks of today's public and financial risks for the EU's and for the Court's financial and financial crisis has had far-reaching consequences for the European Union.
In order to tackle the crisis, the EU has taken steps to ensure the long-term sustainability of the financial sector, to promote economic recovery and growth, to provide financial assistance to the Member States and to strengthen financial and economic coordination between Member States.
In addition, these measures have a decisive impact on the way public funds, i.e. EU taxpayers' money, are used in the EU.
Changes in the regulatory structure of the Union pose new challenges of accountability, transparency and public financial control.
The Court considers that the implementation of these new measures is in line with the principle that, whenever the use of public funds is concerned, appropriate rules of transparency, public responsibility and public financial control should be laid down.
Therefore, on 19 May 2011, the Court adopted a document on the impact of the current financial and economic crisis on public responsibility and financial control in the EU and on the role of the Court.
In that document, the Court concluded that, where possible, it would take into account in its audits the Commission's activities in the framework of the European Semester, the new supervisors, support mechanisms with EU budgetary guarantees and, where possible, support in the framework of the European Semester.
The Court considers that the Treaty establishing the European Stability Mechanism should provide for the form of external financial control by public authorities.
Finally, the Court notes that, in many cases, the issues of accountability and transparency, in particular in the European Parliament and the Council, must be examined by the relevant EU institutions.
The Court cooperates with other Supreme Audit Authorities (ORCs) mainly with the following bodies: the Contact Committee (ORCs) of the EU Member States; the Network of Candidate States and potential Candidate Countries; international bodies for the control of public finances, in particular the International Organisation of Supreme Audit Offices (INTOSAI) and their European Regional Group (EUROSAI).
The CONTACT COMMITTEE The Court of Auditors and national audit authorities, in accordance with the EU Treaty, cooperate with full confidence and respect for their independence.
The Court is actively working with OLAF in the EU Member States within the Contact Committee.
The EU-ORKB President and the Court meet each year in the Contact Committee.
The Contact Committee shall provide a forum for cooperation and exchange of knowledge and experience on the evaluation of EU funds and other EU issues.
Working groups have been set up to support the development of common positions and practices.
In 2011, the Court acted as the President of the Contact Committee, continued to provide administrative assistance and actively participated in various working groups and networks.
The 2011 annual meeting of the Contact Committee was held at the Court's premises on 13 and 14 October 2011.
The seminar focused on the impact of the European Semester and other recent developments in the EU's economic governance on the ORKB and the Court.
In this context, the issues of regulation and supervision of financial systems and financial institutions, state aid to the financial sector and the assessment of crisis management mechanisms in the euro area have been addressed.
The Contact Commission has adopted a statement addressed to the European Parliament, the European Council and the European Commission, and to the parliaments and governments of the EU Member States.
In addition, the Contact Committee adopted a resolution to take account of the ORKB call of the euro area countries for appropriate external financial control of the European Stability Mechanism.
The declaration and resolution are available on the website of the Contact Commission (www.contactcommittee.eu).

On 15 November 2011, the Court of Justice delivered a judgment in Case C-539/09 Commission v Federal Republic of Germany on the control powers of the European Court of Auditors in the field of own resources accruing from VAT.
This is due to the refusal to grant the European Court of Auditors a refusal in 2006 to carry out checks on administrative cooperation in the field of value added tax in Germany, in accordance with Regulation (EC) No 1798/2003.
In preparing Special Report No 8/2007, the Court decided to carry out audits in eight Member States, including Germany.
Germany objected to the Court's right to carry out the audit.
The German Government pointed out that cooperation between the administrative authorities of the Member States referred to in Regulation (EC) No 1798/2003 has no direct link with EU revenue, since value added tax should be distinguished from national tax and, therefore, with value added tax own resources.
The latter are determined according to a number of calculations and represent a relatively small proportion of the amounts collected by the Member States as value added tax.
The Court strongly rejected the argument of the German Government, which is based on the strict contrast between the VAT revenue of the Member States and the Union's own resources on value added tax.
In the light of the arguments put forward by the Commission, the European Parliament and the European Court of Auditors, the Court stressed the dependence of the VAT own resources on the revenue of the Member States on value added tax.
The Court of Justice confirmed that the scope of Regulation (EC) No 1798/2003 on administrative cooperation in the field of value added tax included the establishment of mechanisms for cooperation between Member States in order to combat the recovery of value added tax more effectively and to collect value added tax more effectively.
This also affects the availability of own resources for VAT for the EU budget.
Where cooperation between national authorities is effective and compatible with the Regulation, it may contribute to the reduction of fraud and the effective collection of VAT in the Member States, and to the maintenance of VAT own resources at the level that has to be ensured by the various relevant EU legislation and thus to the maintenance of the total value of own resources.
The Court found that the Court of Auditors was entitled to carry out the planned audit in the context of administrative cooperation in the field of VAT since it referred to the EU revenue, in terms of legality and sound financial management, and was therefore directly linked to the powers conferred on the Court of Auditors under the Treaty.
In Case C-539/09, for the first time, the Court had to clearly define for the first time the scope of the Court's audit powers.
The Court of Justice ruling is valuable and encouraging as it clarifies and confirms the powers of the institutions as regards the control of the Member States.

In 2009 and 2010, the Court concluded that the best way to achieve the safety objectives was the most cost-effective and cost-effective management of the risks of audit and security services provided internally.
In April 2011, this was done by replacing an external security service provider with a small team of contract staff.
The annual costs will be lower by more than €0.5 million in 2012 than in 2009.
THE OFFICE During the Court's audit work, auditors must travel to the Member States, to other beneficiaries of EU funds, as well as to the headquarters of international organisations such as the United Nations.
The purpose of these inspection visits is to obtain physical proof of inspection.
These visits usually apply to central and local authorities involved in the approval and management of EU funds and their payment as well as to final beneficiaries.
In the EU, inspection visits are often carried out in conjunction with the highest control authorities in the Member State visited.
The audit teams shall normally consist of two to three auditors and the duration of the audit visit may be up to two weeks, depending on the type of examination and the distance.

46 INTERNAL CONTROL AND IMPLEMENTATION The internal audit body's task is to ensure independence and objectivity and to provide advisory services to increase and improve the added value of the Court's activities.
The Commission shall assist the Court in the achievement of the objectives of the institutions through a systematic and rigorous approach to the evaluation and the submission of recommendations in order to improve the effectiveness of risk management, control and management procedures.
In carrying out its task, the Internal Audit Office shall act in accordance with the EU Financial Regulation, the rules applicable to EU officials and the international standards of professional practice in the field of internal audit.
In 2009, the Court's internal audit services were assessed and certified in accordance with the international standards of the Institute of Internal Auditors.
THE COURT'S EXTERNAL AUDIT The annual accounts of the European Court of Auditors shall be audited by an independent auditor.
This is the main element of the Court's efforts to ensure that the Court applies to itself the same principles of transparency and accountability as to the authorities that it is investigating.
In 2011, the Court's internal audit services presented reports on: the state of implementation of the Court's 2009-2012 strategy; the implementation of key performance indicators; the creation of a new K3 building of the Court; the use of a trust account for payments to eligible beneficiaries; the implementation of previous recommendations.
The internal audit service has fully supported the Court's independent auditor in his audit of the Court's certification of the Court's annual accounts and the effectiveness of its internal audit procedures.
The Court's Internal Audit Committee shall advise on internal audit matters and monitor the related internal control environment in the framework of the institution's risk management procedures.
In 2011, the Internal Audit and Audit Committee examined the results of the mid- and internal audit bodies' audits, the implementation of action plans affecting the internal control environment and the risks related to the institution's management.

48 DECLARATION OF POWERS I, the Secretary-General of the European Court of Auditors, hereby declare that the information contained in this report is correct and accurate, and with sufficient assurance that the budget made available for the activities described in this report has been used for the purposes set out and in accordance with the principles of sound financial management, and that the control procedures put in place give the necessary guarantees for the legality and regularity of the transactions underlying the annual accounts, and to ensure that they are used for the proper management of the charges and fraud.
This is sufficient certainty on the basis of the assessment of the signed and the information available to it, such as the results of the ex post audit, internal auditor's reports and the independent auditor's opinions on the previous financial years.
Luxembourg, 8 March 2012 Mr Eduardo RUIZ GARCÍA Secretary-General
The European Court of Auditors shall be an independent external audit body of the European Union established in Luxembourg.
The Court of Auditors shall act as a collegial body consisting of 27 members, each of which shall consist of one member of each Member State.
The members of the Council shall be appointed by the Council for a term of office of six years after consulting the European Parliament.
Members shall elect a chairman from among themselves for a period of three years, with the possibility of re-election also possible.
The Court shall be organised in accordance with the chambers to which the members are assigned.
The Chambers shall prepare reports and opinions for adoption by the Court.
The control chambers I-IV cover different areas of revenue and expenditure, while the fifth, the CEAD, is responsible for horizontal issues.
The Comoros shall be assisted by audit directors.
Since the revision of the Court's Rules of Procedure in 2010, certain categories of Court reports and opinions may be adopted by chambers instead of by the entire College of the Court.
The Management Committee shall meet under the chairmanship of the chairman and shall consist of the Chairman of the Chambers and the Secretary-General (responsible for the administrative services and assistance of the Court).
The Committee shall act as coordinator and prepare the Court's decisions on strategic planning and management of results and administrative issues.
Each member shall have the power to perform specific tasks, in particular in the field of control.
Members shall submit to Parliament proposals for controls and reports on the tasks for which they are responsible, to the Chamber and to the Court.
It shall be submitted to the European Parliament, the Council and the other interested parties by the rapporteur member following the adoption of the report.
Members shall be assisted by their cabinet members and a team of auditors appointed for the examination of 49 tasks.

3 THE EUROPEAN COURT OF THE COURT OF AUDIT OF THE EUROPEAN COURT OF COURT OF COURT OF AUDIT IN THE COURT OF INCLUSION OF THE COURT OF INCLUSION OF THE European Court of Auditors shall be responsible for the control of the EU's finances in accordance with the Treaty.
As an external EU auditor, it contributes to improving EU financial management, contributes to accountability and transparency and acts as an independent guardian of the financial interests of EU citizens.

5 TUEUE Page 6 INTERPOL-UNCLE 6 INTERPOL-UNCLE INTERPOL-UN Security Council Special Notice web link: https://www.interpol.-search/un/un/en/un/un/un/-notice/un/un/un/en/un/un/un/un/un-en/un/en-un/un/-un/en/un/en/un/un/un-search/un-search-search/un-un-search/-notice/un/un-un-search/un-un/un-un/un-notice/un-un-un-notice/-notice/-search/un/un-en-un-search/un-int-un/un-search/notice/un/un-un--un-notice/un-un/un/un-notice/un-un
In 2012, the Court focused on preparing the Union for the key challenges of financial management after 2013.
At the beginning of the year, the Court adopted an opinion on certain proposals for regulations on the common agricultural policy (CAP), which is the most popular EU policy.
The draft regulation was part of a package of legislative proposals for the 2014-2020 multiannual financial framework.
In 2012, it adopted a number of opinions and reports that the Court adopted and actively contributed to strengthening the new rules that would be subject to EU revenue and expenditure during that period.
Moreover, in 2012, the Court continued to closely monitor the impact of changes in the EU's economic governance on public responsibility and financial control.
This year, the Treaty establishing the European Stability Mechanism entered into force and, at its first meeting, the audit committee of the new body, including the representative of the Court, took place.
In December 2012, the Council of the European Union adopted a position on the establishment of a single supervisory mechanism to ensure the supervision of euro area credit institutions and the Court presented its position to EU policy makers on public responsibility and financial control.
Many changes in the EU's economic governance and budget are due to the fact that better political results are needed with lower public resources whilst strengthening democratic legitimacy and accountability.
Given its unique competences and views, on the one hand, and the experience on control, gained over 35 years, and based on the partnerships thus built, on the other hand, the Court has good experience to help the EU cope with these challenges.
On the basis of the achievements achieved in recent years, the Court aims to maximise the Court's contribution to improving the EU's reporting obligation in 2013-2017.
The farm celebrates 35 years of its existence.
Europe has changed significantly since the Court started working in 1977.
The structure of the Court and the way in which it is carried out reflect these changes.
With the accession of the new Member States, the transfer of competences to the Union and the creation of a number of posts at EU level, the scope of controls has been extended.
The Court also developed as an organ from nine members and 120 employees in 1977 to 27 members and almost 900 employees in 2012.
This increase enabled the farm to build professional, committed and experienced staff.
In 2012, this was the last year covered by the Court's 2009-2012 strategy.
During this period, the Court noted positive results.
As the annual activity report shows, the results have increased, external experts consider the quality of our reports to be good, and their main institutional addressees are those who consider them useful.
The level of acceptance of the Court's recommendations remains high and the Court's new monitoring report highlights the positive effects of these recommendations.
The Court can also point to an increase in administrative and translation productivity which could lead to the use at the end of the period of 40 additional staff in the field of control.
In order to achieve the 2013-2017 objectives, the Court will prioritise products to improve the EU's reporting obligations and extend and extend its partnerships, professionalism and efficiency.
In 2013, the international peer review team will examine the Court's performance check practice and will follow the results of the previous 2008 peer review procedure.
Other key actions to be taken in 2013 include improving the Court's reporting procedures and improving the use of our Common Knowledge Fund, our expertise and our expertise.
With these and other initiatives, the Court intends to help the EU to address the growing challenges of accountability and financial control in the coming years.
Vítor Manuel da Silva Caldeira President 7

11 The main conclusions of the 2011 Annual Report on the 2011 Financial Statements constitute the relevant financial situation of the European Union and the results of its operations and cash flows for the year concerned.
Revenues and commitments were not significantly affected by errors.

12 ANNUAL REPORT ON THE EUROPEAN DEVELOPMENT FUND 2011 The European Development Funds (EDFs) are financed by EU Member States but are managed outside the EU budget and are subject to their financial rules.
The European Commission is responsible for the financial management of the actions financed by the EDF.
With the European Development Fund (EDF), the European Union provides assistance to African, Caribbean and Pacific (ACP) and Overseas Countries and Territories (OCTs) in development cooperation under the Cotonou Agreement signed in 2000.
These expenditures aim to reduce poverty, in line with the objectives of sustainable development and gradual integration of ACP and OCT countries into the world economy, and ultimately to eradicate poverty.
The agreement is based on three complementary pillars: development cooperation, economic and trade cooperation and the political dimension.
The Court's 2011 Annual Report on the EDF was published on 6 November 2012 in parallel with the annual report on the EU budget.
The Court concluded that the annual accounts of the EDF for 2011 adequately reflect the financial situation of the EDF and the results of its operations and cash flows.
However, 33% of EDF operations were affected by errors, including an estimated percentage of 5,1% of payments made as a result of an error.
SPECIAL ANNUAL REPORT ON THE AGENCIES, DECENTRAL AUTHORITIES AND OTHER EU AUTHORITIES FOR 2011 The Court published 50 special annual reports, mainly concerning the 2011 financial year, concerning agencies, decentralised bodies (e.g. Joint Undertakings) and other EU bodies.
Agencies and decentralised EU bodies shall be established on the basis of EU legislation to carry out specific tasks.
President Caldeira during the presentation of the 2011 Annual Report at the plenary session of the European Parliament (November 2012)
In 2012 SPECIAL REPORTS In addition to its annual reports, the Court shall publish, throughout the year, special reports containing the results of the performance and compliance audit carried out by the Court in specific budgetary areas or management matters selected by the Court.
When selecting and organising these audit tasks, the Court ensures that the maximum results and, therefore, the best use of its resources are made.
In selecting the subjects, the Court takes into account the following factors: the risk to profitability or compliance with the legal standards in the area of income or expenditure; the level of income or expenditure; the time since the previous audit; the upcoming developments in the relevant legal framework; the political and public interest.
In 2012, the Court adopted 25 special reports covering a wide range of issues.
This represents a significant increase compared to the 16 special reports adopted in 2011 (and 12 in 2008).
All special reports are available in 22 EU languages on the Court's website: http://eca.europa.eu.
The following pages present the topics identified in the 2012 special reports, in the relevant headings of the 2013-2017-2017 financial framework, i.e. in the EU's multiannual budgetary plans.
14 THE THE GROWTH OF SUSTAINABLE FINANCIAL GROWTH EU spending on sustainable development covers two areas: competitiveness includes promoting research and technological development, the creation of European networks through EU networks, education and training, the promotion of competitiveness in a fully integrated internal market, the social agenda and the dismantling of nuclear facilities.
EU expenditure on growth and employment for 2007-2013 amounts to EUR 89.4 billion, i.e. 9.2% of the EU budget, of which almost two thirds are R &amp; D.
Cohesion for growth and jobs mainly concerns cohesion policy for specific areas of activity: the European Social Fund (ESF), the European Regional Development Fund (ERDF) and the Cohesion Fund (CF).
The EU budget for cohesion 2007-2013 amounts to EUR 344.4 billion, or 35.7% of the EU budget.
In 2012, the Court adopted the following special reports: the financial instruments for SMEs co-financed by the European Regional Development Fund (N° 2/2012) The special report assessed the effectiveness and effectiveness of the financial engineering activities co-financed by the ERDF for the 2000-2006 and 2007-2013 programming periods.
The Court found that the impact on the effectiveness and effectiveness of the expenditure on financial instruments for small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) incurred under the European Regional Development Fund (ERDF) was limited as the legal framework did not provide an adequate basis for the use of the various types of financial instruments.
Small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) are the backbone of the EU economy and provide employment, innovation and prosperity.
However, SMEs may not be able to cover the financial needs in the required form and amount.
To support them, the EU uses enterprise and cohesion policy, mainly in the form of grants and increasingly under the ERDF under the financial instruments.
Financial instruments are repayable and renewable instruments.
According to the Commission's figures, ERDF allocations for financial instruments amount to EUR 1.6 billion and EUR 10.4 billion respectively for the 2000-2006 and 2007-2013 programming periods.
o Structural Funds Kommt Did the Commission respond effectively to the shortcomings identified in the management and control systems in the Member States?
(No 3/2012) (Special Report) has examined the extent to which the Commission has put in place appropriate corrective measures in order to implement them on time and to ensure that appropriate financial corrections have been made in the framework of these measures on past irregularities and on improvements in the systems in order to avoid the recurrence of irregularities.
The audit was carried out mainly on the basis of a review of 40 programmes for which significant shortcomings were identified.
The Court found that, with regard to the weaknesses in the management and control systems in the Member States, the Commission was able to ensure the correct application of financial corrections, but to a lesser extent, it ensured that their actions led to improvements in the Member States' systems.
Expenditure on Structural Funds shall be managed by the Commission and the Member States.
Member States shall draw up multiannual programmes which shall be examined and approved by the Commission and subsequently implemented by the Member States.
If significant shortcomings are identified in the management and control systems in the Member States, the Commission shall endeavour to ensure the correction of irregularities and the improvement of systems. to use the Structural Funds and the Cohesion Fund to co-finance transport infrastructure in maritime ports: an effective investment?
(No 4/2012) ) ) This special report assessed the effectiveness of the objectives and results of 27 projects co-financed by the ERDF and the Cohesion Fund for the period 2000-2006 under the ERDF and Cohesion Fund transport infrastructure reporting code.
The Court found that investment in maritime port infrastructure under cohesion policy was only effective for 11 out of the 27 projects audited.
Maritime transport is the second most important mode of transport in the EU.
The Commission envisages an increase from 3.8 billion tonnes in 2006 to 5.3 billion tonnes in 2018.
Since 2000, the EU has allocated around €6.2 billion from the Structural and Cohesion Funds to co-finance maritime port infrastructure.

(No 20/2012) Chromatography This special report assessed the results of the 26 infrastructure projects for the management of sampled waste, assessed whether the EU waste policy objectives and the implementation of accompanying measures in the eight regions in which the infrastructure is located.
The Court found that the effectiveness of the infrastructure support for municipal waste management in EU structural measures was hampered by insufficient implementation of accompanying measures and by shortcomings in EU legislation and guidance.
In 2010, every citizen of the 27 EU Member States produced on average approximately 500 kg of waste, which, if not properly collected, processed and disposed of, could have a negative impact on the environment.
The EU introduced common standards and objectives in the form of directives on municipal waste management and co-financed waste management infrastructure in certain regions.

The Court notes that the average time for the EU's return on energy efficiency investments is more than 50 years (in extreme cases up to 150 years), which means that funds for this type of investment could be used more cost-effectively.
The cost of increased energy consumption, the consumption of fossil fuels and the impact of human activities on global climate change are the driving force behind the recent EU energy efficiency policy.
Since 2000, under cohesion policy, the European Union has spent almost EUR 5 billion on the co-financing of energy efficiency actions in the Member States.

18 THE EU'S FINANCIAL FRAMEWORK'S WORKINGS PROSPERITY AND MANAGEMENT OF THE EU'S NATURAL RESOURCES is politically responsible for agriculture and rural development, fisheries and the environment.
The planned budget for 2007-2013 is EUR 413.1 billion, i.e. 42.3% of the EU budget.
Three quarters of the expenditure concerns direct payments to farmers and support to the agricultural markets through the European Agricultural Guarantee Fund (EGF) Metalle the larger pillar of the common agricultural policy (CAP).

In 2012, the Court adopted the following special reports: on the reform of the common organisation of the market in wine: progress so far (No 7/2012). This special report assessed progress towards one of the main objectives of the reform of the wine sector, i.e. progress towards a better balance between supply and demand.
The audit focused on "premiere on grubbing-up" and "restructuring and conversion of vineyards" which are two main areas of expenditure and are essential to achieving the objective of achieving a better balance between supply and demand.
The Court found that these two measures were contradictory and that the structural supply surpluses were not significantly reduced.
Over a period of three years of application of the grubbing-up measure ( 2008/2009-2010/2011), the EU budget was EUR 1.1 billion.
The specific report examines whether EU aid for the modernisation of agricultural holdings was targeted at the priorities and specific needs of the EU in the Member States.
The Court found that actions to modernise agricultural holdings would potentially be more effective by using more targeted funds to achieve EU priorities and specific needs in the Member States, and by making effective use of selection procedures.
This aid concerns the financing of investments in agricultural holdings which may include investments in simple goods such as agricultural equipment or wooden fruit boxes or even investments in complex projects such as biogas plants.
The EU budget for this assistance (the EAFRD) for the 2007-2013 programming period amounts to EUR 11.1 billion, representing around 11% of the EU's rural development expenditure.o Control of the control system for the production, processing, distribution and import of organic products (No 9/2012) under this special report, j, whether the control system for organic products provides sufficient assurance of the fulfilment of the key production, processing, distribution and import requirements for organic products.
It examined how the various authorities concerned (the European Commission and the competent authorities of the Member States, accreditation bodies and control authorities) carried out their tasks in the EU and in the management of import systems.
The Court found that the competent authorities in the Member States encountered difficulties in ensuring the traceability of organic products, including that the system needs to address shortcomings in order to ensure that the system works effectively and that consumer confidence is not undermined.
The aim of the EU legal framework for organic production is to provide the basis for the sustainable development of organic production, to ensure a level playing field, to protect consumers' interests while ensuring the smooth functioning of the internal market.
A control system has been put in place in which each operator in the supply chain is controlled and certified. for Direct aid for suckler cows, sheep and goats for the partial implementation of the single payment scheme (No 11/2012) In this specific report, it has been assessed whether the aid has been targeted to the most relevant regions in the Member States, whether it has been effective in maintaining production, thus avoiding the negative social, economic and environmental impact, and whether it has been subject to appropriate monitoring and evaluation by the Commission and the Member States.
The Court found that direct CAP support for maternal herds does not produce better results than decoupled aid.
Following the 2003 CAP reform, agricultural aid previously granted in the form of direct payments linked to the production of certain agricultural products (so-called "aid combined with the volume of production") should not be paid depending on the volume of production (i.e. it was separated from production after the introduction of the single payment scheme).
However, for certain sectors and regions, certain derogations were provided for from total separation from production in order to limit the potential negative effects of the immediate transition to such systems.
The total budget for this direct aid for 2011 was EUR 1.0 billion.

The Court notes that part of the aid was paid to beneficiaries who had carried out only marginal agricultural activities or did not carry out agricultural activities, including public entities, and that the disposal of the aid did not take into account the specificities of regional agricultural activities or the farmers' contribution to the production of public goods.
Moreover, a large majority of farmers receive a very small amount of aid.
The single area payment scheme is a simplified income support scheme for farmers in the Member States that have joined the EU since 2004.

The draft programme reduced the effectiveness of the funds and the coordination with other EU funds was insufficient.

In 2012, the Court adopted the following special reports: on the effectiveness of EU development aid for food security in subSaharan Africa (No 1/2012) This special report examines the effectiveness of EU development aid for food security in subSaharan Africa, by analysing whether EU aid for food security development is relevant for the needs and priorities of countries and whether EU action has been effective.
The review focused on direct EU development assistance for the three pillars of food security: food availability, access to food and a sustainable diet.
The Court concluded that EU aid for the development of food security in sub-Saharan Africa is predominantly effective and contributes significantly to the achievement of food security.
However, the Commission has not taken sufficient account of the possibilities of EU support to other countries, which are also affected by chronic food uncertainty, and has not considered that food should be given priority.
Food security is a serious and persistent problem in Sub-Saharan Africa, where hunger affects 30% of the population.
In the period 2002-2010, the EU financed over EUR 3.2 billion from the European Development Fund (EDF) in the region, the Common Information System RELEX (CRIS) (5/2012). In this special report, it examined whether the CRIS was developed in a manner that was effective in meeting the Commission's needs and whether the information it provided was reliable.
The assessment took into account the review of the CRIS dossier available to the Commission and the review of the data contained in the CRIS.
The Court found that CRIS to a large extent met the Commission's needs for information on external actions.
After ten years of development, however, it still has flaws.
CRIS is an information system set up by the Commission to support the management of external actions.
The system's functions have continued to develop since its launch in 2002.
It is currently the main reference system for the management and documentation of external actions, together with relevant reports, and is financed both from the general budget of the EU and from the European Development Fund (EDF).

25 ECONOMIC SUPERVISION European Union Rule of Law Assistance to Kosovo Rule of Law Assistance in Kosovo Kosovo Kosovo Police Mission in the Kosovo Border Patrol © EULEX, 2011, photo of Enisa Kasemi As part of the control of EU Rule of Law Assistance to Kosovo, the EU has for the first time joined the Mission for a Common Security and Defence Policy (CSDP).
Kosovo is the world's largest beneficiary of EU financial assistance per capita and the largest civilian crisis management operation ever launched by the Union (European Union Rule of Law Mission Kosovo's EULEX mission).
The Court's Special Report No 18/2012 assessed the effectiveness of EU assistance to Kosovo in the field of the rule of law.
The audit focused on four sectors: police, judiciary, customs and the fight against corruption.
The Court also examined the coordination with other donors and the implementation of the EULEX mission.
The study of such a complex area was a challenge.
Four inspection visits were carried out in Kosovo.
There has been consultations with EULEX officials and the European Commission, as well as local officials, representatives of the international donor community and civil society organisations.
The evaluation team examined the projects of the Instrument for Pre-Accession Assistance and the Instrument for Stability and the monitoring, advisory and advisory activities (MMA) of the EULEX action.
Meetings took place in Brussels with the Commission, the European External Action Service, the Council and NATO Secretariat.
In addition, the Court supported a team of experts.
The Court concluded that EU aid was not sufficiently effective.
Although the EU has contributed to capacity building, particularly in the area of customs, the success of police and justice assistance has been modest.
The level of organised crime and corruption in Kosovo remains high.
Justice continues to suffer from political pressure, inefficiency and lack of transparency and enforcement.
The limited ability to protect important witnesses in Kosovo and the difficulty in transferring Witnesses to another country are serious shortcomings.
In the words of Gijs de Vries, a member of the Court responsible for the report, the Kosovo authorities have failed to have a sufficient number of priorities for the rule of law and EU assistance should be more effective.
Francisco de Miguel Rodriguez, the team leader, says there is no place in the world other than Kosovo, where in such a small area there would be so many international donors for capacity building.
The Court concluded that the EU coordination mechanisms, including coordination with the international community, need to be improved.
Unlike the other Western Balkan countries, the lack of a common EU position on its independence threatens the possibility of EU accession in the case of Kosovo.
With regard to communication, this attempt has taken new steps.
This was most frequently quoted in 2012 in the Court's report, in which more than 130 articles were published in printed and electronic media.
In addition, a summary video was published on the Court's website.
It was a premiere for the court, in which it reflected its desire to reach a wider audience.
The European Commission and the European External Action Service have accepted the Court's conclusions and recommendations.
The report was presented to the European Parliament and to the Council working groups.
Given the importance of its findings, the Upper Chamber of the United Kingdom has decided to examine the report in detail.

29 COMMENTS No 1/2012 ON THE COMMISSION'S LEGISLATIVE PROPOSALS ON THE COMMISSION'S REFORM OF THE COMMON AGRICULTURE POLICY FROM 2014. The Common Agricultural Policy (CAP) is to be reformed by 2013.
In October 2011, the Commission published a proposal containing the main elements of the CAP legislative framework for 2014-2020.
The new legal framework proposes to maintain the current two-pillar structure of the CAP and thus the two existing European financial instruments for the agricultural policy: the European Agricultural Guarantee Fund and the European Agricultural Fund for Rural Development (EAFRD).
The Court recognised the Commission's efforts to simplify the CAP rules (e.g. not to apply the different models of the implementation of the current single payment scheme, the introduction of a simplified scheme for small farmers).
In its conclusions, the Commission presented a number of observations by Parliament, the Council and the Court.
However, legislative proposals are, in principle, still focused on expenditure and control, and are therefore still in line with the performance provisions, contrary to the stated intentions.
The Court took note of the Commission's objective of financing the CAP in a way that favours active farmers and of trying to achieve a more balanced distribution of direct payments among beneficiaries.
However, the Court doubted whether the proposed measures could be effectively implemented without imposing an excessive administrative burden on administrative authorities and farmers.
In his view, the solution can consist of a combination of the general principles set out in the Regulation and a systematic monitoring and monitoring of their implementation by the Commission.
He noted that the so-called "introduction' (shortening the aid above a certain ceiling) would have a limited impact on the redistribution of the aid.
This opinion has had a significant impact on the reflection on the future of the CAP.
More than 2,000 articles have been published in the media.
The Court has been invited by a number of NGOs, farmers' fair organizers and other industrial forums to make public, and the European Parliament invites the Court's representatives to participate in working groups on the subject.
Most of the recommendations made by Members of the European Parliament have been included in their own proposals on changes to legislation.
The legislative package will be put to the vote after the adoption of the multiannual financial framework.

THE CONTACT COMMITTEE OF THE MAJOR DEPARTMENTS OF EU MEMBER STATES' ACCOUNTS 31 In accordance with the EU Treaty, the Court of Auditors and the national audit authorities shall cooperate with full trust and respect for their independence.
The Court is actively working with the Court of Auditors of the EU Member States within the Contact Committee.
The Contact Committee shall meet once a year with the Presidents of the EU-ORKB and the Court.
Working groups and task forces have been set up to support the development of common positions and practices.
In 2012, the Court supported the Presidency-in-Office of the Contact Committee (ORKB of Portugal) in the preparation and organisation of the 2012 annual meeting held in Estoril (Portugal) on 18 and 19 October 2012.
The meeting focused on two main issues: the challenges facing the ORB in preparing for the forthcoming EU financial framework (2014-2020) and recent developments in response to the financial crisis and the EU's audit experience in this area.
At its meeting, the Contact Committee decided to set up a task force to analyse the tasks and role of the ORKB, taking into account recent developments in the EU in terms of the creation of a new economic, budgetary and financial structure and the possible impact on the ORK.
The Court is a member of this Task Force, which is to report to the Contact Committee in 2013.
In addition, in 2012, the Court also provided administrative support to the Contact Committee and actively participated in the various working groups and networks.
In addition, in 2012, the Court contributed to the euro area OrkB initiative to ensure adequate external financial control of the European Stability Mechanism.
In April 2012, the Secretary-General of the Council of the European Union was given a common position on the proposal for a Statute for Article 30 of the Treaty establishing a mechanism.
The final version of the Statutes is broadly in line with this Common Position with regard to the Audit Committee.

34 OUR MANAGEMENT: STRATEGIES FOR 2013-2017 The Court adopted and published its strategy for 2013-2017 in 2012.
The Court's objective during this period is to maximise the Court's contribution to the EU's public responsibility.
The most important priorities for achieving this objective are: to focus the Court's products on improving the EU's accounting requirements; to cooperate with other actors to enhance the Court's contribution to the EU's accounting requirements; to develop as a professional audit body; to make optimum use of the Court's existing knowledge, experience and knowledge; to demonstrate the Court's capacity for implementation and accountability.
The Court will use its unique competences and views and knowledge, expertise and partnerships it has built over a period of 35 years in order to contribute in future to the development of control, policy and financial management mechanisms of the EU; to help other parties involved in the accountability process at EU level to identify the risks associated with the EU control obligation and to facilitate the use of control results; to enhance their professionalism by contributing and applying new control standards and best practices; to enhance the process of reporting and opinion; to improve the results and accountability framework, in line with their commitments, as EU institutions and the ORKB; to implement budgetary discipline measures, in line with the multiannual financial framework for 2014-2020, including the necessary financial management framework for the duration of the strategy.
In 2013-2017 the Court will focus on its reports, opinions and comments on the following aspects: on stepping up public responsibility and audit systems; on improving financial management and reporting on the implementation of the EU budget and its impact; on improving the planning of EU spending policies and programmes.
IN THE COURT'S COLLEGE In accordance with the Treaty, the term of office of the Members of the Court shall be six years and the term of office shall be renewable.
In 2012, five new members of the Court were elected: Henrik Otbo (Denmark), Pietro Russo (Italy), Ville Itälä (Finland), Kevin Cardiff (Ireland) and Baudilio Baugurz (Spain).
The revised Code of Conduct for Members of the Court in February 2012 adopted a new Code of Conduct for Members, which takes account of the changes that have taken place since the adoption of the previous Code of Conduct eight years ago.
Furthermore, the Court publishes declarations of the interests of its members on its website, which, to a large extent, contributes to transparency. 35

40 EFFIBILITY AND EFFECTIVENESS OF RESOURCES The Court shall assess the effectiveness and effectiveness of the use of resources on the basis of how well it is able to report and report on controls in due time, to comply with its financial management obligations and to ensure the well-being and competence of its staff.
The Court shall monitor the effectiveness of its reporting procedure by comparing the number of reports scheduled for a given year with the number of reports adopted and by verifying that the reports have been adopted within the time limits set for that purpose.

In order to achieve the objective of making the best use of resources, the possibilities of improving efficiency through simplification of procedures were re-examined and implemented in the framework of all actions in 2012.
The posts released for efficiency gains outside the control area have, as far as possible, been transferred to the control service and to the service of the President.
As a result, since 2006, the number of audit posts has increased by 14.4 %, while the number of posts approved by the Court has increased by only 3.5 %.

Professional Education The controller profession requires constant training to keep up with new achievements and acquire new skills.
Moreover, due to the specificities of the Court's audit environment, the auditors need good knowledge of foreign languages.
In 2012, the Court's staff (experts and other staff) completed an average of 8 days of vocational training (9.3 days in 2011).
Language courses accounted for 52% of the total number of training days (compared with 54% in 2011).

In 2012, the value of translations reached a maximum of 158 861 pages and was therefore 11 % higher than in 2011.
More than 99% of translations were completed on time.

54 35 YEARS BETTER EU FUNCTION The European Court of Auditors has been an external auditor of the EU for 35 years and has constantly added value to the financial management of the Union and provides public responsibility for the use of taxpayers' money.
The Court was founded at a time when the European Community (the original European Union) developed towards greater democracy and greater responsibility towards its citizens.
Two particularly important steps are to strengthen the European Parliament's powers in the field of budgetary control and to fully fund the European Community budget from its own resources.
The Community has recognised that it needs an independent external auditor that has helped Parliament and the Council to ensure democratic financial control.
Heinrich Aigner, President of the European Parliament's Committee on Budgetary Control, who has been firmly in favour of an external audit body at Community level since 1973, referred to an initiative which led to the creation of the European Court of Auditors under the Brussels Treaty of 22 July 1975.
The Court began its activities in October 1977 with its registered office in Luxembourg.
At that time, the President of the Court of Justice, Hans Kuucher, declared the Court to be the financial conscience of the Community.
The Court obtained the status of a fully-fledged European institution on 1 November 1993 following the entry into force of the Maastricht Treaty, which guarantees its independence and authority as an equivalent institution.
The Maastricht Treaty also introduces key elements, which are currently one of the Court's main products: the statement of assurance (DAS) of the EU accounts and the legality and regularity of the underlying transactions.
With the entry into force of the Treaty of Amsterdam on 1 May 1999, the role of the Court of Justice was extended, which increased its independence and extended its control powers to other policy areas.
The Nice Treaty of 1 February 2003 confirmed the principle that the Court should belong to one member of each of the Member States and stressed the importance of the Court's cooperation with the national audit authorities and enabled the Court to acquire the structure of the Chamber.
Since its establishment, the Court has consistently supported cooperation with the highest audit authorities of the Member States in the control of EU funds, in particular through cooperation with the Contact Committee of EU-ORKB Presidents.
As part of its role as CRKB, the Court also sought to better prepare for developments in the field of public sector control through cooperation with other control bodies within the International Organisation for the Supreme Audit Authority (INTOSAI) and their regional EUROSAI group in order to define technical standards and best practices.
In its early perspective, the Court noted that the peer review process is a tool for the development and dissemination of best practices in the Community in the framework of the European Monitoring Centre for Racism and Xenophobia.
Over 35 years, the Court has sought to improve the EU's financial management by presenting high-quality products reflecting the EU's changes and the changing needs of its addressees.
Over the last 35 years, the EU has adopted new Member States, has acquired new powers and has created new institutions at EU level.
As a result, the Court's results increased significantly compared to the two opinions drawn up by the Court in the first year of its activity.
Among the Court's products today are annual reports, special reports, statement of assurance, special annual reports, opinions and positioning documents.
The number of products increased to 87 publications in 2012.
For several years, the Court has given a higher priority to monitoring the results of EU policies and to providing guidance to improve productivity.
Like the EU, the Court has evolved.
On the basis of nine members and 120 employees in 1977, the Court now has 27 members and nearly 900 employees.
Like the Union itself, the success of the Court depends on close cooperation between members and employees from all European countries.
The Court is proud that it has been able since 1977 to build skilled, professional and experienced workers to protect the financial interests of citizens.
In the coming years, the Court will aim to contribute to increasing accountability from the budget to achieve the objectives towards citizens.
55 Members of the first College of the Court, November 1977

To commemorate our colleague, Henrik Otbo, a member of the Court, who died unexpectedly on 1 February 2015, Henrik Otbo was born in 1949 and was Danish.
From 1995 to 2012 he was the President of the Danish Court of Auditors and from 1 March 2012 he was a member of the European Court of Auditors in the CEAD chamber (coordination, evaluation, quality assurance and development) with particular responsibility for development and evaluation of audit.
His commitment to the policy of public financial control throughout his life, in particular his leading role in creating international standards for the highest control bodies, as president of the INTOSAI Committee on Technical Standards, was particularly valuable for the Court, his former colleagues in the Danish Court of Auditors and for the whole audit sector.
01 European Court of Auditors 02 The mandate of the European Court of Auditors shall be responsible for the audit of the EU's finances in accordance with the Treaty.
As an external EU auditor, it contributes to improving EU financial management, contributes to accountability and transparency and acts as an independent guardian of the financial interests of EU citizens.
The leading and dynamic Court of Auditors, which is of integrity and impartiality and is considered to be a professional, quality and impact of its work and provides valuable support to its addressees to improve the EU's financial management.
Values Independence, honesty and impartiality Professionality Value added Excellence and efficiency Independence, honesty and impartiality of institutions, its members and employees.
An impartial check which takes account of the views of the addressee of the Court but rejects any form of influence on the Court by means of instructions or external pressures.
Maintaining a good level of professionalism in all aspects of his work.
Active participation in the further development of financial control at EU and global level.
developing appropriate and timely high-quality reports based on sound findings and evidence, taking into account the most relevant issues on which it is based and based on scientific and scientific evidence.
contribute to the effective improvement of EU financial management and contribute to the strengthening of the EU's financial management obligation.
Supporting team spirit through effective communication.

The President's foreword 04 Dear Reader, Dear Readers, 2014 was a year of profound change for the EU and its finances.
The EU has entrusted the European Central Bank with responsibility for the supervision of large banks in the euro area.
This was the first year of the new Multiannual Financial Framework of relevance for the implementation of the EU budget for the period 2014-2020.
