Our activities 07 Audit reports and other products The three main products of the European Court of Auditors are: • Annual reports and annual reports on the Court of Auditors' work and the results of the audits of financial reporting and compliance with the rules on the European Union budget and the European Development Fund (EDF).
This includes detailed annual reports on the agencies, decentralised bodies and EU Joint Undertakings. • Special reports, which may be published at any time during the year, together with the results of audits of their choice, in certain budgetary areas and/or management issues.
These are essentially economic checks. • Opinions on new or amended legislation affecting financial funding and other analysis-based products, prepared at the request of another institution or on the Court's own initiative.
In 2014, the Court developed more products than ever before and also presented new products.
The annual reports continue to contain a lot of analytical information, as well as a lot of information, which gives a full description of the results of our annual accounting audits and compliance audits.
In 2014, more focus was given to efficiency audits in order to provide the EU budgetary authority with additional information on the quality of the implementation of the EU budget.
In addition to the annual reports, for the first time, we published a summary of our audit results on agricultural and cohesion expenditure under shared management, in the period 2009-2013, in order to provide a multiannual perspective.
Their important development was a new product called Landscape analysis.
Rural analysis shall provide information and analysis on key issues on the basis of our audit expertise.
In 2014, we published two Landscape analyses: the first focused on the key challenges facing the EU, namely accountability and financial control, and the second focused on the risks related to EU financial management.

Our activities 08 Audit visits in 2014. While most of the audit work takes place in our premises in Luxembourg, our auditors also carry out verification visits with the authorities of the Member States, among other beneficiaries of EU funds (including in the premises of international organisations such as the World Health Organisation in Switzerland) and with EU agencies and agencies.
The purpose of these visits is to obtain direct proof of control from the actors involved in the approval and management of EU funds and to pay them as well as from their final beneficiaries.
Our audit teams typically consist of two or three controllers, and the duration of the audit visit is several days to two weeks, depending on the type of exam and the distance.
In the EU, our audit visits are often carried out in consultation with the highest audit authorities in the Member States visited.
The frequency and intensity of checks in individual Member States and beneficiary countries depends on the nature of the checks and the results of the selection of the sample.
The number and duration of inspection visits may therefore vary from country to country and from year to year.
In 2014, the Court's auditors spent 4,915 days on on-the-spot checks in the Member States and outside the EU in order to obtain evidence and evidence on annual reports and selected audit tasks (audit reports).
In addition, they have spent a lot of time in Brussels and Luxembourg, as well as in decentralised agencies and agencies across the EU.
In 2014, our auditors used less days for on-the-spot checks than in previous years.
This is due to more effective work procedures and increased use of technologies such as video conferencing.
EU inspectors used EU inspectors to verify maritime freight installations.

Our actions 14 The 2013 Annual Report on the European Development Fund (EDF) is funded by EU Member States and is subject to separate financial rules and is managed outside the EU general budget.
The European Commission is responsible for managing the financial management of actions financed by the EFF.
Within the framework of the EDF, the European Union grants funds for development cooperation with the African, Caribbean and Pacific States (ACP States) and with the Overseas Countries and Territories (OCTs) under the Cotonou Agreement of 2000.
Expenditure is aimed at reducing and reducing poverty, and finally reducing poverty, in line with the objectives of sustainable development and gradual integration of ACP countries and OCTs into the world economy.
The agreement is based on three complementary pillars: development cooperation, economic and trade cooperation and a political dimension.
The Court's 2013 Annual Report on the EDF was published on 5 November 2014 as an annual report on the EU budget.
It contains the 20th EDF Statement of Assurance.
The Court found that the 2013 annual accounts adequately reflect the financial situation and financial situation of the EDF, the results of its operations and the cash flow, as well as the changes in net assets as a whole.
The Court estimated the error rate for EDF expenditure for the financial year 2013 at 3.4 %, which means an increase of 3.0% compared to 2012.
Specific annual reports for the financial year 2013 In 2014, the Court prepared and published 51 annual reports for the financial year 2013.
The reports concerned 41 decentralised EU bodies, executive agencies and agencies, seven EU Joint Undertakings active in research, as well as the European Central Bank, the European Schools and the communication infrastructure Sisnet.
The Court also published two reports summing up the results of its annual audits for the financial year 2013 for the financial year 2013 for one of the EU agencies and other agencies and the other through joint research undertakings.
These two comparative analyses and analyses were submitted to the President of the European Parliament, the Committee on Budgetary Control of Parliament, the General Affairs Council and the Council's Committee on Budgets.
These summaries are available on the Court's website (eca.europa.eu) together with specific annual reports.
EU agencies, bodies and joint undertakings are prepared on the basis of EU legislation to carry out specific tasks and are established throughout the European Union.
They operate in many areas such as safety, health, research, finance, migration and travel.
Each of them shall have a mandate, a management, a director, a staff and a budget.
While agencies, bodies and joint enterprises, for the entire EU budget, represent a relatively small financial risk, the risk of reputation in the Union is high, as they are clearly visible in the Member States and have a significant impact on policy-making, decision-making and programme implementation in areas of key importance for European citizens.

Our actions 17 Smart and Inclusive Growth Smart and Inclusive Growth covers two areas: competitiveness for growth and jobs covers research and innovation, education and education, trans-European energy, transport and telecommunications networks, social policy, business development, etc., EU measures for growth and jobs for the period 2014-2020 are: employment and economic growth of a total of EUR 142 billion and 13% of the EU budget at current prices.
Economic, social and territorial cohesion includes a regional policy aimed at promoting the least developed EU countries and regions to move closer to the others, enhancing the competitiveness and cooperation of all regions.
The EU's cohesion funding for 2014-2020 amounts to EUR 367 billion and 34% of the EU budget at current prices respectively.
In 2014, the Court prepared the following special reports in this field: • the effectiveness of public transport projects financed by the EU (No 1/2014), in this special report, the Court assessed the implementation and effectiveness of public transport projects co-financed by the EU Structural Funds in order to determine whether the projects meet the needs of users and whether the objectives have been met.
The audit showed that two thirds of projects in the area of short transport co-financed by the EU Structural Funds have not been sufficiently used.
This development was mainly due to flaws in the design concept and insufficient mobility policy.
However, these insufficient results were not theoretically carried out by project promoters or by national authorities.
In general, infrastructure and vehicles in most projects were designed in accordance with the project specifications.
There were significant delays and overcosts, but almost all of the projects audited met the needs of the users.
European cities need to increase mobility and reduce congestion, accidents and pollution through local mobility strategies.
Projects co-financed the cities to develop local transport systems such as metro, trams and buses.
Trams and buses are important means of public transport.
Our actions 18 • Have cohesion policy funds to support renewable energy production been successful?
(E6/2014 No) states that in this special report, the Court examined whether the two main sources of funding for the promotion of renewable energy sources under the European Regional Development Fund (ERDF) and the Cohesion Fund (FS) had the objective of determining whether, in this period, the resources had been sufficiently priority, cost-effective and refined for the production of renewable energy sources, and of the extent to which they had achieved good results in order to achieve the EU 2020 renewable energy target.
The audit concluded that improvements are needed to ensure that EU funding contributes as much as possible to this objective.
The projects audited have produced results according to the plan and most of them have been mature and ready to be implemented at the time of selection.
No significant cost overruns or significant delays were observed and renewable energy capacity was installed as planned and launched as planned.
However, the results of energy production have not always been achieved or have not been properly measured.
The total budget was limited because the cost-effectiveness of the projects was not the guiding principle and the expenditure had limited added value for the EU.
The EU Council has set a binding EU target of 20% of the share of renewable energy in gross final energy consumption by 2020.
Between 2007 and 2013, some €4.7 billion were allocated to renewable energy from the ERDF and the Cohesion Fund.
(I read in a special report that the Court assessed whether, in the framework of ERDF funding, it successfully supports empirical start-ups that have a strong potential for economic growth.
The audit concluded that the EU has made a significant financial contribution to the creation of infrastructure in centres, in particular in Member States where this type of support to businesses is relatively rare.
However, the results of the centres of incorporation audited were not sufficient.
In view of the financial constraints and the limited scope of business creation, the provision of business services was rather limited.
This situation was mainly due to the lack of expertise in support procedures in support of support and the shortcomings in management systems.
The founding centres aim to support new businesses in the creation and development of businesses.
Support for small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) has become an increasingly political priority over time.
During the period 2007-2013, EU expenditure in this area amounted to EUR 38 billion.

Our actions 19 • Is the ERDF effective in funding projects aimed at the direct promotion of biodiversity in the framework of the EU Biodiversity Strategy 2020?
(No 12/2014) The donors examined in this special report whether the ERDF funds available for direct support for biodiversity were used by the Member States.
The audit showed that the Member States are lagging behind when it comes to project financing compared to other expenditure areas under the ERDF.
For the ERDF to continue to be useful in the implementation of the EU Strategy to reduce biodiversity loss by 2020, the Commission should further support Member States in the implementation of specific conservation and management plans for habitats and natural species.
Projects co-financed were broadly in line with biodiversity priorities at national and EU level.
However, the assessment of the effectiveness of these projects has been undermined by the fact that most Member States have not combined result indicators or monitoring systems to assess the development of natural habitats and species.
The protection of biodiversity is one of the EU's main priorities.
Following the failure to reach the 2010 target to reduce the loss of biodiversity in Europe, the Council adopted a new strategy by 2020 and, in the 2007-2013 programming period, direct support for biodiversity and nature protection was allocated to the ERDF of €2.8 billion. • Has ERDF support to SMEs in the context of e-commerce been effective?
(No 20/2014) Freizeit ) The Court assessed in its special report whether operational programmes were a good basis for effective support for e-commerce activities for SMEs, whether management bodies had correctly selected and monitored e-commerce projects, and whether projects co-financed by the ERDF had successfully implemented e-commerce projects and whether they had had tangible benefits.
The Court found that ERDF support to SMEs in the e-commerce sector containing goods that have been online has contributed to increasing the availability of e-commerce services to businesses on the Internet.
However, due to the lack of control, it was not possible to assess the extent to which ERDF support contributed to the achievement of the information technology objectives in the Member States and in the EU.
Insufficient selection procedures in the Member States lead to the fact that for many projects it is unlikely that a good cost/cost ratio is true.
The programme managers focused more on resource use than on results.

Our actions 20 Approaching the economic control procedure: EU-funded airport infrastructure: insufficient cost-benefit ratio (No 21/2014) Closed part of the oversized terminal at Fuerteventura airport.
While EU aviation policy aims to address capacity problems, including the creation of additional infrastructure, the better use of existing structures, the optimisation of airport services and better access to other modes of transport, Europe will not be able to address a significant part of this demand due to the lack of ground transport infrastructure.
There are more than 500 airports in Europe with more than one million employees directly or indirectly employed, with a value of more than EUR 140 billion, including airlines.
Airport infrastructure projects are an important area of expenditure in the EU budget: in the 2000-2006 programming period, the EU has allocated €4.5 billion, of which over €2.8 billion from cohesion policy funds.
The Court assessed the results of this support to determine whether the investments were fully needed, whether the time and cost framework for construction projects had been met and whether the newly built or modernised infrastructure had been fully used.
The Court assessed whether the investments led to an increase in the number of passengers, an improvement in after-sales services and whether the supported airports could be financially viable.
The auditors carried out their work between May 2013 and October 2014, with particular emphasis on 20 airports in Estonia, Greece, Italy, Poland and Spain financed by EU funds.
In total, over EUR 600 million were allocated to these airports between 2000 and 2013.
The team assessed the relevant legislation, air traffic planning in five Member States and the publication of the main interbranch organisations.
In particular, the auditors visited 20 airports to assess the results, use, results and impacts, as well as the economic situation of airports, as well as to obtain direct evidence that they originate from EU funds.
The Court found that the cost-benefit ratio for EU-funded investments to airports was not consistent.
Too many airports, often close to each other, have received financial support for similar infrastructures, and in many cases the infrastructure has been overdeveloped.
Only half of the airports audited managed to increase the number of passengers.
No improvement in customer service or regional socio-economic benefits, such as the creation of additional jobs, has been measured or has been shown to be effective.
In addition, the study showed that seven airports were not self-financed and that they would not be able to maintain their activities without further support from the public authorities.
For most airports, the audit team found significant delays in the construction and construction of the infrastructure.
For almost half of airports, the costs were exceeded and the Member States had to pay almost EUR 100 million more of the national budgets than originally planned.
Our actions 21 Funding was not well coordinated by Member States: in most countries there was no strategic long-term airport development plan.
Moreover, the Commission has not monitored financing, which is normally not aware of which airports receive grants or what amounts are concerned.
In this way, it will not have a complete picture of all EU investments in airports, it will have limited possibilities to ensure monitoring and ensure proper development and implementation of the strategy.
On the basis of these findings, the Court recommended to the Commission, starting from the 2014-2020 programming period, that Member States should benefit from EU funding only for airport infrastructure that is financially stable and the investment needs of which have been adequately assessed and proven.
Another recommendation was that Member States should have coherent airport development plans at regional, national and transnational level to avoid overcapacity, duplication and uncoordinated investments in airport infrastructure.
In its reply, the Commission ensured that lessons were learned from the experience.
In this context, the Commission has, in principle, introduced a different approach in the relevant provisions for the 2014-2020 programming period.
The report was presented to the European Parliament, which fully supports the Court's conclusions and recommendations.
The publication of the report was of great interest to the media.
The media response was the biggest in Spain, but in the press was also available in the press, television press and social media.

Our actions 22 Sustainable growth: The European Union has political responsibility for agriculture and rural development, fisheries and the environment.
The planned budget for 2014-2020 is EUR 420 billion and 39% of the EU budget at current prices.
Three quarters of the expenditure concern direct payments to farmers and support to the agricultural markets through the European Agricultural Guarantee Fund (EGF) Guarantee Fund (EGF) direct payments to farmers to the strongest pillars of the common agricultural policy (CAP).
Another fifth of the expenditure concerns EU support for rural development financed by the European Agricultural Fund for Rural Development (EAFRD), the second pillar of the CAP.
Agriculture and rural development shall be managed jointly by the Commission and the Member States.
In 2014, the Court drew up the following special reports in this area: • Inclusion of EU water policy objectives in the CAP: the partial achievement (No 4/2014) In this special report, the Court assessed whether the objectives of EU water policy were fully integrated into the common agricultural policy (CAP).
The audit showed that the EU can only partially achieve the objectives of water policy within the CAP.
Two instruments on the integration of water-related issues (the application of cross-compliance and rural development) have shortcomings and the implementation of the Water Framework Directive have an animosity and weakness.
The CAP instruments have so far had a positive impact on supporting policy objectives to improve water quantity and quality.
However, these instruments are limited compared to the ambitious objectives of the CAP.
For example, none of these two instruments allows the "polluter pays" principle to be fully applied to the financing of the CAP.
Furthermore, there is insufficient knowledge at the level of the EU institutions and the Member States about the risks of water resources being exposed to agricultural activities and the trends they generate.
The EU attaches great importance to the protection of European water resources.
Agriculture, one of the largest consumers and polluting water resources, has a key role to play in sustainable water management.
Almost 40% of the EU budget (over €50 billion for 2014) is allocated to the CAP and the EU is trying to influence agricultural procedures affecting water resources.
Our actions 23 • Did the Commission effectively manage the integration of coupled support into the single payment scheme?
(No 2014/EU) (No 2014/EU) () In its special report, the Court assessed how the Commission, following its 2008 Health Check, how EU support related to production (e.g. the land and animals managed) (e.g. animals) was incorporated into the single payment scheme.
The audit showed that in the period 2010-2012, the Commission did not adequately monitor how Member States calculated farmers' entitlement to support under the Union's single farm payment scheme.
Although most Member States have properly used the reference data of farmers, there have been serious shortcomings in the correct application of the rules and rules of calculation.
The Commission has not used its mandate to ensure that the criteria for the allocation of the available support have always been in line with EU rules, in line with the principle of sound budgetary management, and have no potential impact on market conditions.
Within the framework set up by the Commission, it was not sufficiently clear what checks are to be carried out by the Member States, and the Member States' control systems varied in quality; the main objective of the single payment scheme was to shift the focus of the CAP from market support to the support of income to non-production farmers: farmers should be able to adjust their production to market demand and their income should be balanced.
EU support for investment and promotion in the wine sector is currently being used to co-finance 54% of the EU's total agricultural and rural development budget. • Is EU support for investment and promotion in the wine sector well-managed and can it be demonstrated that wine competitiveness in the EU is well managed?
In this special report, the Court assessed whether the investment and marketing promotion activities had been adequately developed and assessed the available monitoring and evaluation data to assess whether the Commission and the Member States had achieved the desired results effectively.
The evaluation concluded that the management of support for investment and promotion in the wine sector was at risk of shortcomings in design and implementation and that it was not always possible to demonstrate that this had an impact on the competitiveness of wines in the EU.
Investment activities specifically targeted at the wine sector are not justified as support is already provided under the EU's rural development policy.
EU support for the promotion of wines was often more likely to consolidate existing markets than to develop new or renewed old markets.
The impact of the investment action cannot be easily separated from investment in rural development.
The EU is the world's largest wine producer.
EU support is aimed at increasing competitiveness and balance between supply and demand.
Between 2009 and 2013, Member States spent EUR 522 million on promotion measures and EUR 518 million on investment measures.
Between 2014 and 2018, the funds allocated to the Member States under this measure increased significantly.
Our actions 24 • Effectiveness of aquaculture support (No 10/2014) given by the European Fisheries Fund (EFF) by the European Fisheries Fund (EFF) partement (EFF) partements (EFF) (EFF) • In the Special Report, the Court assessed whether aquaculture support measures were well designed and properly implemented by the EU and the Member States, and whether the European Fisheries Fund (EFF) provided an adequate cost-benefit ratio and support for the sustainable development of aquaculture.
The audit showed that by 2013 aquaculture support measures were not well designed and implemented at EU and Member State level, that the EFF did not provide an adequate cost/benefit ratio and did not provide effective support for the sustainable development of aquaculture.
The current framework was not adequate to meet the EU's objectives for the sustainable development of aquaculture and the results were insufficient.
Actions to promote the sustainable development of aquaculture in the Member States have not been well designed and implemented.
The national strategic plans and operational programmes of the Member States were not clear enough and the Member States did not have a coherent strategy for the sector.
In many cases, EDF funds have not been used sufficiently towards aquaculture projects, and the audit has shown that these projects have generally not been able to achieve the planned results nor have they been able to achieve the benefits which will generate the benefits.
Every year aquaculture produces 1.3 million tonnes of fish in the EU, with a turnover of EUR 4 billion.
One of the objectives of the Common Fisheries Policy (CFP) for the period up to 2013 was to promote the sustainable development of aquaculture.
By May 2013, more than EUR 400 million were allocated under the EFF to finance production investment and environmental and health measures in the aquaculture sector. • Economic economy: the control of the costs of EU aid for rural development projects (No 22/2014) in the the Special Report (No 22/2014) the Court examined whether the approaches adopted by the Commission and the Member States were most effective in controlling the costs of rural development aid.
The audit showed that EU Member States can achieve significant savings in aid for rural development projects, while at the same time making greater use of resources.
The auditors have set out practical and economic approaches which could be wider in relation to Member States' control of the costs of rural development aid.
The control systems of the Member States were intended to control the prices of the goods or works referred to in the aid applications in question without paying the same attention to whether the goods were measured.
Some price controls were time-consuming or were not certain that the approved costs were appropriate.
At the beginning of the programming period, the Commission did not provide sufficient guidance or ensure the dissemination of procedures which are not recommended.
It did not ensure the effectiveness of the Member States' systems before granting large-scale aid.
About half of the EU's rural development expenditure for 2007-2013 was EUR 100 billion in grants for investment projects and other projects carried out by farmers, agricultural enterprises, associations and local authorities.
Our actions 25 • Errors in rural development expenditure: What are the causes and actions taken to eliminate them?
(No 23/2014) those, including the Special Report, have examined compliance with the existing legislation and other provisions on the implementation of rural development and identified the main reasons for the high level of error in this area.
The audit showed that most of the errors in rural development policy are due to a breach of the conditions laid down at Member State level.
Control authorities in the Member States could and should have detected and corrected most of the errors in investment in rural development.
Member States' control systems are insufficient because controls are not comprehensive and are based on insufficient information.
The average error rate in rural development expenditure over the last three years was 8.2%.
The investment error was two thirds of the error and the area aid was one third.
Only 16% of the error rate was due to non-compliance with the rules contained directly in the EU regulations, while the majority among stakeholders was due to non-compliance with the conditions established at Member State level.
During the 2007-2013 programming period, the EU and the Member States have allocated more than EUR 150 billion to rural development policy, which, in almost equal parts, has been used for investment and area aid.
• Is EU aid to prevent and mitigate forest damage well managed and managed by natural disasters and natural disasters?
(No 24/2014) this special report of the Court (Special Report) assessed whether the European Agricultural Fund for Rural Development (EAFRD) support measure for forest recovery and the introduction of prevention measures (Action 226) was well managed and whether the Commission and the Member States could demonstrate that the objectives of the aid were achieved in a cost-effective manner.
The audit showed that EU funding to prevent forest fires and to rebuild forests affected by natural disasters and fires was not properly managed.
The Commission and the Member States are unable to realise that the financing objectives have been achieved in a cost-effective manner.
Over the last 30 years, the EU has destroyed on average 480 000 hectares of forest every year.
Preventive actions accounted for more than 80% of the EU's funding of €1.5 million for the period 2007-2013.
Our actions 26 Security and citizenship This policy area has been established to ensure the free movement of persons and to ensure a high level of protection for citizens.
It covers both the management of the EU's external borders and judicial cooperation in civil and criminal matters, as well as asylum and immigration policies, police cooperation and the fight against crime.
It is estimated that expenditure on this area for the period 2014-2020 amounts to EUR 18 million and less than 2% of the total budget respectively.
In 2014, the Court drew up the following special reports in this field: • Conclusions from the development by the European Commission (No 3/2014) of the SIS II Information System (SIS II) on the development of SIS II • In this special report the Court examined why the Commission provided SIS II more than six years later than was planned and incurred eight times the costs envisaged.
The analysis revealed whether there was a stable business structure throughout the project's duration in SIS II, which took into account the significant changes in costs and expected benefits.
The audit concluded that delays and excessive costs were due to shortcomings in the Commission's management.
The original deadline was unrealistic and the Commission was not able to effectively manage the main development mandate before 2009.
The actual level of investments needed was clearly underestimated in the initial cost estimates.
The total cost of SIS II was EUR 189 million, which initially corresponds to the estimated amount of EUR 23 million.
The Commission has not fully demonstrated that SIS II provides its best cost/cost ratio.
However, she gained the experience gained during the first phase of the project, and some of them have already been used in other large IT projects.
The Schengen Information System shall be used by the customs, border, police, customs, visa and judicial authorities throughout the Schengen area.
It shall contain information on persons who may have been involved in a serious crime or who do not have the right to enter or stay in the EU.
• The External Borders Fund has helped to increase financial solidarity, but it is necessary to improve the measurement of results and to create additional added value for the EU (No 15/2014) to increase the effectiveness and added value of the External Borders Fund for the EU (No 15/2014) • In this special report, the Court assessed the effectiveness of the External Borders Fund for the EU and assessed to what extent the objectives of the projects and programmes co-financed have been achieved.
The audit showed that the External Borders Fund has contributed to ensuring the management of the EU's external borders and increasing financial solidarity between Member States.
However, the EU added value was limited and the results could not be measured due to shortcomings in monitoring by the competent authorities and serious shortcomings in the evaluations at the level of the Commission and at the level of the Member States.
Member States' programmes were not integrated into national border control strategies and visas and did not contain SMART objectives or measurable indicators.
The project selection procedure does not ensure that the real needs of the Member States are met.
Insufficient procurement procedures in the Member States pose a threat to the cost-effectiveness of budgetary management.
The majority of the Member States concerned (Greece, Spain, Italy and Malta in the first years of funding) experienced 4 weaknesses in the management of the Fund.
The EU's main financial instrument supporting the protection of external borders was the External Borders Fund for the period 2007-2013, which received EUR 1.9 billion.
Its overarching objective was to support the current and future Schengen countries in ensuring uniform, effective and effective controls at their common external borders.
Our actions 27 Europe in the world The EU's external relations activities focus on: enlargement, stability, security and prosperity in the neighbourhood, active promotion of sustainable development at international level, promoting global political governance and ensuring strategic and civil security.
The EU has allocated EUR 66 billion to these objectives for the period 2014-2020 on the basis of current prices or 6 percent of planned expenditure.
The Commission shall manage expenditure directly through its central services or delegations.
In 2014, the Court prepared the following special reports in this area: • the establishment of the European External Action Service (EEAS) (No 11/2014) In this special report, the Court examined whether the establishment of the EEAS had been adequately prepared as to whether its resources had been best targeted, organised and allocated and whether it had cooperated effectively with the Commission and the Member States.
The audit concluded that the EEAS should increase its efficiency and increase its efforts for the EU and its citizens.
The establishment of the EEAS was premature and was not properly prepared.
The lack of priorities, organisation and allocation of resources has made its efficiency weak.
Coordination between the EEAS and the Commission was only partially effective, mainly due to the lack of effective coordination mechanisms and the rigid financial and administrative framework at the level of the Delegate.
Coordination with Member States may be strengthened with a view to exploiting synergies in the exchange of information or shared accommodation and improving consular services, including the protection of EU citizens.
The EEAS shall have its headquarters in Brussels, comprising 140 delegations worldwide.
In 2014, the EEAS had a budget of EUR 519 million, divided between headquarters (41%) and delegations (59%). • EU aid for rehabilitation following the earthquake in Haiti (No 13/2014) Weiterverkauf In this special report, the Court examined whether EU aid for rehabilitation in a country was well designed and implemented in an appropriate manner and whether the Commission ensured an appropriate combination of emergency aid with rehabilitation and development activities.
The audit showed that EU aid for rehabilitation after the earthquake in Haiti in 2010 was generally well designed and targeted at the country's urgent needs, but that the programmes were not implemented in a sufficiently effective way and that emergency aid, rehabilitation and development were not sufficiently linked.
Most of the programmes audited met or checked production requirements, although almost all programmes were delayed.
Although the Commission was aware of the difficult situation, it did not sufficiently assess certain important risks that would jeopardise the achievement and achievement of the objectives of the programme.
The programmes have been monitored but the Commission and the EEAS have not taken timely action to increase the resources of the EU Delegation to Haiti.
In March 2010, 55 donors granted USD 5.4 billion for the period 2010-2012 for rehabilitation and development and USD 3.0 billion for 2013 and the period thereafter.
The European Union was one of the main donors, promised it would receive EUR 1.2 billion.
Our actions 28 • The effectiveness of combining financial assistance with regional investment instruments with loans granted by financial institutions to support EU external policy (No 16/2014) in this special report The Court examined the establishment and management of investment instruments and wondered whether the intended benefits had been achieved.
The review gave a positive decision on mixed funding, i.e. a combination of financial assistance from regional investment instruments with loans from financial institutions with a view to supporting the EU's external policy as regards structure and overall efficiency, but the Court also draws attention to a number of key issues which need urgent attention.
Although these systems have been well developed, the potential benefits of pooling funds have not been fully realised due to shortcomings in the Commission's management of funds.
Almost half of the projects examined did not have sufficient evidence that the grants were justified.
In some cases, investments would probably be carried out without an EU contribution.
The Commission should ensure that the allocation of funds is based on an accurate and documented allocation of added value to the objectives of the EU's development policy, neighbourhood and enlargement.
Since 2007, the Commission has created eight regional investment instruments.
They combine EFF grants with the EU's general budget with loans mainly from European financial institutions for development.
Combined funding is usually intended to exploit investment opportunities in the form of large infrastructure projects that can be financially viable but cannot be mobilised within the financial market. • Can the EU's initiative on centres of excellence effectively contribute to reducing chemical, biological, radiological and nuclear (CBRN) risks that come from outside the EU?
(No 1 Vorleistungen) Vliese In this special report, the Court assessed whether the initiative was based on a reliable analysis of the situation prior to 2010, whether the organisational structure of the initiative was appropriate to meet the identified challenges and whether there was an appropriate governance system and whether it was applied.
In the context of the audit, the Court generally welcomed the contribution of centres of excellence to the reduction of the risk associated with CBRN.
This initiative is in line with the priorities set out in the European Security Strategy and the EU Strategy against the proliferation of weapons of mass destruction.
It provides for the involvement of all stakeholders in partner countries in order to improve the sustainability of the actions undertaken.
The organisational structure is generally appropriate, but its complexity has contributed to the delay in the launch of the project.
The Centres of Excellence initiative aims to create regional platforms in different regions of the world in order to address the risks of CBRNs.
This is the largest measure of the Instrument for Stability in the long term and a budget of EUR 100 million has been allocated for the period 2010-2013.
Our activities 29 • In EuropeAid in terms of performance-oriented assessment and monitoring (Results oriented Monitoring entrichtet RM) (No 16/2014) (including the Special Report, the Court has examined whether the systems are reliable, whether the structure and resources are adequate, whether they are adequate and reliable, and whether they are derived from the findings as far as possible.
The Court has carried out a critical assessment of the reliability of these systems.
The bodies responsible for assessing and monitoring the results are well organised, but more attention should be paid to the efficient use of resources.
These systems do not provide sufficient information on the results obtained and do not ensure the greatest possible use of the findings.
The evaluations of projects and programmes organised by the Commission's delegations and implemented in partner countries are not satisfactorily managed: the overall monitoring is not consistent and is not fully clear on the scope of the resources used and does not have access to the results.
The two main elements of the legal framework for the European Commission's Directorate-General for Development and Cooperation (EuropeAid) are its performance-based evaluation and monitoring systems.
The total annual cost of the schemes is estimated at EUR 34-38 million.

Together with other forms of assistance, the measures of the Instrument for Pre-Accession Assistance (IPA) have contributed to the implementation of social and economic reforms by Serbia and to the improvement of public finance management.
Based on the experience gained in the implementation of financial and non-financial assistance projects for Serbia, the Commission attaches increasing importance to governance.
The Commission has effectively managed non-financial assistance to Serbia in the management and fight against corruption.
As regards Serbia's preparation for the management of EU decentralised funds, the Commission has also provided effective support, but only to a limited extent of IPA management structures.
One quarter of the IPA funding for Serbia was allocated for management, which, according to the Commission, is the country's biggest challenge.
The EU complements IPA funding through a number of non-financial measures to help Serbia prepare for EU membership.
Our actions 30 Management Administrative expenditure of EU institutions, agencies and other bodies includes staff expenditure (staff and pensions) and expenditure on buildings, equipment, energy, communication and information technologies.

In 2014, the Court adopted the following special report: • How do the EU institutions calculate, reduce and compensate for greenhouse gas emissions?
(No 14/2014) the Court's Special Report assessed whether the EU institutions and bodies implemented strategies to reduce the environmental impact of their administrative activities and whether these strategies were effectively implemented.
In its report, the Court called on the EU institutions and institutions to develop a common policy approach to reducing greenhouse gas emissions (carbon emissions and CO2).
The implementation of the eco-management and audit scheme is slow and the information available on actual emissions is insufficient.
Few institutions and bodies systematically use public procurement to transform into a world.
While EU institutions and bodies have managed to reverse the trend of energy-related greenhouse gas emissions in their buildings, the available data shows that there are no clear trends in reducing greenhouse gas emissions compared to other sources of emissions such as business trips.
More than half of the EU institutions and bodies audited have not set any quantitative targets for reducing emissions.
EU environmental policy aims to achieve a high level of protection.
The Treaty (TFEU) requires that environmental protection requirements be taken into account in the definition and implementation of Union policies and actions to promote sustainable development.
Our activities 31 Income and own resources are EU revenue to finance expenditure.
There are three types of own resources: traditional own resources (customs duties imposed outside the EU, sugar production levies), VAT-based own resources and GNI-based own resources (the largest source of revenue from the EU budget).
In 2014, the Court adopted the following special report: • Are preferential trade schemes properly managed?
(No 2/2014) depends on whether the Commission has assessed whether the economic effects of the preferential trade rules and whether the controls effectively guarantee that imports will not be subject to the wrong preferential customs duty resulting from the loss of EU revenue.
The audit concluded that although the Commission has increased the quality of impact assessments over time, it has still not sufficiently analysed the economic impact of preferential trade schemes on the economy.
The EU is losing revenue due to shortcomings in customs controls in the Member States: this check must not prevent the introduction of preferential duties on certain imported goods in an inappropriate way.
The EU grants preference through unilateral preferential trade arrangements to developing countries to ensure their duty-free access to the EU market, thereby contributing to the eradication of poverty and the promotion of sustainable development.
In 2011, the value of products imported into the EU under preferential trade arrangements amounted to more than EUR 242 billion, representing 14% of imports into the EU.
Our actions 32 Financial and economic management The EU economic governance framework aims to prevent or detect and correct problematic economic developments, such as excessive deficits and debt levels, which may hamper growth and put public finances at risk.
In 2014, the Court adopted its first special report on the subject: • the European Banking Authority: in • EBA in a changing environment (No 5/2014). In this special report, the Court examined whether the Commission and the European Banking Authority (EBA) satisfied their competence to establish new regulation and supervision in the banking sector, and how these systems functioned.
The analysis showed that the Commission's reform of banking legislation and the establishment of EBA were the first important responses to the financial crisis.
EBA has established the basis for the new banking regulation and supervision system.
These shortcomings concerned cross-border banking supervision, assessment of the resilience of EU banks and the promotion of consumer protection.
In the context of the 2011 stress test, which was carried out at EU level without financial security measures, EBA had a limited legal mandate and limited human resources.
Although the stress test led to the recapitalisation of many banks in 2011, it became clear that such stress tests are limited if they are not related to the assessment of the quality of the total assets.
Questions remain concerning the future role of EBA in banking supervision and the role and responsibilities of EBA and the ECB.
As a result of the financial crisis, the Commission has launched measures to stabilise the banking sector to strengthen the regulatory framework and banking supervision, in particular in the case of banks operating across borders.
EBA was established in 2011 in the context of specific proposals for regulatory changes.
EBA plays a role in the supervision of European banking rules and in the protection of consumers.

Our actions 35 Lukes, duplication and challenges: an analysis of the EU's rules of responsibility and public control The purpose of this analysis is to raise awareness and to encourage the EU's democratic legitimacy of the institutional system.
It describes the basic features of the accountability framework, the role of public financial control, the key elements of a robust chain of responsibility and financial control, as well as six important areas where responsibility and financial control challenges are at EU level, and examines the principles of accountability and financial control as regards the various new EU and intergovernmental instruments developed in response to the financial crisis.
Best use of EU funds: an EU financial risk analysis At a time when governments and taxpayers in the Member States want the funds they are bringing more benefits, the analysis summarises the Court's observations on all aspects of the EU's financial management.
Based on the Court's 35-year experience in the control of EU revenue and expenditure, the analysis presents an overview of the EU's financial management and a summary of the issues to be addressed in order to ensure a better cost-benefit ratio of the EU budget.
This analysis will be complemented by detailed data on the main features and topics related to the various areas of revenue and expenditure and on proposals for improvement.

The strategy for international cooperation The Court's cooperation strategy aims to ensure the fullest possible implementation of the EU's public responsibility, in particular through enhanced bilateral and multilateral cooperation with relevant partners, such as the National Supreme Audit Authorities and the International Audit Authorities.
Since the Court's audit duties cover areas where there are impacts (e.g. budgetary management) and global (e.g. climate change) in Europe, our international cooperation activities are even more important than in the past.
As part of its cooperation strategy, the Court has the following priorities: ο Cooperation at EU level within the Contact Committee and individual cooperation with the EFTA Surveillance Committee in the EU Member States will continue to be the main priorities.
In the context of enlargement of the EU, the Court will assist the ORBN of candidate countries and potential candidate countries in their activities to develop competences and expertise. The EU Court, for example INTOSAI, will become more involved in cooperation activities to establish technical standards, as this organisation will be essential to develop expertise and exchange knowledge in the public finance sector. The EU Court, a member of international audit organisations such as INTOSAI, will be involved in cooperation in the establishment of technical standards.
As part of the cooperation strategy, in conjunction with other recent actions such as new high-level conferences and meetings, the Court will contribute to raising awareness of the EU's financial management and to enhancing the EU's financial management requirements.

The Court also joined the newly created working group on the audit of civil protection assistance.
In the context of the Joint Conferences of the Regional Working Groups INTOSAI, the Court actively participated in the II Joint Conference ASOSAI2 EUROSAI, which focused on the experience gained with the adoption of the ISSAI3 and its impact on the future.

EU action 42 Main events International Court International Review 2013 The Court asked the ORKB of France, Germany, Sweden and Germany to carry out a specialist evaluation (peer review) to carry out an economic evaluation.
The peer review was based on the experience of all three partners and was very useful both for the Court and for experts.
The methodology was based on generally recognised criteria for the work of the ORKB and took into account the guidelines adopted in international standards.
In 2014, this review was published on the Court's website (eca.europa.eu).
Since the last peer review, the Court has made significant progress in 2008.
The Court examined the challenges arising from the complex institutional framework of the EU and took a number of steps to increase the effectiveness and effectiveness of its audits and the quality of the audit reports.
International rules of control encourage international peer reviews.
They enable the highest audit authorities to obtain a voluntary assessment of the performance of their tasks based on international standards.
In 2014, the Court carried out a peer review of the Lithuanian Supreme Audit Authority and was asked to assess the financial control of the jury and to participate in the peer evaluation of the ORKB Spain and Lett-lands.
High-level conference on improving accountability in the EU From left to right: Jacques Sciberras, Head of Cabinet, Kevin Cardiff, Member of the Court, Vítor Caldeira, and Vice-Presidents of Olli Rehn.
In October 2014, the Court organised a high-level conference at which a number of people were invited to ensure that the European Union fulfilled its responsibility for the public resources that are used to achieve its objectives.
The meeting was devoted to errors, oversets and challenges at EU and Member State level, as outlined by the Court in the Landscape analysis on EU legislation on financial accountability and control (see page 35).
The Conference has made it possible for participants, including members or representatives of the European Parliament, the European Commission, the Court, the European Central Bank, the European Investment Bank, the European Stability Mechanism, national settlement and science tribunals, to discuss how these arrangements should be developed to respond to developments in economic, budgetary and monetary integration.
The focus was on accountability in the EU, in particular with regard to central banks and supervisors, the structure of the crisis and the post-crisis period, increasing the leverage effect of EU funding through participation in real estate, and increasing the focus on EU performance.
The conference agreed that there was a need for closer cooperation between government authorities, parliaments and auditors at EU and Member State level to help the public understand the benefits of EU action and programmes.
Our actions 43 Strengthening the partnership with the national authorities in Lithuania The High Level Delegation of the Court visited Lithuania in September 2014 in order to strengthen the partnership with the parliament, the government, the central bank and national central banks and to support the best use and control of EU expenditure.
The Court and its partners in Lithuania exchanged priorities for strengthening the EU's reporting obligation and considered how best they can contribute to the added value of EU spending and to help policy makers and Parliament in Lithuania make the best use of the Court's audit results.
During the visit, the delegation of the Court actively participated in a conference of the Lithuanian Parliament, which participated in the challenges of the public sector's calculation and audit.
In addition, the delegation and its partners discussed the issues of financial and economic governance and the benefits of Lithuania's accession to the euro area on 1 January 2015.
Lithuania was the first of many EU Member States to visit the Court in the coming years in order to strengthen the partnership with the national authorities responsible for the management and control of EU funds.
Our management of the 44th College of the Court of Justice belongs to one member of each Member State.
Under the agreement, the term of office of the members of the Court shall be six years, renewable.
Members shall be assigned to one of the five chambers.
The Houses shall adopt audit reports and opinions and take decisions on broader strategic and administrative issues.
In addition, each member shall be responsible for his or her own tasks, which are mainly audit tasks.
The Court's auditors shall carry out the basic audit work and shall be coordinated by the Court's auditors and by the relevant member assisted by the Court's office.
The member then takes note of the report to be adopted by the House and/or the entire College of the Court and then to the European Parliament, the Council and other interested parties, including the media.
In line with Member States' proposals and after consulting the European Parliament in 2014, the Council of the European Union appointed six new members of the European Court of Auditors.
Four of these members e Alex Brennankmeijer (The Netherlands), Danièle Lamarque (France), Nikolaos Millionis (Greece) and Phil Wynn Owen (The United Kingdom) on 1 January welcome two members of Klaus-Heiner Lehne (Germany) and Oskar Herics (Austria) on 1 March 2014.
On 23 January 2014, 28 members of the Court of Vítor Caldeira were re-elected as President of the Court for a period of three years.
The President shall be responsible for supervising the implementation of the mandate of the Court and shall represent the institution outside.

Our management strategy 46 of the Court for 2013-2017: The progress achieved in 2014 was the second year of the Court's implementation of the 2013-2017 strategy.
The aim of this period is to maximise the value of the Court's contribution to the EU's public responsibility.
In order to achieve this objective, the Court mainly seeks to prioritise: ο the focus of the Court's products on improving the EU's responsibility; ο the cooperation with other stakeholders to increase the Court's contribution to the accountability of the EU; ο the further development of the Court as a professional audit body; ο the optimal use of the knowledge and knowledge at the Court's disposal; ο the demonstration of the Court's contribution to its implementation and accountability.
In 2014, the strategy initiated a major change in the Court's organisational structure.
Two internal working groups dealing with the strategy (including the improvement of the audit process including the better definition of tasks and tasks) have presented their results.
This was linked to the European Parliament's report on the future role of the European Court of Auditors and the results of the peer review procedure that the Court has been through.
The various recommendations were summarised in a comprehensive reform proposal that started at the end of 2014 and will run until mid-2016.
In the case of special reports, this means that they should be drawn up within a shorter period of time and, in the case of the annual report, the aim should be to increase the concentration and saving of resources.
The aim is to rebuild the Court into a task-based organisation.
This will enable it to make better use of resources for audits and analyses, which represent the greatest added value for EU citizens.
Our management 47 The Court has been using key performance indicators (ZLIs) since 2008 to inform management of the progress of its objectives, to support the decision-making process and to inform its addressees of the results.
The CLIs reflect the Court's priorities and define its audit performance and responsibilities as a professional audit body.
These indicators shall measure the basic parameters of the quality and impact of the Court's work, with particular regard to the views of the main recipients and the effectiveness and effectiveness of its use of resources.
For the period covered by the strategy for the period 2013-2017, the CLI was updated.

Support for control actions Human resources Allocation of human resources In view of the difficult situation of public finances in Europe, the Court continued to reduce employment by 1% per year by five years (2013-2017), in accordance with the Interinstitutional Agreement of December 2013 on budgetary discipline and financial management.
In 2014, from 891 to 882 temporary officials and temporary staff (excluding contract staff, seconded national experts and trainees) were reduced to 882 temporary officials and temporary staff.
A total of 561 posts were allocated to 561 persons assigned to the inspection (including 113 employees in the members' office).
In 2014, with the objective of the best use of resources, all actions re-identified and extended the capacity to increase efficiency by simplifying procedures.
In 2014, the relocation of staff from support staff to the control services was also continued.
However, this was compensated by the transfer of certain support services from the members' offices to administrative support and the transfer of the Department of Communication and Institutional Relations to the services of the President.

Support for control activities 55 Vocational training support services In order to develop the Court as a professional audit body and to make the best use of the knowledge it has and the knowledge and expertise it has, it is necessary to continuously train the staff to keep up with professional development and acquire new skills.
In 2014, the Court's staff (researchers and other staff) completed an average of eight days of vocational training.
The participation of language courses in vocational training continues to decline.
In 2014, they accounted for 43% of the total number of training days (compared with 46% in 2013).
In order to make the best use of available resources and technologies, the Court has been offering tailor-made e-learning courses and training to its employees since 2014, in the form of integrated training, in the form of e-learning, in which the participants will receive general e-learning training on the Internet before participation.
In addition, as part of the objective of exchanging internal information and information on the progress of public sector audits, internal and external experts' presentations on changes in audit and other relevant fields of information and information on audit progress in the public sector continued to be organised.
Written translation is an action to support checks to enable the Court to carry out its mission and to achieve its communication objectives to ensure its results in the languages of EU citizens.
In 2014, total translation volume increased by 4 % more than in 2013.
More than 98% of the translations were completed in time.
In addition to normal translation work, the Translation Directorate continued the direct participation of translators in the Court's main office: translators provided linguistic support during 40 audit visits across the EU and in the preparation of audit reports.
In 2014, the Translation Directorate focused mainly on quality assurance.
To this end, the first quality assurance manual in the field of translations was adopted and a quality assurance system was developed for customers.
In order to improve service efficiency, a review and optimisation of the translation process was carried out and process automation was started in cooperation with the Directorate for Information Technology.
Support for control activities 56 All processes related to the development and sharing of tools were carried out with safety and continuity: for example, in 2014 a comprehensive test was carried out to restart the new K3 building after the collapse of the IT systems (disaster recovery) and the central IT components (e.g. the start of migration of the Court's e-mail system) were modernised.
The management and infrastructure of the Directorate for Finance and Support Services shall be designed to provide adequate resources, services and infrastructure to enable the Court to carry out its mission and pursue its strategic objectives, and to ensure that the necessary internal control, internal control and audit mechanisms are available to support all of the Court's activities.
In 2014, the Directorate continued to focus on improving the efficiency and efficiency of its activities.
An environmental management system is currently being developed for the Court, which is in line with the principles of the Community environmental management and audit system (EMAS), to be approved by the end of 2016.
In 2014, a number of actions were successfully implemented to deliver concrete results and to demonstrate the Court's commitment to environmental protection, such as: • the adoption of environmental policy; • carrying out environmental analysis and carrying out environmental compliance measures; • increasing the number of environmental awareness campaigns for workers from four in 2013 to eight in 2014; • obtaining Breeam's environmental certification (the most important method for designing and evaluating sustainable buildings in the world) in building K3 and maintaining a mark of compliance with best practices in waste management; • promoting the sustainable transport of workers by providing a new bicycle space and a bicycle changing room, by installing a charger for electric cars and by.

Supporting control activities 59 Auditing and clearing The Court's internal audit The internal auditor shall advise the Court on risk control issues, issuing opinions on the quality of management and control systems and recommendations on improving the conditions for the management of operations and the promotion of sound financial management.
The internal auditor shall also support the work of the external auditor responsible for certifying the Court's accounts.
The internal auditor informed the Court of the results of the audits carried out in 2014, the findings, recommendations and actions taken on the basis of those recommendations.
The Court shall report annually to the European Parliament and the Council on the results of the internal auditor's work.
In October 2014, the Court's internal audit was certified in accordance with the definition of internal audit, code of conduct and standards established by the Institute of Internal Auditors (IAA).
This certification was the result of a comprehensive assessment of the quality of the Court's internal audit carried out by an external expert at the request of the internal auditor and of the Internal Audit Committee at the request of Deloitteput and met international standards of professional practice for internal audit in IIA.
The Court's external audit The Court's annual accounts shall be audited by an independent auditor.
This is an important aspect of the Court's approach to applying the same principles of transparency and accountability as those of the individuals it has carried out.

European Court of Auditors HUTER EU FINANCE
The European Court of Auditors 02 The Court of Auditors is an independent external audit body of the European Union based in Luxembourg.
It has 28 audit and administration members from each EU Member State and employs about 900 employees from all EU Member States.
Since its establishment in 1977, the Court has contributed to improving financial management in the EU and to improving accounting.
The Court's tasks are to verify whether EU funds have been correctly booked, whether they have been adopted and used in accordance with the relevant rules and regulations and whether the funds have been used optimally.
It warns against threats, provides security and guidance to policy makers in the EU, how to improve public finance management and ensure that European citizens know how to make full use of their funds.
In its audit work and other activities, the Court contributes to strengthening the democratic legitimacy and stability of the European Union.
Heading 03 Page 2 European Court of Auditors 4 Preface of the President 5 2015 at a glance 5 Our activities 5 Our management 6-40 Our activities 6-9 Audits 10-13 Annual reports 14 Special Annual Reports 15-33 Special Reports 34 Reviews 35-36 High-level events and conferences 37-38 Relations with addressees 39-40 Cooperation with the highest audit authorities 41-49 Our management 41-42 College of the Court 43-45 Court Strategy 2013-2017 46-49 Measurement of achievements 50-59 Support with control 50-53 Human resources 53-55 Support services 56-57 Financial information 58-59 Control and accountability 60 Declaration by the authorising officer by delegation
The President's introduction 04 Dear Reader, to which this activity report refers in 2015, the European Union has again addressed the major challenges and, in particular, the creation of the European Fund for Strategic Investments (EFSI) and the introduction of a single resolution mechanism for banks in the euro area, there has been a significant development in the management, policy and financial management of the EU.
Both these and other changes have led to new audit tasks of the Court.
In 2015, we re-examined the activities of EU institutions and other bodies and all EU funds paid to Member States, non-EU countries, international organisations and other beneficiaries.
In accordance with our obligations under the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, we have prepared annual reports on the general budget of the European Union and the European Development Fund and specific annual reports on the accounts of more than 50 EU agencies and other bodies.
Furthermore, we have prepared 25 special reports on a number of topics, the results of which are summarised in this activity report.
We would like to draw your attention in particular to two specific reports: our report on the Emissions Trading Scheme, which shows that our actions go beyond purely financial issues, as well as our report on financial assistance to countries in difficulty, which forms part of a series of new special reports on financial and economic governance.
In addition, last year, we issued eight opinions on new or revised EU legislation with significant financial implications, including an opinion on the EFSI Regulation.
In order for our work to be successful, we need to communicate the information gathered to stakeholders both at EU level and at national level.
During the year, we have deepened our cooperation with the European Parliament and with the Council of the European Union, and we have deepened our cooperation with our key partners in ensuring the EU's commitment to the fight against fraud.
The results of our audits have been presented by an increasing number of specialised committees of these institutions, and we have taken into account their concerns when planning future audits.
In addition, the Court's members have made high-level visits to strengthen their partnership with national authorities, parliaments and audit bodies.
In 2015, we organised two significant conferences: one in Brussels on EU energy security and one in Luxembourg on the future of development aid in the context of the new UN Sustainable Development Goals.
We have also prepared a wide-ranging internal reform in order to respond better to ongoing changes in the European Union.
This report presents some important changes in our relations with stakeholders, our research and our resources.
In addition, you will receive important information about our management of human resources, finance and services, as well as about the results of our internal and external controls last year, as well as about the latest annual discharge procedure.
I hope that this report will provide useful and interesting information on the Court's activities in 2015, in which we want to do our job to improve the financial management of the EU, improve accountability and transparency and protect the financial interests of EU citizens.

An internal reform has been carried out to improve our control and reporting procedures and to allow greater flexibility in the management of our resources. • 25 Special Reports on specific management and budgetary issues, including the emission trading system, youth employment programmes and assistance during the financial crisis. • • Eight Opinions on new and revised EU legal acts and other decisions affecting the financial management, from the proposed regulation on the European Fund for Strategic Investments to the revised Regulation on a single management mechanism. • Meetings, seminars and conferences with our addressees, including two high-level conferences on EU control, • Opinions on security of energy supply and development aid, and other decisions on financial management, from the proposed regulation on the European Fund for Strategic Investments to the revised Regulation on the security of the EU to the two conferences, the two addresses on the internal restructuring mechanism. •

Our activities 06 Audits Our audit reports and opinions are an important part of the EU's responsibility chain, because they are used to hold EU financial management entities responsible for opinions, especially in the framework of the annual discharge procedure for the implementation of the EU budget discharge in respect of the implementation of the budget.
They are primarily the European Commission, as well as other EU institutions and bodies.
In shared management areas, Member States also play an important role, as in agricultural and cohesion expenditure.
Our three main products are: • Annual reports mainly containing the results of audits of accounts and compliance checks on the budget of the European Union and the European Development Fund (EDF), but also on aspects of financial management and performance aspects.
Other reports should be accompanied by specific annual reports for EU agencies, decentralised agencies and joint undertakings. • Special reports presenting the results of selected cost-effectiveness audits or compliance with the rules for specific policies or policies, or for budgetary or management issues. • Opinions on new or amended legal acts affecting financial management and other products on the basis of analyses carried out at the request of another institution or on the Court's own initiative. • Opinions on new or amended legal acts affecting financial management and other products based on analysis, or at the request of another institution or on the Court's own initiative.
We are trying to manage our resources in such a way as to ensure a proper balance between our different activities while at the same time ensuring adequate coverage of the different areas of the EU budget and ensuring adequate results.
In 2015, we used a significant part of our resources to prepare annual statements of assurance, which were then presented in our annual reports.
The work underlying the Statement of Assurance covers two aspects for which, in accordance with the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, we must issue an annual audit opinion: the reliability of the accounts and the legality and regularity of the underlying transactions.
Furthermore, we take into account, as far as possible, the work of other auditors (see the audit section of the EU agencies on page 14) and the management declarations in the form of annual work reports of the Directors-General of the Commission.
In addition to the checks required by law, we choose, at our discretion, specific expenditures or policy areas on the basis of criteria such as the risk of irregularities or insufficient results, the potential for improvement and the public interest.
This issue is completely independent, but we take into account the views of our address circle.
In 2015 we prepared 25 special reports, which are in particular the result of our economic control.
A summary of the special reports is presented in this activity report (pages 15-33).
In 2015, we issued eight opinions on proposals for new or revised provisions and regulations (p. 34).
In particular, we pay attention to our opinion on EFSI to highlight both the subject and the impact of our opinions.
All audit reports and opinions are available on our website (eca.europa.eu).

Our activities 08 Audit visits in 2015 While most audit work carried out at the Court's premises in Luxembourg, the auditors also carried out audit visits to the authorities of the Member States, to other beneficiaries of EU funds within and outside the European Union (including in the case of organisations involved in Union funds, such as the European Investment Bank's regional offices in Kenya and Uganda) and to other EU institutions, agencies and bodies.
As a result of these visits, we received direct proof of control from those involved in the granting, management, collection and payment of EU funds as well as from the final beneficiaries.
Our teams of controllers usually consist of two to three controllers, and the duration of the inspection visit may be several days and several weeks.
The frequency and intensity of control activities in individual Member States and beneficiary countries depends on the type of control and, where appropriate, on the selection of the sample.
Therefore, the number of inspection visits may vary depending on the country and year.
In the EU, our audit visits are often carried out in conjunction with the highest audit authorities in the Member States visited.
In 2015, the Court's auditors transferred 4 310 days to on-the-spot checks in the Member States and outside the EU in order to obtain evidence of annual reports and selected audit tasks (special reports).
In addition, they devoted a lot of time to the EU institutions in Brussels and Luxembourg, as well as to decentralised agencies and bodies across the EU.
On-the-spot checks took less days than in 2014.
This is due to more efficient working procedures and increasing use of technologies such as secure data and documents exchange and video conferencing.
Detecting fraud Although our research is not specifically designed to detect fraud, our research is sometimes about cases where we suspect irregularities or fraud.
The Court cooperates with the European Anti-Fraud Office (OLAF) to combat fraud against the EU budget.
Any suspicion of fraud, corruption or any other illegal activity to the detriment of the EU's financial interests, which appear during our audit work, we will hand it over to OLAF.
OLAF will then continue the investigation which will decide on possible investigations and, where appropriate, cooperate with the authorities of the Member States.
In 2015, we handed over 27 cases of suspected fraud to OLAF (2014: 16).

Our activities 10 Annual Reports for the financial year 2014 Most of our financial audits and compliance audits for 2015 have been devoted to the implementation of the EU budget for the financial year 2014.
The 2014 Annual Report, which was published on 10 November 2015, was presented to our addressee, including the European Parliament and the Committee on Budgetary Control, the Council of the European Union (Ecofin and Financial Councils), national Parliaments and governments, as well as to the media.
The main objective of our annual report is to assist the European Parliament, the Council and the citizens in assessing the quality of the EU's financial management by presenting the findings and conclusions.
In the 2014 Annual Report, we have ensured the use of EU funds in the financial year in question and we stress the areas where the risk of misuse of EU funds was greatest.
In addition, we analyse the causes of errors and make useful and cost-effective recommendations on possible improvements.
We have revised the structure of our annual report for the financial year 2014 to make this report clearer.
The titles of these chapters correspond to the headings of the multiannual financial framework 2014-2020.
The main element of the report is still the statement of assurance in which we deliver an opinion on the reliability of the EU accounts and the compliance with the rules on revenue and expenditure.
In addition, we have carried out a detailed evaluation of all the main areas of EU activity and have provided extensive information on budgetary and financial management.
The report also contains information on the implementation of the EU budget and on the Commission's reporting, in particular on progress towards the Europe 2020 objectives.
President Vítor Caldeira presented the European Parliament with the annual report of the European Court of Auditors for 2014 of EUR 142.5 billion in 2014 = almost EUR 300 per citizen.
