Conclusions and recommendations in 2014 The EU Annual Report was drafted in a manner consistent with international principles and provides a true and reliable picture of the situation.
For this reason, we could once again deliver an unlimited opinion on their credibility.
However, we have issued a wrong opinion on the regularity of payments. the estimated error rate for 2014 is 4,4% of payments in 2014; this level is close to the error rate in 2013 (4,5%) and is constantly above the materiality level of 2%. In 2014 the estimated error rate for expenditure managed in shared management with the Member States and expenditure managed directly by the Commission was equal to 4,6%).
The greatest error rate has been set for expenditure in economic, social and territorial cohesion, for 5.7% and for 5.6% for competitiveness for growth and growth and employment, for 5.6% for social and territorial cohesion expenditure.
With regard to administrative expenditure, the lowest estimated error rate (0.5%) was established. With regard to administrative expenditure, there is a clear link between expenditure types and error rates.
The estimated error rate for reimbursement schemes (5.5%) for which the EU reimburses the eligible costs of actions based on the cost statements prepared by the beneficiaries is twice the estimated error rate for payment entitlements schemes (2.7%) for which payments are non-refundable but are subject to certain conditions.
Without these measures, the estimated overall error rate would be 5,5 %.

Our actions 14 Special Annual Reports for the financial year 2014 Total for 2014 for all EU agencies, bodies and joint enterprises, around EUR 4 billion has been allocated.
EU agencies, other bodies and joint undertakings perform specific tasks on behalf of the EU and are established in different EU Member States.
They operate in many areas such as safety, health, research, finance, migration and transport, as well as have their own mandate, management, director, staff and budget.
In 2015 we prepared 52 special annual reports for the financial year 2014.
They concern 41 decentralised agencies, executive agencies and other EU bodies, eight European Joint Research Undertakings, European Schools, the Galileo Joint Undertaking in the decommissioning and communication infrastructure of Sisnet.
In addition, we have published two summaries of the results of our audits in this area (one summary on EU agencies and other bodies and the other on joint enterprises).
These reports have been submitted to the President of the European Parliament and to the Committee on Budgetary Control of the European Parliament, the Council for General Affairs and the Committee on Budgetary Affairs of the Council.
In 2014, each annual accounts of 33 decentralised EU agencies and other bodies were independently audited by a private audit firm for the first time.
In drawing up our opinions on our audit accounts, we have taken into account these audit work and the actions taken by the audited entities on the basis of the audit findings.
The accounts of other agencies and joint ventures have been fully audited by us.
In 2014, we considered the accounting of all agencies, other institutions and joint enterprises to be reliable.
The processes were legal and correct, except Artemis (built-in ICT systems), ENIAC (nanoelectronics) and ECSEL (elements and electronic systems).
Overall, the agencies continued to improve their procedures by taking corrective action in response to our comments in previous years.
Our special annual reports and two summaries of the results of our audits on agencies, other bodies and Joint Undertakings for 2014 are available on our website (eca.europa.eu).
52 special annual reports on EU agencies, other bodies and joint undertakings established throughout Europe, based in Europol, The Hague, the Netherlands.
Our activities 15 Special Reports developed in 2015. In addition to our annual reports and special annual reports, we publish special reports, covering the results of the performance and compliance checks in the various areas of the budget or in the various areas of the management of our elections, throughout the year.
When selecting and organising these control tasks, we try to achieve the maximum effect and use our resources in the best way possible.
Our profitability checks often cover several financial years and their subject is complex, so their completion may last longer than a year.
In 2015, the special reports focused in particular on the following issues: the EU's overall objective of creating added value and growth and the EU's response to global challenges such as the sustainability of public finances, the environment and climate change.
For each heading corresponding to the headings of the multiannual financial framework, 25 special reports prepared in 2015 were briefly presented.

Our actions 16 100 80 60 40 20 0 Competitiveness for growth and jobs EUR 143 billion 13% Smart and inclusive growth In the Intelligent and Inclusive growth section in the Intelligent Growth section, the spending equivalent section of the EU budget includes most of the expenditure.
This area comprises two sub-headings: competitiveness for growth and jobs: economic, social and territorial cohesion.
The Competitiveness Sub-heading for Growth and Jobs and Jobs and Financial Resources for Trans-European Energy, Transport and Telecommunications Networks, Enterprise Development, Research and Innovation, Education and Training, Social Policy, etc. The expenditure planned for 2014-2020 represents 13 percent of the total EU budget for the programming period, i.e. EUR 143 billion.
A budget of EUR 15.7 billion was made available for 2015. • Inland navigation in Europe: no significant improvement in the share of transport and navigation conditions since 2001 (No 1/2015), the detailed report examines whether the projects co-financed by the EU budget have effectively contributed to the share of inland waterway transport in inland waterway transport and to the improvement of the quality of inland waterway transport and whether EU inland waterway strategies were consistent and based on appropriate and comprehensive analyses.
Projects co-financed by the EU have not been successfully implemented as an alternative to road transport or an improvement in the capacity to sail could not be implemented effectively.
Although the Commission considered inland navigation a priority, the Member States have given little attention to inland waterways.
There is no coherent overall strategy between Member States, combined with the main maritime corridors, and the maintenance of river resources, as well as political and environmental considerations, have not been sufficiently addressed in the EU strategies.
Member States should prioritise inland waterway transport projects that have the greatest and most direct benefits and the Commission should focus its resources on projects where advanced bottlenecks are available.
Between 2007 and 2013, grants from the TEN-T programme, the European Regional Development Fund and the Cohesion Fund amounted to EUR 1.3 billion.
Our actions 17 • Is EU financial support best suited to the needs of micro-entities?
(No 8/2015) The special report examines whether the European Social Fund (ESF) and the European Progress Microfinance Facility meet the needs of micro-entities.
The auditors found that programming and planning of financial assistance from the ESF was weak and that the implementation of the tasks was not adequately and reliably monitored.
Neither the Commission nor the Member States had comparative information on the administrative costs incurred by the Member States and the financing mechanisms.
These circumstances may undermine the effectiveness of EU financial support to micro-enterprises.
Member States should assess needs when developing financial instruments and developing operational programmes, including financial support to micro-entities by the EU.
The Commission should make the use of ESF financial instruments by Member States conditional on the existence of sound risk management systems.
In the case of microfinance, loans are typically less than EUR 25 000 and often less than EUR 10,000.
The total demand for funding in EU Member States is estimated to be over EUR 12 billion.
The examples mentioned in the report include: the provision of EUR 5 000 for the development of urban cinema and the provision of EUR 9 500 for the development of the playground and clothing store. • Improving security of energy supply through the development of the internal energy market: this special report addresses whether the implementation of internal energy market policies and energy infrastructure expenditure in the EU have effectively contributed to the benefits of security of energy supply.
The audit showed that energy infrastructure in Europe is not yet fully integrated and is therefore currently not ensuring effective security of energy supply.
The Commission should therefore identify energy infrastructure in the EU which is not actively used and work with the Member States to overcome barriers to its use for the internal energy market.
The Commission should also consider new ways of making energy available to customers from another Member State from one Member State.
The internal energy market aims at enabling the free movement and trade of natural gas and electricity across the EU.
Within the EU budget, EUR 3.7 billion has been allocated to the financing of energy infrastructure for the period 2007-2013 and a further EUR 7.4 billion is expected for the period 2014-2020.
However, the report underlines that the EU's objective of completing the internal energy market by 2014 has not been achieved.
Our actions 18 Economic, social and territorial cohesion Smart and inclusive economic growth The sub-heading of economic, social and territorial efficiency in regional policy, in order to support the least developed EU countries and regions, aims to increase the competitiveness and cooperation of all regions.
The planned expenditure for cohesion policy 2014-2020 represents 34% of the EU budget for the entire programming period, i.e. EUR 367 billion.
100 80 60 40 20 0 367 billion EUR 34% • Efforts should be stepped up to address public procurement problems in EU cohesion expenditure (No 10/2015) in a special report on assessing whether the Commission and the Member States are taking appropriate and effective action to address public procurement errors in cohesion policy.
The audit showed that there are still widespread procurement problems across the EU for public authorities.
Although the Commission and the Member States have started to address this issue, much remains to be done.
Serious errors have led to a lack of fair competition and a lack of contracts for the best tenderers.
The systematic analysis is very limited and lacks sufficiently accurate, reliable and consistent data on the nature and scale of errors.
Where the situation does not improve by the end of 2016, it is recommended to suspend payments to the Member States concerned for the period 2014-2020.
Between 2007 and 2013, € 349 billion was spent on regional policy expenditure to be paid through the European Regional Development Fund (ERDF), the Cohesion Fund and the European Social Fund.
A significant proportion of these funds are issued through public procurement.
The errors were noted in around 40% of the projects that the Court verified for its annual accounts for the 2009-2013 financial years for public procurement.
Our actions 19 • EU funding of urban waste water treatment facilities in the Danube basin: Member States need further support in the implementation of the EU waste water treatment policy objectives (No 2/2015) for the implementation of the EU waste water treatment policy objectives (No 22/2015) The specific report assesses the effectiveness of Member States' assistance in the Danube basin with the European Regional Development Fund and the Cohesion Fund in the implementation of the EU waste water treatment policy objectives.
The audit showed that although spending programmes in the EU have contributed significantly to the progress made in the Czech Republic, Hungary, Romania and Slovakia, there have been delays in compliance with the rules and the use of available EU funding in all countries.
While waste water in these countries was usually properly cleaned, in some cases treatment with sewage sludge and rainwater leaks was insufficient.
One third of the installations were too extensive and potentially unable to survive in the long run.
These countries have slowly benefited from the available EU funds, which threatened to lose EU funds or to have to obtain additional funds from national budgets.
The Commission should tighten up reporting requirements and Member States should lay down rules to ensure rapid connection to public sewage channels.
The Commission and the Member States should establish criteria for all types of use of sewage sludge and ensure reliable monitoring of pollution.
The Danube basin area is the largest access area in Europe.
The EU contribution to waste water treatment projects in the four Member States audited • in the 2000-2006 and 2007-2013 programming periods amounted to EUR 7.9 billion. Water quality in the Danube basin: progress in the implementation of the Water Framework Directive, but further action is still needed (No 23/2015) in this special report. The implementation of the Water Framework Directive by the Czech Republic, Hungary, Romania and Slovakia is examined whether the implementation of the Water Framework Directive by the Czech Republic has contributed to improving the quality of surface water in the Danube basin.
The audit showed that few improvements have been introduced since 2004.
The main reason for the limited progress was that the Member States' plans were not ambitious enough.
Targeted measures were missing in relation to the water bodies with inadequate quality status.
In addition, shortcomings in monitoring systems have led to a lack of data on both the type of contamination and the sources of contamination that have led to a negative assessment of the state of aquatic organisms.
In addition, Member States have removed a significant number of water bodies without sufficient justification for relevant deadlines.
Between 2007 and 2013, Member States in the Danube basin received €6.35 billion from the European Regional Development Fund and the Cohesion Fund for waste water treatment.
During the same period, the European Agricultural Fund for Rural Development, the European Agricultural Fund for Rural Development, received €6.39 billion to compensate farmers for agri-environmental measures.
Our actions 20 • EU Youth Guarantee: Our actions are starting, but the risk of implementation is predictable (No 3/2015) in this special report the Commission is examining whether it has duly supported the Member States in creating the Youth Guarantee and whether the risk of implementation is possible.
The audit identified three risks that could hinder the effective implementation of the Youth Guarantee: the adequacy of the overall funding, the definition of a high-quality job position, and the way the Commission monitors the Youth Guarantee and reports on the results.
The auditors concluded that the Commission had helped Member States to implement the Youth Guarantee in a timely and appropriate manner.
However, the Commission has not carried out an impact assessment indicating the expected costs and benefits, although this is a standard procedure.
The Commission asked Member States to provide cost estimates when submitting their plans to implement the Youth Guarantee, but some Member States did not provide the necessary information, but none of the Member States indicated the estimated costs of the necessary structural reforms.
The Youth Guarantee was established in June 2013 in response to the deterioration of the situation of unemployed young people as a result of the economic and financial crisis.
In the period 2014-2020, the Youth Guarantee In the framework of the European Social Fund and the Youth Employment Initiative, a total of EUR 12.7 billion has been co-financed within the EU budget. • Support for young people by the Commission: The transfer from the ESF to the employment of young people has been successful but has not sufficiently focused on results (No 17/2015).
The auditors concluded that, despite the fact that the Youth Action Teams set up by the Commission managed to translate the funds into projects to support young people, they only applied to a limited extent.
The Commission provided advisory assistance to the Member States but was limited in the scope and quality of the information available.
While the initiative has led to the re-programming and re-allocation of the European Social Fund, the Commission has focused mainly on their budgetary impact when assessing the changes in the operational programmes.
If there are discrepancies between the promises made and the real objectives of the Commission, there should not be too high expectations of such initiatives.
As part of the Youth Opportunities initiative, the Commission set up teams of young people in 2012.
The team consisted of experts from eight Member States with the highest number of unemployed among young people and experts from the Commission.
This initiative covered almost EUR 10 billion of the European Social Fund, which were still available in the Member States concerned.

Our actions 22 • Are financial instruments in the field of rural development an effective and promising instrument?
(No 5/2015) ) The purpose of this special report is to determine whether the financial instruments (credits and guarantee funds) used in rural development policy in the 2007-2013 programming period have been fully developed and managed.
The audit showed that the financial instruments have not yet succeeded.
This is mainly due to the overcapitalisation of financial instruments and the lack of their potential to achieve the desired leverage and renewable effect.
There was no clear argument for the introduction of financial instruments for the 2007-2013 programming period.
Furthermore, reliable, quantitative information has not been obtained to justify the nature of the financial instruments established, to identify the need for financial instruments in the agricultural sector and to demonstrate that, for the Fund, the amount for this purpose was adequate.
Incentives should be stepped up for Member States to develop financial instruments for rural development and to increase demand for farmers or other beneficiaries and to set for 2014-2020 appropriate standards and targets for leverage and renewable effect.
By the end of 2013, the EU and its Member States invested around €700 million in guarantee and credit funds for rural development.
The Commission wants Member States to commit to at least doubling the use of these instruments for the period 2014-2020.
Efficiency analysis: the integrity and implementation of the EU ETS (No 6/2015) The EU Emissions Trading Scheme (EU ETS) differs in a way from the other policies and programmes that we are investigating, as it does not receive significant funding from the EU budget.
However, it has a very strong impact on the implementation of EU policies and on the quality of life of citizens.
The EU ETS was introduced in 2005 and is often referred to as the reference model for the development of climate change strategies and emissions trading systems elsewhere in the world.
Therefore, appropriate frameworks are expected to ensure regulation and market surveillance, legal certainty and management systems for relevant information.
The basic structures of the implementation systems should also be sufficiently robust.
At the end of 2013, our auditors examined the framework for protecting the integrity of the EU ETS and the system for the real implementation of the programme by the Commission and the Member States by phase II (end 2012).
The evaluation was carried out due to the risks associated with the creation of a functioning market for the implementation of the EU's climate change policy and the difficulties associated with control of activities that are not understood (not known on the market, how to measure hot air? in the picture).
Our auditors examined whether the EU ETS was properly managed.
To this end, they not only checked the files and checked the officials involved in the management of the EU ETS in the European Commission in Brussels, but also checked the competent authorities in the five Member States (Germany, France, Italy, Poland and the United Kingdom).
In addition, in two other countries (Greece and Spain) documents were examined and experts were consulted.
More evidence has been obtained from auditors who have checked the documents of the national authorities concerning 150 installations selected in the seven Member States, as well as the data contained in the EU transaction protocol.
Our activities 23 are being analysed and the auditors have not been able to verify equipment on the spot because they have not received EU funds in connection with the emissions trading scheme and the Court therefore does not have the right to access to the controls necessary.
The evidence obtained by our controllers indicated that the emissions market was not being monitored and that there was insufficient cooperation between regulators.
For example, our auditors concluded that the legal definition of allowances should be clarified and that procedures for the opening of ETS accounts in the Union Registry and the monitoring of transactions were not appropriate in order to ensure adequate control in order to combat fraud.
However, the initial situation was difficult: Member States were not able to effectively monitor cross-border transactions as they did not have direct access to the central database, and the Commission was not able to monitor the transactions as there was no legal basis for it.
Our auditors also found that the emission monitoring and reporting systems are not harmonised and that there are weaknesses in control that the Commission's support and reporting from the Commission and the Member States were not sufficient.
On the basis of their findings, the auditors concluded that the framework for protecting the integrity of the market is not robust enough and that, at the last stage, there were serious shortcomings in implementation, which partly require further action at this stage.
However, our report clearly shows that this innovative system is constantly being improved.
At the time of publication of the report, the debate on possible reforms of the EU ETS, which focused on the effectiveness of the system and the over-regulation of the system, was not yet completed.
However, in our report, we note that we should also pay attention to the fundamental issues of market integrity and implementation, so that the EU can trust that this fundamental instrument is appropriate to meet the expectations of reducing emissions and low-carbon technologies.
We have made some practical recommendations to the Commission and the Member States' authorities to improve market integrity and implement the system so that the EU ETS becomes a more effective tool to achieve the climate targets by 2020 and beyond.
The Commission agreed with the recommendation contained in the report that, in order to improve the integrity of the market, significant regulatory and market surveillance problems should be addressed in order to improve, if necessary, emissions, and that, in phase III (2013-2020), numerous improvements have already been made, in particular with regard to our comments.
The report attracted a lot of media interest and was presented to accredited EU journalists at a press conference in Brussels.
In the EU and around the world, the press reported that the EU ETS should be more closely supervised to improve the carbon market and that the system should be more protected from market abuse, including the high risk of VAT fraud.
As usual for all the special reports, the Commissioner responsible for the report, Kevin Cardiff, in this case, presented the report of the Committee on Budgetary Control of the European Parliament and of the Committee on Parliament and of the Environment with a view to providing them with information from the Court on the basis of future decisions on the relevant provisions and regulations.
Parliament and the Council welcomed our comments and recommendations and will take into account future proposals to improve the integrity and implementation of the system.

Our actions 24 • Does the Commission manage fisheries partnership agreements well?
(No 11/2015) ÖFFENTliche This special report is intended to verify that the contracts are well managed.
The auditors assessed the negotiations and implementation of the agreements, the Commission's monitoring of catches and the selection and control of the actions financed.
The audit concluded that although contracts were generally well managed, the quantities negotiated were often higher than the quantities reported during the previous periods.
This leads to a regular under-use of funds.
As the EU makes full payments, regardless of the actual fishing activity, the actual costs were often higher than the negotiated price.
In addition, reliable, uniform and complete data on actual catches of the EU fleet were missing.
When negotiating new systems, the Commission should take into account the previous levels of use that more closely bind payments to actual catches and ensure that the new fishing database is fully used by flag Member States and contains reliable catch data that can be monitored and updated.
The aim of the agreements is to ensure the sustainability of the fisheries concerned by allowing EU vessels to only fish surplus stocks of partner countries.
However, the auditors doubt that the so-called surplus can be reliably calculated due to the lack of reliable information. • The EU's priority to support the knowledge economy in rural areas has been breached by insufficient management of knowledge transfer and guidance (No 12/2015) of the wife in this special report, in particular to examine the existence of management and control systems in order to effectively implement knowledge transfer and advice actions in rural development.
The audit showed that the implementation of EU-funded vocational education and training and vocational advice programmes is too expensive in rural areas, often leads to duplication of existing programmes and promotes education and training purchasers.
The auditors have detected incorrect administrative procedures in the Member States and insufficient supervision by the European Commission.
Member States relied too much on instructors' proposals and considered all kinds of training to be good and eligible for public funding.
The lack of fair and transparent choice has led to multiple choice of existing and existing suppliers and to most support.
Member States should select training projects corresponding to the skills needs set out in the periodic analysis and thus avoid the designation of competitions by suppliers.
The EU supports training and advisory projects in rural areas through the European Agricultural Fund for Rural Development.
For the period 2007-2013, €1.3 billion has been allocated to these projects.
Together with Member States' co-financing, the total amount of public support amounted to EUR 2.2 billion.
This amount could amount to over EUR 4 billion over the period 2014-2020.
Our actions 25 • Cost savings for EU rural development aid for non-productive investments in agriculture (No 20/2015) gesandt The special report specifies in particular whether non-productive investments in agriculture (NPI) are cost-effective and whether they contribute to the achievement of the European Agricultural Fund for Rural Development objective for sustainable agriculture for the 2007-2013 programming period.
The auditors concluded that although the aid to the NPI contributed to the achievement of the objectives, it was not in a cost-effective manner, as in 75% of the projects audited the costs were disproportionate.
Many of these projects have been fully funded by public funding, although these collections have clearly stated that they have positive results, they have been visited by four Member States that have spent 80% of the total EU budget on NIP: Portugal, Denmark, the United Kingdom (England) and Italy (Apulia).
Only five of the 28 projects audited proved cost-effective.
The report warns that the lack of cost efficiency may not be limited to the sample as the problems identified were due to shortcomings in the management and control systems in the Member States.
Non-productive investments are investments which do not lead to significant income or to a significant increase in the value of the beneficiary's holding but have a positive impact on the environment. • EU infrastructure support in rural areas: these measures can be used in a much more efficient way (No 25/2015) a special report examines whether the European Commission and the Member States have achieved a positive cost-benefit ratio by financing roads, water supply systems, schools and other institutions under rural development programmes.
The audit showed that, although some infrastructure projects have made a positive contribution in rural areas, Member States and the Commission, in shared management, have achieved only an insufficient cost-benefit ratio.
Member States have not always clearly justified the need for EU funding for rural development.
The risk that projects that would have been implemented without EU funding could not be effectively controlled.
The report concludes that the Commission has adopted a more active and coordinated approach since 2012.
Correct implementation should lead to improved financial management for the period 2014-2020.
For the period 2007-2013, the rural development programmes allocated EU funds of EUR 13 billion to rural infrastructure.

During the 2014-2020 programming period, the EU allocated 6% of the planned total expenditure, i.e. EUR 65 billion.

Additional appropriations will be made available through the European Development Fund, which is not part of the EU budget and is therefore not covered by the multiannual financial framework. • The EU Police Mission in Afghanistan: mixed result (No 7/2015) in the Special Report assesses whether the EU Police Mission (EUPOL) was well planned and coordinated, whether it received appropriate operational support and appropriate guidance, whether it contributed to the progress of the Afghan National Police and whether it was prepared for appropriate forms of exit.
The audit has shown that EUPOL has partially fulfilled the objective of contributing to the establishment of permanent and effective civilian police forces under Afghan responsibility.
In an environment characterised by the lack of trained, fully functioning Afghan police forces, high illiteracy and massive corruption in Afghan police and judicial systems, EUPOL has managed to contribute to the reform of the Ministry of Home Affairs and the professionalisation of the national police.
However, given the continuing shortcomings in the police and justice system in Afghanistan, there is a risk that the results of EUPOL and, in general, the Afghan police will not remain in the area by the end of 2016.
The total cost of EUPOL between May 2007 and December 2014 amounted to almost EUR 400 million. Security costs represent almost a third of this amount.
At the end of 2014, the EU carried out 32 missions under the common security and defence policy, of which 16 have ended, ended and ended, and 16 are still ongoing.
Our actions 27 • EU support for the fight against torture and the abolition of the death penalty (No 9/2015) of the death penalty (No 9/2015) of the views on whether the European Instrument for Democracy and Human Rights effectively supports the prevention of torture, rehabilitation of torture victims and the abolition of the death penalty.
The audit has shown that, although EU-funded projects are effective, projects are often not sufficiently targeted and are limited in scope as they are distributed in accordance with the principle of wealth.
The allocation of funds was usually appropriate, but the Commission did not sufficiently take into account the priorities of individual countries in the field of human rights.
Projects have often not been well coordinated with other EU actions such as development aid and political dialogue.
They were usually implemented by involved and competent organisations.
The recommendations of the auditors concerned the targeting of financial resources, better coordination with other EU actions, the selection and improvement of projects, the measurement of results and the sustainability of beneficiary organisations.
The European Union operates through diplomatic channels and grants grants to NGOs through the European Instrument for Democracy and Human Rights.
• EU support for timber producing countries under the FLEGT Action Plan (No 13/2015)... in the framework of this special report... to examine whether the EU FLEGT Action Plan to combat illegal logging was well managed by the Commission in the framework of the EU Action Plan to combat illegal logging.
The auditors said that although the Action Plan is a desirable initiative, the results are generally thinner.
The aid was not granted to wood-producing countries on the basis of clear criteria and its impact was weakened due to the large number of countries competing for aid.
There have been significant differences in progress in these countries.
Inappropriate progress is particularly due to the lack of appropriate planning by the Commission and the lack of clear priorities for the allocation of resources to wood producing countries.
The auditors recommended that the Commission set clear objectives and measures to achieve them.
Four Member States still need to fully implement the EU Wood Regulation, which has been introduced to prevent the import of illegally harvested timber into the EU market.
Between 2003 and 2013, 35 countries received EUR 300 million under the Action Plan.
Two of these countries, Indonesia and Ghana, have made significant progress towards a full timber licensing system.
Overall, little progress has been made, and many countries have struggled to overcome the obstacles to good policy-making.
Within 12 years of the Commission's implementation of the action plan, no partner country has been able to implement a fully approved authorisation scheme.
Our actions 28 • ACP Investment Facility: does it offer added value?
(No 14/2015) s y y h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h
The audit has shown that the Investment Facility actually adds value to EU development cooperation with ACP countries and that it is also useful to achieve the EU's policy objectives.
At the end of 2014, the credit lines represented 28% of the instrument's portfolio compared with 14% at the end of 2010.
The increase in participation reflects the lasting importance of the long-term funding offered under the instrument.
The instrument also acted as a catalyst in a positive sense by triggering additional measures.
However, the auditors concluded that the contractual obligation to inform the final beneficiaries of the financing from the European Investment Bank (EIB) or from the Investment Facility is not always fulfilled, and that technical assistance is not always targeted at small and medium-sized enterprises.
They have made recommendations to address these problems.
The ACP Investment Facility established in 2003 receives its capital from the European Development Fund and is managed by the EIB.
Over the last ten years, projects worth €5.7 billion have been approved under the Facility.
The facility provides funding in the medium to long term and aims to achieve sustainable economic, social and environmental benefits. • The promotion of renewable energy in Eastern Africa under the ACP-EU Energy Facility (No 15/2015) in this special report examines whether the Commission has successfully used the Energy Facility to improve access to renewable energy in Eastern Africa to the poor.
The audit has shown that some significant results have been achieved, but even better monitoring of the instrument is needed.
Although the Commission has made a good choice between the projects proposed, it has not monitored sufficiently sufficiently the progress made in the implementation of the project.
The project managers' reports were different in quality and the Commission did not make any efforts to enforce compliance with the reporting requirements.
In the case of projects known to be facing serious problems, the Commission officials have carried out insufficient visits and on-the-spot inspections as part of the monitoring to supplement the information provided by the administrators.
The report sets out recommendations for stricter choice, stricter monitoring, and improvement of the sustainability of future projects.
By mid-2014 a total of EUR 268 million was allocated, of which EUR 106 million was allocated to projects in Eastern Africa, which was allocated to the lowest access to electricity in Africa.
Our actions 29 • Analysis of the risk of a performance-oriented approach to EU development and cooperation actions (No 21/2015) to issue a special report due to the growing interest in recent years to shift the priorities of EU development policy and cooperation from action to results.
The auditors have identified nine major risks: inconsistent terminology based on results or inconsistent chain of activities, products, impacts and impacts; increased complexity resulting from the inclusion of cross-cutting issues in EU programmes; lack of harmonisation of aid tools, impact frameworks and the structure of the partners' responsibility for development; weaknesses in evaluation and evaluation of results; lack of consolidated reports or review of results from EU assistance; lack of sufficient, relevant, reliable and up-to-date data; focus on budgetary results as a target; change of the context of the action.
The audit showed that these risk areas were correctly identified by the Commission in a number of different documents.
However, further action is needed to exploit the full potential of the Commission's initiatives and to improve the EU's development and cooperation performance.
A number of recommendations have therefore been made which the Commission should take into account.
Our actions 30 100 80 60 40 20 0 Financial and economic governance The objective of the EU economic governance framework is to address problematic financial and economic trends, such as excessive public deficits or public debt, which can undermine economic growth and undermine the sustainability of public finances.
Part of this framework is the creation of an EU Banking Union.
According to the 2014 report of the European Banking Authority, this special report was the second report to be submitted on this subject.
In 2008, Europe met with a financial crisis that has become a sovereign debt crisis.
The debt crisis was the result of various factors, including weak banking supervision, insufficient fiscal policy, and difficulties faced by large financial institutions (and the resulting costs of saving them by society).
The crisis broke out in two waves in the EU Member States: in 2008-2009 it first met with non-euro area countries and later spread to the euro area.
Our auditors examined how the European Commission managed financial assistance under the Balance of Payments Instrument and the European Financial Stabilisation Mechanism during the crisis, for which the Commission absorbed financial resources on the capital markets, and the EU budget was to be guaranteed.
The audit concerned financial assistance to Hungary, Latvia, Romania, Ireland and Portugal, with particular emphasis on the Commission's role in these programmes.
In addition, our auditors examined the Commission's cooperation with the European Central Bank (ECB) partners in Frankfurt and the International Monetary Fund (IMF) in Washington.
They have obtained evidence of the audit through detailed review and analysis of documents and consultation of Commission officials, national authorities, the ECB and the IMF.
These parties were not subject to control or to decisions taken at EU political level.
The audit showed that the European Commission was not prepared for the initial requests for financial assistance during the financial crisis in 2008, as the warning signals were not omitted, which explains, in the beginning, the significant shortcomings in their administrative processes.
The auditors identified four main areas of crisis management of the Commission: differentiated approaches, limited quality control, insufficient supervision and shortcomings in the documentation.
In some programmes, the conditions for granting the aid were less stringent and easier to comply with.
Furthermore, they claimed that the Commission's teams had not sufficiently verified the relevant documents that the calculations on which they were based had not been verified by anyone outside the team that they had not been sufficiently monitored by the experts and that they had not been sufficiently documented in the verification procedures.
However, our actions 31 Auditors believe that, despite the lack of experience, the Commission has managed to carry out its new administrative tasks and to launch grant programmes of relevance to the reform process, which, given the pressure of time, should be considered to be a success.
In addition, the auditors argued that, during the crisis, the Commission has increasingly developed internal knowledge and cooperated with a number of stakeholders in the countries concerned and that improved macro-economic surveillance has been introduced in the course of future reforms.
For example, the objectives of the programmes have been met, the adjusted deficit targets have been largely achieved, structural deficits have been improved and the Member States have largely met the conditions of their programmes, albeit with some delays.
In most cases, the countries continued the reforms under the programme, and in four out of five countries the current account adjustment was faster than expected.
Our auditors said that there are still a number of weaknesses and that the Commission has to improve the procedures for managing financial aid.
We have made a number of recommendations to the European Commission to ensure that financial assistance will be managed to a greater extent in the future when Member States in difficulty are asking for assistance.
The report was heard widely, especially in the European media, but also in the United States and Australia.
Like our other special reports, it is presented to the addressees in the European Parliament and the Council by our Baudilio Veneto Muguruza, responsible for the report.
Control team (left to right): Didier Lebrun, Ignacio García de Parada, Kristian Sniter, Josef Jindra, Giuseppe Diana, Baudilio São Thomas Muguruza, Adrian Savin, Daniela Hristova, Zacharias Kolias, Marco Fians and Daniel Costa de Magalhães.
Our actions 32 • EU supervision of credit rating agencies is based on solid grounds, but is not yet fully effective (No 22/2015) on the basis of a special report, it is examined whether the European Securities and Markets Authority (ESMA) (ESMA) is effective in the supervision of credit rating agencies in the EU.
The financial crisis in 2008 increased the focus on credit rating agencies and their impact on financial markets.
At that time, credit rating agencies in Europe were not fully regulated.
The audit concluded that although ESMA has developed good grounds, its principles and guidelines are not complete and that there are still serious risks.
The auditors concluded that ESMA could reduce the average duration of the registration procedure, but the procedure is still complex.
While rating methods should be rigorous, systematic, sustainable and subject to approval, ESMA's activities focus mainly on whether these methods are rigorous.
The current Eurosystem credit assessment framework does not guarantee the smooth functioning of all credit rating agencies registered with ESMA, which creates a two-stage market structure which puts small credit rating agencies at a disadvantage.
The auditors made certain recommendations to ESMA on the registration procedure, the traceability of the risk detection process, the surveillance process and the IT systems. • Technical assistance to Greece: Improving accessibility requires a greater focus of the results (No 19/2015) and in this special report analyses whether the task force on Greece has fulfilled its mandate and whether technical assistance to Greece has effectively contributed to the reform process.
The Task Force was set up by the Commission in 2011 in order to support the economic adjustment of Greece by means of a number of technical assistance measures.
The auditors checked whether the task force had fulfilled its mandate and whether technical assistance had effectively contributed to the reform.
They obtained evidence from the Commission, service providers, Greek ministries and other interested parties.
The audit showed that the Greek authorities had received technical assistance in accordance with the mandate, but that they had not always made sufficient progress in the reforms.
Due to the urgency of the situation, the Task Force was set up in a short time without a full analysis of the other options or within its own budget.
The Task Force did not have a complex, comprehensive strategic document to provide technical assistance or to set priorities.
This aid was appropriate and largely in line with the requirements of the programme, and the Task Force developed a flexible and diversified implementation system and was still weak at project level.
Greek parliament, Athens, Greece.
Our actions 33 Other 8,2% 100 80 60 40 20 0 VAT 12,8 % TEM 13,3% % GNI 65,7 % revenue The EU budget is financed mainly from revenue from three types of own resources.
These include own resources based on gross national income (GNI) and VAT and traditional own resources (SCI), in particular customs duties on products and sugar levies imported into the EU.
The EU also receives taxes on the remuneration of EU workers from third countries paid to certain EU programmes and fines from companies that violate EU rules and regulations.
Revenue must fully cover EU expenditure.
In 2015, revenue amounted to EUR 141.3 billion. • Combating intra-Community VAT fraud: further action is needed (No 24/2015) The report• examines whether the EU is effectively combating intra-Community VAT fraud.
As a result of organised crime, the European Union loses between EUR 40 billion and EUR 60 billion of VAT revenue each year.
Since exports of goods and services from one EU Member State to another are exempt from VAT, criminals in both countries can cheat in relation to taxation.
In this way, both the countries concerned and the EU lose their income.
The audit identified serious shortcomings indicating insufficient effectiveness of the current system.
The EU has many tools to combat VAT fraud within the EU, but some of them need to be improved or more consistent in application.
In most Member States that have visited, there are no effective cross-checks between customs and tax data; Member States' tax authorities exchange information on VAT; however, there are problems regarding the accuracy, completeness and timeliness of the data; there is no cooperation and there is no cooperation between administrative, judicial and judicial authorities between administrative and judicial authorities.
In order to improve the system, the Member States, the European Parliament and the European Commission must take action.

As part of the priority axis: Opinion on EFSI In response to the fall in investment in 2007 in November 2014, the Commission launched an offensive for Europe in the field of investment.
The Investment Plan is based on the logic of intervention on which there is a high demand for investment in Europe and on which many economically viable projects are based and on which there are sources of funding.
The challenge is to make effective use of savings and liquidity to promote sustainable employment and growth in Europe.
The Investment Plan will be implemented without burdening national budgets and new commitments.
From this investment plan to its full implementation, the Commission promises to create between 1 million and 1.3 million new jobs and to mobilise additional (mainly long-term) investment funds of at least EUR 315 billion between 2015 and 2017.
In order to contribute to the success of this initiative, in our opinion, we have drawn attention to the issues of governance and the legal framework, the principles of accountability and external audit, as well as financial commitments to public budgets.
We have also noted that for instruments where the EU works with the private sector, an adequate level of transparency and accountability with regard to public funds should be ensured.
In addition, the results of these instruments should be measured in terms of the extent to which the objectives of the actions financed are achieved.
We have noted that the proposal does not explicitly describe the agreements between the Commission and the European Investment Bank.
Our opinion has been taken into account by regulatory authorities in Regulation (EU) 2015/1017 on EFSI.

Our actions 36 Conference of the Court on the Future of Development Assistance On 20-21 October 2015 we organised an international conference in Luxembourg on post 2015 Development Assistance on the occasion of the European Year for Development, the adoption of the new UN Sustainable Development Goals and the Luxembourg Presidency.
At the beginning of the two-day conference chaired by our member, Danièle Lamarque, the President of our President, Vítor Caldeira, the Luxembourg Minister for Development Cooperation and Humanitarian Affairs, Romain Schneider, on behalf of the EU Presidency, the President of the European Parliament Development Committee, Linda McAvan, EU Commissioner for Development, Neven Mimica and UN Undersecretary-General Grete Faremo.
The conclusions of the conference were summarised by Marc Angel, President of the Committee on Foreign and European Affairs, and President of the Luxembourg Chamber of Deputies.
The EU is the largest donor of development aid in the world and cooperates with many public and private partners, including international organisations, foundations, NGOs and countries.
The effectiveness of aid is becoming increasingly important, which can be achieved by carefully respecting the criteria for the allocation and assessment of aid.
In this context, there is a great role for the court.
The new UN Sustainable Development Goals for 2015-2030 are more ambitious than the previous Millennium Development Goals and move the recipients to think and act differently.
Participants agreed that development aid must be adapted to environmental policy, energy policy and migration policy and to other policy areas, as well as to new stakeholders.
In addition, development agencies need to adapt to the increasing diversification of funding and financial instruments: innovative financial instruments contribute to increasing leverage and to the approximation of market conditions while making financial decisions and determining the added value of the aid difficult.
The European Commission has given a lecture on how a result-oriented budget is to look like, setting out clearly how EU funds are to be spent and how results are to be spent.
To this end, the Court also participates in the joint interinstitutional working group.

Our activities 39 Cooperation with the highest audit authorities The Court cooperates with the other highest audit authorities (ORKBs), mainly through the • Contact Committee with the ORKB of the EU Member States; • The ORKB network of candidate countries and potential candidate countries; • international audit organisations of public finances, in particular the International Organisation of Supreme Audit Authorities (INTOSAI) and its European regional group (EUROSAI).
The Contact Committee of the Supreme Audit Authorities of the EU Member States In accordance with the EU Treaty, the Court and the national audit authorities shall cooperate in a reliable manner in accordance with their independence.
Cooperation with the Steering Committee of the EU Member States shall be actively conducted within the Contact Committee, including within the framework of an annual meeting and of the various working groups, networks and task forces dealing with specific issues of common interest.
A Contact Committee meeting took place in Riga in 2015.
At the meeting, the members of the Contact Committee discussed the European Fund for Strategic Investments (EFSI), the prevention of irregularities and fraud, and the multiannual financial framework for the period 2014-2020.
The issues concerning the Single Supervisory Mechanism have also been addressed.
The Contact Commission has adopted a statement on the rules on accountability and financial control of the Single Supervisory Mechanism addressed to national parliaments and governments and to the EU institutions and bodies concerned.
In addition, the Contact Committee agreed to carry out parallel controls on the implementation of the Single Supervisory Mechanism and on the contribution of the Structural Funds to the Europe 2020 strategy and on the risks to the sustainability of public finances.
In November 2015, the Court was involved in the inaugural meeting of the Working Party on the Structural Funds VII in order to draw up a work plan for the new multilateral parallel control in order to determine to what extent EU financial support in the field of education and employment contributes effectively to the implementation of the Europe 2020 strategy.
The Network of the highest audit bodies of candidate countries and potential candidate countries Cooperation between the Court and the Surveillance Office of candidate countries and potential candidate countries is mainly carried out through a network1 which is comparable to the Contact Committee.
In 2015, we continued to support the network in carrying out a parallel energy efficiency control.
The last workshop devoted to this project took place in May 2015 at the Court's premises in Luxembourg.
The Court participates in the preparation of new projects to start in 2016 and which focus on audits and audits of accounts.
In May 2015, representatives of the Court took part in the celebration of the 90th anniversary of the establishment in Albania.
President Caldeira and President of the Republic of Albania Bujar Nishani met for this purpose.
Eight examiners from the network from OBRK took part in our internship program for 2015.
1 In January 2015, the network included six candidate countries (Albania, the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia, Iceland, Montenegro, Serbia and Turkey) and a potential candidate country (Bosnia and Herzegovina).
Since November 2013, Kosovo* has been participating in the network as an observer*. * The use of this name is without prejudice to positions on the status of Kosovo and is in line with United Nations Security Council Resolution 1244/99 and the opinion of the International Court of Justice on the Kosovo Declaration of Independence.
Our 40 multilateral activities (INTOSAI EUROSAI) and bilateral cooperation In 2015, we continued to actively participate and participate in INOSAI and EUROSAI activities, in particular in their bodies.
In November, starting with the International Congress of Supreme Audit Authorities (INCOSAI) at the end of 2016, at the end of 2016, the Court was appointed Vice-President of the INTOSAI Technical Standards Committee.
In addition, we have heard the request of the ORB of Ukraine, which chair the working group on the assessment of civil protection assistance assistance, to take part in the first meeting of this working group.
The Court is also an active member of the EUROSAI Task Force on Control and Ethics. Ethics which wishes to promote ethical behaviour and integrity in the ORKB and public institutions.
The main objective of the Task Force is to create and strengthen a framework to support ethical behaviour by creating and strengthening appropriate practical guidelines and tools to support day-to-day control.
We took part in the fifth joint EUROSAI-ARABOSAI conference on the supervision of state aid plans and the second Young-EUROSAI conference, attended by young auditors who took part in the discussion on current issues.
We also visited the World Leader Forum, the main theme of which was the role of public sector auditors in 2030.
The Court maintains good bilateral relations with other research and innovation committees.
For example, in 2015 our delegation participated in an international seminar organized by ORKB Poland for auditors from Georgia, the Republic of Moldova and Ukraine in Warsaw.
Members of the delegation spoke with the ORKB of the Czech Republic, Estonia, Hungary, Latvia, Lithuania and Slovakia about their experience of developing and building the capacity to join the EU, and organised training on our methods of verifying compliance with the law and compliance with the law.
Cooperation with the ORKB in the framework of international peer reviews (expert evaluation) is a customary way of promoting good practices and promoting quality assurance.
The Werkzeuge Peer Reviews Sub-Committee presents INTOSAI updates of the ISSAI 5600 peer review guide (ISSAI refers to international standards for the highest control authorities).
In 2015, we made a decisive contribution to the review of this guide, which will be adopted by the INCOSAI Congress in 2016.
We have also taken up the leading role in international peer reviews of the ORKB of Latvia, Spain and Switzerland.
The technical evaluation of the ORKB of Latvia was very comprehensive and covered the methods and procedures for auditing the financial statements and for checking compliance and efficiency and the effectiveness of the support functions.
The technical evaluation of the Spanish ORKB, led by the Portuguese ORKB, also covered many aspects of the functioning of the Spanish ORKB.
During the specialized evaluation of the 'ORKB Switzerland' we were the only observers.
The evaluation assessed the relevance of the strategy and the planning and quality control processes.
Our management 41 The College of the Court of Justice of the Court belongs to one member from each Member State.
Members shall be appointed by the Council after consulting the European Parliament for a period of six years, as proposed by each Member State.
In accordance with the Treaty, the members shall carry out their tasks in the full independence and in the general interest of the European Union.
The chairman shall be elected from among their members for a period of three years.
The term of office of the Chairperson and of the Members shall be renewable.
The majority of members belong to one of the five chambers which adopt audit reports, opinions and opinions, and take decisions on strategic and administrative matters.
In addition, each member shall be responsible for his or her own tasks mainly in the field of audit.
The member, assisted by his office, shall coordinate the relevant teams of auditors.
It shall then adopt the presentation of reports, opinions or opinions to be adopted by the Chamber and/or the entire College of the Court and then by Parliament, the Council and other relevant addressees, including the media.
In selected cases and at the initiative of the members, the report may also be submitted to the authorities of the Member States concerned.
One member took part in institutional relations in Ville Itälä.
In 2015, at the request of a Member State and after consulting the European Parliament, the Council of the European Union appointed Bettina Jakobsen (Denmark) as a member of the Court.
This Decision shall apply from 1 September 2015 until 28 February 2018, i.e. for the remainder of the current term of office of the previous Danish member of Henrik Otbo, who died suddenly in February 2015.

Our main objective is to achieve this objective in the following graph: many initiatives in the Strategy have already been implemented.

Our management 45 Flexible response in a rapidly changing environment We have developed a new work planning process that will allow us to plan our work based on priorities and a comprehensive risk assessment throughout the Court.
We are now systematically taking into account the views of the addressees in the planning of our work to ensure that our reports are as appropriate as possible.
With the support of our Member responsible for institutional relations, our President and Members cooperate with EU citizens, including the European Parliament's committees.
Flexible provision of resources for the implementation of priority control tasks We have organised our staff in flexible teams around specific tasks, not in departments, to facilitate the allocation of priority tasks.
This means that now we can use the funds to use the right person for the right job and thus make full use of their skills and potential.
The reform also led to better governance of the Court: the heads of departments have become management managers who share management tasks under the direction of the manager and who are also making efforts to acquire quality and supervision expertise.
We also strengthen our expertise in control and introduce knowledge transfer tools in order to further improve our knowledge management processes.
Product delivery speed We have simplified our control procedures and simplified task management so that we can deliver our products in a short time.
In recent years, we have shortened the average time needed to prepare our special reports and the reform will allow for further shortening.
This is particularly important in the context of the entry into force of the new Financial Regulation.
Better communication about our role and our work We have amended our annual report so that it applies to the headings of the multiannual financial framework and so it is easier to use and clearer.
In the annual report we present a few years report on the main expenditure areas and the results.
In addition, we have strengthened the communication and relations functions with the addressees and we have hired one spokesperson.
Our management 46 Performance measurement Since 2008 we have used key performance indicators (ZLIs) to inform management about progress in achieving our goals, to support decision-making and to inform our addressees about results.
They reflect our priorities and define our results and accountability as a professional examination body.
Indicators measure the basic parameters of the quality and impact of our work, with particular emphasis on the position of the main addressees and the effectiveness and effectiveness of the use of resources.
In this context, the Commission considers that the Commission considers that the measure which constitutes State aid constitutes State aid within the meaning of Article 107 (1) of the Treaty, in particular within the meaning of Article 107 (1) of the TFEU, since the measure constitutes State aid within the meaning of Article 107 (1) of the Treaty, since State aid may affect trade between Member States within the meaning of Article 107 (1) of the TFEU within the meaning of Article 107 (1) of the TFEU.

The answers show that 90% of our main addressees assess the value of our reports as suitable for their work (compared with 94% in 2014). 92% say that our work is working (91% in 2014).

Follow-up to the recommendations We contribute primarily to improving the EU's financial management by making recommendations to the Commission and other actors in our reports.
Some recommendations can be quickly implemented while others require more time due to their complexity.
We regularly review the extent to which our recommendations have been implemented by the audited entities.
By the end of 2015, 73% of the more than 600 recommendations we made in 2012-2015 were implemented.
This represents an increase compared to the implementation rate of 69 % in 2014 in relation to the recommendations adopted in 2011-2014.

Our management 49 Drafting special reports In order for our special reports to have effect, they must be submitted in due course.
In recent years, we have managed to reduce the time needed for checks, mainly on the basis of initiatives stemming from the 2013-2017 strategy.
In 2015, we prepared 25 special reports over an average period of 17 months (19 months in 2014), i.e. for the first time in less than 18 months.
We will continue to seek to reduce the time needed to prepare our special reports, in particular in response to the new principle introduced by the amended Financial Regulation.
Vocational training In accordance with guidelines published by the International Federation of Accountants (IFAC) we try to provide each auditor with an average of 40 hours (five days) of vocational training (except language courses).
The target level of professional training for controllers has been exceeded again, which shows how important we attach to the development of human resources.
In 2015, taking into account language courses, one examiner represented an average of 9.4 days of training.

Support for 50 control activities Human resources Human resources Allocation In 2015 we continued to reduce employment by 1 % per year, as referred to in the Interinstitutional Agreement on budgetary discipline and sound financial management of December 2013, for a period of five years (2013-2017).
As a result, in 2015 the number of employees decreased from 882 temporary officials and temporary staff to 872 (excluding members, contract staff, seconded national experts and trainees).
The staff of the controller consisted of 562 staff, including 113 staff in the members' office.
The employment of the Court's staff has a broad academic and professional context and the quality of its work and its involvement are reflected in the Court's findings.
Our employment policy is in line with the general principles and conditions of employment of the EU institutions, the staff of which consists of both officials and temporary staff.
In 2015, we employed 63 people: 30 officials, 17 temporary staff, 11 contract staff, four seconded national experts and one consultant.
In addition, we have provided 74 graduates with traineeships for a period of between three and five months.
On 31 December 2015, only 15 posts were not occupied by the Court (1.7% of the total number of posts).

Support services Vocational training The controller profession requires continuous training to keep up with professional development and acquire new skills.
In 2015, our employees completed an average of 7.3 days of vocational training.
The participation of language courses in the total number of training days continues to decline.
Language courses accounted for 35% of the total number of training days in 2015 (compared with 43% in 2014).
Our main vocational training activities include the modernisation of our training programmes and closer cooperation with and beyond training offers in EU institutions and institutions.
We have ordered cooperation with the University of Lorraine in Nancy, France, in order to offer postgraduate studies to public and political and political organisations in the field of public research and master's studies in public organisations in the field of management.
Cooperation with the European Commission continued, which offers language courses for our staff and with the European School of Administration which supported us in organising training courses on personal skills in the field of skills in the field of training (soft skills) and ECA training day.
In addition, we have increased our offer of courses thanks to tailor-made e-learning courses and training in integrated learning.
In addition, we continued our successful series of presentations organised by internal and external experts on the development of research and other issues related to the work of our auditors.
Finally, we have introduced a framework for the awards of the cjonalizPerformance Recognition Awards in order to highlight the robots who do not work in managerial positions, with special trainings outside the Court.
Support for control activities 54 Translation Translation is one of the control support activities that allows us to fulfil our mission and achieve our communication objectives.
In 2015, the total volume of translations was as high as ever: almost 200,000 pages, almost 3 % increase compared to 2014.
About 99% of translations were completed on time.
In addition to normal translation work, our translators provided language and translation support during 26 EU-wide check-ups during internal events and meetings.
They also supported the preparation of preliminary comments and special reports and were thus more involved in the Court's central audit procedures.
In 2015, the Translation Directorate was optimised by creating a pool of assistants as a result of a review of the Court's translation and reform process.
The large project of the GroupShare Directorates will lead to significant improvements by further improving the functioning of the assistant teams to create space for improving efficiency and automation, thus improving the procedures of all language teams.
Information Technologies In 2015, the Directorate for Information Technologies focused its efforts on adapting our administrative information systems to cope with the successful reform of the Court and on preparing for the development of knowledge management to support the new organisational structure of the Court.
In addition, all functions of the full Assist audit documentation system2 have been put in place with regard to the statement of assurance, economic control and related reports, and the major project has therefore been completed.
Our new audit management system (AMS) has been launched: more than 300 plans have been created in the system and 180 audit tasks have been created and monitored by this instrument.
Based on the technical basis of the mobility introduced in recent years (the provision of the WLAN in all areas of the Court, the equipment of all laptop workers), the Directorate is currently focusing on global mobility, i.e. access to all content anywhere, at any time, and on all devices.
The project to develop a solution to ensure that workers have access to our information on all devices will help to maintain the functioning of the Court and to increase its effectiveness and effectiveness.
The maintenance of operational activities during the development and delivery of IT solutions was provided and the critical systems were 99.82% available.
Support for control activities 55 Management and infrastructure The task of the Directorate for Finance and Support Services is to provide adequate resources, services and infrastructure to enable the Court to fulfil its mission and fulfil its strategic objectives.
The Directorate shall also ensure that the necessary internal control, internal control, accounting mechanisms are available to support all the Court's activities.
In 2015, the Directorate continued to focus on making its activities more efficient and efficient.
Due to the exceptional situation following the terrorist attacks in Paris in November and the crisis situation in Belgium in November, we stepped up our security measures and acquired the necessary security measures in public procurement procedures.
Information on public procurement is available on our website (eca.europa.eu).
The Farm Building currently has three buildings: K1: K2: K2: and K3: and it rents small space for the IT center for data reconstruction and conference room.
The European Parliament also rents three offices in Brussels and one office in Strasbourg.
To ensure the cost-effectiveness of our building policy, we take into account three factors: purchasing, renting, additional costs and interinstitutional cooperation.
As in all areas of our business, in the development and implementation of our building policy, we try, as in all areas of our business, to establish and comply with the highest standards of transparency and accountability.
The Community Environment Management and Audit System (EMAS) The Community Environmental Management and Audit System (EMAS) is an instrument for the management of businesses and other organisations developed by the European Commission to assess, report and improve their environmental performance.
In 2014, we started developing an environmental management system2 which complies with the principles set out in the European EMAS standard provided for in the 2009 Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council.3.
Our goal is to certify EMAS by the end of 2016.
In 2015, the EMAS project made the planned progress.
In July 2013, the EMAS project was launched at the Court.

Supporting control measures 58 The Court, like other EU institutions, is subject to a discharge procedure.
In April 2015, the European Parliament granted our Secretary-General discharge in respect of the implementation of our budget for the financial year 2013, which means that our 2013 annual accounts were finally approved.
We have looked closely at the problems raised during the discharge procedure with regard to our responsibility for audit and management and have taken appropriate action in the framework of our reform.
We have told the European Parliament about our follow-up.
Internal audit and external audit The internal audit department shall provide advice to the Court on risk control by issuing opinions on the quality of internal management and control systems and recommendations on improving the management of our operations and the promotion of sound financial management.
In addition, the services support the work of the external auditor, the task of which is to certify the Court's annual accounts.
Finally, the Internal Audit Department shall provide information on the relevant risks and corporate governance issues.
The internal audit department will be supervised by an Internal Audit Committee composed of three members of the Court and an external expert.
The Committee shall regularly monitor progress in the implementation of the various tasks set out in the work programme of the Internal Implementation Division in the work programme.
The Committee shall also ensure the independence of the internal audit department.
In 2015, the Inner Review Service gegenstandslos prepared specific reports on strategic issues such as the changes in our annual report, the mid-term review of the implementation of our strategy for 2013-2017, as well as the review of the implementation of the recommendations under the peer review procedure and the European Parliament.
Taking into account the recommendations of the Department of Internal Audit of 2014, according to which the internal control cycle should be strengthened, we have updated our IT security system and formalised the existing risk management framework and existing guidelines.
The Tatsächlich Internal Audit Office monitored the implementation of the new guidelines and ensured that their recommendations were taken into account.
Every year we report to the European Parliament and the Council on the results of the internal audit.
External audit of the Court Our financial statements are audited by an independent auditor.
This is an important aspect of the Court's approach to applying the same principles of transparency and accountability as they apply to the entities to which the Court is investigating.
The auditor's report on any PricewaterhouseCoopers S.à r.l. on our financial statements for the financial year 2014 was published on 15 September 2015.
Therefore, in accordance with our beliefs, the annual accounts provide a true and reliable view of the financial position of the European Court of Auditors as at 31 December 2014, the financial position and cash flows for the year ending on that date, in accordance with Regulation (EU, Euratom) No 966/2012 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 25 October 2012 on the Financial Regulation applicable to the general budget of the Union and Commission Delegated Regulation (EU) No 1268/2012 of 29 October 2012 on the rules for the application of the Financial Regulation. As regards the use of resources and the control procedures, our actions, as described in this report and as these actions have not been taken in relation to our fundamentals.
Declaration by 60 of the authorising officer by delegation I, the undersigned Secretary-General of the European Court of Auditors, hereby declare that, as authorising officer by delegation, the information contained in this report is correct and accurate and • I confirm with sufficient assurance that the appropriations for the activities described in this report have been used for the intended purposes and in accordance with the principles of sound financial management, the costs and benefits of the checks established are justified in order to ensure the legality and regularity of the underlying transactions and the correct management of the allegations of fraud and suspected fraud.
This security shall be based on the assessment given by the undersigned and the information available to him, such as the reports and statements of the authorising officers by subdelegated officers, the internal auditor's reports and the independent auditor's reports from previous financial years.
