The European Court of Auditors 02 Court of Auditors The European Court of Auditors (ECA) is an external auditor of the EU and one of the seven institutions of the Union.
The College of the Court has 28 members, one of each EU Member State.
The Court employs around 900 employees of all EU countries employed by auditors and administrative staff.
It was built in 1977 and is based in Luxembourg.
The Court's tasks are to verify that the EU ensures sound financial management, that financial rules are properly complied with and that EU policies and programmes are used optimally.
Through its audit work, the Court contributes to improving the EU's financial management and to improving accountability and transparency.
It warns against threats, ensures security of control, points to shortcomings and successes, and provides guidance to policy makers and EU legislators.
The Court presents its observations and recommendations to the European Parliament, the Council of the EU, the national parliaments and the general public.
Building of the European Court of Auditors at the Placeau Kirchberga in Luxembourg, 2017

Preface of the President 04 Dear Reader, dear reader!
In 1977, the European Court of Auditors started its work 40 years later, bearing in mind many successful contributions to the EU's public responsibility and financial management.
In October 2017, an official ceremony attended by Her Majesty the Grand Duke and Grand Duke of Luxembourg, President of the Republic of Estonia, Kersti Kaljulaid, President of the European Parliament, Antonio Tajani and President of the European Commission Jean-Claude Juncker, took place on the occasion of the jubilee of the court.
Their participation in the event is to a large extent proof that the Court is a financial institution of the European Union.
However, during the course of the year, we also had to look forward.
In this way we discussed and agreed on a strategy for the remaining three years of the current multiannual financial framework by the end of 2020.
Our citizens need access to clear and reliable information so that they do not lose confidence in the EU and its bodies.
People need to see that the EU is acting honestly, upholding the rule of law, using public resources, aiming to achieve clear political goals and to achieve the goals it promised.
As an external auditor of the Union, we are well prepared to examine these aspects and to report on them.
We have issued special reports throughout the year on a wide range of EU policies and programmes and based on an analysis of publications, such as land analysis and rapid analysis.
We have also drawn up several opinions on legislative proposals and we have drawn up an annual report on the general budget of the EU and the European Development Fund, as well as on EU agencies and many other EU bodies.
This activity report provides a comprehensive overview of our activities in 2017 and provides important information on the Court, its budget and its staff.
Klaus-Heiner Lehne President

Our activities 06 Checks We carry out different types of controls in different areas of the EU budget: • Performance checks in different areas: in this respect the effectiveness, cost-effectiveness and cost-effectiveness of EU policies and programmes are analysed.
It focuses on specific management or budget issues that we choose on the basis of criteria such as the public interest, potential for improvement, the risk of insufficient efficiency or irregularities; • accounting audits and audits of compliance with the rules on financial liability, including the reliability and legality of the underlying transactions (in particular with regard to the statement of assurance) and the assessment of whether systems or transactions in specific budgetary areas comply with the rules and regulations.
Based on the evidence gathered during our audit work, our reports have made clear conclusions on the achievement of the EU policy objectives and on the situation of the Union's budgetary and financial management.
This information will help us to make appropriate recommendations in terms of cost-effectiveness.
Verification visits in 2017 Most of the audit work is carried out at the Court's premises in Luxembourg.
At the same time, in 2017, our auditors carried out numerous audit visits to other EU institutions, agencies, agencies and agencies and EU delegations, national, regional and local authorities in the Member States and international organisations, such as the United Nations, which participate in the allocation of EU funds.
We also carry out on-the-spot checks on beneficiaries of EU funds within and outside the European Union.
These controls provide direct evidence of controls from stakeholders involved in the management of EU policies and programmes and the collection and collection of EU funds and their payment.
Checks are our core activities The frequency and intensity of our control activities in individual Member States and beneficiary countries depend on the type of controls we have carried out.
In 2017, our auditors spent 3,670 days on on-the-spot checks in the Member States and outside the EU (2016: 4 246 days).
In the EU, on-the-spot checks are often carried out in conjunction with the highest control authorities in the Member States visited.

Our actions 08 Detecting fraud In the fight against fraud from the EU budget, we work closely with the European Anti-Fraud Office (OLAF).
Next, OLAF shall take further action to take a decision on a possible investigation and, where appropriate, cooperate with the authorities of the Member States.
In 2017, although our controls are not specifically designed to detect fraud, during our audit work from time to time we may encounter cases where we suspect irregularities or fraud.
In 2017, we handed over 13 such cases to OLAF (2016: 11 cases) where fraud was suspected. We suspected that fraud was committed as part of our audit activity as regards the assurance of the financial years 2016 and 2017 as well as the other audit tasks.
Publications Our publications: Special reports, annual reports, opinions and publications based on analysis Our reports and opinions constitute an important link in the EU reporting chain, because they are used to attract bodies responsible for EU financial management, in particular in the framework of the annual discharge procedure.
In shared management areas, national, regional and local authorities in the Member States play an important role, as in the case of agricultural and cohesion expenditure, and thus around 80% of the EU budget is being implemented.
Our range of publications includes: • specific reports showing the results of selected audits on specific policy areas or expenditure or budgetary or management issues; • annual reports containing mainly the results of audits on accounts and audits of compliance with the rules on the budget of the European Union and the European Development Fund, taking into account the issues related to the management of the budget and the results; • specific annual reports on the agencies, decentralised bodies and joint undertakings of the EU; • opinions on new or revised acts which have a significant impact on financial management, drawn up at the request of another institution or on the Court's own initiative;
Our activities 09 • Analysis-based publications: • Landscape analysis is a descriptive and analytical document on complex, broad policy areas or management-related issues, in which, often from a cross-cutting perspective, we present our experiences and knowledge on the subject selected; • Thematic analysis is similar as it is also a descriptive and analytical document on policy or management; • in the Rapid Case Reviews it presents and presents facts related to very specific topics or problems.
All publications are available on our website (eca.europa.eu).
In addition, all special reports, opinions and publications based on the 2017 analysis are at the end of this report.

Our actions 14 Annual report on the European Development Funds Financial support is provided under the European Development Fund (EDF) for the African, Caribbean and Pacific (ACP) countries and the overseas countries and territories.
The EFF is financed by the Member States and managed by the European Commission and by the European Investment Bank (EIB) for certain grants and outside the EU budget.
Around one third of the total number of errors in the EFF is due to non-compliance with public procurement rules.
Other significant types of errors concern, inter alia, expenditure which has not actually been incurred or which is not eligible for funding.
Our annual report on the EDF will be published together with our annual report on the implementation of the EU budget and is available on our website (eca.europa.eu).

Special reports In 2017, we published 28 special reports.
In these reports, we have examined in particular whether the objectives of selected EU policies and programmes have been achieved, whether the results have been achieved effectively and economically, whether the EU funds have added value.
We have also made recommendations on improving financial savings, better working methods, prevention of waste, or more cost-effective achievement of the intended policy objectives.
Special reports examine in particular the effectiveness, efficiency and efficiency of EU policies and programmes, focusing on issues of relevance to the EU, such as sustainable and environmentally friendly use of natural resources, economic growth and the promotion of social inclusion, migration and global development challenges, the internal market and the banking union, and ensuring the accountability and accountability of the European Union.
Here we will discuss two of these 28 special reports: a special report on food waste, which examines whether EU policy has been able to solve this problem throughout the food supply chain, as well as a special report on the Greek financial crisis which examines how the EU reacted as part of the economic adjustment programmes to the financial and debt crisis in one of its Member States.

Our actions 17 Special Report: Avert food waste: A chance for the EU to improve resource efficiency in the food supply chain is a global food waste problem that has been a global problem in recent years that is increasingly at the heart of public and political debate, in particular in view of the need to feed the growing world population.
Current estimates indicate that around one third of food produced for human consumption worldwide is wasted or lost, resulting in high economic and environmental costs.
EU auditors have examined the role that the EU can play in the fight against food waste The Court's auditors have in particular examined the actions taken so far and the way in which the various EU policy instruments can act in order to reduce food waste.
The priorities for combating food waste include prevention of food waste and facilitating food donation, as these two aspects are, first and foremost, in the fight against food waste.
Our auditors consulted the Commission's officials responsible for the policy, carried out documentary checks and carried out checks in five Member States: Italy (Lazio), the Netherlands, Portugal, Romania and Finland.
They visited the appropriate ministries and visited the place.
In addition, relevant stakeholders were consulted in the field of food production, retail trade, research and charitable organisations.
The approach so far is fragmented and inconsistent and coordination at Commission level is uncertain.
Our report sets out a number of unused opportunities and potential improvements which would require no new legislation or additional public funding, and the auditors recommended a better alignment of existing policies and a clear political objective of reducing food waste.
The report was submitted to the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety, the Committee on Budgetary Control, the Council of the EU and several national parliaments across the EU.
Both the European Parliament and the Council welcomed the report and adopted its conclusions.
The report also noted a significant echo in the media, in particular in social media.
Our actions 18 Special Report: The role of the Commission in the Greek financial crisis in Greece needed support to ensure financial stability After the financial crisis in 2008 there was an economic crisis in Europe and a debt crisis, which revealed the weaknesses of the Greek economy.
Greece was no longer able to finance itself in the financial markets in April 2010 and has therefore requested financial assistance from the euro area Member States and the International Monetary Fund (IMF).
Since then, Greece has been involved in three economic adjustment programmes managed by the European Commission, the European Central Bank and the IMF in the so-called "troika."
The third programme also involved the European Stability Mechanism (EMS).
The total support of EUR 368.6 billion was based on political conditions which were jointly defined by the Greek authorities and creditors.
These programmes aimed to stabilise Greece's economic situation by meeting the financial needs of the Greek economy, which was intended to prevent the crisis being transferred to the rest of the euro area.
In return, Greece committed itself to carrying out extensive structural reforms.
EU auditors have examined whether the Commission has properly managed the economic adjustment programmes, including a number of performance checks carried out by the Court in recent years, on the measures and reforms taken in response to the financial crisis in 2008.
Our auditors assessed how the Commission applied the first two programmes for Greece and how it developed the third programme.
They checked the documents on EU financial assistance programmes, examined the terms of the programmes and consulted the Commission staff, the staff of national authorities (such as specialised ministries), the Bank of Greece, the Bank, economic operators, the IMF staff, the European Stability Mechanism and the OECD..................effective adjustment programmes for Greece: despite shortcomings, progress in the reform process, etc.................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................
However, the programmes in Greece have achieved only limited regeneration.
The auditors also found that the Commission had no experience in managing such a process, that the conditions of the programmes had not been sufficiently high priority, had not been included in a broader strategy for Greece, and that the macroeconomic assumptions of the programmes had been extraordinary.
This special report has been submitted to the Committee on Budgetary Control of the European Parliament and to the institutional stakeholders in Greece.
This report was the subject of extensive media coverage and reached the biggest media echo of all the special reports that we published in 2017.

Our management of the 26 College of Members of the Court The term of office of Members of the Court lasts six years and is renewable.
Members shall carry out their activities in the full independence in the general interest of the EU.
They swear before the Court of Justice of the European Union that they swear by swearing by that position.
The College shall have 28 members, one from each Member State.
Individual members shall be appointed by the Council of the EU after consulting the European Parliament in accordance with the proposals of the national government.
In 2017, the Council appointed two new members: • Juhan Parts (Estonia), who took office on 1 January 2017; • Ildikó Gáll-Pelcz (Hungary), who took office on 1 September 2017.
The Chairpersons shall elect a Chairperson from among themselves for a period of three years and may elect again.

In addition to other duties, the President shall monitor and represent the Court outside.
In September 2016, Klaus-Heiner Lehne (Germany) was elected President.
The Audit Chambers and Committees The members belong to one of the five Audit Chambers of the Court, which adopt audit reports, opinions and other analytical publications.
The Chambers shall be managed by Doyen elected from among the members.
Each member shall be responsible for his or her specific inspection tasks.
Members shall be assisted by their office.
In December 2017, five examination chambers were managed by the following Doyens: Phil Wynn Owen (United Kingdom), Iliana Ivanova (Bulgaria), Karel Pinxten (Belgium), Baudilio Faroe Islands Muguruza (Spain) and Lazaros S. Lazarou (Cyprus).
Danièle Lamarque (France) chaired the Quality Control Committee.
Rimantas Šadžius (Lithuania) was responsible for coordinating the interinstitutional relations of the Court.
Decisions on broader strategic and administrative issues shall be taken by the Management Committee and, where appropriate, by the College of Members, the Chair of which shall be the Chair.
In 2017, the members of the Court of Auditors met at 21 college meetings.

Our governance 28 Strategy The next three years will be a very important time for the European Union to take key decisions.
We are aware that EU citizens need access to clear and reliable information so that the EU can effectively address the challenges that we are facing.
Citizens must see that the EU works honestly, respects the rule of law, acts cautiously, strives to achieve clear objectives and achieve the expected results.
As an EU external controller, we can contribute to this process.
Our strategy for 2018-2020: increasing trust through external financial control In July 2017, we published our strategy for 2018-2020 in which we set four strategic objectives: • pointing our addressees in a clear way, • focusing more on the performance aspects of the EU's activities; • Improving the added value of the statement of assurance; • focusing on our products across the organisation.
Finally, the EU is not about figures, but about people As part of external financial control, the Court can show what is working and what is not, it can help EU citizens to help them help them to answer the question of whether the EU institutions are working to help them to increase confidence in the EU.
In this context, the Court's audits must also take into account the concerns of European citizens, their most important addressees at the last instance.
The Strategy for 2018-2020 sets out five priority areas for the Court's activities in the coming years.
Sustainable management of natural resources and combating climate change Investments for cohesion, growth and integration Migration, security and sustainable development challenges in the world A functioning internal market and a stable monetary union Funding and management of the Union with respect for accountability and cost-effectiveness
Our governance 29 While developing our strategy, we attach great importance to internal and external consultations.
We discussed the strategy with our employees and addressed Members of the European Parliament, representatives of the EU Member States, the European Commission, other supreme audit authorities and stakeholders other than institutions, such as scientists, tankers, NGOs (NROs) and private sector auditors.
The Court's 2018-2020 strategy is available on our website (eca.europa.eu).
Work Planning In January 2017, we decided to introduce new work planning procedures, which we applied for the first time to our annual work programme for 2018, published in October last year.
Main changes to our work plan: • drawing up a list of audit tasks for the whole Court; • centralised procedure for the selection of audit ideas, possible audit tasks and final audit proposals; • more flexible allocation of resources and allocation of resources between each audit chamber, including the workload; • extending the scope of products to audit tasks including analytical publications; • defining audit tasks of a high priority for shorter deadlines.
In addition, we agreed with the conference of the chairmen of the European Parliament's committee on a procedure in which all the permanent committees of Parliament may propose to the Court a potential subject of scrutiny.
The Court's 2018 work programme is available on our website (eca.europa.eu).
Measurement of results In 2013-2017 we used seven key performance indicators (KPIs) to inform management of progress in achieving our goals, to support decision-making and to provide information to addressees about our achievements.
These indicators were used to measure the basic parameters concerning the quality and impact of our work, with particular emphasis on the views of the main recipients and the effectiveness and effectiveness of the use of resources.
A revised set of performance indicators will be introduced in 2018 and will apply for the period 2018-2020.
Quality and impact of our work We assessed the quality and impact of our reports on the basis of the evaluations of the addressees and evaluations carried out by experts and the next criterion of the evaluation was the follow-up of our recommendations to improve the EU's financial management.
Our management 30 Evaluation of the addressees We have asked the Committee on Budgetary Control and the Committee on Budgets of the European Parliament, the Committee on Budgets of the Council, the Commission and the European Agencies and the EU-ORKB Presidents to evaluate our reports.
As in previous years, the vast majority of respondents estimated that, in 2017, our reports were very sublime or very touching.
Each year independent external experts review the content and presentation of the sample of our reports in order to assess their quality.
In 2017, the auditors assessed six special reports* and the 2016 annual reports.
They assessed the quality of the various aspects of the reports on a four-stage scale from a large extent to a narrow one (1) to a narrow one from the most valuable one (4).
The results in recent years have changed slightly and the quality of our reports is assessed as satisfactory in 2017-2017. * In 2017-2017 the auditors assessed our special reports Nos 3/2017, No 4/2017, No 5/2017, No 10/2017, No 14/2017 and No 17/2017.

The audit period In 2017, an average of 14.6 months elapsed from the beginning of the audit task until the adoption of the special report.
This is the shortest processing time since the beginning of the period 2013-2017.
It took us less than 13 months to produce eight reports (29%) published during the year.
It took an average of 16 months to publish the reports and about two months less than in 2016.
This positive trend shows that measures to achieve the 13-month objective set out in the Financial Regulation are effective.

Vocational training As recommended by the International Accounting Association (IFAC), we are trying to provide each auditor with an average of 40 hours (five days) of vocational training per year.
In 2017, we again exceeded this goal by using 6,7 days of training for one controller.
Taking into account also the language courses necessary for the effective functioning of our auditors in all EU Member States, the controller in 2017 represented an average of 8.3 days of training.
For other employees, our goal is to provide an average of 16 hours (two days) of vocational training (without language courses).
This target was reached on an average of 2.3 days of training in 2017.

Our staff 34 Human Resources Allocation In 2017, we completed a staff reduction of 5 % over a five-year period (2013-2017), in accordance with the Interinstitutional Agreement of December 2013 on budgetary discipline and sound financial management.
At the end of 2017, 853 officials and temporary staff worked in the Court. 548 of them worked in the control chambers, including 118 staff in the members' office.
The employment of the Court's employees has a broad academic and professional context.
Our employment policy follows the general principles and conditions of employment of the EU institutions and promotes equal opportunities at all levels.
The staff shall consist of both officials and temporary staff.
General selection procedures are usually organised by the European Personnel Selection Office (EPSO).
In 2017, the Court had 72 staff: 29 officials, 13 temporary staff, 24 contract staff (of which seven had left the Court by the end of the year) and six seconded national experts.
In addition, we provided 71 graduates with traineeships for a period of between three and five months.

Our staff 35 Age profile The profile of active staff on 31 December 2017 indicates that almost half of our employees are 44 years of age or younger.
31 of the 68 Court's directors and managers (46%) are 55 years of age or older.
As a result, in the next five to ten years, these workers will retire and become senior managers.
A balanced relationship between men and women is being pursued by the Court by a policy of equal opportunities, which covers all stages of the career of its employees.
Overall, we have achieved a balanced share of men and women among our employees; 43% of our auditors and boards are women.
In recent years, we have managed to increase the participation of women in managerial positions in our examination chambers from 7% in 2015 to almost 20% in 2017.
We continue to fight to strike a balance between men and women at all levels of governance.
Our policy of equal opportunities for the years 2018-2020 also addresses issues related to age and disability.

Translation of the Directorate for Translation, Language Services and Publications of the Court has translated and improved more than 211 000 pages.

Information Technologies Our IT management contributes significantly to our audit processes by optimizing the flow of information through modern and secure technologies.
We have made further progress in document management and have fully digitised production, reception and publication processes.
We have introduced a simplified tool to facilitate remote access to mobile devices.
In addition, we have carried out an upgrade of the system (the installation of Windows 10 and SharePoint 2013).
To make even better use of interinstitutional synergies, we have introduced new audit management systems, business trips and training, which are currently being used by other EU institutions.
Support for control activities 38 Building The farm currently has three buildings (including K1objects, K2objects and K3w) and rents office buildings for the data restoration center in Luxembourg.
K1 K1 building, opened in 1988, has office rooms for up to 310 staff and conference rooms.
There are parking lots, technical devices, warehouses, libraries and main archives, while the entire top floor is used for technical devices.
The K1 building was modernised in 2008 in order to adapt it to national health, safety and environmental requirements.
The technology in the K1 building has been adjusted as far as possible in order to comply with the K2 and K3 buildings.
In this way, these three buildings constitute one integrated technical unit.
K2 K2 building was opened in 2003.
The missiles include parking lots, technical equipment, warehouses and a fitness centre.
The entire top floor is used for technical installations.
Other missiles are used in offices for as many as 241 staff, in which there are conference rooms, conference room with conference rooms, video conference room, café and dining room.
The Court has commissioned a study to assess the feasibility of setting up areas of work related to K2 and the modernisation of the technical installations.
The study shows that the structure of working areas could be improved and that some technical installations need to be modernised.
In 2018, a detailed examination of this project will be carried out and work will begin in 2019.
As the Council and the European Parliament approved in March 2014, the Court will use the remaining resources in the framework of the K3 construction project completed a few years ago to finance this modernisation.

Project for safety at work In 2017, the project for safety improvement continued as planned.

Environmental management As an institution of the European Union, we consider it our duty to respect the principle of sound environmental management in all activities, and we aim to continuously reduce the Court's environmental impact.
In 2017, we received an EMAS (Eco Management and Audit Scheme) certificate.
We successfully operate an EMAS-compliant environmental management system and fully meet the certification requirements set out in ISO 14001:2015.
Our goal is to systematically reduce CO2 emissions.
In 2017, in the third year in a row, we analysed greenhouse gas emissions resulting from our activities (i.e. our CO2 footprint).
The results of this study are available on our website (eca.europa.eu).
Liability 40 Court Financial Information The Court is financed by the general budget of the European Union and its budget falls within the scope of administrative expenditure.
In 2017, the Court's budget was around 141 million euro.
This represents less than 0,1% of the total EU expenditure or around 1.5% of the total EU administrative expenditure.
The budget share for 2017 was 98%.

Court's liability 42 Risk management In a year's time, in accordance with the provisions of the Financial Regulation, we have checked the risk assessments for each Directorate.
The results of these checks should be taken into account in the annual declaration by the authorising officer by delegation in the annual activity report and used for the risk assessment for the following year.
If necessary, we have prepared action plans for ex ante and ex post controls.
In September 2017, after carrying out these checks, we strengthened internal controls and financial procedures concerning travel costs and the management of service vehicles.
The internal audit and external audit of the internal audit service shall fully advise the Court on issues relating to risk management.
The Commission shall issue opinions on the quality of the internal management and control systems and shall report to the internal control committee of three members of the Court and to the external expert.
The Committee shall regularly monitor progress in the implementation of the various tasks set out in the annual work programme of the internal audit body in the implementation of its tasks and shall ensure its independence.
In 2017, the Agency examined the implementation of the Court's 2013-2017 strategy, the operational structure of the President's Service Directorate, as well as the management of licences and software products.
The Commission has also examined the implementation of risk management policies by the Court and has monitored the implementation of the recommendations in order to ensure that action plans are drawn up.
The internal auditor considers that in 2017, the existing procedures for the management, management and internal control of risks generally provide sufficient assurance of the achievement of the Court's objectives.
Every year we report to Parliament and the Council on the results of the internal audit.
External audit Our annual accounts are audited by an independent auditor.
This is an important aspect of the Court's approach to applying the same principles of transparency and accountability to the bodies they have audited.
The auditor's auditor's report was awarded to PricewaterhouseCoopers S.à r.l. on the Court's accounts for the financial year 2016 and was published on 31 October 2017.
The Court's discharge discharge, like the other EU institutions, is subject to the discharge procedure.
In April 2017, the European Parliament granted our Secretary-General discharge in respect of the implementation of our budget for the financial year 2015.
This means that our annual accounts were finally approved for 2015.
As every year, we have carefully analysed the issues raised during the discharge procedure with regard to our responsibility for audit and management, we have applied the appropriate measures and we have voted to the European Parliament for our successful actions.

The European Court of Auditors 4 The Court of Auditors is the external auditor of the European Union.
It was established in 1977 and is one of the seven EU institutions.
The Court is based in Luxembourg and employs around 900 employees from all EU countries, including controllers and employees of horizontal and administrative services.
The College of the Court shall be composed of one member of each EU Member State.
The Court's tasks shall verify that the EU ensures that its financial rules are properly applied and that its policies and programmes and programmes are consistent with the objectives and ensure that the funds are used optimally.
Together with the audit work, the Court contributes to improving the EU's financial management and to promoting accountability and transparency.
The Court makes its observations and recommendations to the European Parliament, the Council of the EU, national governments and national parliaments and the general public.
Preface of the President 5 Dear Reader, Dear Reader!
We have increased our efforts to assess the results of EU actions, to make our statements clear to the Court's addressees and to increase the value of our work for our stakeholders.
In this activity report we present a review of our work in 2018, in which we have so far published the largest number of special reports, analyses and opinions.
You will also find information about our employees, our management and our finances.
Our reports ensure an impartial evaluation of the Union's policies and programmes and the quality of the EU's financial management both within and outside the European Union.
We are checking whether EU spending is in line with the rules and whether EU policies and programmes ensure the optimal use of resources.
We will be pleased to work with the newly elected European Parliament and the new European Commission to further improve the EU's financial management and ensure results in the EU.
In this report, we express our determination to continue to adapt the organisation of the Court to "prepare us for the future" and to continue to support the developments in the control situation in the public sector.

Our 2018 strategy is the first year of our current strategy, which refers to the period up to and including 2020.
Our strategic objectives for this three-year period are: to increase the added value of the statement of assurance for the current EU financial management, to give greater emphasis to the performance aspects of the EU's activities, to give clear statements to our addressees.
Furthermore, we have agreed to make our organisation more focused on our products.
As regards the implementation of our strategy, we have agreed on an action plan for these objectives, to continue to be among the leading leaders in the development of the public sector.
All these measures were applied at the end of 2018.
At the same time, we have commissioned an independent peer review procedure to implement our strategy, which should end at the end of 2019.
Progress towards achieving our strategic objectives 7
In the focus of the communication activities of our products in the communication of clear communication information to our addressees, our strategic objective is to provide clear information to our addressees, including the EU's action bodies and the Member States responsible for the control and management of EU policies and programmes, for the other supreme control bodies, for businesses and industrial organisations, for researchers and, in particular, for the general public, in our focus.
In 2018, we learned how much the media are interested in our work.
In particular, our special reports have met with great media interest, and have been increasingly discussed in national and EU media channels, in particular in the section on media presence.
In 2018, we published 12 examinations forecasts (formerly referred to as "documents ") that serve as a source of information for people who are interested in specific policy areas or programmes that are audited.
The information provided therein shall be based on preparatory work prior to the commencement of the ongoing examination task.
The audit forecasts contributed to the stable and balanced results of the Court's publication throughout the year: 2018 was the first year in which there was not a single month without the publication of the European Court of Auditors.
In 2019 we will continue to publish such communication products. 8

Research More focus on results We carry out various types of controls in various areas of the EU budget: o Control of the implementation of the budget on the effectiveness, cost-effectiveness and cost-effectiveness of EU policies and programmes, which focus on specific governance and budget issues.
In the selection and organisation of such audit tasks, the Court shall take into account the risks of cost-effectiveness or compliance, the level of revenue or expenditure, and the political and public interest, accounting audits and compliance audits, taking into account the reliability of the annual accounts and the legality and regularity of the underlying financial operations, in particular as regards the reliability of the statement of assurance and the assessment of the compliance of the systems in certain areas of the budget.
Our random random procedures ensure the same probability of carrying out checks for each euro issued.
Our research focuses on issues that reflect issues relevant to the EU, such as sustainable and environmentally friendly use of natural resources, economic growth and social inclusion, the challenges of migration and global development, the internal market and the banking union, and ensuring the accountability and cost-effectiveness of the European Union.
On the basis of the evidence gathered in our audit work, our reports draw clear conclusions on the achievement of the EU policy objectives and the state of budgetary and financial management of the Union.
Our tests are in line with international public sector control rules.
The examination work consists of the following stages: 10
PLANNING Fixing the suitability and feasibility of the proposed study.
BEFORE THE FORM CONTROL COOPERATION Multi-disciplinary teams collect evidence of on-the-spot checks at the Commission's headquarters and in the Member States and beneficiary countries.

Adoption of the report by the Audit Chamber or by the entire College of the Court.
PUBLICITY Publication of a special report in 23 official languages together with the response of the audited entity.
Planning work The audit priorities are based on main EU issues Our work programme is adopted annually by the members of the Court.
In January 2018, President Lehne presented the work programme for the 2018 Conference of Commission Chairs of the European Parliament and asked all Parliament committees to propose potential topics for the review of the 2019 work programme in the framework of the annual stakeholder consultation.
12 In October 2018, we published the first work programme prepared in accordance with the new strategy. In this 2019 work programme we presented our audit priorities and 36 reports and analysis-based products, the publication of which is planned for this year.
These tasks included, at least in part, 29 of the 69 requests submitted by Parliament (42%) (2017: 32%).
Our research will continue to focus on important issues such as sustainable use of natural resources, economic growth and social inclusion, migration, security and global development, the single market and the EU's responsibility and cost-effectiveness to determine whether the EU will achieve what it has promised.
On-the-spot checks 3 761 days of audit work in and outside the EU Most of our examination work is carried out in the premises of the Court of Justice in Luxembourg.
At the same time, our auditors carry out numerous visits to the European Commission to the main body verified by the Court at the same time as the other EU institutions, agencies and bodies and EU delegations, national, regional and local authorities in the Member States, as well as international organisations and international agencies, in order to finance the EU.
In addition, in and outside the European Union, we carry out on-the-spot checks on the beneficiaries of EU funds.
Through these controls, we can understand the audit path and obtain direct audit evidence from the bodies involved in the management of Union policies and programmes and in the collection or payment of EU funds and from the relevant beneficiaries13.
The frequency and intensity of our control work in individual Member States and beneficiary countries depends on the type of controls we have carried out.
In 2018, our auditors spent 3,761 days (2017: 3,670 days) on on-the-spot checks in the Member States and outside the EU.
In the EU, our on-the-spot checks are often carried out in conjunction with the highest control authorities in the visited Member States.
In addition, our auditors spent 2 723 days (2017: 2 300 days) in the EU institutions in Brussels and Luxembourg, and in decentralised agencies and agencies across the EU, international organisations such as the United Nations, OECD and audit firms.
In order to obtain and approve exam evidence, we are increasingly using video conferencing and other information technologies, such as secure data exchange and documents 14.

Combating fraud to the detriment of the EU budget Nine suspected cases of fraud In the fight against fraud from the EU budget, we work closely with the European Anti-Fraud Office (OLAF).
OLAF will, if necessary, continue these cases by deciding on a possible investigation and by cooperating, if necessary, with the authorities of the Member States.
Although our controls are not specifically designed to detect fraud, we sometimes find cases where we suspect irregularities or cases of fraud.
In 2018, we handed over nine of these cases to OLAF (2017: 13 cases) where fraud was suspected.
For further information on the nature of the suspected fraud of OLAF and the related recovery as recommended by OLAF, see our annual reports on the EU general budget 16.
Publications New record: the highest number of publications in 2018 Our audit reports, analyses and opinions are an important part of the EU's liability chain.
They assist the European Parliament and the Council of the European Union in monitoring and verifying that the EU achieves its political objectives, and in particular in clearing the bodies responsible for EU financial management, in particular in the framework of the annual discharge procedure.
These are primarily the European Commission, but also other EU institutions and bodies.
National, regional and local authorities in the Member States also play an important role in the areas of shared management, where most of the EU budget is spent, including agriculture and cohesion.

Special reports Evaluation of the results of EU action in our Special Reports In line with the 2018-2020 strategy, we are increasingly focusing on assessing the results of EU action in order to ensure the optimal use of EU funds by EU citizens.
In 2018, 35 special reports (2017: 28 special reports) were published on the different areas of EU spending in which we discussed the challenges facing the EU, such as air pollution, the high-speed rail network, the refugee instrument in Turkey, the banking supervision and funding of non-governmental organisations (NROs).
In these special reports, we examine whether the objectives of selected EU policies and programmes have been achieved, whether the results have been achieved effectively and economically, whether the EU measures have provided added value, whether they have been achieved more than through action at national level.
In addition, we make recommendations on financial savings, better working methods, prevention of waste, or more cost-effective achievement of policy objectives.
Here we will discuss two special reports in 2018: a special report on high-speed railways in the EU and a special report on a refugee instrument in Turkey.
In accordance with the EU Financial Regulation, we are trying to prepare our special reports within 13 months 20.
COMPETITIVENESS FOR GROWTH AND JOBS FOR GROWTH AND GROWTH 21 Special reports: • JASPERS • Employee mobility • Project sustainability • Public-private partnership • Construction of broadband • Use of cohesion spending • Fast rail transport • Project effectiveness • Erasmus+ • Simplification under Horizon 2020 • Passenger and driver rights • Driving licences Special reports of the Court in 2018: • EU assistance to Myanmar/Birma • Pre-accession assistance to Turkey • EU assistance to the Sahel region • Africa.
Special report on the European high-speed rail network: not the reality but the inefficient high-speed rail plan brings many benefits to passengers.
It is a convenient, safe, flexible and ecological means of transport.
Improving the links between the regions in the EU enhances their competitiveness and contributes to European integration by bringing people closer together.
In this way we analyzed various connections, driving times and prices for business and private individuals.
We also examined whether co-financed investments on high-speed lines were cost-effective, effective, well-thought-out and planned.
The Court found that the European high-speed network is only an inefficient combination of high-speed rail lines from individual Member States that are not sufficiently interlinked.
There is no realistic long-term plan for connecting different parts of the existing EU network; high-speed lines crossing national borders are not the priorities of the Member States and the European Commission does not have the power to force the Member States to do so.
In such circumstances, the EU's financial contribution to the high-speed railways represents little added value.
However, we have one good news: the number of high-speed passengers in Europe is increasing steadily, and in 1990 the number of high-speed passengers increased from 15 billion passengers to 124 billion passengers in 2016.
Both institutions welcomed the report and agreed with our proposals.
We have also presented it to numerous national and national authorities, as well as to researchers, stakeholders and media.
Across the EU, the media, in particular EU-oriented media and financial media, in particular in Spain and Germany, have fully addressed this report.

Special Report The Programme for Refugees in Turkey: although helpful, the optimal use of the funds can only be achieved through the improvement of Turkey's situation, which affects almost 4 million people, is as large as in any other country in the world.
About 3.5 million of these refugees are Syrians, most of whom live outside refugee camps.
Support under the Refugee Instrument in Turkey, which the EU and its Member States have received for a total amount of EUR 6 billion, includes humanitarian actions and not humanitarian actions for refugees and host communities.
Under the political agreement, Turkey was committed to ending the illegal migration from Turkey to the EU.
Humanitarian projects could meet the basic needs of refugees, but in some cases the expected optimal use of the funds has not been achieved, nor has the objective of effective coordination of this support been achieved.
The humanitarian projects audited provided help to refugees.
For example, social security in emergency situations supported 1.3 million refugees by helping in cash.
However, for half of the projects, the expected effects in the greater half of the projects are higher in the greater extent of the effects that they are able to maintain, without further financial support, they are not expected to achieve, and for nine out of ten projects, nine out of ten projects of the next six projects on the day.
Due to the difficult working environment, the implementation of projects managed by NGOs was difficult in due time.
This was due to the Turkish authorities' refusal to grant the data of the potential beneficiaries of the two cash aid projects in our sample of a total of EUR 1.1 billion in the amount of its data.
We presented our report at a joint meeting attended by the Committee on Development, the Committee on Foreign Affairs and the Committee on Budgetary Control of the European Parliament and the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs.
It was also presented to the EU Council's enlargement and candidate countries and the press.
In particular, in Germany, this report was of great interest to the media, but also to Denmark, Austria, the Benelux countries and the Mediterranean countries, and to the EU-oriented media.

Annual Annual Report on the implementation of the EU budget for the financial year 2017 Annual Annual Report for the financial year 2017 Annual Report for the financial year 2017, Full Audit Opinion on revenue, Limited Audit Opinion on expenditure Every year we check the revenue and expenditure from the EU budget and check that the annual accounts are reliable and that the revenue and expenditure operations comply with the financial rules of the EU and the Member States.
In addition, we assess all relevant areas of the EU budget, we, in particular, on the basis of the headings of the Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF) for the period 2014-2020, providing information on budgetary and financial management and information on results.
We also examine why errors have occurred, we make recommendations for possible improvements, and we assess whether and to what extent our previous recommendations have been implemented.
As part of our last annual report on the EU budget for the financial year 2017, our auditors have examined a sample of some 700 payments worth a total of EUR 100 billion to beneficiaries in the various spending areas of the EU budget.
This means that we have analysed about 700 different cases where EU funds have been used to support key infrastructure projects, SMEs, research institutes, farmers and students in EU Member States or to support non-EU beneficiaries.

The downward trend in the estimated error rate continues in this extensive work as the basis for our statement of assurance to be presented to the European Parliament and the Council, in accordance with our mandate as set out in the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union.
As in previous years, the Court issued an unreserved opinion on the reliability of EU accounts and revenue.
In addition, in the second year in a row, we were able to deliver an opinion on EU spending to a limited (and not disappointed) extent.
A significant part of the expenditure audited in 2017 did not show a significant error rate.
In addition, the estimated error rate in payments in 2017 was 2,4% after the error rate in 2016 was 3,1 % and 3,8% in 2015.
The establishment of the discharge procedure by Parliament The publication of our annual report is at the beginning of the discharge procedure by the European Parliament, in which, on the Council's recommendation, the decision on whether the management of the EU budget by the Commission and other bodies is satisfactory.
On 4 October, we presented our annual report to the European Parliament's Committee on Budgetary Control at the same time as its publication and then the plenary session of the European Parliament and the Economic and Financial Affairs Council, as well as at the meeting of the national parliaments and the authorities of 14 Member States.
Mr Lehne, President of the European Court of Auditors and Mr Lazarou, Member of the Court, during the presentation of our annual report at the European Parliament plenary session in Strasbourg in November 2018 28
As regards cohesion expenditure, we have assessed the control and reliability framework for 2014-2020 and the reliability of the information provided by the Commission on regularity.
This was the first step towards the creation of a possible certificate of assurance as a test based test.
Overall, through a change of approach and a transition to a test-based audit, we intend to take better account of the different levels of internal control in the European Commission and the authorities of the Member States responsible for managing EU expenditure.
In this context, it is more clear where there are still shortcomings in both the European Commission and the Member States, which allows us to contribute to the promotion of accountability and further improvement of the EU's financial management.
This approach shall apply only if the relevant conditions set out in the international audit rules are met. 29

About We issued an opinion without reservation on the reliability of the accounts of all agencies; on unlimited opinions on the legality and regularity of the revenue underlying the annual accounts of all agencies; on the legality and regularity of the payments underlying the accounts of all agencies; on the legality and regularity of the accounts of all agencies; on the legality and regularity of the revenue underlying the accounts of all agencies; and on the legality and regularity of the payments underlying the accounts of all agencies; on the opinion on the legality and regularity of the accounts of all agencies; on the legality and regularity of the payments underlying the accounts of all agencies; on the legality and regularity of the accounts of all agencies; and on the legality and regularity of the payments underlying the accounts of all agencies; on the legality and regularity of the accounts of all agencies; on the legality and regularity of the payments underlying the accounts of all agencies, with the exception of the reservations on the reliability of the accounts of the accounts of all agencies; and on the reliability of the accounts of the accounts of all agencies; on the reliability of the accounts of the accounts of the accounts of all agencies; on the accounts of the accounts of the various problems identified.
The main requests for we confirmed the accounts of all EU Joint Undertakings for the financial year 2017 and confirmed their credibility. The Seven Joint Undertakings received the full opinion of the audit of revenue and payment transactions.The Joint Undertaking "The electronic components and systems of the leader of Europe" received a limited opinion from the audit, because the auditors detected problems which, in some cases, conflict with effective internal control.
Opinions also contribute to improving the EU's financial management by publishing opinions on the Commission's proposals for new or revised legislation.
Where such acts are acts having significant financial implications, the Court is required, in accordance with EU law, to deliver an opinion.
They are primarily used by the legislative body the European Parliament and the Council in their work.
Opinions may also be initiated at the request of other institutions or at the Court's own initiative.
In 2018 we issued 10 opinions In 2018 we issued the largest number of opinions on governance in the EU.
Firstly, they concerned mainly the Commission's legislative proposals on the new multiannual financial framework, such as the reform of the common agricultural policy (CAP), the effectiveness of the European Anti-Fraud Office (OLAF) and its cooperation with the future European Public Prosecutor's Office.
In its opinion on CAP reform, a greener and more coherent CAP is needed, which focuses more on accountability When the European Commission published its legislative proposal on the new CAP after 2020, it stressed that environmental and climate objectives would be given priority.
However, in our opinion on CAP reform, we have noted that many proposed policy options differ slightly from the current CAP system.
In particular, the majority of the budget will continue to constitute direct payments to farmers on the basis of the number of hectares of own or used.
We have also noted that this instrument is not the most cost-effective way of supporting appropriate income and that it does not take into account many environmental aspects.
In addition, the Commission's assessment of the CAP's contribution to the EU's climate targets appears unrealistic and the Court therefore recommends greener and more coherent plans for the next CAP, which should focus more on accountability. 34
In accordance with the procedure that we apply to our reports, this opinion has been submitted to the Commission of the European Parliament, in particular the Committee on Agriculture and the Committee on Budgetary Control, the Council, the environmental and agricultural stakeholders and the press. 35
Analysis-based publications: Landscape analysis, Rapid Case Reviews Analysis, Rapid Case Reviews A comprehensive analysis, and own analysis of the Landscape Court In 2018, we prepared two analyses of Landscape.
In the first instance, the Court took up the practical application of Union law and pointed out that the Commission's supervisory activities in the application of Union law by the Member States should be strengthened.
In the second analysis of the Leader programme, we dealt with mobility and transport and recognised them as the basis for European integration.
However, we have been concerned about the delays in investment, as investment in transport infrastructure will decrease, which slows down the modernisation of the transport network in the EU.
Thematic documents A total of six thematic documents were published in 2018: five on the Commission proposals for the future multiannual financial framework and one on the integration of migrants in the EU.
The Court's observations on the MFF focussed in particular on the proposed procedure for setting priorities for EU spending, the flexibility of the EU budget, the focus on the results and simplification of management, and on the principles of accountability and control.
We welcomed the Commission's efforts to modernise the EU budget for the period after 2020, but at the same time identified a number of potential threats, identified a number of weaknesses and proposed concrete improvements.
We stressed the need for effective parliamentary scrutiny, fair accountability and that the Court should in principle be designated as an external auditor for all bodies set up by the EU.
Rapid Case Reviews The only rapid analysis submitted in 2018 on cohesion concluded that VAT may be wrong and that it is not always the optimal use of EU funds.
We were of the opinion that the VAT refund to the public authorities should no longer be possible for expenditure co-financed by the EU for the period after 2020. 36
Conference on Financial Instruments In January 2018, in cooperation with the Ministry of Finance of the Republic of Lithuania, we organised a high-level joint conference on EU financial instruments in Vilnius.
The conference enabled experts from EU institutions and Lithuanian institutions, experts and other public and private stakeholders to exchange views and ideas.
Symposium on public funding of parliaments In March 2018, the Court organised a two-day international symposium on public funding of parliaments in Europe, the aim of which was to discuss their autonomy and to analyse the budgetary systems of the EU Member States.
Global Audit Leadership Forum Leadership In April 2018, we hosted the 5th meeting of Global Audit Leadership Forum, where the presidents and representatives of about twenty of the highest control bodies from around the world hosted.
In particular, the practice and reduction of performance control in the political context and the challenges and opportunities for the transmission of control reports in the digital age were discussed37.
38 The fifth meeting of the Leadership Audit Forum in April 2018, in which the European Court of Auditors met the presidents of the twenty highest audit bodies, the presidents of the European Day of Europe in May 2018 took part in European Day events in Brussels, Strasbourg and Luxembourg.
At information levels, our controllers were able to obtain information about our role and our work, as well as first-hand information on how controls are carried out.
We will continue to organise open days at the European Court of Auditors and participate in public events in order to contact the citizens.
Symposium on Good Public Administration In September 2018, we took part in the UN Symposium on Sustainable Development and Public Governance entitled "Good Public Administration and Benefits for Citizens "The Role of Parliamentary Control Bodies," organised by the Austrian Court of Auditors, the Secretariat of INTOSAI and the Austrian Public Prosecutor's Office.
The conference on the application of Union law In September 2018, we organised a conference on the application of Union law, during which we discussed the need for accountability, transparency and audit as part of our analysis of the implementation of Union law in practice.
This meeting took place at the Committee of the Regions building in Brussels.
Conference on e-commerce and related taxes In October 2018, we organised a conference on e-commerce and tax challenges in the digital age.
Speakers and panel participants discussed the risks associated with the current VAT model in e-commerce and proposed alternative tax models with the aim of using modern technologies such as Blockchain.
Conference of the European Insurance and Occupational Pensions Authority (EIOPA) In November 2018, we took part in the eighth annual Conference of EIOPA in Frankfurt.
Over 400 people from the financial services, science, consumer organisations, media, international organisations, EU institutions and national authorities met during the conference.
The Court presented its audit work on supervision and financial stability in the European insurance sector in 2018 on the specific report on EIOPA in 2018. 39

Our management of the College of Members of the Court The term of office of the Members of the Court is six years and is renewable.
The College shall be composed of one member of each Member State.
The Court shall not take part in the appointment and appointment of members.

The Audit Chamber and the Committees shall belong to one of the five Audit Chambers of the Court.
They shall be under the direction of Doyen or Doyenne, chosen from among the members.
Each member shall be responsible for his or her specific tasks and shall be assisted by his or her office.
The examination work shall be carried out by professional examiners working for the Directorates of the Examination Chambers.

Effects and perception of our work Our reports Sensitive and effective We assess the impact and perception of our work on the basis of the evaluations carried out by the addressees. Another criterion of evaluation is the follow-up to our recommendations on improving the EU's financial management.
At the beginning of 2018, we started to call on our stakeholders (the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission, the EU agencies, the permanent representations of Member States, the Member States' authorities, national supervisory authorities, non-governmental organisations, science, the media, etc.) to give an opinion on the validity and the expected impact of our reports.
The feedback shall cover selected special reports and analyses and the Court's annual reports and shall be collected by anonymous electronic surveys from all persons who have previously received a copy of those reports.
This study will also enable stakeholders to provide qualitative feedback on reports and provide general proposals on the Court's work.
A total of 87% of respondents confirmed that our reports were suitable for their work and 78% responded to them.

Support for control activities Vocational training Vocational training: in this way we will equip our employees and the Court for the future In line with the recommendations published by the International Federation of Accountants (IFAC) we try to provide each auditor with an average of 40 hours (five days) of professional training per year.
In 2018, we again exceeded this goal after 6.9 days of training per controller.
We have continued to expand the scope of the training that we offer to employees both inside and outside the scope, and we support controllers in obtaining different certificates.
We continued with a successful series of presentations organised by internal or external experts on the development of audit or other issues related to the work of our auditors.
We continued the "Performance Recognition Awards" programme, which allows employees who do not have managerial positions to take part in specialized external trainings.

Successful cooperation with educational institutions We have signed a partnership agreement with the European College (Brussels, Belgium), which provides for cooperation in several areas, including training, traineeships and reporting.

Information, work environment and innovation Our Directorate for Information, Labour and Innovation supports our employees in the efficient and efficient use of information technologies by supporting innovation and knowledge management.
Information Management We have launched a new initiative called tecaway, which enables our employees to access the network while travelling.
This enables them to access the Court's digital resources and services on all devices, anywhere and at any time.
The Court has created a new harmonised document management system and has introduced multi-functional printing, photocopying and scanning devices.
We expect these devices to have a beneficial impact on information security and paper consumption.
In addition, we have introduced a new model of cybersecurity management and are currently working on the implementation of the cybersecurity plan.
All IT projects and IT solutions took due account of the continuity of the operation, thus ensuring the full availability of critical systems.
Innovation We have also established ECAlab, an interdisciplinary innovation lab, which, through the use of data and the use of technology, focuses on digitisation of the scope of control.
ECAlab tests the use of technologies such as artificial intelligence, the use of natural language, intelligence as well as "natural language processing" and "text processing" in actual examination tasks.
This support has already been used in several tasks and publications.
In addition, we have carried out a pilot project on the use of Blockchain technology for a notarial notarial presentation of verification and publication documents.
The ECA register was thus chosen by the European Blockchain Partnership (European Blockchain Infrastructure) established by the European Blockchain Partnership (ECA registry) by the EU Member States and the Commission in the European Blockchain Infrastructure (EBlockchain) (EB) in order to provide services to be developed since 2019.

45 people from ORKB, EU institutions and universities took part in the summer course, which focused on the analysis of the data on the exams.

This conference was addressed mainly to participants from other EU institutions.

EuRH's main building "K1' and the new security control centre at Rue Alcide De Gasperi, Luxembourg Environmental management As an institution of the European Union, it is our duty to respect the principle of good environmental management in all activities.
We are therefore constantly trying to reduce the Court's environmental impact.
Currently, we successfully run an EMAS-compliant environmental management system and fully comply with the certification requirements set out in ISO 14001:2015.
As part of our goal of systematically reducing CO2 emissions, we are regularly investigating greenhouse gas emissions caused by our actions.
The total greenhouse gas emissions in 2017 amounted to 10 451 tonnes of carbon dioxide equivalent (tCO2e), representing a 3% reduction compared to 2016.
2018 was the fourth year in a row for which the Court examined its CO2 footprint.
67 Court audit Financial information The Court is financed by the general budget of the European Union and its budget falls within the scope of administrative expenditure.
In 2018, the Court's budget was around EUR 146 million.
This represents less than 0,1% of the total EU expenditure or around 1.5% of the total EU administrative expenditure.
The share in the 2018 budget was 96%.

Internal audit and external audit Internal audit body shall advise the Court on issues relating to risk management.
It provides an independent and objective guarantee and provides advice to increase and improve the added value of the Court's activities.
In addition, they shall report to the Internal Audit Committee, consisting of three members of the Court and an external expert.
The Committee shall regularly monitor progress in the various tasks set out in the annual work programme of the internal audit agency and shall ensure its independence.
In 2018, she carried out a review of the Court's cyber security systems and works related to its external protection.
The service also examined the implementation by the Court of the risk management policy and the annual declarations by the authorising officer by delegation.
In addition, it monitored the implementation of previous recommendations to ensure that the agreed action plans became a reality.
In 2018, the inspections carried out by the services did not reveal any shortcomings which, due to their nature or scope, could undermine the overall credibility of the internal control systems which have been introduced by the authorising officer by delegation to ensure the legality and regularity of the Court's financial operations.
Every year, we report to the European Parliament and the Council on the results of the internal audit.
External audit Our financial statements are audited by an independent auditor.
This is an important aspect of the Court's approach to applying the same principles of transparency and accountability as those applied to the entities he has carried out.
The annual report of the Court for the financial year 2017 was published on 17 May 2018. 70
