European Court of Auditors 5 Who are we about the European Union's external auditor; Who are we about the European Union's external auditor, created in 1975 by the Treaty of Brussels; the start of office in October 1977; the EU's full-value institution since the Maastricht Treaty of 1993; the head office in Luxembourg; the member from each EU Member State appointed by the Council after consulting the European Parliament; about 900 workers from all EU countries.
Our role in ensuring that the EU ensures proper financial management, that its financial rules are properly applied, that it achieves its objectives through its policies and programmes, and that it achieves the best use of resources. o We warn against the risks, we ensure the security of control, we point to weaknesses and successes, and we provide guidance to policy makers and EU legislators. o We present our comments and recommendations to the European Parliament, the Council, national governments and national parliaments, as well as to the general public.
2019 meant a number of changes for the Union: the European Parliament elections and the new European Commission joined the European Union.
The strategic priorities have been recast and important package measures have been launched, such as the European Green Agreement and the European Digital Future (early 2020).
At the end of the year it also appeared that we will now be the Union of the 27 Member States.
At the same time, the EU is at an important financial crossing.
We are very close to the conclusion of the negotiations on the next multiannual financial framework, the results of which will be crucial to the financial capacity of the Union over the next seven years.
All EU institutions must now build on their efforts to further improve EU financial management and ensure that the EU delivers results.
As an external auditor, we ensure an impartial evaluation of the Union's policies and programmes and the quality of the EU's financial management within and outside the Union.
We are checking whether EU expenditure is in line with the rules to ensure that EU policies and programmes ensure optimum use of resources.
This activity report provides a review of our work in 2019 in which we have published a wide range of recent special reports, analyses and opinions.
For more information about our employees, management and finance, please visit our website.
We hope that this information will be useful.
We are publishing this year's activity report at a time when public health in the EU and its Member States is unprecedented due to the COVID-19 pandemic.
Our institution responded quickly to this situation in accordance with the Luxembourg Government's health and safety instructions.
I would like to thank all my colleagues for their good work and their willingness to adapt flexibly to the current situation.
We must now work together to continue to play our role as an external EU controller in these difficult times.
Klaus-Heiner Lehne President 6
7 2019 at a glance
8 Our actions Strategy To continue to prepare the development of public financial control, we are based on multi-annual strategies to make long-term control choices and to promote organisational change initiatives to make continuous improvements.
At the end of 2019 we completed the second year of the current strategy for the years 2018-2020.
During this three-year period, we have set the following strategic objectives: increasing the added value of the statement of assurance; increasing the focus on the effectiveness of EU action; ensuring a clear position for the addressees.
In order to implement our strategy in practice, we have agreed on an action plan covering these objectives.
Over the last two years, we have made significant progress in achieving our strategic objectives.
A number of initiatives and projects have been launched for all planned areas, sometimes going beyond the objectives of the Action Plan, in particular the pilot phase of the test-based audit approach, with regard to the drafting of the Statement of Assurance, which has significantly contributed to the provision of useful information; the significant increase in the number of performance controls and analytical products and a number of different issues, which cover both EU spending and regulatory action; better contacts with the European Parliament and the visibility of traditional and social media.
During the year, a group of the four highest audit bodies (Estonia, the Netherlands, Denmark and the United States) peer reviewed our strategy.
The report of our colleagues was published in March 2020, just in time, in order to give a valuable impetus to our next strategy, starting in 2021.
Good progress in implementing our strategy 9
Monitoring the efficiency and regularity of EU activities Performance audits, audits and conformity audits Our performance audits take into account the efficiency, cost-effectiveness and cost-effectiveness of EU policies and programmes.
It focuses on issues that are relevant to the EU, such as sustainable and environmentally friendly use of natural resources, economic growth and social inclusion, the challenges of migration and global development, the internal market and the banking union, as well as ensuring the accountability and cost-effectiveness of the European Union.
These controls aim at helping the EU achieve its political objectives.
Our accounting and compliance audits lead to the statement of assurance of the accounts and the legality and regularity of the underlying transactions.
We may also carry out selected conformity audits to examine or assess the Union's budgetary and financial management, whether the management and control systems established for the collection and use of EU funds comply with EU and national legislation in force.
Our research is in line with international standards for public sector audit. 10
Work programme Strategic perspective In 2019 we continued to introduce a strategic perspective in our audit work in order to better address the main future challenges facing the EU through a forward-looking approach.
To this end, we have set up an advisory committee on strategies and perspectives.
One of the current tasks of this Committee, composed of five members, is to monitor the development of the post-2020 strategy.
The audit priorities for future EU issues Our work programme was published in October 2019 in which we will present our audit priorities for the coming years and 41 reports and analyses which will be published for 2020.
Our audits for 2020 and beyond will continue to provide independent reports to citizens and policy makers on issues relevant to the future of the EU.
We draw up a work programme for our exams in an independent way, but not in complete isolation from our surroundings.
It is therefore very important for us to cooperate with our institutional stakeholders, especially the European Parliament.
As usual, at the beginning of 2019 we asked all parliamentary committees to propose possible monitoring topics. 11
Exam work in the area The most important part of our examination work is done in our rooms in Luxembourg.
Our auditors also carry out a number of audit visits to the European Commission in the field of information on the field of education and education in the field of education and education, and in the field of education, education and training, and education and training in the field of education, training and training, education, education and training, training and training in the field of education and training, education and training in the field of education and training in the field of education and training in the field of education, education and the field of education, training, education and training, and the field of education, education and training in the arts and arts of the arts and arts.
In addition, we carry out on-the-spot checks within and outside the EU, among the beneficiaries of EU funds.
These audits will enable us to understand the audit trail and to obtain direct proof of control from the bodies involved in the management of Union policies and programmes and in the collection or payment of EU funds, as well as from the beneficiaries of such funds.
In line with the objectives set out in the EU Financial Regulation, within 13 months, we are seeking to complete selected controls 12.
3 605 days of field audit work in the EU and beyond Our audit teams typically consist of two to three auditors and the duration of the audit visit may be several days and several weeks.
In the EU, our on-the-spot checks are generally coordinated with the highest audit authorities of the Member States concerned.
13 The frequency and intensity of our audit work in the individual Member States and beneficiary countries depends on the type of audit we have carried out.
In 2019 our auditors spent 3 605 days (2018: 3 671 days) on on-the-spot checks in the Member States and outside the EU.
In addition, our auditors spent 2504 days (2018: 2 723 days) in the EU institutions in Brussels and Luxembourg, as well as in decentralised agencies and agencies across the EU, international organisations such as the United Nations and the OECD, as well as audit firms.
As part of our interaction with our research units, we are increasingly using video conferencing and other information technologies, such as secure data and documents exchange. 14
Audit reports, analyses and opinions Our audit reports, analyses and opinions are an important link in the EU's responsibility chain.
They shall assist the European Parliament and the Council in monitoring and monitoring the implementation of the EU policy objectives and in ensuring the accountability of the bodies responsible for EU financial management in particular in the framework of the annual discharge procedure.
Special reports and analysis products In line with our 2018-2020 strategy in recent years, we have focused more on assessing the results of EU action.
In 2019 we issued 36 special reports and studies on the many challenges facing the EU in the various areas of EU spending, such as food security, renewable energy, e-commerce, border control, budget management and the ethical framework of the selected EU institutions, to mention only a few. 15
16 In special reports, we examine whether the objectives of selected EU policies and programmes have been achieved, whether the results have been achieved effectively and economically, and whether EU action has brought added value, i.e. whether more has been achieved than only through action at national level.
In addition, we make recommendations on financial savings, better working methods, prevention of waste or better achievement of the policy objectives.
Our analyses often aim to provide analytical descriptions and analyses on the basis of previous studies and other publicly available information.
They can also help us to present our analysis of areas or issues that have not yet been analysed, or to present facts on specific issues or problems.
Unlike controls, they do not deal with either assessment or they do not guarantee credibility.
17 Sustainable use of natural resources Analysis 01/2019: EU response to the diesel scandal In 2015 diesel engines differed between the emission values of the test bench and the road exhaust emission values.
Studies have shown that so-called "cut-off devices" have been used that have resulted in lower emissions than in normal driving conditions during official tests.
The type-approval authorities of certain Member States responded to the pollution scandal by re-testing diesel vehicles.
Studies have shown that exhaust emissions from road transport, for almost all light vehicles used for diesel engines in emission classes Euro 5 and Euro 6, have in some cases significantly exceeded the NOx limit values, and in some cases more than 10-fold.
We have considered the measures taken by both the EU and the Member States in response to the diesel scandal.
We have also introduced changes in the exhaust emission measurement system after September 2015.
We have noted that many legal changes have been accelerated in the EU type-approval and vehicle emission testing system.
The Commission shall be empowered to check the work of the national type-approval authorities, may also carry out vehicle tests, withdraw or suspend type-approval.
In addition, the third parties concerned may now carry out emission tests.
The Commission has also opened infringement proceedings against certain Member States.
We have also noted that in several Member States there has been a greater willingness to reduce car traffic in order to improve air quality, and in several European cities low-carbon zones have been set up in which traffic is limited or prohibited.
We have presented the results of our work in the form of an analysis, because in the near future, legislative changes will have no tangible impact.
Our analysis doesn't make recommendations.
18 Investment for Cohesion, Growth and Integration Special Report No 08/2019: Wind and solar energy for electricity generation: in order to achieve the EU's objectives, considerable efforts are needed to generate electricity from non-renewable energy sources such as fossil fuels, non-renewable waste and nuclear fuels in conventional reactors, or renewable energy sources such as water, wind and solar energy, biomass, etc.
Renewable energy sources also serve the production of heat and cooling energy and the production of fuels for the transport sector.
Currently, 79% of all greenhouse gas emissions in the EU come from the use of fossil fuels for energy production.
Increasing the share of renewable energy in electricity generation will contribute to the EU's greenhouse gas reduction target.
Member States shall determine how they make best use of their energy resources and how they organise their energy supplies.
The EU can support Member States' actions through additional resources for investment in renewable energy projects.
We have assessed the progress made by the EU and the Member States in meeting the targets for the share of renewable energy sources in order to achieve the overall EU target of 20% by 2020 and 32% by 2030.
In Germany, Greece, Spain and Poland, we checked whether the support for wind and photovoltaic electricity production was effective.
We have noted that since 2005 significant progress has been made in the share of renewable energy sources in the energy mix, but this trend has slowed since 2014.
The share of renewable energy in electricity production in the EU increased from around 15% (in 2015) to around 31% (in 2017) and doubled.
Wind and solar energy are the technologies that have contributed the most to this growth.
However, achieving the targets will be a major challenge for around half of the Member States.
We recommended that the Commission encourage the Member States to continue to develop through auctions in order to grant additional capacity for renewable energy, by promoting greater involvement of citizens, by simplifying administrative procedures and by removing shortcomings in the networks.
We also recommended that the Commission review the legal requirements for the Member States in order to improve the timeliness of statistical data.
19 External policy, security and justice Special Report No 24/2019: Asylum, relocation and repatriation of migrants: time for action to eliminate disparities between objectives and results In 2015, the influx of migrants into the European Union has been unprecedented, followed by an increase in the number of asylum applications.
In recent years, the number of immigrants has returned to pre-crisis levels.
We interviewed European Commission staff, the European Asylum Support Office (EASO) and the European Border and Coast Guard Agency (hereinafter Frontex).
Monitoring visits were carried out with national authorities, international organisations and non-governmental organisations implementing EU-funded projects, and 20 EU support actions were carried out in Greece and Italy.
Both Member States are particularly affected by these migration flows.
We have assessed whether the objectives of EU-funded support have been achieved and whether asylum and return procedures have been achieved effectively and quickly.
We also checked whether the objectives and objectives for temporary and exceptional relocation systems were achieved.
We learned that the rates for registration and fingerprinting significantly improved in hotspot sites.
However, many migrants continue to move to other EU Member States and apply for asylum without storing fingerprints in the Eurodac database.
In addition, asylum procedures continue for a long time and a narrow throat in both Member States.
A large number of applicants were transferred to Italy (80% in Greece and 89% in Italy).
However, since February 2018, the Commission has not monitored the relocation process in the host countries.
As in other EU countries, return rates from Greece and Italy are low.
We recommended that the next Commission take appropriate action to improve the management of emergency aid.
In addition, the Commission should take advantage of the experience gained so far in developing future voluntary relocation mechanisms.
Finally, EASO's support for asylum procedures should be improved and Frontex's support for return operations should be adapted.
20 Market regulation and competitive economy Special Report No 10/2019: EU-wide stress tests for banks: the need for as much information on banks as possible, but greater coordination and concentration of risk The aim of the EU-wide stress test for banks is to assess the potential effects which could be stress on the financial situation and profitability of large European banks.
The European Banking Authority (EBA) in cooperation with the European Systemic Risk Board.
Stress tests have been carried out in the EU since 2011, in the case of all of them according to the bottom-up approach, with the banks providing the results of the shock scenario based on the methodology approved by EBA.
We assessed the implementation of the EU-wide stress test of banks within the framework of the mandate granted to EBA.
We noted that at the beginning of the procedure EBA did not specify the level of risk or the level of risk that it considered relevant for the stress test procedure.
The ESRB, which has developed a stress scenario, has, in turn, received a significant contribution from the ECB, the national central banks and the public authorities.
As a result, EBA had no control over the relevant stages of the procedure.
In the United States, the supervisory authorities are based on a top-down approach, giving them much more control over the performance of the banks.
On the other hand, EBA's role in the EU is limited to the launch of stress tests, the provision of methodology and coordination of stress tests to a broad extent.
The EBA stress test assessed the vulnerability of the system and banks to the economic downturn and not to the severe financial shocks affecting the system.
Although EBA sought wide coverage, some risk-bearing banks were excluded from the stress test.
The bottom-up approach of EBA has led to a limited credibility and comparability of the results of the banks.
We recommended that EBA strengthen control of the stress test and develop a top-down approach to complement the current bottom-up approach.
Furthermore, in order to achieve the objective of assessing resilience to adverse market developments, future stress tests should take due account of the risks posed by the EU financial system, provide a minimum level of stress and provide clear explanations of the resilience of banks.
In addition, the choice of banks for the stress test should be made not only on the basis of size but also on the basis of risk.
21 The Union's financing and management of Special Report No 14/2019: "Your opinion counts!"
The Commission's public consultation involves citizens, but there is a lack of transparency Within the framework of "better regulation', it is important to ensure that policy decisions are conducted in an open and transparent way, are based on the best facts available and are conducted by citizens and other stakeholders, such as civil society organisations and representative organisations in which civil society organisations are fully involved.
The Commission shall consult citizens and representative organisations in all areas of Union activity.
The Better Regulation Guidelines define consultation with stakeholders and define them as "stakeholders."
Consultation of interested parties of notifications and views of citizens and other interested parties shall be convened when the Commission prepares a policy initiative or an evaluation of ongoing interventions, in particular in the course of a public consultation.
On average, the Commission conducts more than 100 public consultations per year.
We assessed whether the Commission's public consultation effectively contributed to reaching out to the citizens and stakeholders and to making use of their contributions.
We have examined how the Commission has prepared and carried out the selection of the public consultation and how it has provided information on the consultation activities and how it has benefited from the consultation.
We reviewed the sample of 26 public consultations carried out by the Commission between 2016 and 2018 by the five Directorates-General and carried out an opinion study to determine to what extent the public consultation participants were actually satisfied.
We have noted that the Commission's public consultation framework has a high standard.
In addition, the Commission's attempt to consult the public has generally shown a positive balance and a generally satisfactory opinion of the participants.
The shortcomings were detected during information and information activities, for example, the full range of communication channels was not always used, there were no clear criteria to justify why the questionnaire was not available in all the official languages of the EU and some questionnaires were long and complex.
We recommended that public consultations be promoted to a greater extent and to a greater extent in order to increase visibility and increase the number of participants in the consultations.
We also encouraged the Commission to report better on the follow-up to the public consultation.
Finally, there is potential for greater participation of citizens in initiating legislative proposals in the framework of the European Citizens' Initiative.
Audit forecasts Audit forecasts provide information on current audit tasks (in the field of cost-effectiveness audit).
They shall be based on preparatory work carried out prior to the start of the checks and shall serve as a source of information for those interested in specific policy areas and/or programmes which are subject to ongoing checks.
In 2019 we published 18 exam forecasts (2018: 12).
Annual reports and special annual reports The annual reports mainly contain the results of our statement of assurance of the budget of the European Union and the European Development Fund (EDF).
The special annual reports include the results of our annual audit of the accounts of the agencies, decentralised agencies, EU Joint Undertakings and European Schools.
In addition, we publish a report on conditional obligations arising from the implementation of the Single Committee on Restructuring and Structured Restructuring and Structured Restructuring 22.
Annual report on the implementation of the EU budget for the financial year 2018 Each year we analyse EU revenue and expenditure to verify that the annual accounts are reliable and that the revenue and expenditure transactions underlying them comply with the relevant EU and Member State rules.
In addition, we are presenting specific evaluations on all important areas of the EU budget of the era on the basis of the seasons of the multiannual financial framework (sub-) for the period 2014-2020.
We also analyse the causes and locations of errors, make recommendations for improvement, and assess whether and to what extent our previous recommendations have been implemented.
Finally, we provide information on budgetary and financial management and information on results.
This extensive work is the basis of our statement of assurance, which we must present to the European Parliament and the Council in accordance with our mandates in the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union (TFEU).
EU general budget: opinion on the overall audit of the reliability of accounts and revenue; limited opinion on the audit of expenditure In 2018, EU expenditure amounted to EUR 156.7 billion, corresponding to 2.2% of the total expenditure of the EU Member State and 1% of the Union's gross national income.
Our auditors analysed a sample of 728 payments to beneficiaries in all spending areas in the EU budget on the basis of a population of around EUR 120 billion in the surveyed population.
This means that we have analysed various cases where EU funds have been used to support key infrastructure projects, SMEs, research institutions, farmers and students in EU Member States or to support non-EU beneficiaries.
For the financial year 2018, we issued an unreserved opinion on the reliability of the EU accounts and revenues.
In addition, in the third year in a row, we were able to present a limited opinion on EU expenditure 23.
About half of the expenditure audited shows no significant error rate, as in previous years, when we discovered that the errors in EU expenditure were not exhaustive and that the payments were legal and correct, except in the case of high-risk expenditure (mainly on the basis of reimbursement rules).
Overall, the Commission and the Member States maintained the error rate of 2.6% in relation to the progress in relation to the previous two years (financial year 2017: 2,4%; financial year 2016: 3,1%).
We find this an encouraging sign.
Venezuelan errors What does that mean? What does that mean?
A mistake or illegal payment is the amount of money that could not be paid out of the EU budget because it was not used in accordance with EU or national rules and therefore does not comply with the objectives set by the Council and Parliament by the relevant EU acts or does not conflict with the specific national rules in the Member States.
We evaluate the error rate using statistical methods and rely on measurable (i.e. measurable methods) errors measured on the basis of sample controls of transactions in the whole of the audited expenditure population.
In the financial year 2018, the area of economic, social and territorial cohesion was the most vulnerable to errors, the MFF errors (part) and economic, social and territorial cohesion, followed by "natural resources" and "competitiveness for growth and jobs." 25.
Annual report on the EDF: the opinion on the reliability of accounts and revenue: the opinion on full expenditure; the opinion on limited expenditure 26 of the European Development Fund (EDF) are the main instruments of EU development cooperation assistance.
The EDF aims to overcome poverty and promote sustainable development and the integration of the African, Caribbean and Pacific States and the overseas countries and territories into the world economy.
The EFF shall be financed by the Member States of the Union and managed by the European Commission and the European Investment Bank (EIB) outside the EU budget.
As in previous years, for the financial year 2018, we have issued a full opinion on the reliability of EDF accounts and revenue and on a limited opinion on EDF expenditure.
Special annual reports on EU agencies and joint enterprises EU agencies are separate entities with legal personality, set up to perform specific technical and scientific tasks and administrative tasks, thus contributing to the formulation and implementation of policies of the EU institutions.
There are 43 agencies in total.
Joint enterprises are EU public-private partnerships with industry, research groups and Member States, which play an important role in the implementation of certain aspects of EU research policy.
The European Commission is a member of the Public Sector Joint Undertaking and represents the EU.
In total, there are eight joint ventures.

For the financial year 2018 for all agencies (except the SRB) for all agencies for a total amount of EUR 4.2 billion, 20% more than in 2017 (3,5 billion) for a total amount of 2,9% of the EU budget for 2018 (2017: 2,7%).

Opinions Opinions: contributing to better regulation One way to strengthen the Commission's approach to better lawmaking is to publish an opinion on the Commission's proposals for new or revised legislation.
In the case of legislative proposals having a significant financial impact, the Court's opinions are required under EU law.
In addition, other institutions may ask us to give an opinion on specific issues.
Our opinions will be presented to the European Parliament and the Council.
In 2019 we published three opinions: on the proposal for a European Union Office for Intellectual Property, on the proposal for a Financial Regulation of the Single Committee for Restructuring and Structured Restructuring and Organized Intellectual Property and on the proposal for a Financial Regulation of the Community Plant Variety Office.
Our comments on the new Multiannual Financial Framework at the beginning of 2019 have also been published by the European Court of Auditors on the Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF) 2021-2027.
This summary focuses on the proposed procedure for setting EU spending priorities, flexibility of the EU budget, focus on results and simplification of governance, and on accountability and audit principles.
This analysis was mainly based on several opinions on the Commission's proposals that we issued in 2018, but also on the latest thematic documents and other reports on EU finances.
During the year, we achieved a relatively balanced number of publications, reaching a climax in October, when we had our annual reports.
31 32 Combating fraud at the expense of the EU's financial interests The Administrative Agreement signed with OLAF The European Anti-Fraud Office (OLAF) is the main leader in the fight against fraud against the EU's financial interests.
We have adopted detailed guidelines for managing the risk of fraud for our auditors.
We report to OLAF any suspicion of fraud or any other illegal activity to the detriment of the financial interests of the European Union which arise during our control work or which are reported to us.
These cases are then dealt with by OLAF, which takes a decision on a possible investigation and, if necessary, cooperates with the authorities of the Member States.
In 2019 we also signed an administrative agreement setting out the operational rules for our cooperation with OLAF, including the coordination of training, workshops and staff exchanges.
10 suspected fraud cases were addressed to OLAF We are the external auditors of the EU.
Our attempts are not specifically designed to detect fraud.
However, our auditors regularly identify a number of cases where they suspect fraud.
In 2019 we submitted 10 alleged frauds to OLAF (2018: nine cases) from which we paid attention to these cases during our inspections, as well as to two cases which were the result of third party observations.
Further information on the nature of suspected fraud and on its recovery, as recommended by OLAF, can be found in our annual report on the EU general budget.
In 2019 we also published two specific reports on the fight against fraud in EU expenditure: Special Report No 01/2019 on fight against fraud in EU expenditure: action needs to be taken and Special Report No 06/2019 on combating fraud in EU expenditure: Managing authorities need to step up detection, response and coordination.
33 Finally, we have dedicated a special edition of the ECA dedicated to the fight against fraud and corruption and the protection of the EU's financial interests.

The peer review of other EU-ORKB units The peer review shall be an external independent verification of one or more elements of the organisation and/or functioning of the OBRK by a team of colleges from at least one OBRK.
It is not an exam, but an opinion and advice from colleges, which are voluntary.
In 2019 the peer review team chaired by our secretary-general, together with the Committee for Banking Supervision of Poland and the United Kingdom, carried out peer review and peer review of the ORB of Lithuania.
The main objective was to determine whether the audit practice of the Lithuanian ORB was in line with international audit standards.
In December 2019 the final report was submitted to the Lithuanian Parliament (Seimas) (Seimas). * This name is without prejudice to the position on the status of Kosovo and is in line with United Nations Security Council Resolution 1244 (1999) and the opinion of the International Court of Justice on the declaration of Kosovo's independence.
Our governance The members of the European Court of Human Rights act as a collegial body, consisting of a single member from each Member State.
After the appointment by the relevant national government, each Member shall be appointed by the Council after consulting the European Parliament.
We have no role in appointing and appointing members.
They shall have a solemn undertaking before the Court of Justice of the European Union at the time of their taking office.

The Farm building currently has three buildings ("K1, "K2" and "K3"), which constitute one integrated technical unit.
K1 The building opened in 1988 offers an office for up to 310 staff and conference rooms.
Downstairs there are parking lots, technical equipment, warehouses, library and main archive, while the entire floor is used for technical installations.
The K1 building was modernised in 2008 in order to adapt it to national health, safety and environmental requirements.
As far as possible, the technology in the K1 building has been adapted to ensure compatibility with the K2 and K3 buildings.
In the the projectiles there are parking lots, technical equipment, warehouses and the fitness centre.
Other missiles are used in offices for up to 241 employees, where there are conference rooms, conference room with conference rooms, conference room, conference room, café and rooms that are simple in the kitchen.
We are currently modernising the K2 building to optimise the organisation of its tasks and to modernise certain technical installations.
In 2019 a detailed study of this project was carried out and work started at the end of the year.
In line with the decision of the European Parliament and of the Council adopted in March 2014, the Court will use the remaining budgetary resources of the K3 project completed a few years ago 61 to finance this modernisation.
Hangars include parking lots, technical installations, warehouses, unloading zones, waste storage facilities, printers, kitchens and archives.

Environmental management As an EU institution, we have an obligation to respect the principle of good environmental management in all activities.
We continue to systematically reduce CO2 emissions and regularly analyse greenhouse gas emissions caused by our actions.
In 2018, greenhouse gas emissions amounted to a total of 10 178 tonnes of carbon dioxide equivalent (tCO2e), representing a 30% reduction compared to 2017.
We are proud of our EMAS certification for environmental management and audit: we successfully implement an EMAS-compliant environmental management system and fully meet the certification requirements of ISO 14001:2015.
In the last quarter of 2019 an external verification of EMAS was carried out which led to the renewal of the EMAS certificate for the period 2020-2022.
New initiatives, such as the 'Be plastic European Criminal Court' initiative, are planned.

Bees are supervised by volunteers.
We assume that this will have a positive impact on the sustainability of pollinators in our surroundings 64.

Internal audit and external audit Internal audit body shall advise the Court on issues relating to risk management.
It provides independent and objective guarantees and advice in order to increase the added value and improve the Court's activities.
In addition, they shall report to the Internal Audit Committee, consisting of three members of the Court and one external expert.
The Committee shall regularly monitor the progress made in the various tasks set out in the annual work programme of the internal audit body and shall ensure its independence.
In 2018, the Internal Audit Service carried out three selected tasks: "Risk and challenges of the Audit Quality Control Committee," "Mission expenses of high-level members and officials, expenditure on the representation of members and the use of the Court's fleet" and "Training activities of the Court."
In addition, our risk management strategy and three annual declarations by the authorising officers by sub-delegated have been reviewed.
In addition, the Internal Audit Department monitored the implementation of its previous recommendations by checking the implementation of the agreed action plans, as well as advising on issues related to the Court's new internal control framework.
Our internal auditor did not show any shortcomings which, due to their nature or scope, could seriously undermine the overall credibility of internal control systems; the control systems were introduced by the authorising officer by delegation to ensure the legality and regularity of the Court's financial operations in 2019.
External audit Our annual accounts are audited by an independent external auditor.
This study is extremely important because it shows that we apply the same principles of transparency and accountability as we apply to the bodies we study.

DE EUROPEAN COURT OF COURT OF OF COURT OF COURT OF ACCOUNT 2013 Brief information on EU audit Presentation of the annual reports of the European Court of Auditors for the financial year 2013
Luxembourg: Publications Office of the European Union, 2014 ISBN 978-92-872-0998-6 doi:10.2865/23970 © European Union, 2014 Reproduction is authorised provided the source is acknowledged.
PL 2013 Brief information on the EU review Presentation of the annual reports of the European Court of Auditors for the financial year 2013
Preface by President 02 Each year in November, the European Court of Auditors shall present the results of its annual audits of the EU's financial management in the previous financial year.
On the basis of the evidence obtained, the Court ensures that the use of EU funds is reliable and stresses to the extent to which and to the extent that EU funds have not been used correctly.
The reports also contain recommendations on possible improvements in EU financial management.
In this way, the Court supports the European Parliament and the Council in the review of EU expenditure and contributes to the effective fulfilment of the calculation obligations towards EU citizens.
In this short-term information on the 2013 EU review, the 2013 review refers to the key findings of our annual EU budget implementation reports in 2013 or the reports on European Development Funds.
As in previous years, the reports indicate to the extent to which the bodies responsible for EU and national financial management have provided a reliable picture of financial management in their reports, have ensured the application of EU financial rules and respect for fundamental principles in terms of savings, efficiency and efficiency.
2013 was the last year of the seven-year programming period and we publish our progress reports this financial year during a transitional period of major importance for the EU and its finances.
As our reports show, the new European Parliament and the new Commission are facing long and new challenges of financial management and accountability in the current 2014-2020 programming period.
The continued impact on EU finances and national pressures requires careful management and control of EU funds as well as better forecasts for long-term financing.
In particular, we emphasise in our reports that the Commission and the authorities in the Member States should make greater use of EU funds in their EU budget to achieve results that cannot be equally effective and otherwise effective.
At the same time, the Court's audit shows that further action can and should be taken to ensure that EU action is taken in accordance with the rules.
The Court will be pleased to take the opportunity to help the new European Parliament and the Commission to address these and other problems related to financial management and the Commission's calculation obligation at EU level.
To this end, on the basis of our experience with control, we have also prepared two analyses on rural areas, which point to the main challenges facing the EU in terms of accountability, auditing and financial management.
Mr Vítor Manuel da Silva CALDEIRA President of the European Court of Auditors

General results 04 Summary of Statement of Assurance for 2013 The European Court of Auditors (ECA) delivered an opinion (ECA) on the reliability of the European Union accounts for 2013.
Revenue for 2013 is generally legal and regular.
The 2013 budget commitments are generally legal and regular.
There are significant errors in payments for 2013.
The Court therefore gives an incomplete opinion on legality and regularity.
The text of the Statement of Assurance sets out Chapter 1 of the Annual Report for the financial year 2013. The EU Court estimates the error rate which measures the level of irregularities at 4,7% in 2013 compared to the error rate for 2012 (4,8%) and at a constant level above the materiality threshold of 2%. General results 05 Proper use of EU funds Every year EU funds for 2013 The Court reviews EU revenue and expenditure and assesses how reliable the annual accounts are and revenue and expenditure operations comply with the rules and rules.
In 2013, spending from the EU budget amounted to EUR 148.5 billion or around EUR 290 per citizen.
These expenditures account for around 1% of the EU's gross national income and account for around 2% of the total public expenditure of the EU Member States.
The EU budget is adopted annually by the European Parliament and the Council on the basis of the seven-year financial framework.
It is primarily the Commission's responsibility to ensure that budgets are spent correctly.
In the case of around 80% of expenditure. In particular in the area of agriculture and cohesion the Commission shares this task with the EU Member States.
Where's the money coming from?
The EU budget is financed from different sources.
The largest percentage is payments made by Member States on the basis of their gross national income (EUR 110,0 billion).
Other sources include payments made by Member States on the basis of VAT (EUR 14.5 billion) and agricultural duties and duties (EUR 15.4 billion).
The EU's annual budget is spent in a number of policy areas (see Figure 1).
In the case of payments, various activities such as research, training for the unemployed or agricultural production should be supported.

Overall results 09 Mistakes, waste and abuse, estimated by the Court, the error rate is not a measure of fraud, inefficiency or waste.
It is a source of funds that could not be paid because they were not used in accordance with the applicable rules.
Typical errors include payments for ineligible expenditure or purchases for which procurement rules have not been correctly applied.
Fraud is a deliberate fraud aimed at obtaining benefits.
The Court shall refer the cases to which the Court is concerned in the course of the audits and where it suspects that they are fraud to OLAF (the Anti-Fraud Office in the European Union), which shall be responsible for carrying out any further investigations.

Overall results 12 The Court analyses the contribution of the different types of errors and the different expenditure areas to the estimated overall error rate (see Figure 6).
Expenditure that did not meet the conditions for the submission of an application for projects funded by the EU accounted for the largest part of the estimated total error rate (including ineligible costs in the statement of expenditure: 39% or 1.8 percentage points of the estimated total error rate).
Second, projects which could not, in accordance with the rules in force, have been financed by the activity or the beneficiary could not be supported (unqualified projects/actions/beneficiary: 22% or 1.1 percentage points of the estimated overall error rate).
As the largest area of expenditure, which represents the largest estimated error rate, regional policy, transport and energy are by far the most contributing to the estimated overall error rate (44% or 2.1 pro-points of the estimated overall error rate).
Agriculture: Market support and direct payments, where expenditure levels were almost the same, contribute approximately half the estimated overall error rate.
Recovery has a positive impact on the level of error in the Member States and the Commission in order to protect the EU budget in cases of ineffective control systems or irregular expenditure.
In the absence of such corrective action for the 2013 payments audited by the Court, the estimated total error rate in 2013 would be 6,3% instead of 4,7%.
However, the estimated error rate could still be significantly reduced by improving the use of existing control systems and corrective actions.
The Court found that, in the case of a significant proportion of the errors in the case of shared management, the authorities in the Member States had sufficient information to detect and correct errors before submitting a request for reimbursement to the Commission.
For example, this would reduce the estimated level of error in regional policy, transport and energy from 6.9 to 3.9%, in rural development, the environment, fisheries and health from 6.7% to 2.0%, and in employment and social affairs from 3.1% to 1.9%.
New challenges in providing reliable financial information The report on the corrections mentioned above does not clearly identify the main types of corrections for financial corrections and this information is largely made available outside the accounting system.
This hinders more in-depth analysis and reduces the accuracy of the figures in the financial statements and financial statements.
Further changes are the increasing use of financial instruments supporting investments in potentially viable projects in the form of loans, guarantees, equity and other risk instruments.
Due to the complexity of the financial instruments, their assessment and recording require particular care in accordance with the international public sector accounting principles.
Overall results 13 Continuous increase in amounts to be financed from future budgets The main features of EU budget and financial management in 2013 include the EU's strong increase in the volume of payments that the Commission could make through the amending budgets: 9.6% of the original budget; the EU's steady increase in commitments that will be the basis for payments in the future (2.6%) despite the large volume of payments; the EU's long period (over two years on average) between the date of initial budgetary commitments and the date of the Commission's adoption of the statement of expenditure; the EU's only 37% of payments to financial instruments to final beneficiaries at the end of 2012; the EU's payments, interest and dividends of EUR 259 million that have been accumulated since 2008 have not been included as revenue.
What are commitments and payments?
The EU budget consists of two elements: commitments (amounts to be paid in current or next year) and payments (amounts to be paid in current year).
Payments may only be made in respect of important budgetary commitments.
The annual ceilings for commitment and payment appropriations shall be laid down in the multiannual financial framework agreed by the Council and the Parliament.
The nature of EU spending programmes, and in particular the long period between commitment and payment, is putting increasing pressure on future payment budgets.
This shows a much higher payment budget in 2013, and this trend will continue to be similar in future budgets.
General results 14 How does the Court consider that budgetary and financial management may increase the quality of the information on the functioning of the correction mechanisms (time point, origin and type) and the accuracy of the figures by requesting information under the traditional accounting systems of the ο, ο in order to record and evaluate all financial instruments and financial instruments in the public sector, in line with internationally recognised accounting principles, in particular through reliable valuation procedures, the ο in order to provide information on the financial resources held for the payment to the final beneficiaries of the ο in order to draw up and publish an estimate of the financial flows of the ο that will be updated on an annual basis, to facilitate the identification of future payment needs and the identification of budgetary priorities for the entities concerned. ο in order to draw up and publish an annual estimate of the cash flows.
For full information on the main findings of the audit, see Chapter 1 on the reliability and presentation of the annual report on the implementation of the EU budget for the financial year 2013.
The overall results of EU 15 funds and results should be used in accordance with the principles of sound financial management (savings, efficiency and efficiency).
In order to achieve good results, it is therefore necessary to implement the programme of financial measures (resources, human, material, organisational or regulatory resources), the results (to be achieved under the programme), the results (to be achieved under the programme, initial changes to the programme, including changes to direct or direct beneficiaries) and the effects (long-term social changes, at least partly linked to EU action).
The Court assesses these aspects in its economic audits.
Not enough attention has been paid to implementation During the 2007-2013 programming period, EU funds focused on absorption (use it or fate it attention to non-use), on compliance, not on good results.
For example, when selecting projects to be funded by the EU, there was a need to use available EU funds and, to some extent, there was a need to comply with EU rules and to some extent to achieve results and results.
This focus on results is a key drawback in the way a large part of the EU budget is built.
According to the Commission, the focus for the 2014-2020 programming period is to a greater extent on elimination, with reserves with the main impetus for implementation.
With these reserves, the Commission will suspend 6% of the resources allocated to individual Member States until they are considered satisfactory.
However, in practice, the input and output indicators will remain largely in line with funding.
The result indicators will only be used by the Commission in certain areas.
The more efficient functioning of performance-related reserves will depend on how effectively the Commission will succeed in negotiating the relevant milestones and milestones at the beginning of the programming period and on whether the Member States will keep up-to-date accurate, reliable and up-to-date data to determine whether these objectives have been achieved.
The reporting framework is not adequate in relation to the expected culture of results The report on results is spread over several general reports at the level of the general budget.
These reports do not provide any information on the progress made towards the Europe 2020 objectives and do not provide a comprehensive review of the results in the form of EU added value.
However, the fourth evaluation report is a step in the right direction, as it seeks to combine the main financial programmes with the available information on the results that are relevant to the Europe 2020 strategy.
At the level of each Commission Directorate-General, the policy performance targets are set out in the management plans and are set out in the annual activity reports.
The Court's analysis of the management plans and the annual reports on the activities of the Commission's DG revealed that the assurance of assurance is limited to the aspects of the regularity and internal control and that it does not take account of the performance aspects.
In addition, the objectives are too general to be used for management purposes, and the selected indicators are not always suitable for performance measurement purposes.
Overall results 16 The added value of EU expenditure is not always demonstrated in 19 special reports adopted by the Court in 2013 in the framework of performance controls, a wide range of issues were discussed, as well as an assessment as to whether the EU intervention was carried out in accordance with the principles of sound financial management (savings, efficiency and efficiency).
The Court examined the conclusions of its special reports on the implementation of the new programmes and projects adopted in 2013 in the 2014-2020 programming period and concluded that the EU added value could not always be guaranteed.
Example: The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund provides compensation to workers affected by collective redundancies.
The Court found that a third of the resources allocated to actions to be paid by the Member States (Special Report No 7/2013 that the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund provided the EU's added value in terms of the reintegration of redundant workers into wine).
For example, a risk-sharing funding mechanism, the Commission has not sufficiently demonstrated that the EU funds allocated under the risk-sharing financing instrument (the financing instrument aimed at facilitating access to debt financing in the field of research) lead to greater investments than the funds that beneficiaries would have purchased without public funding (Special Report No 2/2013 on ensuring the effective implementation of the Seventh Framework Programme in the field of research by the Commission?)
Overall results 17 Most of the Court's recommendations have been injected The Court's follow-up of recommendations made by the Court as a result of the audit of performance is a key element of the audit cycle and can contribute to the effective implementation by the Commission of the recommendations contained in the reports.
The Court examined how the Commission's recommendations in the eight special reports adopted in 2007-2010 continued to apply and concluded that the Commission had implemented in full or to a large extent 79% of the recommendations.
The Court recommends the Commission: ο The Commission should improve the reporting framework for the next revision of the Financial Regulation. ο The Commission should ensure that the evaluation report summarises all available information on the progress made towards the Europe 2020 objectives. ο The Commission should further develop the performance management and reporting system so that it can be responsible for the sound financial management and the contribution of the EU budget to political success.
Full information on the Court's evaluation of the results can be found in Chapter 10 of the EU budget and the results of this annual report on the implementation of the EU budget for the financial year 2013.
All special reports are available on the Court's website: http://www.eca.europa.eu/en/Pages/AuditReports Opinions.aspx.
In 2013, the contributions to the Member States' basic gross national income (GNI) and the VAT charged by the Member States represented 74% and 10% of the income respectively.
Import duties and sugar production duties charged by the Member States' authorities on behalf of the EU account for 10% of the EU's revenue and the remaining 6% are derived from other revenue.
Explanations on the analysis of EU revenue The EU revenue based on GNI and VAT shall be calculated on the basis of macroeconomic statistics and estimates of data provided by the Member States.
The Court's audit of the regularity of the underlying transactions refers to the processing of the data by the Commission and not to the preliminary collection of the data by the Member States' authorities.
Consequently, the Court's request concerns the impact of possible errors of the Commission on the total amount of revenue.
As regards customs duties, the Court examines how the Commission is acting in the manner in which the Member States submit information on the powers established.
These data are not sufficiently harmonised among the Member States.
The reservation is an instrument which allows for an adjustment for GNI data transmitted by the Member State in respect of the disputed element.
There is a general reservation for Greek GNI data for 2008 and 2009 as these data are still based on preliminary estimates.
This is part of the problem that affects the macroeconomic accounts of Greece.
For more information on the areas of revenue and expenditure 19 The customs authorities of the Member States shall carry out checks to verify that importers comply with customs and import rules.
The Court noted that the quality of the checks was very different in the Member States in which the visits were carried out.
This may lead to a decision by importers to notify the goods in a Member State other than that in which they are established in order to reduce the likelihood of controls and reduce the levying of fees due.
An example seems to be one of the importers who, in Hamburg, Germany, disposed of Chinese textile products to transport them to Rotterdam, where they were declared for free circulation, and then disposed of them in Poland for their final sale.
Our recommendations The Court recommends the Commission: ο Commission should seek to harmonise the methods for the calculation of the data on unseen economic activities by the Member States. ο Commission should draw up a detailed action plan containing a detailed action plan containing clear steps of action and to closely monitor its implementation in order to address the problems of the creation of the Greek national accounts. ο Commission should establish minimum standards for controls carried out by customs authorities in the Member States in order to ensure better targeting importers at high risk. Do you want to know more?
Full information on the Court's audit of EU revenue can be found in Chapter 2 of the annual report on the implementation of the EU budget for the financial year 2013.
20 This expenditure area includes the European Agricultural Guarantee Fund (EGF), one of the two main instruments of the EU's common agricultural policy.
The aim of this policy is to increase the productivity of agriculture, ensure an adequate standard of living for the agricultural population, stabilise the markets, ensure supplies and ensure a fair supply of consumers.
Expenditure shall be managed shared with the Member States.
Yes Estimated error rate: 3.6% (2012): 3.8 %) Checked control systems: Conditionally checked Most expenditure in this area is calculated on the basis of agricultural land.
Many of the quantifiable errors are due to the inaccuracies in the applications of the beneficiaries, most of which are distorted (see example).
For example: excessive declarations of ineligible land In Germany, Ireland, Greece, France, Poland and Romania*, some areas that have been recognised as permanent grassland have been recognised as areas for which payments have been paid, in fact planted in whole or in part ineligible vegetation (head or tree).
For these ineligible areas, Union aid could not be paid.
This error occurred in Greece because the land was classified as eligible grassland and the agricultural parcel identification system was duly taken into account.
Examples of errors should reflect the most common types of errors.
They do not give rise to conclusions on the Member States, beneficiary countries and/or regions concerned.
For all direct aid schemes under the EAGF, the beneficiaries of EU aid are legally obliged to comply with the existing obligations (cross compliance principle) concerning the protection of the environment, human, animal and plant health and animal welfare, as well as the protection of land in good agricultural and environmental condition.
Where farmers fail to fulfil those obligations, their aid shall be reduced.
As a result of the audit, the Court found infringements in 25% of the cases in which those obligations were linked.
In the event of a significant number of errors, the authorities of the Member States had sufficient information to detect and correct errors before requesting reimbursement to the Commission.
If this information had been used to correct errors before the Commission was notified of expenditure, the estimated error rate in this respect would have been 2,5%.

More information on revenue and expenditure areas 25 The Court's auditors also check whether EU State aid rules are being complied with.
Illegal State aid confers an unjustified advantage on the beneficiaries and thus affects the internal market.
The State aid errors represented 17% of the estimated error rate in this area (see example).
For example, State aid for a cost-effective project for small or medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) in Slovenia was granted for research and development in the automotive industry.
However, SMEs were wholly owned by large enterprises and carried out research activities solely on their behalf.
As large enterprises are subject to stricter public funding rules, the company was not entitled to finance all the funding.
Similar cases have been reported in Bulgaria and Hungary.

General information 37 The European Court of Auditors and its work The European Court of Auditors (ECA) is an independent audit body of the European Union (EU) established in Luxembourg.
There are around 900 workers from all EU countries, which are made up of controllers and horizontal service workers.
Since its creation in 1977, the Committee has been raising awareness of and improving the EU's financial management.
The Court's audit reports and opinions are an important part of the EU's responsibility chain.
Our results will be used to bring to account those responsible for managing the EU budget, in particular in the context of the discharge procedure.
These are mainly the Commission, but they also apply to other EU institutions, bodies and agencies.
In the case of shared management, Member States also play an important role.
Our main task is to audit accounting and to control compliance, mainly with regard to the statement of assurance; the audit of accounting issues that are chosen in a way that makes our work most effective; the opinion on the provisions on financial management and other important issues.
We are trying to use our resources to strike a balance between the different fields of activity to achieve robust results and the appropriate range of different areas of the EU budget.

Our actions contribute to raising awareness of financial management in the EU and to increasing transparency in financial management, ensuring the reliability of financial management and recommending further improvements.
This is in the interests of the citizens of the European Union.

INTRODUCTION 1. The Agency for the Cooperation of Energy Regulators (hereinafter referred to as the Agency) established in Ljubljana was established by Regulation (EC) No 713/2009 of the European Parliament and of the Council1.
The main task of the Agency shall be to assist national regulatory authorities in carrying out regulatory tasks in the Member States at Union level and in coordinating the activities of those authorities as necessary.
Within the framework of the Regulation on the integrity and transparency of the wholesale energy market (REMIT Regulation) 2, the Agency and the national regulatory authorities are given additional tasks to monitor the European wholesale energy market3.
Therefore, for the 2011 financial year, the period from 8 March 2011 to 31 December 2011 was examined.

8 Annex Agency for the Cooperation of Energy Regulators (Ljubljana) The scope of the Union's competence under the Treaty (Article 114 (ex Article 95 TEC) and Article 194 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union) The Agency's competence (Regulation (EC) No 713/2009 of the European Parliament and of the Council; Commission Regulation (EU) No 838/2010; Regulation (EU) No 1227/2011 of the European Parliament and of the Council) The European Parliament and of the Council, acting in accordance with the ordinary legislative procedure and after consulting the Economic and Social Committee, shall adopt measures with a view to the approximation of the laws, regulations and administrative provisions of the Member States for the establishment and functioning of the internal market.
The Union's energy policy shall have the following objectives: (a) ensuring the functioning of the energy market; (b) ensuring energy security in the Union; (c) promoting energy efficiency and energy savings and the development of new and renewable energy sources; (d) promoting interconnection between energy networks; and
The European Parliament and the Council, acting in accordance with the ordinary legislative procedure, shall adopt the measures necessary to achieve those objectives.
Those measures shall be adopted after consulting the Economic and Social Committee and the Committee of the Regions.
The Agency's objective is to assist national regulatory authorities in carrying out regulatory tasks in the Member States at Union level and in coordinating their activities as necessary.
Tasks - complementing and coordinating the work of national regulatory authorities - contributing to the development of European network rules - in certain circumstances to take binding individual decisions on the conditions of access and operational security of cross-border infrastructure, - advising the European institutions on energy issues, - monitoring the development of energy markets and reporting in this respect, - preparing a proposal to the European Commission on the annual amount of compensation for cross-border infrastructure under the ITC mechanism, - cooperating with national regulatory authorities, ESMA, the competent financial authorities of the Member States and, where appropriate, national competition authorities for monitoring energy markets in the wholesale market, - assessing the functioning and transparency of the various categories of market and trade market, - making recommendations to the Commission on market rules, trade registers, trade agreements, standards and procedures to improve the integrity of the market and the functioning of the internal market.
Composition of the Management Board: The Management Board shall consist of two members appointed by the European Parliament, two members appointed by the Commission and five members appointed by the Council.
Each member has an alternate.
Tasks: The Management Board shall adopt the Agency's annual work programme, adopt its budget and monitor its implementation.
The Board of Regulators will take the position of Director after obtaining a positive opinion of the Board of Regulators on the basis of ADB001375DE04-12PP-CH058-12APCFIN-RAS-2011_ACER-TR.DOC 19.9.2012
Composition of the Board of Regulators: The Board of Regulators shall consist of high-level representatives of the regulatory authorities of each Member State and a representative of the Commission who does not have the right to vote.
Each member shall have an alternate nominated by the national regulatory authority of each Member State.
Tasks: - The Board of Regulators shall submit opinions to the Director on the opinions, recommendations and decisions to be adopted and adopted. -. - - The Board of Regulators shall direct the Director in the course of the performance of its duties. - -. - The Board of Regulators shall present an opinion to the Director on the candidate to be appointed Director and approve the Agency's work programme.

COMMENTS ON INTERNAL CONTROLS 17. In its May 2016 work report, the Commission's Internal Audit Service (IAS) highlighted the urgent need to clarify the roles and competences and to analyse the workload of the contracting entity in order to increase the efficiency of processes and procedures.
In addition, IAS considered that planning and monitoring of public procurement should be significantly improved.
The Agency and the IAS have agreed on a corrective action plan.

CONTROL INFORMATION General context 6 The European Centre for the Development of Vocational Training (Cedefop) was established by Council Regulation (EEC) No 337/75 (EEC) No 337/75) as the European Community Satellite Centre for the promotion of vocational education and training at European Community level.
Cedefop started work in Berlin in 1976 and moved to Thessaloniki in 1995.
7. As defined in that Regulation, the Centre should assist the Commission in promoting vocational and continuing education and training at Community level, in contributing to the implementation of a common policy on vocational education and training, and in particular in promoting the exchange of information and experience."
In the field of vocational education and training, the Centre shall be responsible in particular for the development of documentation, contributing to the development and coordination of research, providing adequate documentation and information, promoting and supporting initiatives in order to achieve a coordinated solution (in particular with a view to bringing the levels of education and mutual recognition of certificates closer together) and the establishment of a meeting point with interested parties." 8. The Centre shall be managed by a management board of 48 members (in 1995 costs of ECU 334 000 were incurred); i1) Council Regulation (EEC) No 337/75, published on 13 February 1975, OJ L 334, 13 October 1975;
The Management Board shall elect its Chairperson and three Vice-Chairs from among its members for a period of one year.
During the audit (May 1996), the Council was chaired by the Council by the Director General of the Council of Education and Youth and Education DG XXII.
The Director of the Centre shall be appointed by the Commission on the basis of a list of candidates submitted by the Governing Board.
9. In accordance with the basic Regulation, the Director shall be responsible for the day-to-day management of the Centre, while the Management Board shall have overall responsibility.
The Management Board shall adopt decisions, adopt the work programme and annual report, draw up the revenue and statement of expenditure for the preceding year and the estimates of revenue and expenditure for the coming year.
10. In accordance with the basic Regulation, the Commission's role, as represented by DG XXI I's representatives, is not only to represent the members of the Commission in the Governing Board, but also to adopt the work programme, to assess the review and revenue report, to assess the report and the financial statements, and to report the estimates of revenue and expenditure to the Council and the European Parliament, but also to report the estimates of revenue and expenditure.
In accordance with Article 23 of Council Regulation (EEC) No 1416/76 of 1 June 1976, as amended by Council Regulation (EEC) No 1948/93* of 30 June 1993, any commitments and payments made by the Centre before the payment of: (a) must... receive the appropriate costs. (a) the benefits and benefits of the budget expenditure for support of Cedefop; (b) the efficient use of human resources and human resources; (c) quality products, meeting the needs of Cedefop customers; (d) a clear and consistent role in the European Community's vocational education and training policy.

Comments on the implementation of the budget Separation of activities 15. Following the move to Thessaloniki, Until the date of the inspection (May 1996), the relevant procedures for the separation of the activities of the authorising officer, the accounting officer and the administrator of pre-financing have not yet been introduced until the date of the inspection.
For example, it is observed that the accounting officer has taken control of the pre-financing administrator.
16. The amount of payments made without the consent of the financial controller remains high (in 1995 it was 60% without remuneration).
The strong use of the paying agency system is not in line with the spirit of the financial rules.
A more acceptable practice would consist of counting only small current expenditure and expenditure on the payment account, where the risk of irregularities is relatively low.
In 1995, transfers between different budget headings amounted to ECU 922 000, i.e. 5.6% of the original budget compared to 10.9% in 1994.
In the last two months of 1995, the transfer of 33% was made in 1994.

The Court's observations from last year (2) were therefore taken into account.

In 1995 only 61% of the funds finally available were paid out compared to 73% in 1994.

The share of the lost funds was 10 % compared to 5% in 1994.

23. Following the decision to transfer the Centre to Thessaloniki, a new deputy director was appointed in 1994 who was living and working in Thessaloniki.
The worker moved to Berlin and received a development allowance of twice the basic salary. Less than a year later, i.e. after the transfer of Zen to Thessaloniki, the same employee again received a development allowance of twice the basic salary.
Since the transfer of the centre took place quickly, the stay in Berlin was short (11 months); in Thessaloniki, he also spent part of that period, as well as the full (including weekends) daily allowance; the Court considered that the decisions were not in accordance with the principle of sound financial management and were contrary to the principle of sound financial management and that they were not in accordance with the principle of Cedefop.

This means that a system has been established whereby up to 50% of the remuneration of workers in the currency to which a higher adjustment factor is applied (i.e. the adjustment factor of 111.4% in Germany) is applied to Thessaloniki (in the case of Greece, an adjustment factor of 80.2% is applied).
The Commission has committed itself to introducing specific rules on mobility to the Centre.
These provisions are contrary to the principle of equal treatment of all officials.
Whereas Article 13 of Council Regulation (EC) No 251/95 of 6 February 1995 makes it clear that the Staff Regulations and the Conditions of Employment of Other Servants apply to the staff of the Centre;
This means that all the provisions of this Article apply to the staff of the Centre, including Article 29 (1) (c), which concerns the acquisition of officials by other institutions.
Therefore, there is no justification for special treatment for mobility; a summary in 67. The Court's audit showed that the Centre's work programme was not carried out in accordance with the plan due to a serious shortage of staff.
This led to significant transfers and cancellations.
The audit also showed that effective administrative and accounting procedures have not yet been established.
68. Two alternate directors received a remuneration corresponding to the basic salary for a period of four months; these payments and a payment of ECU 71 030 to one of the alternate directors were not in line with the sound financial management and with the interests of the Centre.
69. During the Court's audit, there were 79 approved posts, but only 37 people actually worked at the Centre.
17 staff were appointed EU officials' even though they refused to move to Thessaloniki or were taken over by another Community institution.
Conclusion 71.It is understandable that, in connection with moving to Thessaloniki, efforts have been made to maintain staff in the EU institutions and to reduce the complex moving problems.
However, the problem is that the regulatory framework, in which the move was carried out, was not in line with the proper treatment of workers with high internships, even after the changes were made and did not allow the smooth transfer of Cedefop without abandoning its activities.

16. As already mentioned last year, increased access to the paying agency system was increased at the request of the financial controller, which last year justified this cost-benefit indicator, which led to large, fast supply costs and led to delays.
As a result, the financial controller had to act more frequently.
The use of the pre-financing procedure for all expenditure which may have required temporary payments reduced administrative costs and prevented delays.
The situation is even more difficult due to the payment method in Greece (most payments are made in cash or in cheque).
Accounts with bank accounts are rare; contractors overlap their claims themselves.
Account should also be taken of geographical remoteness from the financial controller and of the lack of reliability of postal supplies.
In addition, the rapid delivery of DHL can only be made once a week due to costs (3 000 BFR per consignment).
The amendment to the decision establishing the pre-financing procedure will soon be submitted to the Management Board to better take account of the wishes of the Court of Auditors.

The first payment was not in line with the rules, but the payment must be preceded by a budgetary commitment which takes some time.

45. The effects in 1996 are obviously serious, but will be minimal after the first months of 1997.
The transfer had its consequences and costs.
However, if we compare them with a similar transfer at national level, for example from Paris to Marseilles (where only 21 out of 120 workers moved to the centre), due to the international transfer to a distance of almost 2000 km, CEDEFOP did not have a very negative impact.
Careful cost estimates suggest that cost neutrality will be achieved in 2000 and that it will be even more cost-effective (mainly due to lower labour costs in Greece). 46-66.
(a) as the Court explains in its summary (2001), it is understandable that the efforts to support workers were made in order to support them in order to continue their activities to the EU institutions, as well as in order to address the problems of relocation. In accordance with Articles 2 and 8 of the Conditions of employment of other EC servants, these posts may be filled only by officials or temporary servants. (h) In addition, the text of Regulation (EC) No 251/95 (over, the staff of the Centre shall be subject to the rules and rules applicable to officials and other servants of the European Communities) expressly provides for the employment of officials.
