They have been established by a Commission Decision and operate under the supervision of a steering committee established by the Commission.
Their work shall be based on multiannual and annual work programmes prepared and carried out under the responsibility of the Executive Director.
They are subject to individual discharge procedures by the European Parliament and the Council with regard to their own budgets.
Unlike decentralised agencies, their budgets cover only staff and administrative expenditure, while all the operational expenditure they cover comes from the Commission's budget and therefore forms part of the overall discharge granted to the Commission.
The budget of the executive agencies therefore only corresponds to a very small part of the budget that they will actually implement.
Other institutions have specific tasks 1.11.
The other three entities are the EIT, the Euratom Supply Agency and the SRB.
The EIT in Budapest is an independent and decentralised EU institution that uses resources in the fields of science, the economy and education in order to strengthen innovation in the Union by providing financial assistance.
The Institute was established by the European Parliament and the Council for an indefinite period.
It shall be managed by the Director and supervised by the Management Board and shall be subject to a special discharge procedure by the European Parliament and the Council.
The Euratom Supply Agency in Luxembourg has been established by the Council for an indeterminate period of time to support the objectives of the Treaty in order to consolidate the European Atomic Energy Community.
This decision shall be subject to a special discharge procedure by the European Parliament and the Council.
The Advisory Committee of Member States shall assist the Euratom Supply Agency in the performance of its tasks by issuing opinions and providing analyses and information.
The Director-General of the Euratom Supply Agency shall act under the supervision of the Commission.
The SRB is a central resolution authority in the Banking Union and is established in Br.
The SRB aims to organise the restructuring and orderly restructuring of bankrupt banks, which has the least impact on the real economy, the financial system and the public finances of the participating Member States, and which goes beyond what is necessary.
The SRB shall be reprented by its President, who shall also act as the recruitment body.
The Chairperson of the SRB shall be subject to a separate discharge procedure by the Committee, the members of which shall be elected by the participating Member States.
The agencies are financed from various sources and under various actions of the MFF 1.15.
The total budget of all agencies in 2017 amounted to EUR 3.5 billion (excluding SRB) (2016: EUR 3.4 billion), corresponding to around 2.7% of the total EU budget for 2017 (2016: 2.4 percent), as shown in Figure 1.3.

Special Report of the Court of Justice not valued by SRB 2.51.
The Single Committee on Restructuring and Restructuring (RSB) based in Brez on August 2014 was set up in the framework of a political response to the financial crisis.
The Committee's task is to eliminate banks in difficulty that fall within its remit.
In January 2017, SRB f 1-4 and 139 banks, including 130 banking groups, continued to do so in.21.
In preparation (22), it examined whether the Committee was prepared for the effective management of banks; particular attention was paid to the quality of the resolution plan for each bank and whether the Committee was prepared to meet the legal requirements for the resolution plan and to sufficient human resources for the performance of its duties.
The Court has identified shortcomings in all these areas, but given that the creation of the Committee as a completely new structure has been a huge challenge, it can be concluded that the shortcomings in this context are significant.
The Court has made a number of recommendations to the Committee on the establishment of resolution structures and the improvement of its principles and guidelines, as well as on increasing the number of employees and improving the procedures for the management of human resources.

The Network would like to express its concern at the fact that in Sysper, given that the Commission only presents to them the basic package of modules, the agencies will be forced, and will in the future, to continue to use separate tools for evaluation, teleworking, sliptime and staff reporting.

Agencies also want the possibility of introducing a common possibility of using the services to support recruitment procedures that are currently not covered by Sysper.
With regard to public procurement, there has been a strong development in the last two years towards the harmonisation of electronic tools.
This development began in 2015/2016, when, in cooperation with DG DIGIT, tools for electronic procurement were developed in cooperation with DG BUDG.
Since then, this series of electronic modules for all stages of the procurement cycle has become the standard for which the agencies apply.
In 2018, this trend continued to change, when the new modules were introduced electronically, the ABAC LCK module and were made available to the agencies.
Over time, agencies stand on the road to using their own, isolated tools, which are very fast, sometimes less fast, but no matter how fast this development takes place, this trend does not exist on its own.
In practice, it is difficult to achieve the proposed efficiency improvement by fulfilling the European Commission's accounting tasks.

COMMENTS ON INTERNAL CONTROLS 3.2.9.
In 2011, the Agency received an additional task related to the monitoring of the energy market in the wholesale market (REMIT).
The first REMIT elements were put into effect for the first time in 2017.
However, the original location in Maribor, Slovenia, was moved to Ljubljana in April 2017 to the Agency's main data centre.
Therefore, the backup data is now stored in the same place as the original data.
Therefore, in the event of natural disasters, there is a significant risk of a continuation of economic activity, as the data may be irreversibly lost. COMMENTS ON BUDGETARY COMMENTS ON BUDGETARY. 3.2.10. On 29 March 2017, the United Kingdom (UK) informed the European Council of its decision to withdraw from the European Union (Brexit).
Unlike most other agencies, the Agency has not carried out a complete analysis of the impact of Brexit on its organisation, its depreciation and its accounts.

CHEMICAL CHEMIC AGENCY AGENCY (ECHA) INTRODUCTION 3.7.1
The European Chemicals Agency (hereinafter referred to as "the Agency') (hereinafter referred to as "the Agency') established in Helsinki was established by Regulation (EC) No 1907/2006 of the European Parliament and of the Council (69).
Their main task is to ensure a high level of protection of human health and the environment and to ensure the free movement of substances in the internal market, while increasing competitiveness and innovation.
The Agency also encourages the development of alternative methods for the assessment of the risks of substances.

OTHER COMMENTS 3.7.14.
The Agency's revenue from employment contracts with companies is indebted for the period for the registration of chemicals in the EU as defined in the REACH Regulation (2010, 2013 and 2018).
The Agency therefore does not charge periodic fees and is not able to distinguish between relatively stable expenditure and stable and less predictable revenues, which makes budget planning difficult.
The Agency shall be supported in this situation in the form of a grant which the Commission shall provide to it.
As the third and last period of registration of chemical substances under the REACH Regulation ends in 2018, income from work and salaries is expected to fall from 2019 and the Agency will continue to finance its activities from the EU budget.

However, the expenditure collected in 2014 covers only 17% of these expenditures, and part of these expenditure was actually financed by the Union contribution (EUR 6,3 million) and the EFTA States (EUR 0,2 million) to the Agency's budget, and consequently EUR 10,1 million and 39% (EUR 7,3 million and 32% respectively in 2015) of the financial contribution made in the following financial year in Title III (the operational expenditure under REACH) was still EUR 1,3 million and 68 per cent (EUR 1,5 million and 74 per cent respectively in 2015).
Such a high rate of return is contrary to the principle of budgetary fairness. The Agency may try to create separate budgetary resources to better balance the multi-annual nature and the inevitable misunderstandings between contracts, deliveries and payments.

The aim of the Institute is to contribute to sustainable economic growth in Europe and to increase competitiveness by stimulating the innovation potential of the Member States and the European Union.

The Agency currently manages three non-integrated IT systems (SIS II, VIS and Eurodac) which include the processing of data on the Union's Freedom, Security and Justice Policy.

The Agency, in consultation with the Commission and the Member States, should carry out a detailed cost-benefit analysis in order to contribute to the discussion on a future system development strategy.

EURATOM ADMINISTRATION AGENCY INTRODUCTION 3.32.1.
The Euratom Supply Agency (hereinafter referred to as the Agency) established in Luxembourg was established in 1958[244].
Council Decision 2008/114/EC, Euratom[245] replaced the Agency's previously existing statute.
The main task of the Agency is to ensure the regular supply of nuclear material to EU users, in particular nuclear fuel, in accordance with the principle of equal access to supply sources under the common supply policy.
3.33.2.
From 2008 to 2011, no budget of its own has been allocated to the Agency to finance its activities.
Since 2012, the Commission has made available its own budget to the Agency, but it covers only a small part of the expenditure.

EN 10.11.2015 Official Journal of the European Union C 373/7 GENERAL INTRODUCTION 0.1.
The European Court of Auditors shall be the institution responsible for the financial control of the European Union (EU) in accordance with the Treaty.
As an external EU auditor, we contribute to improving the financial management of the EU and, at the same time, we are an independent guardian of the financial interests of EU citizens.
For more detailed information on our work, see the Annual Activity Report, including the Special Reports on EU spending and revenue programmes, as well as the opinions on new or revised legislation on our website www.eca.europa.eu.
This is our 38th annual report on the implementation of the EU budget; this is the financial year 2014.
The annual report on the European Development Funds shall be presented separately.
0.3.
The EU's general budget shall be adopted annually by the Council and the European Parliament.
Our annual report, together with the special reports, is the basis for the discharge procedure during which the European Parliament, on the basis of a recommendation from the Council, decides whether the Commission has satisfactorily carried out its tasks with regard to the implementation of the budget.
Together with the transmission to the European Parliament and the Council, we present our annual report to the national Parliaments.
0.4.
A key element of our annual report is the statement on the reliability of the consolidated accounts of the European Union as well as on the legality and regularity of transactions (hereinafter referred to as "the regularity of transactions ").
We complete this statement of assurance through detailed assessments of all major areas of EU activity.
0.5.
The structure of the chapters now reflects the headings of the Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF) and therefore our report is even more important.
The financial framework entered into force in 2014 in order to determine the volume and breakdown of EU expenditure in the period up to 2020.
This should make it easier for readers to establish a link between the findings in our report and the relevant budgetary and accounting information.
0.6.
There are no separate financial statements for the individual MFF tours and the proposals submitted for the individual evaluations are therefore not audit opinions.
0.7.
Our report this year is divided as follows: Chapter 1 Our findings on budgetary and financial management are presented as follows: Statement of assurance and summary of the results of the audit of the reliability of the accounts and regularity of transactions: the findings on budgetary and financial management: Chapter 3 contributes strategically to improving the EU's public responsibility. Chapter 3 focuses on the extent to which the implementation framework allows the Commission to monitor and manage progress towards the Europe 2020 strategy. Chapter 4 presents our findings on revenue. Chapter 5-9 (on the implementation framework 1a, 1b, 2, 4 and 5) (on the implementation framework) (point 1), our findings on the regularity of the transactions, on the control of selected systems and annual activity reports.
0.8.
The Commission's (or, where appropriate, other EU institutions and bodies' replies) replies to our comments are contained in the report.
However, as an external auditor, our task is to present our audit findings, to learn from these findings and thus to carry out an independent and impartial assessment of the reliability of the accounts and the regularity of the transactions.
(1) As no detailed assessment of the expenditure for the MFF actions 3 (for security and citizenship) and 6 (for compensation for security and citizenship of MFF expenditure) under the 6 (including environmental and environmental expenditure) under the MFF programme and 6 (including environmental expenditure) under the MFF programme (for environmental and security expenditure) under the MFF programme (including environmental expenditure) under the MFF programme under the MFF programme (including security and citizenship) and under the 6 (for compensation) under the MFF programme (including environmental expenditure) under the MFF programme.

Responsibility for the management of II. In accordance with Articles 317 and 318 TFEU and the Financial Regulation, the Commission is responsible for the drawing up and correct presentation of the consolidated accounts of the European Union on the basis of recognised international public sector accounting principles and for the legality and regularity of the underlying transactions.
This liability shall include the creation, creation and maintenance of internal control structures necessary for the preparation and presentation of financial statements, which shall be free of material and unintentional presentation of...
The Commission is ultimately responsible for the legality and regularity of the underlying transactions of the European Union (Article 317 TFEU).
It is our task to present to the European Parliament and the Council, on the basis of our audit, a statement on the reliability of the accounts and the legality and regularity of the underlying transactions.
We carried out the audit in accordance with the International Audit Standards and the requirements for the professional behaviour of the IFAC and with the International Standards of the Supreme Audit Authorities of INTOSAI.
In accordance with these standards, we must respect the requirements of professional behaviour and plan and carry out checks in such a way as to obtain reasonable assurance as to whether the consolidated accounts of the European Union are free from material false presentations and the underlying transactions are legal and regular.
IV. The audit shall include the carrying out of the audit activities in order to obtain evidence of the accounting and other information contained in the consolidated accounts as well as the legality and regularity of the underlying transactions.
The choice of control activities shall be the responsibility of the controller, including the assessment of the risks associated with material or unintentional coerced or incorrect, or the consolidated accounts as well as material or unintended in the case where, in the sphere of transactions underlying the transactions of the European Union, with regard to the risks associated with material or unintended, incorrect presentations.
When assessing those risks, the auditor shall take into account all internal controls relevant for the preparation and proper submission of the consolidated accounts and the legality and regularity of the underlying transactions, with a view to planning the audit activities relevant to the circumstances, but not with a view to giving an opinion on the effectiveness of the internal control system.
The verification shall also include an assessment of the adequacy of the accounting rules applied, the adequacy of the accounting estimates and the overall statement of the consolidated accounts.
V. In the area of revenue, as a starting point for our assessment of VAT-based and gross national income-based own resources, we use macroeconomic aggregates appropriate for their calculation and we evaluate the Commission's systems for the processing of this data until we receive the contributions of the Member States and until they are included in the consolidated accounts.
In the area of traditional own resources, we examine customs accounts and analyse the movement of customs authorities until they are received by the Commission and until they are entered in the accounts.
1. Consolidated financial statements include balance sheet, profit and loss account, cash flow account, changes in net asset value, summary of relevant accounting rules and other explanations (including segment reports).
In the area of expenditure, we check the payment transactions after the expenditure has been made, entered in the accounts and accepted, we check all types of payment, except in advance and after payment, after the purchase of the assets has been made.
Prepayments shall be analysed when the beneficiary presents or has to provide evidence that they are properly used and when the advance is cleared or can be recovered.
VII. We believe that the evidence obtained is sufficient and adequate to serve as the basis for our test opinions.

10.11.2015 Official Journal of the European Union C 373/13 DE COMMENTS FROM THE COURT PRELIMINARY EU expenditure is an important tool for achieving the policy objectives 1.1.
EU spending is an important tool for achieving policy objectives.
Other important instruments are legislation, the free movement of goods, services and capital and the free movement of persons throughout the Union.
EU spending averages 1.9% of total EU spending (see Figure 1.1).
In line with the Treaty, it is our task, inter alia, to assess whether the use of the EU budget is in line with applicable rules and other rules; to issue an audit opinion on the EU annual accounts; to report on the savings, efficiency and effectiveness (4) of EU spending; to issue an opinion on the legislative proposals from the budget.
Our audit work in support of the Statement of Assurance meets the first and the second of these objectives.
This audit work allows us to identify risks that reduce economy, economy and efficiency.
It is also an important contribution to the drafting of an opinion on the proposed financial rules.
Regulation (EU, Euratom) No 966/2012 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 25 October 2012 on the financial rules applicable to the general budget of the Union (OJ L 298, 26.10.2012, p. 1).
Regulation (EU, Euratom) No 966/2012 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 25 October 2012 on the financial rules applicable to the general budget of the Union and repealing Council Regulation (EC, Euratom) No 1605/2002 (OJ L 298, 26.10.2012, p. 1).
The principle of cost-effectiveness concerns the optimal relationship between the measures used and the results achieved.
The principle of effectiveness refers to the achievement of certain objectives and objectives.

COMMENTS FROM THE COURT 1.11.

REPLY OF THE COMMISSION 1.11.
The Commission notes that the error rate reported by the Court is an annual estimate that takes account of corrections in the accounts of expenditure on projects carried out before the Court's audit is announced.
The Commission recalls that it is bound by a Financial Regulation in which Article 32 (2) (e) provides that its internal control system should, inter alia, ensure adequate management of the risks associated with the legality and regularity of the underlying transactions, taking into account the multiannual nature of the programmes and the nature of the payments in question.
In its 2014 summary report (COM (2015) 279 final), the Commission assessed the impact of the adjustment mechanisms on the amount of EUR 2.7 billion in the future, which represents 1.9% of payments from the EU budget.
The Commission will continue to play a supervisory role through financial corrections and recovery at a level equivalent to the level of irregularities and shortcomings identified throughout the period as well as at the end of the programmes.

DE COMMENTS FROM THE COURT New approach to scrutiny...
In 2014, we reworded our approach to quantifying serious infringements of public procurement rules.
This approach clarifies how we assess the effects of these infringements.
In particular, we have introduced a proportionate approach to calculating the error of contract change.
1.14.
To ensure comparability of the results of this report, we adjusted the figures for the years 2012 and 2013 in Table 1.1 and figures 1.2, 1.3, 1.4, 1.5 and 1.6, in line with this new approach.
Annex 1.4 presents unadjusted historical data on the estimated error rate established for the period 2009-2013.
As a result of this adjustment, the estimated total error rate was reduced by 0,2% in 2013 and by 0,3% in 2012.
The adaptation does not affect the conclusions we have reached with respect to these years and it clearly remains an important level of error.
1.15.
In 2015, we will adapt our approach to cross compliance to the revised legal framework of the common agricultural policy.
We will continue to report on the information provided by the Commission on cross compliance, but this element will no longer be the subject of our controls.
This year we have discovered many errors in cross-compliance in respect of every fourth of the visited farms.
The proportion of these errors in the estimated total error rate shall be 0,2 percentage points (2013: 0,2) ((14))) and 0,6 percentage points (2013: 0,5) at the error rate for the distribution of natural resources and for the distribution of natural resources in 2013.
The Commission welcomes the revision of the Court's approach since 2015.
As regards 2014, the Commission confirms its view that the breach of cross-compliance does not affect the eligibility conditions for payments (see the Commission's reply to paragraph 7.7).

We analysed the relationship between the type of expenditure and the risk of error.
A characteristic feature of EU spending is the extent to which the correct calculation of payments to beneficiaries depends on the information provided by the beneficiaries themselves.
This applies to the largest category of expenditure schemes based on payment entitlements: area aid paid to farmers.
This is particularly important for refund schemes: the beneficiaries must provide information in the application confirming that they participate in the eligible activities and have incurred eligible costs.
This applies to all types of management (15).

Remedies 1.31.
We are trying to take into account the corrective actions taken by the Member States and the Commission before making the payment or our investigation.
We also note the corrections that take place after the inspection has been announced, but we cannot reduce the estimated error rate when the inspection itself triggers the corrective action (24).
We check the application of these corrections (including recovery from beneficiaries and corrections at project level) and, where appropriate, adjust the calculation of the error rate.
However, the effects of corrective action vary considerably depending on the area of expenditure and corrective action.
1.32.
The Commission and the authorities of the Member States applied corrective measures in respect of 24 sampled transactions in 2014, which had a direct impact on the operation and were relevant for our calculations.
These corrective actions led to a reduction in our estimated error rate by 1.1 percentage points (in 2013 1.6 percentage points), which accounts for around EUR 1.6 billion.
Changes in the number of operations concerned and their impact on the estimated error rate do not indicate that corrective measures are more or less effective: in view of the fact that they concern a relatively small part of our sample, fluctuations can be expected from year to year.

Conformity decisions (on financial corrections in the agricultural sector) are often taken on a lump sum basis.
In general, they refer to system flaws rather than to errors at the level of the final beneficiaries.
In rare cases, they lead to recovery from the farmers concerned.
Such corrective measures encourage Member States to improve their management and control systems.
They contribute to the legality and regularity of transactions at the level of the final beneficiaries if they lead to continuous improvements in the accounts of expenditure adopted by the paying agencies (see Boxes 1.2 and 1.3).
The Commission services shall also recover funds j at source, deduction of ineligible expenditure (measured in previous or current cost statements) from payments made.
1.38.
The financial corrections made by the Commission on agricultural expenditure are intended to protect and impose on the Member States the EU budget.
They do not directly lead to recovery from farmers because the Commission does not pay directly to the final beneficiaries, but returns the payments that the Member States have made to farmers.
However, where incorrect payments can be identified as a result of a conformity clearance procedure, the Commission expects the Member States to continue payments by means of recovery actions against the beneficiaries.
See response to Box 1.3.
The paying agencies shall implement conformity decisions by reducing future requests by the Commission for reimbursement for payments to farmers.
The Commission shall recognise the full amount paid to farmers as expenditure, i.e. the correction does not entail a reduction in the amount of registered payments.
Instead, the difference between payments to farmers and refunds to paying agencies is recorded as assigned revenue to finance agricultural expenditure (26).

1.40.
In the area of consistency, financial corrections within the 1988 group account for more than two thirds of the total reporting in cases where the Member States' authorities withdraw the expenditure incurred and replace it with new expenditure.

1.40. The Commission considers that any financial corrections, including financial corrections, for which Member States may submit new projects and new expenditure for the re-use of the adjusted amounts, protect the EU budget against undue expenditure and may encourage Member States to recover amounts from beneficiaries and thus contribute to the improvement of management and control systems.
However, the deterrent effect of net financial corrections where Member States are unable to re-use the corrected and recovered amounts and are therefore losing resources is certainly higher.

1.43.
The legislator has made available to the Commission an instrument of financial corrections to ensure that expenditure made unlawfully is not financed by the EU budget.
The financial corrections relate primarily to system flaws which give rise to a risk of error.
It is the responsibility of the Member States, not the Commission, to establish irregular amounts and to recover them from the beneficiaries.
If this is not the case, EU funds will be replaced by national funds, as national budgets have to bear the cost of financial corrections.

10.11.2015 Official Journal of the European Union C 373/39 DE COMMENTS FROM THE COURT Box 1.5 The comments in the 2014 Annual Activity Reports were made by the Directors-General in 2014 by a total of 20 quantitative reservations against 17 in 2013.
The increase in the total number of reservations is due to the three new reservations of the Directors-General for the Communication, Content and Technology Network (37) and the Neighbourhood Policy and the Enlargement Negotiations (DG NEAR) (37) (43) and the Services for Foreign Policy Instruments (FPI) (40) (43) (43) (43) (43) (43) (42) (42) (42) (42).
In 2014, the conditional expenditure fell from EUR 2.4 billion in 2013 to EUR 2.3 billion in 2014 (43).
1.49.
The European Parliament resolution on discharge for 2013 ([44]) calls on the Commission to further clarify the calculation of the amount of risk by clarifying the estimated impact of corrective mechanisms on this number.
(37) Reservation for the ICT Policy Support Programme for the Countries participating in the Competitiveness and Innovation Framework Programme (CIP), as the residual error rate exceeds 2.94%.
(38) Reservation for indirect management by beneficiary countries as the residual error rate exceeds 2% (2,67%).
(39) The problems identified in the 2013 Annual Report led to new reservations due to the reputation of DG NEAR (formerly DG Enlargement), see paragraph 7.16 of the 2013 Annual Report).
(40) Reservation for expenditure related to the Common Foreign and Security Policy (CFSP) as the residual error rate exceeds 2% (2.13%).
(41) The Directorate-General for Regional Policy and Urban Development (DG REGIO) has divided its repeated reservations on the European Regional Development Fund (ERDF)/Cohesion Fund (FS)/Instrument for Pre-Accession Assistance (IPA) into two reservations: ERDF/FS and IPA.
(42) The Directorate-General for Health and Food Safety (DG SANTE) has removed reservations regarding programmes for the eradication and monitoring of animal diseases in the policy area.
(43) See summary report, Annex 2.
(44) Report on the implementation of the general budget of the European Union for the financial year 2013, Section III, implementation of the general budget of the European Union, Section III, implementation of the general budget of the European Union, and implementing agencies 2014/2075 (DEC) (A8-0101/2015).
DE COMMENTS FROM THE COURT 1.50.
As requested by the discharge authority in 2014, the Commission developed internal guidelines (45) for the submission of information in the annual activity reports.
Director Generals are currently to present the average error rates detected (46).

The summary report presents this amount together with estimates of the future ex post control capacity of the Commission. The Commission acknowledges that the expenditure is heavily affected by errors...
1.51.
In its 2014 summary report, the Commission identified the risk of EUR 3.7 billion to EUR 5 billion.
This corresponds to between 2.6% and 3.5% of the payments covered by the 2014 summary report ((48)).
These figures show that total expenditure is largely burdened with errors... but points out the estimated impact of future corrections of 1.52.
The 2014 summary report provides for a total estimate of the number of future corrections.
On the basis of the corrections[49] taken into account in the last six years, the Commission estimates that in the coming years it will be able to detect and correct errors of EUR 2700 million in total and for an apparent amount of EUR 50.
